 EASTON - The Talbot County Board of Education approved the design development submission for the Chapel District Elementary School renovation and addition at a Board of Education meeting Wednesday evening.The design development plan needs to be submitted to the state for review by Nov. 1. TCPS Director of Operations Kevin Shafer said this submission is the next milestone in the design process.Before the board voted unanimously to submit the design development plan, Shafer and Adam McDonald, project manager and architect from design firm Hord Coplan Macht, gave a presentation to update the board on plans for the project, including the schedule and estimated project costs.McDonald explained that the project includes a full renovation of the existing building and 16,600 square feet of additions.Three total additions at different corners of the building will add additional learning space."The additions are also going to help us enhance the overall design of the building," McDonald said.Since the board's last update on project plans, McDonald said they have made changes to the addition on the north corner of the building to "work better with the existing utilities" during construction.A traffic pattern has been formalized, and a first submission has been made to the State Highway Administration to create an additional curb cut to separate the parent entry loop from the bus drop."To help alleviate some of the traffic concerns that come with a shared entrance," McDonald said.The design plans for outside also include an extension to the parking lot to provide more space for parents dropping off students.Inside the building, McDonald said that most spaces will remain in the same areas as they are pre-renovation.The main change, he said, is that the media center will move to the front of the building and the art classroom will take over where the current media center is.Currently, bidding for the project is expected to take place in April and May of 2024. Construction would begin in June of 2024 and is estimated to take about two years.The estimated cost of construction and site work is $25.18 million. State and county funding for this will come out of FY2025 and FY2026 budgets. With additional expenditures, for things like design costs, the project is expected to cost $29.97 million.Shafer said this estimated cost is $1 million less than the state projection for the project."So I feel like we're within where we want to be," he said, adding that this is still just a projection and the real numbers will come when they bid the project out.After the presentation, board members asked questions.Board Member Deborah Bridges asked about the plan for the school's roof."The slanted roofs really have me worried," she said, expressing concern about drainage.Shafer said the pitched roof is not near the courtyard."The architect will make sure that any kind of drainage that's coming off the roof, whether it's roof drain or exterior drain, is properly sized to accommodate that water shed," he said.

There are still spots open for William Messner's lecture on the "Rise and Fall of the Talbot Boys Memorial" and for "Integrity and Effective Leadership" at the USNA.Join Messner on Tuesday, Nov. 14, from 1 to 2:20 p.m. as he lays out the factors that prompted the Talbot Boy's statue's removal last year.As he explains, the pre-WW I period marked the zenith of racism in the nation. Especially in the South, this period saw the institutionalization of segregation and the utilization of extra-legal means, such as lynching, to insure the maintenance of the racial order.Not coincidentally, throughout the South, memorials to the Confederate lost cause appeared, often in the form of statues of Rebel soldiers. Talbot County was not immune to this pattern of activity, as a memorial to those county residents who fought for the Confederacy - the Talbot Boys - was constructed on the Courthouse lawn in Easton.A century later the statue, one of the last in the South still standing on public grounds, was dismantled, the result of a decade of agitation on the part of Black residents and their allies who demanded the erasure of all vestiges of the old racial order.The event will be hybrid, in person at Easton Family YMCA or via ZOOM.It is $20 to reserve a spot. To register, visit https://chesapeakeforum.org.On Wednesday, Nov. 15, travel to the US Naval Academy for a lecture on how ethics and moral reasoning guide behavior, while integrity defines how individuals conduct their daily lives.Taking from both classical and contemporary thought in moral philosophy, Jeff Macris, Ph.D., the deputy director of the Stockdale Institute, will show how the USNA seeks to provide its future Naval officers with the ability to understand the moral complexities of leadership."Integrity and Effective Leadership" is a field trip to the USNA by carpool or private vehicle from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. It costs $20 to participate.To register, visit https://chesapeakeforum.org.

 CHESTERTOWN - On the afternoon of Oct. 27, the Washington College Chemistry Club hosted its annual exploding pumpkins event on campus, to the delight of a large crowd who had gathered to revel in science-based gourd detonation.The event, which is conducted in conjunction with the American Chemical Society Student Affiliates Club and GAMMA ETA Chemistry Honor Society, draws Washington College students, students from Kent and Queen Anne's Country public schools, and combustion-loving Eastern Shore community members each year ahead of Halloween.Students put together several experiments to test the best way to either explode designs into pumpkins to create unique jack-o-lanterns or generate emissions of various ooze and smoke to come out of unique designs.This year, methods used to induce cool explosions and Halloween-themed demos included glow-in-the-dark luminol, color changing acid and base paired with dry ice, liquid nitrogen, and elephant toothpaste (a foamy substance caused by the rapid decomposition of hydrogen peroxide using potassium iodide or yeast and warm water as a catalyst)."We take immense pleasure in sharing the wonders of chemistry with our students and the promising leaders of tomorrow," said Sarah Arradondo, Washington College Assistant Professor of Chemistry. title: Black and Hispanic faculty underrepresented in universities
author: Nira Dayanim; Capital News Service
content:
Black and Hispanic faculty underrepresented in universities

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Nira Dayanim; Capital News Service | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 816
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Black and Hispanic communities are underrepresented among university faculty at Maryland's six largest public universities, according to the 2021 Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS).This analysis does not include Maryland's online universities or historically black colleges and universities.IPEDS is an annual data collection system run through the U.S. Department of Education.These findings align with trends across the country, data shows.The U.S. Census projects that 32% of Maryland's population are Black and 12% are Hispanic.At Maryland's six largest in-person public universities, not including HBCUs - University of Maryland, Baltimore County; University of Maryland, College Park; Towson University; Frostburg State University; Salisbury University and St. Mary's College of Maryland-less than 6% of the total faculty are Black and less than 5% are Hispanic, as of 2021.According to Laura Perna, Vice Provost for Faculty at University of Pennsylvania and a researcher on college access, faculty underrepresentation is a widespread issue, though the specifics differ by university.Across Maryland, faculty demographics vary widely. At Towson University, 7% of faculty were Black in fall 2021 and 3% were Hispanic. At Frostburg State University, those numbers were about halved, with 4% Black faculty and almost 1% Hispanic faculty.Prior to 2022, Maryland's education code allowed individual public universities to implement their own plans for "cultural diversity," which ranged in length and breadth. In 2022, a new code was instituted, requiring public universities to ensure that faculty, staff, and administration demographics reflect the state's diverse population.Between 2016 and 2021, the percentages of Black and Hispanic faculty at the universities included in the analysis both increased by just under a percentage point."It really is amazing how little progress there has been in some ways on this," said Perna.According to Dr. Kimberly Griffin, Dean of University of Maryland's College of Education, many people assume that faculty will diversify alongside the student body. This "trickle up" system is unrealistic, she says.The problem is multifaceted, says Griffin. Academia is tasked with generating a pool, hiring inclusively, yielding candidates, onboarding hirees, retaining them, and ultimately, promoting them. "We have to do more in all of those spaces," says Griffin, whose research has focused on issues of diversity, equity and inclusion in post-secondary education.According to Perna, one roadblock is "invisible labor" faculty of color often take on work that requires time and energy, but does not fit academia's standard promotion metrics."We should be looking at to what extent our definition of merit is very narrow," said Perna.Underrepresented minorities often spend more time serving on committees and mentoring students of color, labor that often goes unrecognized, says Perna. Come time for promotions, publications and course evaluations are weighted more heavily.As the student body has diversified, the gap between representation among students and faculty has widened, straining faculty of color.As of fall 2021, Black students made up 17% and Hispanic students made up 8% of the student body at the universities included in the CNS analysis. That was an increase of 10% and 19% since 2016, respectively.Faculty demographics remained stable.In 2021, the resulting ratio of Black students to Black faculty members was 60:1. The ratio of white students to white faculty members was 15:1.According to Griffin, while it's crucial for students of color to have role models and mentors of color, there isn't enough faculty of color to shoulder that responsibility alone."That's a load everyone should share," she said.A lack of diversity also impacts faculty of color pursuing tenure. At Maryland's six largest in-person public universities, not including HBCUs, in 2021, 71% of tenured professors were white, 5% Black, and 4% were Hispanic, according to IPEDS.A lack of diversity among tenured faculty can make it harder for some faculty of color to find mentors as they pursue tenure, though many members of academia, like Griffin, are trying to combat this by developing intentional mentoring policy."Mentorship that helps you build a sense of connection and community in your unit and in your college is also really important for helping folks get to tenure," said Griffin.Katharina Maisel, a bioengineering professor at the University of Maryland, College Park, co-authored a list of best practices for increasing diversity alongside several other faculty members in the STEM field.According to Maisel, diversifying the faculty, especially tenure and tenure track, takes intention at every stage of the process, from inviting people to apply, inviting people for internships, and checking your shortlist to make sure you're not just inviting people from Ivy League schools.But it's possible.In science, technology, engineering and math, says Maisel, a tendency to be overspecific in job listings can discourage faculty from underrepresented backgrounds.Using rubrics to evaluate a candidate for hiring or promotion can help ensure an objective set of criteria, helping reel in internal biases, Maisel said."If you as a department are really actively interested in increasing the diversity of your faculty, there are things you can do," Maisel said.

 EASTON - Local veterans representing all branches of the military shared their personal experiences and perspectives with fifth grade students at Easton Elementary school on Wednesday, Nov. 8.Michael Feehley, who served in the Army, coordinated the event on behalf of the Easton Elks Veterans Affairs Office.He began by explaining that Veteran's Day is celebrated on Nov, 11, which was originally recognized as Armistice Day. The date is significant because fighting between the Allied countries and Germany ended on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month in 1918, marking the end of World War I."Stop and think about this day, Veterans Day, celebrating all the service and all the sacrifice of the U.S. Military Veterans," Feehley said to the students. "Veterans sacrificed so that you and I have the freedoms we enjoy today." Each of the seven fifth-grade classes at the school provided one question for the veterans to answer.Brian S. asked "what advice would you give an individual who was considering entering the military?" Jasiah P. asked "what is the most positive thing that happened to you because you served in the armed forces?" "The military gave us the chance to do something we had never done or would never do, like go to the Philippines, or for me, to learn about C-4 and other demolitions, fly in planes and helicopters, or be on a ship." said Mike Detmer, a former Marine and member the Dorchester County Council."It also gives you a chance to grow close to people. When you go through training and hardship or danger with other people, just like when you're on a football or soccer team, you feel a closeness with them. I have brothers who I love a lot, but I feel extremely close to my Marine brothers." "When you have served in the military, you know that you've accomplished something," Detmer said, "and you are serving something much bigger than yourself.You can see how proud all of these gentlemen are about what they've done. But it's not as much pride in what they personally have done, as it is pride in what they have been a part of. That is why I would encourage you to think about it." At the end of the assembly, the students presented cards to the veterans, which will be delivered to patients in a Maryland VA hospital during the holidays."Students in fifth grade across Talbot County write letters to veterans as part of their fifth grade service learning project," said Jeff Bell, Easton Elementary fifth grade teacher. "It is only appropriate that we get those letters to veterans at this time of the year."

 EASTON - The Talbot County Board of Education has created a new committee to address updating, modernizing and funding special education in Talbot County Public Schools.In a unanimous vote, the board directed Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi to lead the charge in the creation of this new Special Education Committee. Board President Emily Jackson introduced the motion at Board of Education meeting Wednesday."I would like to create a committee focused on special education," she said. "As we all know, looking at Blueprint, the way that we are doing our budget and our funding is going to change."The Blueprint for Maryland's Future is a statewide plan to increase public education funding, improve student outcomes and improve the quality of public education. Jackson said this change in the way the budget is done means that there would not be a lot of specific line items "directly applicable to special education" in the budget."Combine that with the fact that our special education population has been growing rapidly," Jackson said to explain why she sees a need for this committee.Jackson said she would like the committee to do a holistic deep dive into what TCPS is currently doing regarding special education as well as what they could be doing. She said she would like the committee to look into modernizing the district's practices and come up with a full proposal for modernizing and funding special education in the county."I think that we all have talked a lot about how we need to approach special ed," she said.Jackson said she would like this committee to spend the year gathering information and come back next year, before budget season, with a proposal that includes what it would cost to modernize special education programming and how the district could fund it.

As the celebration marked one year of the Mobile Library's operation, it also provided an opportunity for attendees to explore the various services and resources the library offers, all within the convenience of the mobile unit.To stay updated on the Mobile Library's schedule and locations, please visit the Queen Anne's County Library website at www.qaclibrary.com/mobile library.The Queen Anne's County Library is committed to fostering a lifelong love of reading, learning, and community engagement.Through its various initiatives, including the Mobile Library, the library serves as a vital resource for residents, promoting education and literacy throughout the county.

title: Education foundation established in Caroline - Four local leaders spearhead funding financial literacy opportunities for students
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Education foundation established in Caroline - Four local leaders spearhead funding financial literacy opportunities for students

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 933
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - "Now we truly do have an education foundation in Caroline County, which is wonderful," Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons said at the Board of Education's Nov. 7 meeting.The announcement followed several months of work by four community leaders to establish the Caroline County Education Foundation, which was launched on Oct. 5.Tolbert Rowe, Robert Willey, Dr. James Orr Jr. and Wayne Cole spearheaded the effort.With the Blueprint for Maryland Education's unfunded mandate, school districts statewide are exploring funding streams beyond the traditional tax base.Other Mid-Shore counties with established education foundations are Kent and Talbot."The Caroline County Public Schools Education Foundation Fund is a subfund through the Mid-Shore Community Foundation," said Rowe, vice president of Bay Capital Mortgage based in Annapolis."Most importantly, I think it's a landing place that we can find philanthropic individuals and organizations we can solicit." A previous foundation was established in 1987, according to Willey, a Denton certified public accountant who took part in its inception."It was set up on a mini-grant system," Willey said. "The grants weren't supposed to be any more than $500, and they were to be awarded directly to classroom teachers to try to do projects that could not be funded through the school board's budget." "We started off great guns, and we operated for around 10 years, and then the board just got tired," Willey said. "We weren't able to recruit new blood and people with more energy and it just kind of died in the mid-90s." However, just over $8,000 remains in bank account once managed by the former foundation, an account which Willey still oversees.In a Nov. 18 interview, he said the new foundation will preserve the intent of the previous foundation's donors."Basically, it's the seed money that went into the educational fund that we've created with Mid-Shore Community Foundation," Rowe said in a Nov. 16 interview.During a conversation about Junior Achievement - a nonprofit providing financial literacy, work readiness and entrepreneurship education to K-12 students - Willey and Rowe decided it was time to reconstitute an education foundation with the Mid-Shore Community Foundation, of which Rowe is a director."We're focusing our efforts initially with financial literacy, career exploration (and) anything that will enhance children," Rowe said at the Nov. 7 meeting. "Much as Junior Achievement does, it's a shotgun approach. We want every kid to experience these things that will help them to make prudent economic career decisions." Orr said the group of four is currently working on bylaws. The purpose of the foundation "shall be to enhance, inspire and support educational opportunities in the area of financial literacy for all students attending Caroline County public schools," he said.On Nov. 16, Rowe said, "The four of us decided that, at least at this point, it would be more impactful to focus our efforts on a specific area like financial literacy, as opposed to everything, because we just don't have a lot of money.If we get more money, then we can expand the mission, but for right now we're going to hold pat with financial literacy." Rowe said the founders "will be setting up a meeting soon get our bylaws adopted and make decisions as to who could serve with us.If anyone knows of anyone in the community that would be good for this organization, we would love to have a conversation." "Times are changing, and this financial literacy piece is going to become so important and we're going to grow this fund," said Cole, chief financial officer of WIN Transport, Inc. in Federalsburg."Financial literacy obviously is very powerful," Simmons said."Caroline County is still one of the only systems in the state that requires all of our high schoolers to complete a full credit of a finance course before graduation, and I'm glad we have that, but at the same time, one only has to look at the current economic situation we're in to realize that one credit during your high school experience in one county on Maryland's Eastern Shore is not solving a fiscal issue that's in front of us everywhere.But financial literacy is a massive undertaking and needed." Simmons explained that CCPS was the first to sign a memorandum of understanding with Junior Achievement of the Eastern Shore regarding providing students opportunities at the organization's 25,000 square-foot regional facility under construction in Salisbury."It's a great center, but it's also a great program that they put together, working with businesses and communities across the Eastern Shore (and it's) great, strong curriculum coming in," Simmons said. The curriculum aligns with the Maryland State Department of Education's requirements.He said the foundation would be in a good position to help with costs associated with students getting to the facility."We are the furthest distance from the center and we have the highest degree of poverty," Simmons said. "We're the (school) system that has the most need with the least amount of funds to spend to get our kids there, and we have the greatest distance to drive to get there." He added that the Blueprint, which requires career exploration as well as dual enrollment, also requires counties to fund compliance with the legislation."We're required to pay for everybody's dual enrollment who are enrolled in our high schools," Simmons said. "The math in Blueprint doesn't add up. They did not take financial literacy." "That's where Blueprint stands right now, and we'll do our part," he said. He added that the foundation could "help support other things that we're trying to do."

title: CCTC AMP students present designs - Rashad Wilson's winning design adorns dartboard cabinet project
content:
CCTC AMP students present designs - Rashad Wilson's winning design adorns dartboard cabinet project

 Page: 1A | Section: News

 RIDGELY - The seventh cohort of Advanced Manufacturing Program students at Caroline Career and Technology Center recently presented design ideas for their current project, a dartboard cabinet.The winning design was created by Rashad Wilson, and was inspired by the doors one might find hanging in a saloon in the Old West."Rashad's dartboard design offers a new challenge for the class and me," teacher Keith Hale said.Although the students possessed the software and the capability to machine a three-dimensional object like the steer skull and horns, they had never attempted it before. "This design is more challenging than designs created by previous classes," he said.This particular project was generated three years ago when an AMP student approached Hale with the idea of manufacturing dartboard cabinets. Hale and the class were excited to make this idea a reality.Since then, AMP cabinets with dartboard with darts included have been one of AMP's most popular products, selling out even before they were presented.Each time AMP students manufacture a product, they follow the same template.It begins with research, mood-boarding and a product pitch. With dartboards, students research the history, rules and professional leagues in the game of darts. Then each student must come up with a design for the project, followed by drafting their design and placing it on a Mood Board.This Mood Board becomes a visual they can refer to as they present their product pitch.Business partners, school officials, parents and former students are then invited to watch the students' product pitches Oct. 26.One by one, students manage the difficult task of individually pitching the details and merits of their designs to the class and guests in attendance.At the end of the presentations, everyone votes and a design is chosen.The next step in the process is called "napkin sketching," which is a sketch of the product views and dimensions.These sketches are then taken to the computer aided drafting lab, where more accurate prints are made. From those prints, numeric commands are created that will drive a computer numeric control machine, which is a robot programmed to cut pieces out of stock material.Once complete, an audience is once again assembled for student presentations of the finished products, which are also offered for sale.

title: Opening Doors (Again) For Literacy
author: Laura Tayman; Ltayman@Chespub. Com
content:
Opening Doors (Again) For Literacy

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; Ltayman@Chespub. Com | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 718
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - This past September, Ashley Singer was holding a tutoring session with a student when they both began to sense a mechanical burning smell.After exiting the building and calling 911, they waited as local responders arrived.Crews quickly gained control of the smoke situation, but the damage had been done.Singer, Executive Director of Open Doors Partners in Education, said it was a saddening setback. "Though we had insurance, there was an estimated $40,000 loss of materials due to exposure to toxic smoke."Enter Associate Director Julie Blyman who had served as a crisis manager at a school."It was really catastrophic," said Blyman, "but then we got so much support from the community."Singer and Blyman met when they were at the Radcliffe Creek School. The school provided them literacy training and both found early on that tutoring was what they were meant to do. Their Open Doors Partners in Education is a literacy focused organization, founded in 2020 as a direct response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the resulting learning loss in local schools.As graduates of Kent County Public Schools and residents of the county, they were alarmed to watch students who were already struggling fall even further behind."We felt the need to do something to help and the decision was made to create a literacy focused nonprofit organization" said Singer. "We initially wanted to help students in first and second grade, a time when intervention can be most efficient and successful," said Singer, "but as word spread through the county, students of all ages, pre-k through 9th grade, were found on our roster."To date, the organization has assisted over 100 students in the Orton-Gillingham literacy method, a direct, multi-sensory, structured, sequential, diagnostic and prescriptive way to teach literacy when reading, writing, and spelling that does not come easily to individuals, such as those with dyslexia.When the fire happened, the two were amazed by the support of local community organizations, including Washington College, the YMCA, and Stam's downtown.It took only one day for them to take an offer from Emmanuel Episcopal Church to use their Sunday school classrooms.Knowing that they needed a more permanent location, the group worked with Sam Shoge of Rivers & Roads Construction to find an appropriate location. They toured office space in the Lynchburg building and worked with KRM Development Corp. to get the space ready as soon as possible.Open Doors depends on grant funding to exist and has worked with Kit Cares, Inc., a charity navigator and a fiscal sponsor for their 501©3 organization. The funding provides the organization the ability to offer free services to Kent County students."By partnering with local schools, we can provide intensive 1:1 structured literacy instruction at no cost to the families," said Singer."We hope to reach those students who might otherwise fall through the cracks."The organization is also working with a nonprofit consultant on a strategic five-year plan. "We would love to be working more with Kent Co. and Queen Anne's County Public Schools," said Singer. They would also like to enhance their bilingual program. "Research says the Orton-Gillingham literacy method is the best literacy training program for bi-lingual students," she said.Since the fire, the organization is in need of replenishing their paperback book library for students ages 5-16. The organization also has a wish list on Amazon.com.Why are Singer and Blyman so committed to their mission? Singer said, "It is the lightbulb moment when students discover why they want to read, when they realize that a book is an adventure, and they realize they can have many more."Blyman said it is all about why students come to the office for a session. "To know that they are coming here willingly after a hard day of school, that is really inspiring," said Blyman. "And it's very rewarding when we see that parents are so relieved that their children are ok to come here and know they will get the help they need."The Open Doors Partners in Education will have a ribbon cutting at their new location, 116-D South Lynchburg Street in Chestertown, on Dec. 1 at 5 p.m.For more information on Open Doors, go to www. opendoorsed.org.

title: Apprenticeships explored at local high schools
author: Laura Tayman; tayman@chespub.com
content:
Apprenticeships explored at local high schools

 November 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; tayman@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 696
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While high school students are still tasked with learning English, math, history, and science, career apprenticeships are being revitalized in Queen Anne's County and across the country, educating future workers and preparing them with marketable skills sought in high-demand industries.Karen Hesson of Kent Island High School and Betsy Ricketts of Queen Anne's County High School are in their first year serving as their school's Career Coach for students, a new position the county created this year."There is so much information available for students now, and it is hard for them and their families to navigate through it," said Hesson. "We help students identify what interests them and how to get to where they need to be to meet their goals, whether it is college, trade schools, or working directly with businesses to allow students to learn on the job." Hesson and Ricketts worked together on securing a week's worth of visitors available to meet with students during a part of their lunchtime. From military and law enforcement to county government and local businesses who are needing workers with specific skills, all were on hand to answer questions and discuss options for the future.One of the presenters was Connie Dean, the Career Technology Liaison for the Queen Anne's County Economic & Tourism Development department. Dean is assisting the two schools with finding businesses who are interested in the apprenticeship program."Students are first given skills that would be required to work in a certain business field," said Dean. Then the students work 450 hours at a partnering business to earn their official apprenticeship recognition."I try to tell businesses internships are a bigger commitment, when the apprenticeship program would be appropriate for future workers in their field," she said.Currently, there are three Kent Island students who were trained in the culinary department at Chesapeake College this semester.Aly Swann said she learned about the basics like cutting meat, how to work with knives and other kitchen tools, and how to make sauces. "I know now 100% that this is what I want to do for a living," she said.James Smith said the school was really helpful in letting him work some during the school day. "I appreciate that I got a pathway for my career. I have learned skills I will use for a long time," said Smith.Last Tuesday, was military and law enforcement day for the Queen Anne's apprentice week, with recruiters from all armed forces branches, answering questions about basic training, money for college, and traveling the globe.Troopers Christopher Bekefiand Doug Prince provided information on the Maryland State Police Cadet program, where students aged 17-19 are assigned to perform duties that do not require police authority (example helping with crowds at large public events). Cadets are also assigned to work under the supervision of a Trooper at a truck inspection station or on patrol.They also have an explorer program for students aged 14-18, where they are introduced to various divisions and tactics like crime scene investigations, traffic stops, and forensics.Adam Tolley, supervisor of Career and Technology Education for Queen Anne's Public Schools, was pleased to see so many students engaging with a variety of workforce representatives. "This is a very organized way to provide students who are beginning to think about real career options," he said.County Commissioner Philip Dumenil was present to view the new apprentice week program first hand at Queen Anne's High School. "I like new opportunities for exposure to these kind of programs," said Dumenil. "Lots of money can still be made in the trade fields. Not every kid wants to go to college." Queen Anne's student Austin Hahn, just a sophomore, has already chosen a career for his future, and that, said Ricketts, makes him a perfect apprentice candidate.Hahn has chosen to pursue a career in marine mechanics and pipe welding and wishes to move to the Gulf of Mexico in Louisiana or Texas where he has family. "My grandfather taught me a lot about it," said Hahn. "He said it would be the best money I could ever make. When he passed away, I knew I would definitely do it."

title: MCAP results show signs of recovery from pandemic learning loss - Science scores still show decline
author: Aya Hussein; Capital News Service
content:
MCAP results show signs of recovery from pandemic learning loss - Science scores still show decline

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Aya Hussein; Capital News Service | Page: 27 | Section: News 
 
 840
 Words 

 Read News Document

 COLLEGE PARK - The results for the 2023 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program tests for grades 3 to 8 show that student proficiency in English Language Arts has surpassed the level it was at before the pandemic.Math scores have improved, but have yet to fully rebound from the pandemic, while science scores have declined, according to the Maryland State Department of Education.MCAP tests are administered annually in public schools to assist educators in understanding student progression so that they can better tailor their methods of instruction, according to MSDE.Students in grades 3 to 8 take tests in English and math, while students in grades 5 and 8 are given an additional science test.ENGLISH PROFICIENCY SURPASSES 2019According to data from MSDE, average English proficiency dropped from 44% in 2019 to 31% in 2021.Proficiency increased significantly in 2022 and by a smaller degree in 2023, with results showing an average passing rate of 47%, according to MSDE.Improvements can be seen across Maryland, as every county except Somerset had an increase in English proficiency between 2022 and 2023.MATH PROFICIENCY STILL BELOW PRE-PANDEMIC LEVELSThe 24% average passing rate for math in 2023 is still lower than the 31% in 2019, indicating that math scores have still not fully recovered from pandemic learning loss.Despite average passing rates in math still not being as high as in 2019, they have gone up since dropping to 15% in 2021. Proficiency increased by 6 percentage points from 2021 to 2022 and 3 percentage points from 2022 to 2023.Not every county had an improvement, as there are four counties that saw a decline in average math proficiency from 2022 to 2023: Baltimore, Kent, Somerset and Talbot.Baltimore County Public Schools Board of Education Member at Large Tiara Booker-Dwyer said that an explanation for the slower improvement in math scores is that the format of math questions in these tests have become more layered, which makes it difficult for parents, teachers and administrators trained in the traditional format to help students get accustomed.HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED STUDENTS LAG BEHINDDespite making improvements over the last two years, average scores for historically underserved students in English and math still lag behind. The most recent scores of Black/African American, Hispanic/Latino and American Indian/Alaska Native students are still below those of white and Asian students.Booker-Dwyer said that it is important to build the cultural competency of educators so that they can connect better with students."When you look at the curriculum that was developed, it speaks to a certain demographic.There are certain people who just 'I'm not going to connect with this,' so it's going to go in one ear and out the other. Or when they try to connect to it, people recognize that it's inauthentic," Booker-Dwyer said.Booker-Dwyer states that another solution is encouraging more historically underserved students to take honors and AP classes, as well as providing resources to schools to give them these opportunities."What the research shows is that if you're placed in an advanced academic class or gifted class, even if you're earning C's in there, you're better off long term than if you're just in the standard class," Booker-Dwyer said."Sometimes it's just exposure to certain things, just being in a classroom, around students who are performing at a certain level will kind of unintentionally make you perform at a higher level," she said.GRADE 8 SCIENCE PROFICIENCY HITS FIVEYEAR LOWScience scores continue to lag, especially for grade 8.In grade 5, science proficiency in the last five years peaked in 2021 at 41%, a 12-percentage point increase from 2019. In 2022, the passing rate dropped to 31% before rising again to 35% in 2023, according to MSDE.Grade 8 scores have been on a steady decline since 2021, with the passing rate dropping from 35% in 2022 to 26% in 2023, the lowest it's been in the last five years.With the exception of Dorchester, every county had at least a 10% decline in grade 8 science proficiency from 2022 to 2023. Six counties had over a 30% decrease from 2022: Kent, Charles, Prince George's, Washington, Allegany and Queen Anne's.MSDE states that this decline is likely due to the grade 8 students being in grade 6 during the 2020-2021 school year, which was predominantly online. As a result, students missed key science instruction during their first year of middle school."The results on the grade 8 assessment make clear the impact of grade 6 and 7 disruptions on a cumulative grade 8 assessment," MSDE said in the press release.Booker-Dwyer stated that rollout for the new Next Generation Science Standards for K-12 education, which has lessons in engineering, technology, earth and space sciences in addition to traditional sciences, was delayed by the pandemic.She remains optimistic that scores will improve as curriculum continues to change."I do believe it will get better as people are getting more and more comfortable with the science standards and more teachers are getting trained and the resources are getting better, as far as the instructional material," Booker-Dwyer said. "But initially it was tough." The 2024 MCAP tests are set to begin in the spring.

title: School principals prepare for the Blueprint For Maryland's Future
author: Cait Kelley And Caley Fox Shannon
content:
School principals prepare for the Blueprint For Maryland's Future

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Cait Kelley And Caley Fox Shannon | Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 777
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OCEAN CITY - As Maryland rolls out the 2021 landmark education reform law called the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, many school administrators are unsure what the plan means for their schools.At the annual School Leaders Conference held Nov. 2-4 in Ocean City, state officials and school principals reviewed the details of the Blueprint and discussed how it will be implemented in each school district.The wave of impending policy changes are meant to address the challenges facing educators and students across the state.The Blueprint is grounded in the analysis of a group of independent policy experts formed by the state in 2016 to establish a baseline for education reform.The group was commonly referred to as the Kirwan Commission after its chair, William E. Kirwan, chancellor emeritus of the University System of Maryland.By 2019, the Kirwan Commission had come to some sobering conclusions about Maryland's education system.Half of all teachers leave the profession within the first five years. Only two out of every five kindergarteners arrive in the classroom ready to learn. And just a third of students leave high school being "college and career ready" in English and math."That was pre-pandemic.So generally speaking, it's gotten worse," said Rachel Hise, a policy specialist who worked for the state in tandem with the Kirwan Commission.Explaining the commission's findings to school leaders in Ocean City, she said the independent body concluded that "ultimately, the status quo is unsustainable."The Maryland General Assembly passed the Blueprint for Maryland's Future in February 2021, overriding a veto by then-Gov.Larry Hogan, a Republican who had cost concerns about the plan.The Blueprint allocates $3.8 billion to schools over the next 10 years.Hise is now executive director of the Blueprint's Accountability and Implementation Board. She said the policy changes will make sure students are ready to learn in kindergarten and ready to succeed when they graduate high school.Because public schools lack the capacity to fulfill this mandate alone, the state will fund programming via private pre-K providers as well."The goal is a socioeconomically integrated pre-K system that is publicly funded, but that is provided by both public schools and private providers," Hise told administrators in Ocean City.The Blueprint will also mean big changes in high schools."What the Blueprint really envisions is we want kids to be college and career ready by 10th grade, so that the second two years of high school students can focus on the pathway that they're interested in pursuing," Hise said.The Blueprint aims to meet this goal through curriculum changes in English and math in addition to apprenticeships and technical education programs.Implementing the Blueprint at the school level falls squarely on school administrators, said Addie Kaufman, executive director of the Maryland Association of Secondary School Principals."There was no doubt that the Blueprint would be a part of this conference, and the understanding of the Blueprint is actually key," she said in an interview.After learning more about the Blueprint at the conference, some principals said they are hopeful that the reforms will address their schools' priorities.Teachers are struggling to make do with salaries in the current economy, said Principal Ryan Daniel of Fort Foote Elementary in Prince George's County."I know a lot of my teachers have to have after-school jobs or second jobs to compensate for their salary," she said.The Blueprint will raise the minimum salary for teachers to $60,000 across the state by 2026. And if teachers obtain National Board Certification, the Blueprint allows them to earn up to an additional $17,000 per year.Other schools have yet to feel the concrete impact of the Blueprint."Honestly, I'm still reading and learning, and I think that they're doing a really slow roll out intentionally for us, which is good," said Jamie Miller, the principal at Broadneck Elementary in Arnold. "We have people at the board level who are becoming sort of experts and then they're going to disseminate to us."Miller expressed a mix of excitement about the expansion of pre-K and trepidation about her school's capacity to meet the need.In March 2023, every school district submitted a detailed plan to the Accountability and Implementation Board for rolling out the Blueprint in their schools."The plans are fine, but they really are a baseline," Hise said. "There's a need for more innovative thinking."The Accountability and Implementation Board expects updated plans from every district in March 2024, and has offered every district a $100,000 grant to hire a strategic planning expert. All but Frederick and Worcester counties took the state up on that deal.

Benedictine Raises Over $100,000 On Giving Tuesday

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News

title: Superintendent Outlines Budget Priorities, Timeline
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com
content:
Superintendent Outlines Budget Priorities, Timeline

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 785
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The conundrum of uncertain Blueprint demands coupled with a projected decrease in pandemic-related grant funding for Caroline County Public Schools is proving to be a challenge for Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons, school administrators and district staff as they build a budget for fiscal year 2025.And because the dilemma impacts the traditional budgeting timeline employed in previous years, at the Dec. 5 meeting of the Caroline County Board of Education, the Superintendent Simmons received more time to develop a more realistic budget.
The Board of Education approved Simmons's request to revise the traditional timeline and move his final budget proposal from February to April.
"We do not have a good idea of what state revenues look like until the General Assembly gets done doing their work, which is April," Simmons said.
While some demands of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a set of policies and spending for education in the state's public schools, are clear, others are still being modified. The "uncertainties" of the unfunded legislative mandate have created budgetary challenges for school administrators across the state.
One of the demands for school districts is funding dual enrollment for high school students who wish to take college courses. Blueprint's College and Career Readiness standards require school districts to pay for any student who meets the minimum requirements for dual enrollment. At roughly $1,000 per student per semester, CCPS spent $130,000 in 2023 for juniors and seniors to take courses at Chesapeake College. While "it's great for the kids," Simmons said, the Blueprint requirement presents a budget challenge.
Another "cost of doing Blueprint business" is meeting the mandated starting teacher salary of $60,000 by fiscal year 2027.
Grant funding "is kind of how Caroline County has survived," Simmons said.
But some of that funding will decrease or cease altogether in 2024.
Both American Rescue Plan and Maryland Leads grant funding will sunset in Sept. 2024. In addition, the funding formula for Blueprint shows a 1.7% increase in state funding from last year, the lowest per year increase in the formula, Simmons said.
The CCPS budget, typical of school systems across the state is 80% people, Simmons said.
"The rule of thumb is anywhere between 80% to 90% of your budget is people, and when you take people out and you take out paying for your electric and your fuel and heating your buildings and running your buses and those sorts of things, you're probably left with somewhere between the neighborhood of 5% to 7% every year that truly is discretionary," Simmons said.
And while "about 14% of our money comes from the county government, the rest of it comes from state and federal, which is also why those numbers are important," he said.
Most categories in Blueprint require financing at the school level, adding additional elements of complexity and compliance, and requiring full time accounting level position, Simmons said.
Besides Blueprint's requirements, budget pressures also include the rate of inflation at over 3.5%, multiyear contracts that will come up for renewal in 2024 that will likely be higher than the rate of inflation and global issues impacting the cost of goods, including fuel.
However, the budgeting challenge is not "all doom and gloom," Simmons said.
Caroline County has schools that qualify for "concentration of poverty" grant funding. While the funding is restricted to individual schools and can't support programs or positions at the district level, it helps take some pressure off the district to fund, for example, an afterschool program or reading intervention at a specific school.
Federalsburg and Greensboro elementary schools already qualify; Colonel Richardson Middle School received its first concentration of poverty grant in 2023.
"It's likely we will see multiple other schools added as the Free and Reduced Meals rates maintain or increase," Simmons said. Because the concentration of poverty funding formula relies on Free and Reduced Meals data, Simmons said, "I feel very confident all nine of our schools will get there."
As for the budgeting process, Simmons and his team will continue to work on the budget, try to find funding sources and work with the County finance office into 2024. Negotiating with the teachers' association will play a role, as well as a joint budget meeting with the Caroline County Commissioners.
"We also have a very good working relationship with the county commissioners," Simmons said. "We are not one of those counties that walks over to the county commissioners and drops an additional increase of $3, 4 or 5 million on them." The final CCPS budget is due to the county commissioners by the end of June.
Priorities in the fiscal year 2025 CCPS budget are competitive salaries and benefits for all employees, maintaining reasonable staffing levels across the district, maintaining high yield positions and programs that were included in pandemic-related grants and implementing the Blueprint as required.

author: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com
content:
Tcps Gives Update On Its Priorities At Board Meeting

 December 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com | Page: 2 | Section: News

 EASTON - At a Talbot County Board of Education meeting Wednesday, administrators gave an update on the school system's priorities.Talbot County Public Schools' three priorities, identified in the spring, are academic equity and achievement, fostering an engaging environment and hiring and retaining highly qualified and diverse staff.
Since sharing the priorities with the entire school system in August, Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said they have been working to "infuse" the priorities everywhere.
"In my roundtables, out in the community, in schools," she said. "We're constantly talking about those three priorities."
At the meeting, strategies and metrics associated with each priority were shared.
ACADEMIC EQUITY AND ACHIEVEMENT When it comes to academic equity and achievement, TCPS has six strategies, including implementing additional interventions for students in and outside the classroom, hiring additional math coaches and implementing more assessments to measure growth.
Assistant Superintendent for Curriculum and Instruction Helga Einhorn said that since improving math was identified as a priority by the board, the district has added the NWEA MAP Growth Assessment for mathematics.
"Prior to this year, we did not have a standardized assessment that would allow us to collect this type of data as we had with reading," Einhorn said. "We felt it was important, if we were going to make changes throughout the year, to progress monitor our students throughout the year."
Students in kindergarten through fifth grade took the beginning of the year MAP Growth Assessment for mathematics.
Einhorn said teachers were impressed with how well students performed.
Overall, 14% of those students were in the 80th percentile or higher, 19% were between the 61st and 80th percentile, 18% were between the 41st and 60th percentile, 21% were between the 21st and 40th percentile and 25% were between the 1st and 20th percentile.
Along with measuring growth through testing throughout the year, Einhorn said teachers are working very closely with the K-6 Math Curriculum Supervisor Daisy Bradwell.
"They are doing a deep dive into the curriculum," Einhorn said, adding that Bradwell is working with teachers to identify what things might be missing from the curriculum.
FOSTERING AN ENGAGING ENVIRONMENT Director of Student Services Darlene Spurrier started off her presentation by listing different strategies the district is employing to achieve fostering an engaging environment.
These strategies include school-based mental health services and substance abuse intervention and prevention; restorative practices training; and individual school wellness plans and wellness coaches.
"Many of (these strategies) are ongoing and will not ever really move to completed because they're things that we're just going to continue to do," she said.
When it came to data, Spurrier shared the results of three climate surveys - an internal survey from this year and the Maryland School Climate Surveys from last year and the year before that. Each of the surveys measure student and educator attitudes on four domains: community, environment, relationships and safety.
Comparing the student survey TCPS took this year to the state's survey from last year, within those four domains, students considered physical safety, physical environment and participation and engagement significantly better this year than the previous two years.
Comparing the teacher survey TCPS took this year to the state's survey from last year, teachers also ranked participation and engagement and physical safety significantly higher. They also ranked substance abuse higher than last year, meaning it is less of a concern in schools this year. Teachers ranked bullying lower on the scale this year compared to last year, meaning it is more of a concern.
HIGHLY QUALIFIED AND DIVERSE STAFF Assistant Superintendent for Administrative and Support Services Lynne Duncan presented data on new hires, recruitment and TCPS's Grow Your Own Teachers Scholarship Program.
Before she spoke, Pepukayi said that retaining, not just recruiting, is important to the district.
"With the shortages across our nation in education, we want to make sure the people who are here, we're tending to," she said.
According to Duncan's presentation, last school year, 197 out of 234 people, or 84%, accepted offers of employment.
This year, 90 out of 126 people, or 71%, accepted offers of employment.
Duncan said that, to date, four of those new hires this year have left employment.
In terms of demographics of new teaching staff this year, 32 teachers are white and two are Hawaiian.
TCPS attended seven recruitment fairs last school year. Duncan said it yielded one support staff employee.
The district plans to attend a total of eight recruiting events this school year. So far, it has visited three.
Of the five people enrolled in the district's Grow Your Own Teachers Scholarship Program last year, four have been hired. The program gives TCPS students enrolled in college a scholarship if they agree to teach in the district after they graduate. Duncan said that of the nine remaining students enrolled in the program, one will graduate this month, one will graduate in June of 2024, three will graduate in 2026 and four will graduate in 2027.
At the end of the meeting, board member Jymil Thompson said he could see that the administrative team has clear vision, alignment and transparency.
"I think you all do a fabulous, fabulous job of that," he said. "I want to see where the district's going to be in a couple years because I think it's definitely trickling in the right direction. So I'm anxious to be a part of that."

 EASTON - Easton High School senior William O'Donnell has been chosen to represent Talbot County in the Maryland General Assembly Student Page Program for the 2024 Legislative Session.In 2022, former Gov. Larry Hogan appointed O'Donnell to serve on the Maryland Youth Advisory Council, where he is vice chair.
He holds several additional leadership positions, including president of the Maryland Junior Classical League, Shore-Rivers Upper Shore Youth Environmental Action Summit leader and Eastern Shore divisional liaison of the Maryland Association of Student Councils.
O'Donnell is co-president of the Easton High Interact Club and vice president of the Latin Honor Society.
O'Donnell also participates in Talbot County Teen Court, Latin Academic Olympics, speech and debate, National Honor Society and rowing. He interns with Talbot County Democrats, helps educate elementary students about STEM and has represented Maryland at the National Junior Classical League convention.
The Maryland Association of Secondary School Principals acknowledged O'Donnell for being one of the first students to present at an principals' conference.
His group presentations on artificial intelligence in education and the panel on school safety motivated the association to allow student presentations at all future events.
O'Donnell has received several awards, including recognition as an Advanced Placement Scholar with honors, the 2023 National Latin Exam Magna Cum Laude medal, and the Maryland Association of Student Councils Certified Workshop Presenter status.
Maryland high school seniors have served as student pages for members of the state legislature since 1970.
Each year, 105 pages and 36 alternates from across Maryland are selected by their local school systems to represent their schools and counties.
Selected pages serve two nonconsecutive weeks in either the Senate or House of Delegates.
During the 13 weeks of session, which run from the second week in January to early April, each page serves one week during the first seven weeks and returns for a second week during the last six. The duties of pages are driven by the schedule of the chamber to which they are assigned.
Requirements include being a high school senior who is at least 16 years of age, residing and attending a public or nonpublic high school in Maryland and having an interest in government and history.
Interested students should apply through their schools in September and selection is completed by Oct. 1 of each year. More information about the Maryland General Assembly Page Program is available at dls.maryland.gov/careers/student-page-program.

title: Stepping into the past - Museum explores Tubman's life through murals
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Stepping into the past - Museum explores Tubman's life through murals

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 941
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - In the back of the Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center on Race Street, one wall acts as a window into Tubman's life.Inside the museum, on one side of the wall, Tubman is painted as a young girl, about 13-years-old, at the Bucktown General Store.
"This was a pivotal time in her life," Linda Harris, the museum's director of events and docent, said. "It was considered her first act of defiance." Outside the museum, on the other side of the wall, Tubman is an adult, holding out her hand.
"(She's) coming back, rescuing family and those that wanted freedom," artist of both murals, Michael Rosato said.
Harriet Tubman, an abolitionist and social activist who was born into and escaped from slavery in Dorchester County in the 19th century, became well-known for her work on the Underground Railroad, a network of routes and safe houses that helped enslaved people escape to their freedom.
Inside the museum, the mural of a young Tubman and the Bucktown Store covers the entire wall - and the other three walls in the room.
With canvas and paint, Rosato has transformed the back room of the museum into the Bucktown Store, a significant place in Tubman's history.
The story goes that Tubman was asked to go to the Bucktown Store to get something for the master.
"And she didn't want to do it," Bill Jarmon, president of the Harriet Tubman Organization, said.
"Part of it had to do with the fact that she wasn't presentable." It had to do with her hair, Jarmon said. So she covered her hair with a cloth made from flaxseed.
When Tubman got to the store, she heard a noise at the backdoor and saw a young boy struggling to get away from his master. When the boy escapes and runs toward the door, Tubman is told to stop him. But she doesn't. She steps out of the way to let him go through. "Her first act of defiance," as Harris said.
As the boy escaped, Jarmon said, a two-pound weight was thrown at him.
However, the weight hit Tubman in the forehead instead, knocking her unconscious.
Harris considers Tubman's head wrap to be a very important piece of this story.
"She wraps her head in this linen made of flaxseed, which in fact - what I'm reading and what I believe now - cushions the blow from that two-pound weight being hurled at her," Harris said.
"Imagine if she had fixed her hair that day. She'd be dead." Sitting in the back room of the museum Wednesday, Dec. 20, Jarmon and Harris pointed to different parts of the room as they told the story. When they officially open this part of the museum - which they hope to do in January - visitors will feel even more immersed in the story.
They plan to put in wood floors and counters to resemble the store. And as they tell the story of Tubman's first act of defiance, Harris said she and her husband will play code songs, songs enslaved people used to share messages.
Eventually, Harris hopes to offer virtual reality goggles to visitors when they enter the room.
"We're going to make this thing come alive," she said.
The idea to do this all started when Harris learned that she would no longer be able to take visitors on tours inside the original Bucktown Store.
Harris said that considering how pivotal the store was in Tubman's life, she couldn't have people visit and not learn the story.
"So I said, 'Well, let's put it in the museum,'" Harris said.
To begin the project, Rosato, who lives in Church Creek and has been an artist for 33 years, went to the store and took photos of the walls.
"Every square inch of the walls and what was on the shelves," he said.
After that, he took the photos back to his studio on Race Street and put paint to canvas.
"(I) just started to recreate the store as close as possible and in a somewhat realistic fashion so when you're in that space you feel as though you can take things off the shelves," he said.
After completing each wall on the canvas, he would bring the canvases to the museum and glue them to the walls so that it looked as if he had painted directly on walls of the museum. To make it look as realistic as possible, Rosato had to consider light, shadow and perspective.
"When you create a painting that you want to look real and dimensional, you have to understand perspective and find the right vanishing point," he said.
"So when you're standing right in the middle of that room, every wall you look at, all the lines converge to a certain point. And that's what gives it a sense of depth." The project, which Rosato worked on in the fall, took between one and two months to complete.
He said that once it is open to visitors, he hopes they will get a sense of the rich history of Tubman's experience in Dorchester County.
"The possibility of being able to stand there and reflect back like, 'I'm in the store where she is.
This is what happened,'" he said. "And then going outside and seeing (adult) Harriet Tubman. This is the outcome."

title: Problems persist in juvenile services schooling
author: Steph Quinn; Capital News Service
content:
Problems persist in juvenile services schooling

 January 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Steph Quinn; Capital News Service | Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 569
 Words 

 Read News Document

 SABILLASVILLE - The graduate's mom, peers and teachers knew he was going to reach his goal, though his principal, Todd Rasher, said the other students incarcerated at the Victor Cullen Center in rural northern Frederick County didn't see "all the footwork" it took to earn his GED."This diploma ain't really too much because I knew that I was going to get it," the 17-year-old said to his graduation audience on Oct. 18, wearing a cap and gown, kente stole and black wristband adorned with, "Don't give up." The graduate, whose identity CNS is shielding because he is a minor, was charged as an adult before his case was transferred to juvenile court.
Rasher said he passed the tests necessary to earn his GED on the first try, inspiring his fellow students to take the tests themselves.
Not all incarcerated young people are able to continue their education, much less attain a degree. Two years after the Maryland General Assembly transferred responsibility for incarcerated students' education from the state Education Department to an independent school board within the Juvenile Services Department, students confined in Maryland's secure youth facilities continue to face multiple long-standing challenges, according to experts and state audit reports.
Teacher vacancy rates of 30% in the most populous Juvenile Services schools have led to reliance on streaming instruction in subjects such as math and science.
David Domenici, director of education and senior adviser to the Juvenile Services secretary, said streaming instruction is "not ideal" for the "vast majority" of students but better than packets of photocopied activities.
Juvenile Services teacher vacancies have persisted through tensions between Maryland's education and Juvenile Services agencies over the past decade about who bears responsibility for educating incarcerated young people and how best to do so. Those vacancies continue through teachers' lack of summer and winter breaks and low pay relative to teachers employed by local school districts.
Bills seeking pay parity and summer breaks for juvenile services teachers failed in 2016, 2019 and 2020, often pitting experts from Education and Juvenile Services against each other. The General Assembly established a statewide education board within Juvenile Services in 2021 in response to monitors' and advocacy groups' repeated findings of high staff turnover and vacancies, inadequate services for learning disabled students and a lack of support for students returning to community schools.
But the law did not require pay parity or align facilities' teaching calendar more closely with local schools.
But lost instructional time is greatest due to a lack of residential advisers, according to audits of Juvenile Services schools by the state Office of the Inspector General.
Departmental policy requires that residential staff escort students from their living units to classrooms while maintaining a minimum staff-to-youth ratio. When there aren't enough residential staff, students don't move.
Students were late to class 203 times across Juvenile Services facilities due to residential staff shortages between April and June alone, according to the audits. Teachers had to teach class inside the living units 43 times in the 90-day inspection period.
Getting students in the classroom, even if they are late, Domenici said, is better than class on the living units.
The department is working toward a goal of 90% on-time attendance in school by shifting all onsite adults to escort students to school, he said.

title: Radcliffe Creek School awarded 'social-emotional' learning grant
author: Staff Writer
content:
Radcliffe Creek School awarded 'social-emotional' learning grant

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Radcliffe Creek School (RCS) was recently awarded a grant from the Queen Anne's County Mental Health Committee (QACMHC) to expand its social-emotional learning curriculum. The new funding will broaden the robust curriculum already in place for younger students, bringing social-emotional resources to older students and their parents, as well as to the local community.Social-emotional skills serve as a guide for people to understand social situations and relationships: these abilities are central to navigating the world successfully in everyday life. Debbie Cohee-Wright, a special education learning specialist at RCS explained, "If a child has a mental health issue of any kind, such as trauma, depression or anxiety, their ability to learn and access information is compromised. For a student to be available for learning, they must first feel emotionally safe. Making connections with teachers and peers and building trust with others must happen before the focus on academics can take place."
Currently, the school's social-emotional learning program encompasses two curriculums targeted to younger students who are identified as needing support to strengthen these skills. The program, administered by Intervention Transition Skills Coach Bryn Ponti, utilizes fun, engaging activities that integrate kid- friendly themes: kids imagine themselves as detectives who look for clues in their environment or as superheroes who earn superpowers, all while learning about executive functioning, perspective taking and self-regulation.
Head of School Peter Thayer said, "At RCS, we always try to meet students where they are in their learning, and here, that includes their social-emotional wellbeing. This grant from QACMHC will make a considerable difference in the lives of our older students and their families, many of whom are neurodivergent and need extra support in this area."
The funding provided by QACMHC will bring two additional curriculums—Brain Talk and Conscious Discipline—to the school, expanding its social-emotional programming to older students and their families.
Brain Talk is a curriculum designed to teach students about the different areas of their brains, educating children about their executive function capabilities and how they impact responses to situations.
Conscious Discipline is a course designed for teachers, parents and guardians, providing adults with tools to show children better ways to self-regulate and build resilience.
"These grants are made possible by community support of our fundraisers and through generous donations from local businesses and individuals," QACMHC President Kelly Phipps said. "We appreciate the outpouring of support whenever we have a fundraiser or ask for donations."
In addition to the new resources this grant will provide to Radcliffe Creek School's teachers, students and their families, the QACMHC grant will allow RCS to bring social-emotional programming to the local community as well. Planning is already underway to host an event for the public, bringing this important topic to local parents, teachers and residents in 2024. "We are so grateful to QACMHC for their support of our school's social-emotional learning program. These funds will directly impact our students' mental health by supporting children both in the classroom and at home, leading to a more positive school environment, a greater sense of empowerment among our teachers and parents, and an increased sense of confidence in our children. We are excited to bring these resources to the Radcliffe Creek School community and beyond in 2024," remarked Director of Advancement Carolyn Thompson.
