title: 'Diving Deep' with dyslexia: Local special education teacher works to raise awareness
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
'Diving Deep' with dyslexia: Local special education teacher works to raise awareness

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 1217
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — What do Robin Williams, Jay Leno, Albert Einstein, Alexander Graham Bell, Magic Johnson, Jennifer Aniston, Gwen Stefani, Abraham Lincoln, and Arnold Schwarzenegger all have in common? They all have dyslexia.Lindsey Parte, a mother of two boys and Special Education teacher, has reignited the Decoding Dyslexia Maryland Eastern Shore Chapter that fizzled out during the Covid pandemic.
Parte shares that she has been "diving deep into advocating and teaching herself (about dyslexia)" for the last three years.
When Parte's older son, Lincoln, was six years old, he struggled with both speech and reading. Parte said a red flag to her son's learning struggle was "knowing how smart he was but not understanding why reading was so hard."
Parte explains that her two-year younger son was making gains on her older son. In contrast, reading was coming with ease to her younger son.
On the first day of second grade, Lincoln (her older son) came home and said, "I can't do this. I can't read. I hate school." Lincoln was frustrated with learning and wanted to quit.
It was heartbreaking for Parte as a mother and as a special education teacher herself as no one wants to see their child struggle, especially with learning. Parte explained, reading is the gateway to learning and lifelong success, and as such, learning to read successfully is vital to all.
Two years after Parte first suspected Lincoln was dyslexic, Lincoln got his formal diagnosis. Parte explained that getting the diagnosis meant freedom for her and her son.
She recounts, "I will never forget the utter sigh of relief when we told him he has dyslexia. It all made sense to him from that moment on. Within a week, he was already talking about it in class and advocating for himself. And most importantly, we got our boy back. His light turned back on."
According to the Mayo Clinic, dyslexia is "a learning disorder that involves difficulty reading due to problems identifying speech sounds and learning how they relate to letters and words (decoding). Also called a reading disability, dyslexia is a result of individual differences in areas of the brain that process language."
An MRI shows the physical differences in the brain composition of a dyslexic thinker versus a non-dyslexic thinker. Dyslexia is so common that one in five people are a dyslexic learners.
What is it like to have dyslexia? How can I help and support a dyslexic learner? What are the early indicators of dyslexia? These questions and many others will be answered at 6:30 p.m., Feb. 20, at the "Experience Dyslexia: A Dyslexia Simulation" workshop at the Queen Anne's County Library Kent Island Branch location.
The free event, hosted by Decoding Dyslexia Maryland Eastern Shore Chapter, aims to raise dyslexia awareness, empower families to support their children, encourage educational interventions, and ultimately influence policy makers to support Maryland students with dyslexia.
All are welcome. The event will offer six stations to help understand the dyslexic learner: Learn to Read, Listen to Me, Write with Mirrors, Name the Letter, Write or Left, and Unfair Hearing Test.
Parte says,"The two biggest takeaways I have learned over the last year of my deep dive into my son's brain and the way he learns are early identification is crucial (as young as five-years-old); and the dyslexic brain requires instruction to be explicit, systematic, cumulative and multisensory.
"It should integrate the teaching of listening, speaking, reading, spelling, vocabulary, fluency, handwriting and written expression. There should be an emphasis on the structure of language: phonology, orthography, morphology, syntax and semantics. Training teachers and educating parents is also of the utmost importance," she continued.
Since then, Lincoln has helped his mom set up and lead workshops. In October, to celebrate Dyslexia Awareness Month, this mother and son duo led the Halloween-themed workshop entitled "There is nothing scarier than not being able to read."
Parte believes in dyslexia awareness and education with her whole being, which is why she fundraised, on her own, to purchase the upcoming workshop materials.
After more than three years of advocating, Parte promotes all adults to learn as much as they can by listening to podcasts, attending free trainings, reading books and fact sheets, and much more.
Moving forward, what steps can we take?
"Release the stigma. Embrace the label," Parte said. "The label means freedom. It gives a child the right to read. The right to appropriate instruction which in turns means success in reading and regaining self confidence. We got our child back the moment we told him he had dyslexia. The label opens a world of resources for your child to feel good about themselves. Priority is a child's mental and social wellbeing."
Dyslexic Learners have many strengths and show a lot of leadership skills. Some other positive skills of dyslexic learners include: problem-solving, big picture thinking, creativity, empathetic, and entrepreneurial skills.
Parte shared things parents can do to help their struggling reader if they suspect their child has dyslexia:
Testing is everything. You will be surprised how relieved your child is with a "diagnosis".
Finding the right intervention specialist (tutors in reading are not the same as someone trained and certified in structured reading interventions like Orton Gillingham). Tutoring at least three times a week is most effective. The key to remediation is "go as fast as you can and as slow as you need to". Early intervention is crucial especially to maintain your child's confidence in school.
Deep dive in your own research. It will help with advocacy, ensuring the right assessments are being used, and knowing the right questions to vet organizations and other folks who claim to want to help your student.
Read to your child not so they learn to read but so that they develop their reading comprehension and vocabulary while they are learning to read with appropriate interventions.
If your child receives the diagnosis of dyslexia, tell them, she encourages. Share all the amazing qualities a dyslexic thinker has and famous people who have dyslexia. Show them a photograph of a dyslexic brain vs typical brain.
Knowledge and support in this process are so important. You don't have to go through this emotional journey alone. Connect with your local Decoding Dyslexia chapter.
Parte explains, "Most children with dyslexia can succeed in school with tutoring or a specialized education program. Emotional support also plays an important role.
Though there's no cure for dyslexia, early assessment and intervention result in the best outcome. Sometimes dyslexia goes undiagnosed for years and isn't recognized until adulthood, but it's never too late to seek help."
Community support, awareness, education, and training will help all our learners learn in the best ways to be successful, happy learners. Together, we can impact our future and the future of our children. If you cannot attend the workshop at the library but are interested in gaining resources and learning more, you can email decodingdyslexiaES@gmail.com for more information and for a Welcome Newsletter with a list of more resources.
Currently, Decoding Dyslexia Maryland Eastern Shore Chapter is a grassroots movement (not a nonprofit), which means it has no funding and is paid for all out-of-pocket. It is run by parents who are also working professionals.
"The fight continues," Parte said, "Until every single child (and their families) don't have to go through this hell and back to learn how to read."
To support and make a donation to Decoding Dyslexia Maryland Eastern Shore Chapter, you can also email Parte at the email above.

title: DCTC Masonry instructor surprised by coworkers on last day
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
DCTC Masonry instructor surprised by coworkers on last day

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — On his last day of teaching at the Dorchester Career and Technology Center, Masonry Instructor Eddie Bailey wasn't the only one sporting a baseball cap, grey sweatshirt and jeans.More than 10 of his coworkers showed up and showed out in Bailey's well-known uniform. Some of his doppelgängers even brought their own fake metal detectors — a hobby of Bailey's.
After eight years teaching at DCTC, Bailey is hanging up his trowel and picking up his metal detector.
"You know, I love metal detecting, so I'll probably go find the Holy Grail or something," he said about what he will do in his retirement.
When Bailey came in for his last day of teaching, right before winter break began, it took a little while for him to figure out what his coworkers had done.
"I'm like, 'Wait a minute, something don't look right,'" he said. "Then, when I saw the metal detectors, I was like, 'Ohh, they got me good!'"
DCTC Principal Ashley Robinson came up with the idea.
"I was just trying to really think about how we could celebrate his time here in a way that he would enjoy and that he would feel appreciated," she said. "So I really thought the best way to do that would be with humor, since that's something he really enjoys."
In order to keep it a surprise, Robinson said she made it a part of the school's holiday spirit week.
"So he thought everyone was just dressing in comfy sweatshirts," she said. "And I let everyone else know we were really just dressing like Mr. Bailey."
Bailey, who was surprised by his coworkers' plan, thought it was funny.
"It was so great because I wasn't expecting it," he said. "I would have never expected that."
Bailey said he knew Robinson had something to do with it.
"She comes up with such cool stuff," he said, adding that she gave him a plaque with a trowel on it to commemorate his time teaching at DCTC.
He said there's a reason he would wear the similar outfit that his coworkers knew so well to work everyday.
"Working in the masonry, you can't really go in there with real good clothes on," he said. "You gotta wear your oldest stuff. Like, inside my car, all you see is dust."
Robinson said Bailey, like the rest of DCTC's staff members, epitomizes the importance of CTE education.
"The majority of the teachers here have worked in industry in their field, they have those life experiences and then they chose to come back and give back and work with kids to set them up to be successful," she said. "We were happy to have (Bailey) and happy that he was able to do this."
Bailey has had a few different careers over the years. He owned a masonry business, was a prison guard and spent four years in the Marine Corps. But teaching is in Bailey's blood. His father taught at James M. Bennett High School in Salisbury.
"He was football coach, track coach," Bailey said. "And we lived right across the street from Bennett, so I was at school every day. I knew it from top to bottom."
He has memories of cigarette smoke "flying out of the teachers' lounge" and teachers coming over to his family's house to play cards with his father.
"I mean, that was the good old days," he said.
Looking toward his retirement, Bailey has plans to further explore the hobby his DCTC coworkers know he loves.
Bailey said the Career and Technology Center staff knew about his metal detecting because he would send them photos of some of his finds.
Over the last five years, Bailey said he has gotten more and more into metal detecting. His neighbors, known as The Hoover Boys on YouTube, post metal detecting videos. They have over 100,000 YouTube subscribers. When they moved next door, Bailey said they started giving him their hand-me-downs.
Over the years, Bailey has found all sorts of things — from shoe buckle frames to Civil War bullets to cannonballs. Two of his major finds were a rare George Washington inaugural button and a pine tree shilling.
Although he has plans to do more detecting, Bailey said he'll miss his students.
"A lot of them played sports, and I'd hook them up with a sub," he said. "It was always a sub, a red Gatorade, orange Doritos."
As he moves on to his next chapter, Bailey now has fond memories of his own teaching experience to look back on.
"Oh I loved it," he said.

title: After-school activities canceled, some Wednesday delays in place due to strong storm
author: Natalie Jones
content:
After-school activities canceled, some Wednesday delays in place due to strong storm

 January 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 574
 Words 

 Read News Document

 UPDATE 1:30 p.m. Tuesday: Impending heavy rains, gusty winds and flooding from the powerful storm system moving across the region have prompted local school districts to cancel after-school activities Tuesday, with delays and closures possible Wednesday.Dorchester County Public Schools are operating on a half-day dismissal schedule Tuesday, with all after-school activities canceled. All of the county's schools will be operating on a two-hour delay schedule Wednesday, Jan. 10, for evaluation of overnight flooding and storm damage, according to the school system.
Queen Anne's County Public Schools were also dismissed early Tuesday due to the storm. As of Tuesday afternoon, all of the county's schools are set to run on a 90-minute delayed opening Wednesday, with reevaluation and modifications possible in the morning.
Schools in Talbot and Caroline counties canceled all after-school activities Tuesday. Both districts are monitoring conditions to determine if delays or closures will be necessary Wednesday.
The Caroline County Board of Education meeting will be held as scheduled at 6 p.m. Tuesday.
Gov. Wes Moore enacted a State of Preparedness declaration Tuesday morning, directing the state's department of emergency management to coordinate responses to the storm's impacts.
Rainfall of 1 to 3 inches is possible across the region Tuesday, with the heaviest rain expected Tuesday night before tapering off Wednesday morning, according to the National Weather Service.
The main concern is the potential for coastal flooding in Talbot and Queen Anne's counties, said Mike Lee, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service's Philadelphia/Mount Holly office. Dorchester County is also expected to experience significant flooding.
A coastal flood warning is in effect from 7 p.m. Tuesday to 7 p.m. Wednesday for areas along the lower Chesapeake Bay, including Cambridge, which will see major impact from flooding early Wednesday morning, according to the Weather Service. Water is expected be two to three feet above ground level in some low-lying areas.
A coastal flood warning and a flood watch are in effect for Talbot, Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent counties from Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning.
Moderate coastal flooding is possible Tuesday with the high tide cycle. Water levels are expected to continue rising Tuesday night from strong southerly winds. The rising water levels could lead to potentially significant flooding.
The highest tides will be early Wednesday morning and again in the afternoon.
Widespread roadway flooding is expected across the region's bayside communities and along tidal waterways. Dorchester County could see road closures.
Strong, gusty winds are also expected to build across the region throughout the day Tuesday.
Dorchester County is under a high wind warning from 4 p.m. Tuesday to 4 a.m. Wednesday, with south to southeast winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 60 mph possible. Fallen trees, downed power lines and widespread power outages are expected.
Talbot, Caroline, Kent and Queen Anne's counties are under a wind advisory from 5 p.m. Tuesday to 3 a.m. Wednesday. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 mph are expected, with gusts up to 55 mph.
The already-saturated ground in the region has also made trees more vulnerable to becoming uprooted with strong winds.
The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services urged residents to make sure loose items are secured ahead of time and reminded residents to not drive through or stand in flooded roadways.
The region will dry out some on Thursday, but a second storm is likely to roll through the region again Friday night into Saturday, the Weather Service said.

title: Superintendent of schools to retire in 2024
author: Staff Writer
content:
Superintendent of schools to retire in 2024

 January 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 987
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Superintendent of Kent County Public Schools, Dr. Karen Couch will be retiring at the end of the current school year, effective June 30. The announcement came at this month's Board of Education meeting. Board President Joe Goetz and Vice President Francoise Sullivan were re-elected to their positions during the Jan. 8 meeting as well.Couch said it has been an honor to collaborate with the exceptional team of administrators, teachers, staff and board members.
"Our collective commitment to the students and families of this county has been profound," Couch said. "Throughout my tenure, we achieved significant milestones, a testament to our collective dedication to excellence in education. This commitment consistently drove us to adapt and innovate, ensuring our students receive the best education possible."
Upon the delivery of Couch's announcement, Goetz, described the meeting as a "heavy night" with the weight of the superintendent's decision in the air.
"But you're not gone," Goetz told Dr. Couch. "And we'll have time to celebrate and we'll have time to reflect on where we've been and where we're going."
Goetz said everyone is a link in the chain driving KCPS, with many having come before them and more to follow. He said they will all do the best they can to continue providing students with a top-quality education.
"Working with you has been an absolute joy," Goetz said to Couch. "There's been a lot of ups and downs, but we'll celebrate all that as we move forward."
As a first step in the KCPS leadership transition, the Board of Education is holding a special meeting at 5:30 p.m. Tuesday, Jan. 23 to discuss the search for the next superintendent. The meeting will be held at the KCPS Administrative Building, 5608 Boundary Ave., Rock Hall.
Couch is retiring in the back half of her third four-year term as the superintendent of KCPS. Her most recent contract renewal was approved in the spring of 2021 for four years.
She first came on board at KCPS on July 1, 2013, having led a candidate field of nearly 20 applicants.
Couch was named the Maryland Superintendent of the Year in 2021. She made her mark on KCPS early, launching a technological revolution by bringing computers and smartboards into classrooms, greatly expanding teachers' and students' access to educational resources.
She built a collaborative environment in schools through fostering professional learning communities, which brought teachers together to share best practices to help reach all students.
She also made KCPS one of the first school systems in Maryland to adopt universal all-day prekindergarten, giving children an important head start on their education. "Amidst numerous budgetary challenges, including declining enrollment and limited resources,
we remained committed to prioritizing organizational improvements and addressing the diverse needs of our students and staff," Couch said.
She improved the school buildings themselves through targeted renovations, enhanced safety features like security vestibules and launching the planning process for a new middle school.
"During my tenure, we also executed a comprehensive six-year Facilities Strategic Plan,
revitalizing educational facilities untouched for over 25 years," she said. "Moreover, we successfully fulfilled preliminary state requirements for the construction of a new middle school while advocating for legislation to increase state funding participation for the project."
Sullivan, praised Couch's professionalism in the face of myriad challenges including tight budgets, declining student enrollment and the COVID pandemic. "You have helped our schools accomplish so much in the time that you've been here and it hasn't been easy," Sullivan told Couch. "You have always been professional and represented our schools really well, and I can only imagine how tough that probably was for some things."
Hailing from New Mexico, Dr. Couch previously served from 2001 to 2013 as the superintendent of the Moriarty-Edgewood School District, about an hour east of Albuquerque. In 2010, she was honored as the New Mexico Superintendent of the Year.
Couch moved to Kent County with a reputation for having turned that rural school district into one of the top-achieving in the state through a focus of continuous school improvement and the incorporation of research-based education programming.
She has likewise implemented similar strategies at KCPS, increasing the visibility and participation in the Career and Technical Education (CTE) program at Kent County High School, encouraging the growth of Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) programs and training elementary school teachers in the renowned Orton-Gillingham method of English language arts instruction.
Trish McGee, the longest serving among the current Board of Education members, was first elected the year after Couch's hiring. McGee covered the search process that saw Dr. Couch come onboard as the associate editor of the Kent County News.
Speaking at the Jan. 8 Board meeting, McGee said Couch paid out of her own pocket for travel from New Mexico to Kent County for one of her first interview visits. McGee said that showed just how prepared Couch was willing to go the distance to address the challenges faced by KCPS.
"I think every decision she ever made personally and professionally was really about how to move our school district forward," McGee said. "And I can't think of a greater legacy than something like that."
Couch's tenure at KCPS caps off a career in education that began in 1980 when she became a kindergarten teacher in the Las Cruces Public Schools in southern New Mexico. She was then employed by the Alamogordo Public Schools and rose through the ranks in that district from teacher to principal and, ultimately associate superintendent.
Along the way, she earned her master's degree and later received her doctorate in educational administration from New Mexico State University.
Couch said she is confident that KCPS will continue to nurture and inspire every child who walks through its doors and she eagerly anticipates hearing all those future success stories.
"As I begin a new chapter, I know that our work has laid a strong foundation for continued student success," Couch said. "The legacy of our efforts is not in the programs we've started or the facilities we've renovated, but in the lives of the students we've touched."

title: CBMM’s Shipyard offers 'Apprentice for a Day' programs

CBMM’s Shipyard offers 'Apprentice for a Day' programs

 The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's Shipyard in St. Michales has an "array of hands-on programs on tap this winter through its Apprentice for a Day Program."According to a release from the local, waterside museum, upcoming opportunities to be a part of CBMM's working waterfront include Shipyard Workdays on Feb. 3, Feb. 17, March 9, and March 30, plus a Leather Working Workshop (Jan. 27-28) and a Dovetail "Ditty Box" Workshop (Feb. 23-25).
These limited-capacity programs are led by Shipyard staff and experienced guest instructors and offer discounted pricing for CBMM members. Advance registration is required. To register and get more information about Apprentice for a Day programming, visit cbmm.org/afad.
Held on select Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. throughout the year, CBMM's Shipyard Workdays offer the chance to learn the fundamentals of boat building and repair while working on new construction and restoration projects. Right now, the projects include the restoration of Concordia sloop Osprey and the refit of 1920 buyboat Winnie Estelle.
The cost for a Shipyard workday is $60 per participant with a 20% discount for CBMM members. Participants must be at least 16 years old or accompanied by an adult.
The Leather Working Workshop is led by CBMM Curatorial Shipwright Sam Hilgartner. The two-day program "is designed to share both the basics and more complex intricacies of leather working for marine applications. This includes identifying leather types, hole punching, stitching techniques, leather conditioning, pattern making, and leather tool usage," according to the release.
Participants will learn while working on a simple project of their choosing, such as a knife and spike sheath, oar wrap, wheel wrap, or sheet block covering. All tools and materials are provided in the cost of registration, which is $100 with a 20% discount for CBMM members.
Participants in the Dovetail "Ditty Box" Workshop spend three days in the Shipyard constructing a custom mahogany box modeled on the ones in which sailors historically made to hold their most cherished belongings while on the water.
Instructor Grigg Mullen will teach participants how to cut dovetail joints, shape the top-edge profile, make and set holly inlays, and set the hardware on their box, which will be roughly 4 inches by 6 ½ inches by 11 ¼ inches. All materials are included in the cost of registration, which is $625 with a 20% discount for CBMM members.
Spring Apprentice for Day programs include a marine welding course in partnership with Chesapeake College (March 22-24) and Small Diesel Engine Familiarization & Maintenance (April 8-9 and 15-16).
The Coffee & Wood Chips programs with Shipyard Education Programs Manager Jenn Kuhn returns on Feb. 20, sharing the latest updates on all that's happening in the Shipyard.
For more: cbmm.org

title: Talbot Board of Education discusses proposed budget, Blueprint's affects
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Talbot Board of Education discusses proposed budget, Blueprint's affects

 January 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 621
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — At a Talbot County Board of Education meeting Wednesday, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi and Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones went over the proposed fiscal year 2025 budget.At the beginning of their presentation, Pepukayi shared the Board of Education and superintendent priorities. These priorities are to improve economic equity and achievement in math; foster an engaging environment for students and staff; recruit, promote and retain staff and meet the the Blueprint for Maryland's Future objectives.
The Blueprint is a plan, passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021, that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state through increasing education funding by $3.8 billion each year over the next 10 years.
Talbot County Public Schools' current draft fiscal year 2025 budget is $80.03 million. According to the presentation, the proposed budget is $7.98 million more than that of the fiscal year prior.
After Pepukayi spoke, Jones listed where those increases to the budget come from. These include the addition of 16 positions and money set aside to achieve a $60,000 starting salary for teachers by fiscal year 2027, a Blueprint requirement aimed at attracting and retaining high quality and diverse teachers.
The district's budget increase in technology devices and software costs is due to the expiration of COVID-19-related grants. Jones said a significant amount of annual technology costs had come out of grant money over the past few years.
"Those grants are expiring," she said. "So that translates to an increase in our request for FY25."
Another reason for the budget increase is the district's community school initiatives for next year.
According to the Maryland State Department of Education, community schools work with community partners, local governments and other stakeholders "to identify and address structural and institutional barriers to achievement." These schools receive Concentration of Poverty Grants, which give schools startup funding and per-pupil dollars to sustain them.
Jones said Easton Middle School will be coming on as a new community school and that Easton Elementary School is in its third year as a community school. She said the cost increases for these initiatives are mainly payroll related.
Jones said there are two potential reductions that could be made to the proposed budget that would save about $259,000 "without impacting student learning."
The first possible reduction would be to bring down the budget line for dual enrollment. Jones said the district realized, after getting the bill from Chesapeake College, that it had overestimated costs — particularly for instruction materials.
The second possible reduction would be to pay over time for a new school bus the district intends to buy, rather than paying for the bus in full.
After the presentation, Board President Emily Jackson asked if it was possible for the district to quantify how much of that $7.98 million increase directly applies to the Blueprint.
"I want to make sure we are telling our story in a way that is effective to the people who have to go and approve the budget and understand why we are asking for this much more money," she said.
Jones said Jackson's ask is a challenge because the Blueprint is "so embedded in what we're doing" that it's hard to differentiate which costs are tied to the Blueprint and which aren't. But, she said that, of the 16 new positions, she could say which were specifically tied to the Blueprint.
Board Vice President Candace Henry said past cuts to the budget could speak to the Blueprint's affect on the proposed fiscal year 2025 budget.
"We could speak to things that we've had to cut out of previous years, and now — because of Blueprint — we have to have," she said. "So I think we can use some of that information to tell that story to the public as well."

title: Superintendent shares schools' budget constraints with Commissioners
author: Connie Connolly

Superintendent shares schools' budget constraints with Commissioners

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County Public Schools officials shared good news and bad news with the Caroline County Commissioners at a Jan. 16 meeting.The good news: Caroline County Public Schools ended the year with a $3.25 million surplus.
The not-so-good news: The Blueprint for Maryland's Future unfunded mandate puts the fiscal squeeze on the budget and pandemic-based grant funding disappears in fiscal year 2025, officials said.
Chief Finance Officer Erin Thornton and Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons shared with the commissioners what they need to prepare for as the school district's budget planning continues.
"We have always been good stewards of the money and we're fiscally conservative, trying not to just spend money just to spend it, so we were prepared to end the year with money on the books," Thornton said.
The unassigned fund balance is currently at $9.5 million, "which is approximately 8.4% of our current operating budget," she said. "Our target range for a fund balance is one to 10%. So, we are approaching a high, which is where we want to be."
Commissioner Frank Bartz asked about maintaining support services salaries, something that he said is not addressed in the Blueprint.
"A lot of people in the county work for support services," he said. "I just want to make sure that they're taken care of."
"You're spot on," Simmons said. "The Blueprint addresses teachers only and leaves out two-thirds of our workgroup, and (it) does not take into consideration any support staff or administration. Required increases to salaries are … for the most part, to classroom-based teachers with kids on the workload."
Simmons said the Supportive Services Association is a negotiated employee group.
"Their contract was ratified to be closed from 2012 until next year, so that has been a closed contract with a required 1% in step every year, and then it's 1% in addition to whatever the teachers get. Their contract comes open next year for us to negotiate."
Simmons said the "biggest challenge that we're going to see this year" is the Blueprint formula's increase of 1.7% over last year's budget "when inflation is currently still running over 3%, and that factors in no increases in health insurance, which is probably 5% to 7% right now, we're hearing."
That percentage does not factor in any pay increase. Blueprint requires first-year classroom teachers to be earning $60,000 by fiscal year 2027.
"After this year, the budget increases roughly 5%," Simmons said. "We're sitting in a different position in our county than some of our colleagues are in others. … A lot of the larger systems are looking at significant cuts of teaching positions because (of) that 1.7% increase. It's a regressive budget no matter how you cut it, when it's only that much of an increase, and the cost of living is definitely a lot higher."
When COVID funding and (Maryland) Leads funding "dries up in September at the same time as we're getting a 1.7% increase, that's the perfect storm," Simmons said. "And again, we'll weather it for our staff. We'll figure it out. I really, truly believe we will. It's just going to be a really tough year."

title: DCPS presentations show improvements in the district
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com

DCPS presentations show improvements in the district

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Kindergarten readiness among Dorchester County kindergarteners is up 7% from last school year.This was one of multiple data points shared during a Dorchester County Board of Education meeting Jan. 18 that show improvements among Dorchester County Public Schools.
Jodi Colman, DCPS director of curriculum, instruction and assessment, gave a presentation on the most recent Kindergarten Readiness Assessment results.
Assessment results are broken down into three sections: demonstrating readiness, approaching readiness and emerging readiness.
According to Colman's presentation, a student who is demonstrating kindergarten readiness "has most of the foundational skills and behaviors necessary for kindergarten." A student who is approaching readiness has some of those foundational skills and behaviors. A student who is emerging readiness has few of those foundational skills and behaviors.
The percent of kindergarteners demonstrating readiness went up to 39% this school year from 32% last school year. The year before that, in the 2021-2022 school year, 29% of students were demonstrating kindergarten readiness.
"I wish I had some confetti and a little horn to celebrate," Colman said about this year's results.
Although the percentage of students demonstrating readiness went up this school year, so did the percentage of students emerging readiness. It was at 38% this school year compared to 30% last year.
The percentage of students approaching readiness decreased to 33% this school year from 38% last school year.
The district saw an increase in the number of its kindergarteners demonstrating readiness in language and literacy and mathematics, but it saw a decrease in its kindergarteners demonstrating readiness in social foundations and physical well-being and motor development.
"I do think that speaks to the level of need for some of our students in the younger grades and the mental health supports that they need, the social development that they need," Colman said. "Those are our COVID babies and I think that kind of hit us here."
STAR RATINGS
Colman also presented on the different star ratings for each school in the district. Star ratings are given by the state and determined by different academic and school quality indicators.
According to Colman's presentation, every school except for Vienna Elementary School kept it's star rating from the year before. Vienna Elementary went down from four stars in the 2021-2022 school year to three stars in the 2022-2023 school year.
Colman said three DCPS schools that were less than one percentage point away from gaining another star. Those schools were Mace's Lane Middle School, Sandy Hill Elementary School and North Dorchester Middle School.

title: Student writes graphic novel about Frederick Douglass
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Student writes graphic novel about Frederick Douglass

 January 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 466
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A recent graduate of Washington College, Andrea C. Proimos spent her final semesters at school creating a web-based graphic novel about traveling in the footsteps of Frederick Douglass.This novel, aimed at young adults, is a playful and curious take on a serious subject. The author wrote it in conjunction with her thesis while completing her bachelor's degree in English.
In it, there are mixed photographs, fine art, cartoons and mixed media together.
After receiving a $3,000 Sophie Kerr Promise Grant, Proimos and her dog, Zelda, traveled from Easton's farm fields, to the city of Baltimore, to Douglass' gravesite in Rochester, New York. It was travel in search of the famed abolitionist's life story.
"This book follows his actual narrative from when Douglass was born to when he escaped to freedom. This tells his biographical story," Promios said about her graphic novel, which she wrote with information gleaned from her travels.
She marvels at his place in history and her own.
"I wonder how many spots Zelda and I stood exactly where Douglass had stood. Each place we went uncovered new information and new stories about Douglass and the early formation of American history. We were able to immerse ourselves in the scenery and make new discoveries through museums, national forest exhibits, books, murals and all kinds of unexpected representations."
The writer said that she moved to Easton while completing her studies and found herself living right next to history.
"When I moved to Easton, they were having a huge debate about a Confederate monument that was still outside of the courthouse. As the community was having this debate, a mural was painted by Michael Rosato. His was the first mural to go up. As I was finishing my thesis statement, Adam Himhoff's mural went up. I was kind of living in the middle of Douglass history that was still going on," she said.
She said she wrote her thesis on the multi-dimensional nature of Douglas. The book "Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass" strikes her as more than just a book and was the spine of her paper.
"I explored a lot of representations, like statues and graphic representations, because that was important to his image as he was the most photographed man of the 19th century. He was way ahead of his time. He was like the American dream of the underdog," she said.
The graphic novel contains lots of photographs of primary historical sites and whimsical drawings by Proimos.
"I can read the graphic novel with my 9-year-old. She is not going to get everything. It is meant to go with the 'Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass.' But there are cartoony elements in there that are fun and light hearted. It shows you that Frederick Douglass is a relatable person," she said.
To read her graphic novel, go to: frederickdouglasseaston.blogspot.com

title: Leonard Hall school closes after lease, maintenance issues arise
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Leonard Hall school closes after lease, maintenance issues arise

 January 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 762
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A St. Mary's County landmark is no more after the commissioners decided to terminate the lease of the Leonard Hall Junior Naval Academy Tuesday in Leonardtown.The school's lease was slated to end June 30, but the school closed last week.
"It's not about wanting to cancel somebody's lease," Commissioner Mike Hewitt said. "It's not about wanting to take away a school that has been in this county for over 100 years. It's about trying to find a plan that allows that school to continue."
The situation became sticky last week when a letter about the closing of the school was prematurely sent to the school, which is in the same complex of buildings where the commissioners meet weekly.
"That was our mistake," Commissioner President Randy Guy said.
The school was paying county government $12,000 a year in rent.
The commissioners voted Tuesday to end the lease, but Commissioner Eric Colvin was against closing the school.
"I've heard the incredible impact the school has had in helping students turn their lives around," he said. "My opposition in ending this lease is that I did not feel as if there were enough alternatives evaluated. I felt that we could have worked with the school a little bit more to try and find a solution and I'm still opposed to it."
A handful of supporters of the school, including alumni, attended the meeting, though no one spoke to the commissioners. When asked, the group said Headmistress Sarah Green was not in attendance.
Olivia Flynn, one of the supporters, said on Tuesday the school had positively impacted her.
Her first year at the school she received 52 infractions in one quarter — three are enough to warrant discipline — but that number dwindled rapidly over the next few years and she said graduated as a top student leader in 2018.
"It's a process and its a fellowship with the teachers and a mentorship built with the administrators," Flynn said in an interview with Southern Maryland News after Tuesday's meeting. "It helped me deal with conflict, it also helped me build good relationships with people and helped me prepare for life."
Flynn returned to the school which served grades 6 through 12, in 2022 as a history, English and algebra teacher.
County Attorney Buffy Giddens went over a timeline of events, beginning with the school being given a fresh 10-year lease in 2013.
On Feb. 28, 2023, the county received an email request from Green to renew the lease as well as fix the AC unit, which was estimated to be about $100,000.
In May, an assessment looked at 27 systems, which discovered a host of needed repairs and maintenance. The estimate was $575,000 with the school on the hook for about $250,000.
Flynn said "no one else in the school was informed" of the needed upgrades, despite the school's extensive alumni and parent network.
Three months later, the commissioners advised Green of the maintenance issues identified in the facilities assessment and requested a financial sustainability plan by the end of 2023.
"We wanted to give them a chance to rectify the situation," Hewitt said. "We told them, 'We need to hear from you, we need to hear your plan,' but we didn't hear anything for a couple of months."
Green was unable to be reached for comment this week by Southern Maryland News.
Hewitt said the school retained an attorney in October.
"My first thought was, 'Why are you wasting money on an attorney? We need you to get to work on this,'" he said. "Then commissioners are no longer talking to headmistresses, [instead] attorneys are talking to attorneys."
Green submitted 10-year and 15-year plans on Dec. 22. One of the points in the plan was to apply for a grant, which was dependent on a long-term lease from the county and was due by Jan. 12.
Hewitt said the grant would have provided a maximum of just $100,000, and added most schools receive about $23,000.
"Years ago that was a thriving school with hundreds of kids," Hewitt said of Leonard Hall, which had 38 students this year before it closed. "It's not that way anymore. It wasn't the idea that we wanted to close the school. We don't, but the business plan just isn't working."
Hewitt added that "subsidizing the cost of a private school is not in the best interest of all the citizens. It's not fair to the thousands of people who send their kids to public school that the county subsidize a private school."
Hewitt said the commissioners have even looked at other locations for the school and added, "If something can be worked out in the future, we're more than willing to revisit it."

Flynn said "no one else in the school was informed" of the needed upgrades, despite the school's extensive alumni and parent network.
Three months later, the commissioners advised Green of the maintenance issues identified in the facilities assessment and requested a financial sustainability plan by the end of 2023.
"We wanted to give them a chance to rectify the situation," Hewitt said. "We told them, 'We need to hear from you, we need to hear your plan,' but we didn't hear anything for a couple of months."
Green was unable to be reached for comment this week by Southern Maryland News.
Hewitt said the school retained an attorney in October.
"My first thought was, 'Why are you wasting money on an attorney? We need you to get to work on this,'" he said. "Then commissioners are no longer talking to headmistresses, [instead] attorneys are talking to attorneys."
Green submitted 10-year and 15-year plans on Dec. 22. One of the points in the plan was to apply for a grant, which was dependent on a long-term lease from the county and was due by Jan. 12.
Hewitt said the grant would have provided a maximum of just $100,000, and added most schools receive about $23,000.
"Years ago that was a thriving school with hundreds of kids," Hewitt said of Leonard Hall, which had 38 students this year before it closed. "It's not that way anymore. It wasn't the idea that we wanted to close the school. We don't, but the business plan just isn't working."
Hewitt added that "subsidizing the cost of a private school is not in the best interest of all the citizens. It's not fair to the thousands of people who send their kids to public school that the county subsidize a private school."
Hewitt said the commissioners have even looked at other locations for the school and added, "If something can be worked out in the future, we're more than willing to revisit it."

title: Education needed on the juvenile crime law
author: STEPEHN RIDEOUT
content:
Education needed on the juvenile crime law

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPEHN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 732
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Juvenile Interrogation Protection Act that passed under the Hogan Administration has raised some concerns. While it appears that this law was carefully written and training materials were provided, the complaints seen in the news seem to indicate that insufficient training was provided to the police or the states' attorneys about its implementation.From my experience in Virginia, I know that when new legislation passes that makes significant changes to laws involving children, training on that legislation, before it goes into effect, is an important part of making a smooth transition to the new law. It appears that the time between the passage of this law and its implementation was sufficient to provide that training but may not have been done. At the same time, taking a second look at new laws to make minor changes is not unusual or out of the ordinary.
As I have thought about this law, one thing that is not being discussed with regard to concerns is how there is a significant difference between how children should be advised of their rights and questioned and how adults are advised of their rights. They are not the same. Children are not simply small adults.
Soon after becoming a juvenile court judge, I received training in a number of areas relating to children. One of them related to child development. Others were about ages when children are able to understand certain concepts and how to question children in a way that is age appropriate. The "Handbook on Questioning Children: A Linguistic Perspective" by Anne Grantham Walker was our guidebook as new judges.
It helped us understand what concepts children could understand at different developmental stages and ages in their lives and how to ask questions of them in a way that they understood so they could give truthful answers. When they were called to testify and take the oath to "tell the truth," I often had to ask them simple questions so that they understood what "telling the truth" meant. During trials, it was interesting to hear how police officers and lawyers would ask questions and get answers that seemed to mean one thing to them and mean something different to me.
As part of my responsibilities with newly charged youth in delinquency cases, I would advise the children of their rights to a lawyer and to remain silent. The police had done it and our Court Service Unit, similar to Maryland DJS, had done it.
I would not just go though the routine questions about their right to a lawyer and right to remain silent, as I knew that many if not most did not or could not understand those words. They might be too young or they might not have done well enough in school to be able to understand the advisement of rights form that we prepared for them.
So I would ask the question and then, after a response or no response, would ask them what that meant to them. My best guess is that close to 90-95% of those youth did not understand their rights before they came to court and few even understood them after I talked with them.
Their concerns and fears about being charged and in court and the possibility of their being locked up were what they were thinking about and not the questions from me or our conversation.
So the General Assembly was reasonably concerned about the whole issue of advisement of rights. An additional concern should be about how the police advise them of their rights. If it is a pro-forma reading as they do with adults, in my view, that is meaningless. So having a video or audio (preferably video) of the advisement is critical for the judge to be able to watch. In addition, how the public defender, under the current law, advises them is also important. Unless the lawyer uses language and understands the age and developmental age of the children he or she are speaking with, what they tell the youth may not help much, if at all.
While I have suggestions for some modifications to the law that I have shared with some of the members of the General Assembly, the most important suggestion would be to be sure that all of the police and lawyers who speak with or advise youth in these matters be trained on how to properly communicate with children.
Stephen Rideout is the mayor in Cambridge.

title: House GOP introduces bill to repeal Biden college plan
author: MATHEW SCHUMER Capital News Service
content:
House GOP introduces bill to repeal Biden college plan

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MATHEW SCHUMER Capital News Service | Section: National 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The House Committee on Education and the Workforce has advanced a Republican-sponsored bill that includes measures repealing key aspects of the Biden administration's plans to make college more affordable.The College Cost Reduction Act, introduced by the panel's chairwoman, Rep. Virginia Foxx (R-North Carolina), passed on a party-line 22-19 vote.
The measure presents numerous programs intended to strengthen the integrity of higher education institutions across the country, but also would gut much of President Joe Biden's efforts to help students afford college. Democrats on the committee offered a series of amendments to the bill aimed at blocking the GOP repeals, but all were defeated.
"Unfortunately, President Biden has decided time and time again that the executive branch should also hold the legislative pen," Foxx said, "Congress has the task of creating laws that reflect the interests of the people. It is not the role of the executive pen."
Last August, the Biden administration launched the Saving on a Valuable Education (SAVE) program, aiming to cancel debt to borrowers who originally owed $12,000 or less in loans and had repaid at least ten years of those loans.
The program is slated to begin in February, with 6.9 million Americans already enrolled, according to the White House.
Biden's original plan, as laid out in his 2022 executive order to cancel up to $430 billion in student loans, was blocked by the Supreme Court in a 6-3 decision last June. The court determined that the secretary of education lacked the power to issue debt relief on the scale described in the administration's plan.
Last September, Foxx introduced a resolution with Rep. Lisa McClain, R-Michigan, to nullify the SAVE plan, but the full House never voted on it.
Foxx's College Cost Reduction Act, introduced in January, would establish a streamlined data system to convey information about colleges, create a performance-based grant program, and hold academic institutions responsible for unpaid student loans.
In the committee meeting to consider the bill, Democrats introduced 30 amendments to alter some fundamental aspects of the legislation.
Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Virginia) praised parts of Foxx's bill, "such as codifying Postsecondary Student Success Grants and eliminating interest capitalization and origination fees on student loans," but the panel's ranking Democrat objected to some provisions that he said would make it harder for people to go to college.
Rep. Kathy Manning (D-Michigan) offered an amendment to strike language from the bill repealing Biden administration regulations to protect student borrowers during changes in ownership of academic institutions.
Another Biden administration regulation the Foxx bill aims to repeal is the 90-10 rule, which requires for-profit universities to secure at least 10 percent of their funding from non-federal sources. Rep. Mark Takano (D-California) introduced an amendment to strike this section from the final bill but was rebuffed by the GOP majority.
Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minnesota) offered a motion to remove the bill's rescission of Biden's SAVE plan, but that motion was defeated.
"The new (SAVE) program created by the Biden administration… creates a generous IDR (income-driven repayment) plan that Republicans now want to strip away," Omar said.
Rep. Suzanne Bonamici (D-Michigan) unsuccessfully tried to amend the bill with language streamlining the process of finding on-campus accommodations for students with disabilities.
Bonamici's proposal is part of a group of bills unveiled Monday by Democratic members of the education panel referred to collectively as the Roadmap to College Student Success.

title: New Fellowship of Christian Athletes club unites and inspires students
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
New Fellowship of Christian Athletes club unites and inspires students

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Life

 CENTREVILLE — As inspirational music plays, students filled the classroom."Get in here and eat donuts! What are you doing buddy? What's up pal?" Jeff Simmons welcomes everyone with his energetic and contagious excitement.
It's 7:30 a.m. on a Tuesday morning. School won't begin for more than an hour. What brings middle schoolers, teachers and community members out early before school?
For some students in Queen Anne and Talbot Counties, it's a new club called Fellowship of Christian Athletes. This club, or huddle, welcomes not only athletes but anyone who wants to come and make a difference.
Although FCA may be new to some local schools, it is well-known around the world. For over 60 years, FCA has had one mission — "unite your two passions, faith and athletics, to impact the world for Jesus Christ."
Founder Don McClanen started FCA after reading that 30 million American youth had no religious training. McClanen began posting his articles in the locker room and praying before games. Soon, he was dreaming of a way for well-known Christian athletes to advertise their faith on television and in magazines the way they advertised other household products. Currently, FCA is in 115 countries with over 20,000 huddle meetings occurring around the world.
At their first huddle, Centreville Middle students spent time together in fellowship.
The "Walk Out Faith'' huddle activity included scripture readings, a memory verse and relevant questions asking teens how they can grow their faith while also building the community around them.
Seventh Grade Social Studies teacher Thomas Hayman helps oversee the FCA huddle with other school staff. A former church youth director and a current Queen Anne's County Public Schools Teacher of the Year finalist, Hayman is dedicated to teaching and investing in his students. His loyalty doesn't go unnoticed, Hayman's students said he's told them he would even "take a bullet" to keep them safe.
Hayman said it was fate that allowed him to meet Simmons, a former CMS tutor, at the school and fate that put him in this position. Hayman said he is looking forward to the fellowship afforded by FCA "to get together, have fun and see what kind of positive change we can make."
Simmons is the area director of the Fellowship of Christian Athletes) for Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
He said he had not heard of FCA until a friend suggested he look into it. After research and attending some huddle meetings, he said he was "blown away by what they were doing, how they were doing it, and the impact it had.
In his new position, Simmons has to annually raise his entire budget. The success here is directly linked to the local community's involvement, Simmons said.
With all the huddles happening, there were still many middle and high schools in both Queen Anne's and Talbot counties that had no FCA presence and did not have the same opportunities.
In this monthly email update, Simmons wrote, "There are 9 schools (middle and high) between both counties that do not have any sort of FCA on their campuses."
With the generous support of the community, the 2024 FCA budget for Queen Anne's and Talbot counties was fully funded.
"Thanks to God's provision, coming in the form of generous one time donations and support from those who signed on as Monthly Partners, we reached the amount needed to support the program's budget for 2024" Simmons said.
"In order to establish FCA programming in the remaining schools, we need to fully fund our FCA budget with recurring donations," Simmons shared. "Securing our annual budget with recurring monthly support will allow us to start planning for the future of FCA on the Eastern Shore. This will allow us to not only provide resources and support to the huddles that are already up and running, but also to establish a FCA presence in the schools without one currently."
"Your support, whether it be in financial contributions, prayer and encouragement," Simmons continued, "has confirmed this community's commitment to see Jesus glorified and lives changed through this ministry, and I am so grateful that we all get to be a part of it. God is working on the Shore through these coaches, students, and leaders and I know that the best is yet to come!"
If you would like more information or would like to volunteer, email Jeff Simmons at jsimmons@fca.org.

 EASTON — The proposed Talbot County Public Schools fiscal year 2025 budget is headed to the County Council for final approval.At a Talbot County Board of Education meeting Wednesday evening, board members voted to approve the budget and send it to the Talbot County Council.

Capital requests include the renovation and expansion of Chapel District Elementary School, the installation of a turf field at Easton High School, the replacement of auditorium lights at Easton High School, the installation of a basketball court at Easton Elementary School, an update to the stadium lighting at Easton High School and a playground replacement at St. Michaels Elementary School.
Next month, the proposed budget will be presented to the County Council. A public budget hearing, held by the County Council, is set for May.

title: TCPS gives Blueprint updates
author: Maggie Trovato

TCPS gives Blueprint updates

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News

 EASTON — Updates regarding the Blueprint for Maryland's Future were shared at a Talbot County Board of Education meeting Wednesday.The Blueprint is a plan, passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021, that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state through increasing education funding by $3.8 billion each year over the next 10 years
Helga Einhorn, Talbot County Public Schools assistant superintendent for curriculum and instruction, gave updates at the meeting.
Einhorn said the Maryland State Department of Education has approved the College and Career Readiness Standard.
The approved standard — which determines whether students are mastering the standards necessary to prepare them for dual enrollment, advanced placement, post-secondary education and careers — offers two options.
First, students can be considered college and career ready if they have earned a high school grade point average of at least 3.0 and either earned an A, B or C in Algebra I or scored proficient or above on the Algebra I Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program.
The second way students can be considered college and career ready is if they score proficient or above on the English Language Arts 10 MCAP and Algebra I MCAP.
Einhorn said that if students do not meet the College and Career Readiness Standard, a team from the school will meet with that student and their family to develop a plan to get them on track.
Einhorn said this new standard will go into effect immediately. However, she said the interim standard will also remain in effect until July 1, 2025.
The interim standard states that students can be considered college and career ready if they achieve certain scores on either the Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for College and Careers, the early fall MCAP or the spring MCAP for both English 10 and either Algebra I, Algebra II or Geometry.
Another update Einhorn gave at the meeting is that the district has hired Sharon Gaskins as a strategic facilitator to support the district's efforts with the Blueprint.
"(Gaskins) has over 25 years in education and really has been a change agent working with organizations to ensure that they meet their goals," Einhorn said.
Einhorn said the district was able hire Gaskins using grant funding through the Blueprint's Accountability and Implementation Board.
Einhorn also gave an update on a report that the district will need to submit to the Accountability and Implementation Board and MSDE by March 15.
The report will detail the district's implementation of the Blueprint so far. Einhorn said this includes discussing any challenges the district might be facing with implementation.
This report is a way for the state to monitor that school districts are "able to transform" through reshaping and adapting new polices and practices that create a more equitable system, Einhorn said.
"I'm here tonight to assure you that we will meet that March 15 deadline," she said. "And I look forward to sharing some of the findings in that report."

title: Corporate tax breaks end up costing schools
author: THE CONVERSATION
content:
Corporate tax breaks end up costing schools

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: THE CONVERSATION | Section: National 
 
 1063
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Built in 1910, James Elementary is a three-story brick school in Kansas City, Missouri's historic Northeast neighborhood, with a bright blue front door framed by a sand-colored stone arch adorned with a gargoyle.As bustling students and teachers negotiate a maze of gray stairs with worn wooden handrails, Marjorie Mayes, the school's principal, escorts a visitor across uneven blue tile floors on the ground floor to a classroom with exposed brick walls and pipes. Bubbling paint mars some walls, evidence of the water leaks spreading inside the aging building.
"It's living history," said Mayes during a mid-September tour of the building. "Not the kind of living history we want."
The district would like to tackle the $400 million in deferred maintenance needed to create a 21st century learning environment at its 35 schools — including James Elementary — but it can't. It doesn't have the money.
PROPERTY TAX REDIRECT
The lack of funds is a direct result of the property tax breaks that Kansas City lavishes on companies and developers that do business there. The program is supposed to bring in new jobs and business but instead has ended up draining civic coffers and starving schools. Between 2017 and 2023, the Kansas City school district lost $237.3 million through tax abatements.
Kansas City is hardly an anomaly. An estimated 95% of U.S. cities provide economic development tax incentives to woo corporate investors. The upshot is that billions have been diverted from large urban school districts and from a growing number of small suburban and rural districts. The impact is seen in districts as diverse as Chicago and Cleveland, Hillsboro, Oregon, and Storey County, Nevada.
The result? A 2021 review of 2,498 financial statements from school districts across 27 states revealed that, in 2019 alone, at least $2.4 billion was diverted to fund tax incentives. Yet that substantial figure still downplays the magnitude of the problem, because three-quarters of the 10,370 districts analyzed did not provide any information on tax abatement agreements.
Tax abatement programs have long been controversial, pitting states and communities against one another in beggar-thy-neighbor contests. Their economic value is also, at best, unclear: Studies show most companies would have made the same location decision without taxpayer subsidies. Meanwhile, schools make up the largest cost item in these communities, meaning they suffer most when companies are granted breaks in property taxes.
A three-month investigation by The Conversation and three scholars with expertise in economic development, tax laws and education policy shows that the cash drain from these programs is not equally shared by schools in the same communities. At the local level, tax abatements and exemptions often come at the cost of critical funding for school districts that students from low-income households and who are racial minorities.
In Missouri, for example, in 2022 nearly $1,700 per student was redirected from Kansas City public and charter schools, while between $500 and $900 was redirected from wealthier, whiter Northland schools on the north side of the river in Kansas City and in the suburbs beyond. Other studies have found similar demographic trends elsewhere, including New York state, South Carolina and Columbus, Ohio.
The funding gaps produced by abated money often force schools to delay needed maintenance, increase class sizes, lay off teachers and support staff and even close outright. Schools also struggle to update or replace outdated technology, books and other educational resources. And, amid a nationwide teacher shortage, schools under financial pressures sometimes turn to inexperienced teachers who are not fully certified or rely too heavily on recruits from overseas who have been given special visa status.
Lost funding also prevents teachers and staff, who often feed, clothe and otherwise go above and beyond to help students in need, from earning a living wage. All told, tax abatements can end up harming a community's value, with constant funding shortfalls creating a cycle of decline.
INCENTIVES AND PAYOFFS
Perversely, some of the largest beneficiaries of tax abatements are the politicians who publicly boast of handing out the breaks despite the harm to poorer communities. Incumbent governors have used the incentives as a means of taking credit for job creation, even when the jobs were coming anyway.
"We know that subsidies don't work," said Elizabeth Marcello, a doctoral lecturer at Hunter College who studies governmental planning and policy and the interactions between state and local governments. "But they are good political stories, and I think that's why politicians love them so much."
While some voters may celebrate abatements, parents can recognize the disparities between school districts that are created by the tax breaks. Fairleigh Jackson pointed out that her daughter's East Baton Rouge third grade class lacks access to playground equipment.
The class is attending school in a temporary building while their elementary school undergoes a two-year renovation.
The temporary site has some grass and a cement slab where kids can play, but no playground equipment, Jackson said. And parents needed to set up an Amazon wish list to purchase basic equipment such as balls, jump ropes and chalk for students to use. The district told parents there would be no playground equipment due to a lack of funds, then promised to install equipment, Jackson said, but months later, there is none.
Jackson said it's hard to complain when other schools in the district don't even have needed security measures in place. "When I think about playground equipment, I think that's a necessary piece of child development," Jackson said. "Do we even advocate for something that should be a daily part of our kids' experience when kids' safety isn't being funded?"
A young student in the East Baton Rouge district told the school board that money going to tax breaks for corporations could provide better internet access or be used to hire someone to pick up the glass and barbed wire in the playground. But at least they have a playground — Hayden Crockett, a seventh grader at Sherwood Middle Academic Magnet School, noted that his sister's elementary school lacked one.
"If it wasn't in the budget to fund playground equipment, how can it also be in the budget to give one of the most powerful corporations in the world a tax break?" Crockett said. "The math just ain't mathing."
This article was written by Christine Wen, Texas A&M University; Danielle McLean, The Conversation; Kevin Welner, University of Colorado Boulder; and Nathan Jensen, The University of Texas at Austin. The Conversation is an independent and nonprofit source of news, analysis and commentary from academic experts.

title: Anti-war protests, rises in antisemitism magnify challenges for free speech on college campuses
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Anti-war protests, rises in antisemitism magnify challenges for free speech on college campuses

 February 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: National 
 
 408
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks inside Israel has birthed contentious protests on college campuses magnifying debates around free speech and how universities should handle ramped up and controversial rhetoric — including antisemitism.The debate can pitt students' and staff's free speech rights — especially at public universities — against safety and harassment concerns voiced by other students and employees.
"I think we forget that there is the possibility that even protected speech can create a hostile environment. I think that's important," said Shira Goodman, senior director of advocacy for the Anti-Defamation League, which has seen a rise in reports of antisemitism since Oct. 7.
Goodman said protests and events on campus can potentially run afoul of Title VI of the federal Civil Rights Act that protects students and others of "shared ancestry" and other protected classes from mistreatment and harassment at colleges and universities receiving federal financial aid and other government money.
The U.S. Department of Education is currently conducting Title VI shared ancestry investigations at more than 40 colleges — including Johns Hopkins University, Harvard University, University of Michigan, Montana State University, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, University of South Florida and University of Wisconsin-Madison.
On the other side of the issue, Haley Gluhanich, program officer for campus rights advocacy for the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, has seen an increase in calls from students and others across the political spectrum about their First Amendment rights being restricted.
"We are seeing events being canceled. We are seeing student organizations being de-chartered. We are seeing students and faculty members getting disciplined for social media posts for some comments made in class," Gluhanich said.
Protests against the war include criticism of U.S. and President Joe Biden's military and other support for Israel.
Gluhanich and Jane Kirtley, a professor of media ethics and law at the University of Minnesota, said even "hate speech" enjoys First Amendment and protections as long as it doesn't cross the line into more direct and specific threats or incites violence.
Kirtley worries about government actors (including at public universities) as well as wealthy donors discouraging speech they don't like.
She said that comes with peril and potential blowback.
"Once we open the door to allowing the government to tell us what thoughts aren't acceptable, we run the risk that, in the future, ideas with which we agree could be suppressed, as well," she said.
For a more expansive story on this issue check out StarDem.com and our e-edition on Monday, Feb. 26.

title: School board adopts 2024-2025 calendar
author: Connie Connolly
content:
School board adopts 2024-2025 calendar

 February 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 743
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County students will be heading back to school before Labor Day this year.Offered two alternatives — a pre- or post-Labor Day start — the five-member Board of Education voted unanimously Feb. 6 to approve the pre-Labor Day calendar for the 2024-2025 school year.
English, Spanish and Haitian Creole translations of the calendar are posted on the Caroline County Public Schools website.
The school year start date is Wednesday, Aug. 28.
CCPS Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons presented the two calendars, along with results of a survey distributed to parents, teachers and staff.
While the current school year calendar began after Labor Day, the school board considered factors that mitigated against the later start, including the presidential election day, which necessitates closing schools Tuesday, Nov. 5, and Christmas falling on a Wednesday.
Fall sports practices will begin Aug. 14. Winter break will begin Dec. 20.
The calendar committee emailed a link to the survey Jan. 12 to over 5,400 parents, guardians and all CCPS staff members. A reminder email was sent Jan. 22, and the survey was closed Jan. 26. Some community members provided feedback, as well.
Although 75% of the 3,500 parents and guardians who responded favored a post-Labor Day start, 696 staff respondents, or 70% preferred a pre-Labor Day start.
Before reviewing the feedback, Simmons cautioned the school board, saying, "No matter what decision you make, you're going to make people upset, period. There is no perfect calendar, period."
Board member and retired Caroline County teacher Donna DiGiacomo favored the earlier start.
"So, one calendar starts Aug 28; the other starts Sept. 3, but the end date is just one day difference," DiGiacomo said. The adopted calendar gets "students in a routine quicker, and you have a shorter week when you start — you have three days, so everybody's not dead by Friday."
She said a 4-day first day of school "doesn't sound like a lot, but it's a lot."
Winter break begins with a half-day Friday, Dec. 20, and students returning to school Jan. 7.
"A hard shutdown over winter break for two solid weeks" would result in reduced heating costs and "significant savings" during "the hardest budget year we're going to have," Simmons said.
The post-Labor Day calendar would have had students returning Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025.
"This might not be a popular thing to say, but the reality is not a whole lot is going to get done on that Thursday and Friday," DiGiacomo said.
Other factors influencing the pre-Labor Day start were academic quarter dates and required parent-teacher conferences, which "we talked about ad nauseum," Simmons said.
Calling the process "wonky" and comparing it to a game of dominoes, Simmons explained the factors that prompted the calendar committee to go through "seven or eight drafts to get down to the two that made the most sense."
For example, the first quarter parent-teacher conference day will occur Nov. 5, even though it's election day, because the first quarter ends Nov. 8 and the conference day "has to fall before the first report card goes out, before grades are secured," Simmons said.
The adopted calendar has four inclement weather days built in. If they are not used, they come off the calendar.
State law, teacher contracts, mandatory conferences, state testing days, a set number of half-days, a mid-year transition day all dictate certain days off. Once all of the days off are built in, "it becomes a game of counting to 90 twice" to achieve a state-mandated 180-day school year, Simmons said.
DiGiacomo recommended surveying students next year and considering staggered starts for sixth grade and ninth grade students as they change schools.
"The pluses of draft two are just not as many as the pluses in draft one," said Rick Barton, president of the school board.
Although he liked "the idea of a longer break," school board Vice President Mark Jones was ambivalent.
"I honestly don't like either one of them, really," he said.
That ambivalence was reflected in the overall survey results, with 54% of all respondents preferring a post-Labor Day start and 46% going with the pre-Labor Day calendar.
Anticipating mixed reactions from the public and staff as well, Jones asked, "When do we want to hear complaints? Do we want to hear them right before the first day of school, or do we want to hear them after Christmas break? I think I'd probably rather hear them at the beginning of the year and get it out of the way."
To view the 2024-2025 CCPS school year calendar, visit www.carolineschools.org/page/ccps-school-calendar. The calendars are available in English, Spanish and Haitian Creole.
