 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Public Schools' Spring 2024 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program successes — along with district concerns — were shared during a Board of Education meeting on Thursday.Although the district ranks in the state's bottom four for MCAP English and math proficiency rates, it did see year-to-year increases.
In English, the district rose 1.4% to 33.7% proficiency, ranking 22nd in the state out of 24 districts. In math, the district rose 1% to 12.3% proficiency, ranking 21st in the state.
During the meetingThursday, Jodi Colman, the district's assistant superintendent of academics and student services, showed proficiency rates and rankings in the state broken down by grade level.
Colman said there were eight grade levels where the district's state ranking in math increased and six grade levels where the district's state ranking in English increased.
In fifth grade science, where 14.4% of students were considered proficient on the 2024 MCAP assessment, the ranking went up to 20th in the state for 2024 compared to 22nd the previous year.
Colman said that at a statewide assistant superintendent meeting recently, Dorchester County was mentioned for its growth in third grade math, sixth grade math and middle school algebra.
"I thought that was nice to be highlighted across the state as seeing a district that is actually moving some of their scores," she said after mentioning that math scores across the state were pretty stagnant in the 2024 MCAP compared to the previous year.
Colman also brought up concerns regarding district MCAP scores.
According to the data Colman shared, 30.6% of 10th graders scored proficient on the English assessment last school year, ranking last in the state.
Colman said the district is looking at its support pathway classes, which it hopes will affect the 10th grade data "more significantly."
Colman also brought up elementary English scores. She said that as students go up in grade, English proficiency levels decrease.
Colman said there have been discussions about whether the district should resume using its instructional program for elementary English or adopt a new one. The district's language arts supervisor is researching this.
Moving forward, the district is getting feedback from the state on a new comprehensive literacy plan, Colman said.
"We are also looking at, across the board, our tier one instruction for any content level," she said. "Making sure that we're really using that instructional planning model, that we're thinking through strategically with our students and that do we have good, formative assessment data to use in order to change teaching within our classrooms. And I think we have a lot of work to do in that area."
Colman said that although the MCAP scores aren't "exactly where we want them," there is hope in the county about increasing the scores going forward.
"So I'm excited about that," she said.
After Colman's presentation, Superintendent Jymil Thompson said although the score increases might not be "monumental," they show progress.
"If we continue that progress over the years, it will add up," he said.

title: Washington College Electric Boat Team visits Radcliffe Creek School

Washington College Electric Boat Team visits Radcliffe Creek School

 CHESTERTOWN — Radcliffe Creek School students were treated to a special presentation by the Washington College Electric Boat Team Sept. 20. Team members shared their inspiring story, detailing the design failures they overcame in the process of building their electric boats, which eventually led to the team's success, winning first place in multiple races against other teams from universities with large engineering programs.Electric Boat Team President Douglas Hewes, a member of RCS' Class of 2018, spoke, along with WC students Mac Sansbury, Tiyaba Jamil, and Team Advisor Brian Palmer, about the strategies they used to design their boats each year and remain competitive against teams like Princeton University.
By thoughtfully building better batteries, stronger electric motors, more efficient solar technology, and hydrodynamic hull designs, they were able to start bringing home top place awards. Palmer noted, "Our students are taking away technical insights that are valuable of course, but perhaps more important is the practice they are getting at recognizing problems to solve, learning how to design solutions, and not getting dissuaded when things don't always turn out as they hoped. It's a great opportunity for them to build technical capabilities as well as perseverance and grit that is needed to see complex projects through to fruition."
Palmer excitedly shared the news about the team's most recent success–breaking the Guinness World Record for the greatest distance by an electric boat on a single charge without solar Sept. 2. WC team broke the previous world record by 21 miles. Hewes remarked, "When we were building the trimaran, we didn't even think about beating a world record or even thought we could…Then, we did the calculations and then we realized, hey, we might actually be able to beat the record."
The students had the opportunity to watch video footage of the record-breaking success and see the winning boat in person, as well as to ask questions about the boat's design and the team's plans for the future. "We are grateful to the Washington College Electric Boat Team for sharing their story about how they overcame failure to find success. It's important for our students to hear that it's okay to try hard and come up short; in all good design thinking, failure is just part of the learning process. It was apparent from the number of hands in the air and the thoughtful student questions that this remarkable story had a real impact on our young learners," said Head of School Peter Thayer.

title: Museum plans to make public trips on Dove next year

Museum plans to make public trips on Dove next year

 Last month, people enjoyed one of the first public sails on the new Maryland Dove along the St. Mary's River, an educational opportunity that will now be offered at Historic St. Mary's City throughout the sailing season.Historic St. Mary's City and the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in St. Michaels recently teamed up to design and build a new Maryland Dove replica, which is now complete and docked at the museum in St. Mary's County.
The previous replica, also operated and maintained by Historic St. Mary's City, was 38 years old and needed to be replaced.
The new Dove has been in the St. Mary's River and open for tours at St. Mary's City since March 2022.
"The ship recently got approval to carry passengers," Capt. Angela Laaro said. "Next year we are hoping to host public sails more regularly, hopefully once or twice a month. … We also like to have the ship dockside for museum guests to explore."
Earlier this summer, Laaro was passed command of the Dove by former Capt. Will Gates. Gates had been acting as the reproduction 17th century trading ship's keeper since 1989.
A St. Mary's native, Laaro began her time with the museum at the age of 14. Initially acting as a volunteer at the museum's tobacco plantation exhibit, she eventually moved to the Dove and said she fell in love with the ship. Later on she traveled to Maine and beyond to gain experience on historical schooners and windjammers.
Over a span of 10 years, she manned several boats before returning to St. Mary's to take over for Gates.
"Having grown up in Maryland, working on the Dove helps me feel connected to my own history," she said. " I love the camaraderie of the crew and being able to help keep history alive."
Karen Adler of Bushwood was a passenger on Sept. 21 along with her daughter, Casey Adler.
"I'm interested in local history and I've lived here in St. Mary's for 27 years," Karen Adler said. "I recently learned of the new Dove and was really excited to learn they were letting the public sail."
Michael Bellis, director of advancement of communication at Historic St. Mary's City, said the ship and the museum onsite are special because of their authentic storytelling and way of reconciling the past.
"We are on the cutting edge of museum best practices," he said, adding the sailing trips are meant to be an educational tool. "We give passengers a really tactile experience of sailing in the seventeenth century. … The crew will typically be dressed in traditional garb reflecting the time period."
According to Chief Mate Jeremy Heveron, it takes a lot of hands to run a tall ship like the Dove. At least seven crew members are required on deck by the U.S. Coast Guard to take it out on the water.
Staff aboard the Dove share the history of the ship throughout the ride and encourage guests to interact with the vessel.
Beginning next spring, public sails on the Dove can be reserved online.

title: Child care priority needed
author: Staff Writer
content:
Child care priority needed

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 260
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As we approach the upcoming election, it is imperative that candidates up and down the ballot prioritize child care.The average cost of child care for two kids is now higher than the average cost of rent in all 50 states, pushing 40% of families with young children into debt. The average annual cost of infant care in Maryland is $15,335 — that's $1,278 per month. Maryland is ranked seventh out of the 50 states for most expensive infant care.
As a single mother living in Talbot County (a known child care desert) who is responsible for paying my mortgage, $80,000 in college loan debt and putting food on the table for my son, I worry every single day how I am going to make it financially to pay for child care until he reaches age 5 and can enter the public school system.
During this election season, we hear candidates talk about putting families first, but we need real policy solutions that ensure that families like mine aren't forced to drown in debt.
This shouldn't be a partisan issue: 89% of voters want candidates to have a plan to help working parents afford high-quality childcare, underscoring the broad, bipartisan support for addressing the child care crisis.
I urge Angela Alsobrooks, Larry Hogan, Blane Miller and Andy Harris to commit to prioritizing child care in their first 100 days if elected.
It's time for our leaders to answer moms across the country who are calling for affordable, accessible, and quality child care. Our families, businesses, and our children's futures all depend on it.
JULIE LEITCH
Wye Mills

title: Washington College Electric Boat Team visits Radcliffe Creek School

Washington College Electric Boat Team visits Radcliffe Creek School

 CHESTERTOWN — Radcliffe Creek School students were treated to a special presentation by the Washington College Electric Boat Team Sept. 20. Team members shared their inspiring story, detailing the design failures they overcame in the process of building their electric boats, which eventually led to the team's success, winning first place in multiple races against other teams from universities with large engineering programs.Electric Boat Team President Douglas Hewes, a member of Radcliffe's Class of 2018, spoke, along with Washington College students Mac Sansbury, Tiyaba Jamil, and team adviser Brian Palmer, about the strategies they used to design their boats each year and remain competitive against teams like Princeton University.
By thoughtfully building better batteries, stronger electric motors, more efficient solar technology, and hydrodynamic hull designs, they were able to start bringing home top place awards. Palmer noted, "Our students are taking away technical insights that are valuable of course, but perhaps more important is the practice they are getting at recognizing problems to solve, learning how to design solutions, and not getting dissuaded when things don't always turn out as they hoped. It's a great opportunity for them to build technical capabilities as well as perseverance and grit that is needed to see complex projects through to fruition."
Palmer excitedly shared the news about the team's most recent success — breaking the Guinness World Record for the greatest distance by an electric boat on a single charge without solar Sept. 2. The Washington team broke the previous world record by 21 miles.
Hewes remarked, "When we were building the trimaran, we didn't even think about beating a world record or even thought we could. … Then, we did the calculations and then we realized, hey, we might actually be able to beat the record."
The students had the opportunity to watch video footage of the record-breaking success and see the winning boat in person, as well as to ask questions about the boat's design and the team's plans for the future.
"We are grateful to the Washington College Electric Boat Team for sharing their story about how they overcame failure to find success. It's important for our students to hear that it's OK to try hard and come up short; in all good design thinking, failure is just part of the learning process. It was apparent from the number of hands in the air and the thoughtful student questions that this remarkable story had a real impact on our young learners," Head of School Peter Thayer said.

title: Four years after her murder, Madison Sparrow's legacy lives on
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Four years after her murder, Madison Sparrow's legacy lives on

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 735
 Words 

 Read News Document

 From a young age, Madison Sparrow always wanted to be a teacher."She definitely knew what she wanted to be and never swayed," her mother, Heather Sparrow Murphy, said. "And kids loved her. She was a tutor and a babysitter and she helped me run my Girl Scout troop for her younger sister."
Madison never got the chance to realize her dream of following in the footsteps of several family members and becoming a teacher. The 17-year-old Newark Charter School junior was murdered by her ex-boyfriend and another friend in Delaware four years ago this month.
Her dream lives on, however, through five Newark Charter students who have received scholarships in Madison's name to pursue a career in education.
"I call them my girls," Murphy said, describing the close bond she has with the scholarship recipients. "They're like my kids. They all keep in contact with me."
The first recipient, Kristen White, is nearly done with her degree and recently started her student-teaching assignment.
"She said to me, 'Miss Heather, as hard as it is...I remember I'm doing this for Madison,'" Murphy said. "And that gets me."
Murphy raises money for the scholarship through the annual Love Wins 5K. Now in its fourth year, the race drew more than 200 people to Glasgow Park on Saturday.
"I definitely cry every year," Murphy said. "It's really emotional, but it also means so much to me and helps me continue to go on and keep her memory alive. You can't even put words on that. I mean, that's what I live for."
The Madison Sparrow Scholarship is awarded each year to a Newark Charter senior pursuing a career in education, and the recipients can reapply for funding each year. Last year, Murphy was able to give a scholarship to two deserving seniors.
Madison was killed Oct. 2, 2020, after her supposed friend Annika Stalczynski lured her into the woods behind Maclary Elementary School, where Madison's ex-boyfriend Noah Sharp fatally struck her with a baseball bat. They then dumped her body near Interstate 95.
Both Sharp and Stalczynski were convicted of first-degree murder in 2022 and are serving lengthy prison sentences.
Murphy is involved with the nonprofit Victims' Voices Heard and recently participated in the organization's victim-offender dialog program, which allowed her to sit down with Stalczynski and talk about the murder and how losing her daughter affected her.
"It was a beautiful experience," Murphy said. "I'm sure it's not for every victim, but as Madison's mom, because I knew these children so well, it was something that I needed from the beginning."
Both Murphy and Stalczynski spent five months meeting separately with a mediator and then spent four hours speaking with each other. As hard as it was to face her daughter's murderer, Murphy felt she had to get answers from Stalczynski.
"She was with my daughter when she was murdered, so there's only that truth, there's only those answers," Murphy said. "And she was very honest with me. Because I was here when Madison was brought into the world, I needed to know how Madison left it, and she was able to give me all the answers."
The meeting helped Murphy process her grief.
"I'll never have closure, but it definitely closed the chapter on the things I needed to know," she said. "I said everything I needed to say and I received everything I needed to learn."
Murphy already forgave Sharp and Stalczynski — both of whom she knew well before Madison's murder — during her victim impact statement during their sentencing.
"Forgiveness is something, I truly believe, that we do for ourselves not something that I do for the people that murdered my daughter," she said. "It's also just the way that Madison lived her life, and that's the whole message of 'love wins.'"
Murphy continues to hear stories about Madison when she sees her daughter's friends and former teachers.
"The community outpouring and love just shows me how much people love my daughter and how much she impacted our community," she said. "It continues every year with this race, and it's a beautiful way for me to see that and be surrounded and for us all to be together."
Madison, Murphy said, "was an amazing soul."
"She just loved children, and they loved her back," she said. "She was a gentle soul, she loved her friends, she was so loyal to everyone, just an amazing daughter."
To donate to the Madison Sparrow Scholarship Fund, visit runsignup.com/Race/DE/Newark/LoveWins5KDE. Murphy is also looking for sponsors for next year's race.

title: How Maryland schools are cracking down on cell phones this fall
author: MADISON KORMAN Capital News Service
content:
How Maryland schools are cracking down on cell phones this fall

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MADISON KORMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 387
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Classrooms across Maryland are a bit more quiet this fall, with students under new rules to keep their phones off and out of sight.At least a third of Maryland public schools have tightened up the rules this fall, according to a Capital News Service survey conducted this month.
Meanwhile, public schools in and around Baltimore are cracking down on phones during instruction — and, in some cases, even on the bus.
In Caroline County, on the eastern shore of Maryland, public schools have a new pilot program in two middle schools. It requires students to place their phones in locked pouches. The pouches stay with the students but remain locked until the end of the school day.
"Today's youth battle constant distraction caused by cell phone alerts and messaging that interrupt their ability to focus," Supt. Derek L. Simmons said in a recent notice to students and parents. He said this "creates a negative impact on school culture and learning."
Elsewhere, administrators are getting creative about persuading students to go along with the plan.
In St. Mary's County, Supt. Scott Smith recently released a video describing the district's new plan to limit the distractions caused by cell phones.
In the video, he comically stops midway through his presentation of the new rules to take out his phone and text, showing students how difficult it can be to have a conversation when they are disengaged and on their phones.
"Hold on, just wait a second, I'm just going to text him real fast," Smith said in the video, pretending to send a message.
"That's really rude isn't it?" he then pointed out. "We're supposed to be having a conversation, and I'm interrupting myself and I'm getting on my phone and I'm texting."
"I'm not really here right?" Smith said. "I'm kind of distracted."
Since the start of the school year, in St. Mary's County, they have confiscated around 30 cell phones per day, Smith told the school board in a recent meeting. That's out of 10,000 students, he said at the meeting.
"We have had many conversations about the joy of being in a classroom without the distraction of cell phones," Smith said, adding that he and his staff "continue to work with our secondary students about the joy and some of the challenges of cellular devices and how we can maximize our joy and fun in life."

title: Talbot Board of Education candidates speak at town hall forum
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Board of Education candidates speak at town hall forum

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 820
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Candidates for the Talbot County Board of Education fielded questions during an open forum Wednesday evening at the Avalon Theatre.The town hall, hosted by The Talbot Spy and the Avalon Foundation, centered on many issues facing Talbot County Public Schools, including standardized test scores, student engagement and teacher retention.
Three of seven seats on the board are up for grabs in next month's election. Incumbent Candace Henry and Ann O'Connor are squaring off for the District 2 seat. In District 5, incumbent Anna Howie and Karla Wieland-Cherry are running.
The District 6 seat, currently held by Mary Wheeler, is a race between Kerry Gunshenan and Cynthia Jurrius.
Henry, O'Connor, Howie and Jurrius attended Wednesday's town hall, answering moderator and audience questions. Wieland-Cherry and Gunshenan did not attend.
TEST SCORESScores released in August showed slight improvements in math and English proficiency rates in the district. The four candidates, though, were adamant that test scores must improve.
In English, 47.3% of Talbot County Public Schools students tested proficient, a jump of 2.8% from 44.5% in 2022-2023. In math, 18.3% of students were proficient, up 1.1% from 17.2% the year prior. The district slots in 14th and 18th, respectively, in those categories among the state's 24 districts.
"Our scores are not what we want," Henry said. She added that an increase in math coaches in the elementary schools and other forms of benchmark testing are current district initiatives.
"Standardized testing is a snapshot in a period of time," Henry said. "(Superintendent Sharon) Pepukayi has worked with her team to really be intentional about gathering data from students on a more consistent basis."
In recent months, county residents have received flyers in the mail questioning the test scores, along with district spending and, most recently, a health education framework bill proposed at the state level.
"These flyers that came out are pretty alarming," O'Connor said. "And I don't look at them as a negative on teachers. Teachers don't want these scores. The system is broken."
O'Connor, who is backed by Talbot County's chapter of Moms for Liberty, a nationwide conservative political organization, said a lack of "meaningful homework" is a "deficiency." She advocated for summer reading and said the district should look at what nearby private schools are doing in order to raise TCPS test scores.
Jurrius, who along with Henry and Howie is endorsed by the Talbot County Education Association labor union, addressed the most recent mailer sent to residents. That mailer stated, in part, that "radical politicians are more worried about forcing harmful gender ideology" on students, referencing a state Senate bill from 2023 that did not pass.
Jurrius stated she does not believe educators are indoctrinating students.
"This destructive polarization isn't helpful," Jurrius said. "And whoever is behind it, (I) would love to see them contribute in a positive way. I think if we all work together, we can do some amazing things to increase our schools' test scores."
STUDENT ENGAGEMENTAcross the state, many districts are exploring ways to reduce cell phone use and other distractions in schools. TCPS has plans to roll out a pilot program for cell phone pouches sometime after Thanksgiving.
Howie, an assistant principal at Federalsburg Elementary School in Caroline County, said Caroline County's current pilot of those same cell phone pouches has been a success.
"You can see engagement going through the roof," Howie said.
She emphasized that technology should be an addition to student learning and not the sole focus. "A computer isn't a replacement, right. A computer should be a tool," she said.
O'Connor said the same of computers. She said cell phones do not belong in schools and added she hopes to see an increased focus on books.
"Going back to the basics," O'Connor said. "Are we reading books? Are books coming home? … I don't see them as much."
Jurrius advocated for "restorative practices" in student discipline to hold students accountable for actions. She said suspensions aren't always the solution.
"Students right now are different," Jurrius said. "They have different challenges in their lives, their social media, their mental health issues."
TEACHER RETENTIONCandidates discussed the need for effective recruitment and retention of teachers and staff amid shortages in the district, along with strategies to rectify those shortcomings.
Howie emphasized the importance of retaining teachers and staff. She said looking at intent forms earlier will help the district and board understand why teachers leave.
"Being very intentional in having those conversations early … instead of getting that intent form at the end of the year and just start tallying up," Howie said.
Henry added that the district should especially consider the feedback from teachers and staff that decide to stay. She hopes to see specific attention dedicated toward the district's "Grow Your Own Teachers" scholarship program.
"We should be growing teachers from our communities that can come back and teach in our communities," Henry said.
Residents in Districts 2, 5 and 6 will see the respective school board candidates on the ballot on Election Day, which is Nov. 5. The three candidates elected will serve four-year terms.

title: Understanding Latinidad: Educator speaks to Chesapeake College students
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Understanding Latinidad: Educator speaks to Chesapeake College students

 October 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 639
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Dozens of students, faculty and community members gathered at the Wye Mills Humanities Cadby Theatre and enjoyed jamaica (hibiscus) agua fresca, fresh fruit, piles of spicy chips and an encouraging message of embracing their native cultures.In celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, Chesapeake College's Hispanic/Latino Student Union hosted advocate, educator and teacher Samantha Martinez to speak on what her Latinidad means to her.
Lindsay Velasquez, president of the Hispanic/Latino Student Union, said she was excited to bring Martinez as a speaker and loved the encouragement she shared with students in attendance to feel empowered by their cultural identity.
"I just feel like all of us feel like we can do it, and that little doubt that we had of not being able to do something, like, we can do it," Velasquez said. "And she's an example of anything that is possible if you put your mind to it."
Latinidad is a particular experience that contains the complexities of immigration, race, color, class and language. Martinez said her story stems from an immigration story.
"I'm really proud of that because of (my parents') struggle, and their survival and their grit, I'm able to stand here in front of you today," she said.
Her mother migrated from Mexico and her father from El Salvador. She grew up in Chicago, which she describes as "a city that really appreciated and celebrated what it means to be Latina," though the city was heavily segregated.
After meeting her husband and getting married, she moved to New York and became a teacher in the South Bronx, known as the poorest school district in the country. There, Martinez learned of excellence.
She said she was expected to perform at a level of excellence that she had never been asked to before, and in turn she learned to expect it from the people and students around her.
She said the South Bronx "will forever be a part of my story and my legacy."
After spending her time in the South Bronx, Martinez moved to Talbot County. It was a culture shock, but to her surprise, she found a growing Latino population. Her new home also forced her to affirm and challenge her own identity as a Latina.
Martinez worked for Talbot County Public Schools and then founded Mid-Shore Scholars, a college prep program that serves first-generation college students.
When leading the program, she decided it was time to focus on the marginalized student population. The program was meant to target a population of students who had the potential to go to Ivy Leagues, but she pushed for a different perspective. Martinez said it was important to focus on the students who lacked the resources to get to college.
"It's these students who don't have any help at home, who don't have any representation, whose parents want to give them the best life but didn't go to college here, who don't know the ropes or don't know how to navigate the system," Martinez said.
During the pandemic, she decided to focus on building an institution to better assist marginalized communities and helped create the Polaris Village Academy. Martinez said the academy centers joy, celebrating culture and empowering students and families, making them feel safe and seen.
Martinez ended her presentation with photos of her family visiting their native countries and the importance that focusing on her roots allowed her the opportunity to help those around her to grow.
"My superpower is that I am bicultural, that I have roots in (El Salvador) and in Mexico, and I have roots here, and that I can be both from there and from here, and then it's not 'and/or.' I could bring my whole self," Martinez said. "And I encourage all the students here who are questioning their identity or wondering if they can be authentically themselves when they go to class or when they step into white institutions that yes, you can."

 The 2024 election season will see voters from several towns in Talbot County choose their representatives for the Talbot County School Board.There are six candidates and, while neither political party is formally endorsing them, they do have varying views concerning the education of our children.
Three are conservative and three are progressive. The conservative candidates are: Ann O'Connor (District 2), Karla Wieland-Cherry (District 5), and Kerry Gunshenan (District 6). The progressive candidates are: Cynthia Jurrius ( District 6), Anna Howie (District 5) and Candace Henry (District 2).
As a public service, the local chapter of a parent support group called Moms for Liberty hosted a debate for the school board candidates on Sept. 23 at the Easton firehouse. All six candidates were invited; four appeared, including Cynthia Jurrius and the three conservatives Ann O'Connor, Karla Wieland-Cherry and Kerry Gunshenan. The event was a success and helpful for parents and grandparents in deciding for whom they will vote to sit on the local school board. Another school board candidates' debate was held on Wednesday, Oct. 2, at 6 p.m. at the Avalon Theater and all six candidates were invited to speak.
While Moms for Liberty, according to several public statements made by the chapter Chair Jan Greenhawk, does not endorse any of the candidates, the Moms have been accused in a local periodical of "inserting their partisan candidates into a non-partisan position." Such an accusation is surprising in light of the fact that another school board candidates' debate was held at the Academy Art Museum, sponsored by the Talbot County Democratic Forum.
Sadly, only three of the candidates were invited to speak. And guess which three. Yes, the three more progressive candidates, who happen to be Democrats. The other three candidates, the three conservative candidates, were not invited at all. And yet Moms for Liberty, which has not endorsed a single candidate, is accused of partisanship? Why are liberals so afraid to hear the opinions of conservatives, especially as regards our children's education? Is it that conservatives put children's well-being ahead of the latest fads of social-engineering and psychological manipulation? Is it because conservatives want to truly educate the children rather than indoctrinating them with left-wing philosophies?

Why are you running for office?
I am running for the school board because I am deeply passionate about children's education. As a former teacher and mother of six, I have dedicated my career to helping children reach their highest potential.
Having witnessed my six children go through (Talbot County Public School), I have observed a decline in academic rigor, expectations and accountability, both in behavior and academics. This experience drives my desire to make meaningful changes on the school board. The fact that our students are scoring 18% proficient in math and 55% in reading indicates a pressing need for new perspectives on our educational strategies.
What are your priorities if elected?
My priorities are the ABCs of education: advancing academics, boosting accountability and cultivating character. The focus is on the whole child. We cannot advance academics without discipline.
When students develop self-discipline, good character naturally emerges. This requires daily practice and consistent reinforcement of rules and clear expectations for all students across all buildings. Disruptive behavior must be addressed promptly and effectively.
Regarding academic accountability: A 95% graduation rate when less than ¼ of our students are proficient in math skills, and less than ½ are reading on grade level is inconsistent — something is broken here and we need to fix it.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
The most important issue is the steady decline of academic rigor. We need to make sure we continue to implement early intervention in elementary schools to support those who need that extra push. It's essential to send home books and ensure that our children have access to/and are accountable for reading materials throughout elementary, middle and high school.
We should place greater emphasis on traditional learning — using pencils and paper, cursive writing, fostering reading and critical thinking skills, while reducing reliance on computers. We need to offer pathways for middle school students interested in college or the workforce, including advanced/honors classes.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
The postcards received in the mail are snapshots of where our schools stand. No one wants these scores, they are abysmal. It's a wake up call to attack the problem and change the way we have been doing education here in Talbot County.
We need to put our focus on reading, writing and math. Our students are distracted. Let's eliminate anything that detracts from our mission as educators and focus on what truly matters — educating the child. Let's get back to basics with my ABCs of education.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
Simply changing a name doesn't lead to improvement. Over the last two decades, this initiative has gone through four name changes. Although there are many wonderful proposals in the Blueprint, I don't believe that top-down programs created by education experts would make our local schools better.
The Blueprint is a blanket principle mandated for all 24 counties in Maryland. The counties have no say in how it is implemented. It removes the schools from the control of locally elected school boards and puts control in the hands of unelected officials. I believe we want control over our local schools.

title: Easton Middle to pilot cell phone pouches in December
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton Middle to pilot cell phone pouches in December

 October 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 585
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Public Schools is following the lead of other school districts across the nation and on the Mid-Shore in implementing student cell phone restrictions.Beginning Dec. 2, Easton Middle School will act as the pilot for the district, implementing a cell phone pouch system in which students must lock their phones in pouches during the school day.
Helga Einhorn, TCPS assistant superintendent for school leadership and student success, outlined the pilot plan to Talbot Board of Education members during a Monday work session.
"It should not be a battle in the classroom that our teachers have to engage in to monitor cell phone use, because that takes (away) their time and their expertise in instructing our students," Einhorn said. " … Cell phones seem to be one of the things that is the most problematic to enforce in our schools."
Einhorn noted the work of administrators and staff to research the impacts of cell phone use during school, as well as surveys collected to gauge parent and staff opinions on cell phone usage.
She said surveys conducted by the district showed 94% of parents/guardians and 96% of staff said there should be restrictions on cell phone use during the school day. 90% of parents/guardians and 95% of staff said students should not be allowed to have their phones "visible and usable" during class instruction.
Talbot County is engaging with the company Yondr, also used by the neighboring Caroline and Dorchester county districts, to provide the pouches.
The pouches will be assigned to each student at Easton Middle. Upon entering the school, students will place their phones in the pouches and use a Yondr magnet to lock the pouch. During dismissal, students will use the same magnetic device to unlock the pouches and retrieve their phones.
Einhorn said the district has talked to Yondr representatives about ensuring there are enough magnets in case of an emergency.
"They've been able to share with us some best practices, which include how many magnets you would need per student in the building to be able to effectively and efficiently get students out at the end of the day," Einhorn said.
Like Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said prior to his district's rollout, Einhorn emphasized that cell phones can be a distraction during emergencies.
"We've had conversations and heard from national experts that during a real school emergency, it is actually greater safety risk for 800 students to be pulling out their phones and making phone calls instead of listening to the directions that will help keep them safe," she told board members.
Debbie Gardner, director of communications for Talbot County Public Schools, said each pouch costs about $27. In all, 975 pouches were purchased for a total just below $27,000, "paid for from the local FY24 materials of instruction budget," Gardner said.
Board Vice President Candace Henry asked how long it will take students to put their phones in pouches and retrieve them at the beginning and end of each day. Einhorn and Pepukayi said they expect it will take some time at first but that the process should become simple and streamlined over time.
Easton Middle families will receive more details from the district about the pouch program later this week, and a presentation will be given to students on Friday.
Board Member Deborah Bridges inquired if the pilot program may extend to other schools in the district this year if it is deemed successful.
"I do think we will need to see at least this year what our data is telling us about the impact," Einhorn said.

title: Safe havens of knowledge

Safe havens of knowledge

 Thomas Jefferson believed that an informed citizenry was essential to the success of a democracy and the best defense against tyranny. He often stated that "whenever the people are well informed, they can be trusted with their own government."As a country, I believe we should heed the words of our founding father as we head to the polls in November. Our democracy depends on it.
Earlier this month, librarians, booksellers, educators, authors and readers throughout the country participated in Banned Books Week, the annual event that highlights the value of free and open access to information. In preparation, The American Library Association released preliminary data documenting attempts to censor books and materials in public, school, and academic libraries during the first eight months of 2024.
The findings are alarming: Between January 1 and August 31, 2024, ALA tracked 414 attempts to censor library materials and services. In those cases, 1,128 unique titles were challenged. Especially troubling is the fact that 47% of the books targeted for censorship are titles representing the voices and lived experiences of people of color and people who identify as LGBTQ+.
These attempts to silence diverse voices in our community are deliberate, coordinated and dangerous. Public and school libraries should be safe havens of knowledge and information, offering access to a variety of viewpoints and empowering readers to be informed citizens.
This Saturday, Oct. 19, has been designated the Freedom to Read Day of Action by Unite Against Book Bans, an organization dedicated to protecting the First Amendment rights of all Americans (uniteagainstbookbans.org). Concerned citizens can join in the fight against censorship by learning about book bans, reading a banned book or participating in the activities on the website. Above all, we can take the pledge to stand with readers across the U.S. in support of the Freedom to Read and vote.
MARY PELLICANO
Easton

title: Thoughts on smart phone restrictions in schools
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Thoughts on smart phone restrictions in schools

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 981
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A recent Pew Research Center survey reports that 95% of teenagers in America have a smart phone or have access to one. It also reports that 45% of teenagers say they are online nearly all the time.Many have suggested this has resulted in a measurable and serious negative impact on the learning environment in middle and high school classrooms. Others have suggested this has resulted in a serious negative impact on standardized student achievement test scores.
As a result, countless school districts in America have put or will be putting new or more restrictions on student smart phones during the school day. Two-thirds of schools in Maryland have already. Talbot County is joining them. Beginning Dec. 2, Easton Middle School will will require students to lock their phones in secure pouches during the school day.
These restrictions have significant public support. Surveys conducted by the Talbot County school district reported 94% of parents/guardians and 96% of staff said there should be restrictions on cell phone use during the school day. 90% of parents/guardians and 95% of staff said students should not be allowed to have their phones "visible and usable" during class instruction.
While I understand and respect these opinions, I suggest restrictions in schools are not addressing more deeply seated roots of the problem.
In his most recent book, "The Anxious Generation How the Great Rewiring of Childhood is Causing an Epidemic of Mental Illness" social psychologist Jonathan Stephen Haidt does a deep dive on a measurable surge in anxiety, depression and suicidal thoughts among American youth.
I understand and respect these decisions. At the same time, I suggest they are not addressing more deeply seated roots of the problem.
In his most recent book, "The Anxious Generation How the Great Rewiring of Childhood is Causing an Epidemic of Mental Illness" social psychologist Jonathan Stephen Haidt does a deep dive on a measurable surge in anxiety, depression, and suicidality among American youth.
In his book Haidt references research showing a measure of anxiety for individuals between ages of 8 to 25 has increased 139% between 2010 and 2020.The measure for depression during the same period, often the result of an inability to resolve interpersonal conflicts or relationship difficulties, has increased 106%.
Haidt suggests three reasons why.
The first is the decline of the what Haidt calls play-based childhood. He maintains children need lots of free play time to prepare them for success as an adult. Out of fears for their safety, many American parents and guardians have reduced children's access to unsupervised free play. The loss of free play and the rise of continual (some may say "smothering") adult supervision has deprived children of what they needed most to overcome the normal fears and anxieties of childhood: the chance to explore, test and expand their limits, build close friendships through shared adventure and learn how to judge risks for themselves.
The second is what Haidt calls rise of the phone-based childhood, which began in the late 2000s and accelerated in the early 2010s. Haidt notes this was precisely the period during which adolescents traded in their flip phones for smartphones. These smartphones were loaded with social media platforms supported by the new high-speed internet and unlimited data plans that has drastically reshaped the social media landscape for adolescents.
The third is what Heidt calls an over reliance on technology that has all but eliminated unstructured face to face interactions from the lives of children and adolescents.
Heidt concludes the negative impact of all three reasons was made worse by many well-intentioned parents, including himself. He writes: "We did not fully understand what was happening in children's virtual worlds and did not grasp that tech companies had designed their online products to be addictive."
As a result, Haidt asserts that all these trends combined, have robbed entire generations of opportunities to develop the resilience, coping skills and independence needed to navigate everyday stressors, and in turn, created unprecedented levels of anxiety at a societal level.
He says these generations have not learned from valuable opportunities to engage in and learn from manageable risks, typical setbacks, failures and healthy social challenges.
What can be done going forward?
Haidt offers the following proactive suggestions for parents and guardians of children in elementary, middle and high schools.
Instead of a giving younger students a smartphone as their first phone, give them a basic phone.
Do not give them a smartphone until high school. Delay the opening of accounts on nearly all social media platforms until the beginning of high school, at least.
Will his suggestions be popular with students? Not likely, especially given the immense power of peer pressure that characterizes life for students in schools at all levels.
One school in Maryland recently surveyed seniors on a new more restrictive smart phone policy to limit the overuse of smart phones during the school day. The questions and answers were: "Do you know overuse of cell phones is harmful? Yes. Do you want to give it up? No."
Are Haidt's suggestions still necessary since efforts are underway when an increasing number of schools are adopting on new or more restrictive rules on smart phone access? Yes.
Despite best intentions and best efforts, schools alone cannot address this problem. One Maryland school district superintendent has observed with thinly disguised frustration — "Students are in school for just 20% of their week. We can't control the other 80% of the time that we don't have them."
Those with some control over most of the other 80% of student's time outside of school are parents and guardians.
Going forward, parents and guardians need to fully embrace two concepts. Success for them is not based on winning a popularity contest with those whom they are entrusted with their care and upbringing. Success for them is measured in part by a willingness to make sometimes unpopular, but necessary decisions on reasonable limits for a young person's own good.
In preparing all our young people for success, they, and our society deserve nothing less.

title: Dorchester ends alternative education contract in middle, elementary schools
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester ends alternative education contract in middle, elementary schools

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 448
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Four months since the Dorchester County Board of Education voted to terminate its more than three-year contract with an alternative education program for high schoolers, the board has decided to terminate its one-year contract with an alternative education program for elementary and middle school students.At a Board of Education meeting Thursday, the board unanimously voted to terminate it's contract with Transforming Lives for convenience. The service provided alternative education for up to 48 Dorchester County Public Schools elementary and middle school students at one time.
Board members did not comment on the decision to terminate the contract at the meeting.
Review of the contract was not originally on Thursday's meeting agenda. The board voted to add it it to the agenda after board member Chris Wheedleton made a motion to do so. Later in the meeting, Wheedleton made a motion to terminate the contract for convenience, which the board unanimously voted in favor of.
Wheedleton did not immediately respond for comment on the decision.
According to the contract, either party can terminate it for any or no reason with 60-days advance written notice.
The program, called Positive Change Academy-Dorchester, began this past summer and was set to end June 30, 2025. It is housed at The Judy Center at Sandy Hill Elementary School and at the New Directions Learning Academy. It cost the district $79,000 per month.
The board approved the contract at a special Board of Education meeting in July. At that meeting, district Superintendent Jymil Thompson said the district looked at this program as one stop in a student's education journey. He said it would be a place where students could remedy behavior and improve academics before going back into a "regular educational setting."
The district did not immediately respond for comment on the board's decision.
This is not the first time the board has terminated an alternative education contract in the past year.
In June, the Board of Education voted to terminate its more than three-year contract with Vision Quest, an alternative education program for district high schoolers that had been met with criticism from residents since the contract was approved in September 2023. The district had been paying Vision Quest $93,363 per month for services, which would have added up to over $3.3 million over three years.
The decision to terminate the Vision Quest contract was one of the reasons former Dorchester County Board of Education Vice President Susan Morgan resigned in June. She was the sole vote in favor of keeping the contract. In an interview with the Star Democrat in June, Morgan said the district needed an alternative program for the fall that would benefit the students as much as she witnessed first-hand with the success of Vision Quest.

title: Group promotes extremist agenda

 As a former teacher in Talbot County, I find the local school board races concerning. Ironically, hate groups in America like to name themselves after our most deeply held values, while acting against those values. Moms for Liberty (M4L) is one such group.Moms For Liberty has an active chapter here in Talbot County. Nationally, M4L was included as an extremist group by the Southern Poverty Law Center, in its annual report because it advances an anti-student inclusion agenda.

According to USA Today, the group, which identifies itself as a "parental rights organization," is known for calls to ban books in schools. Founded in Florida, three members have been named to the Department of Education workgroup that oversees school libraries. One cannot help but wonder how influential they were in developing the new standards that require students be taught that being enslaved was beneficial to Black Americans because it helped them acquire new skills.
I encourage you to speak with local Black citizens to hear their views on this.
It is critical in this election year that Talbot County voters reject the three candidates supported by the local Moms for Liberty chapter. I have seen the posts claiming that M4L supports, but doesn't endorse these candidates.
Either these candidates did no homework into M4L or they know their agenda and concur. In my opinion, either option disqualifies Ann O'Connor, Karla Wieland-Cherry and Kerry Gunshenan. Candidates who can't be bothered to understand the agenda of the groups that support them are potential pawns in the hands of extremists. Candidates who agree with M4L would engulf our system in culture wars that do nothing to advance the education of our children.
If you live in a district with a school board race this election, one of these three names will appear: Candace Henry, Anna Howie or Cynthia Marrah Jurrius. I respectfully ask you to vote for one of them.
I can promise you that the educators in this county truly want what is best for our children, and they are the ones qualified to make decisions about their education.
Moms for Liberty's hateful rhetoric and anti-inclusive agenda does not belong anywhere in our schools.

title: Should Maryland schools ban cellphones?
author: Sasha Allen and Audrey Keefe Capital News Service
content:
Should Maryland schools ban cellphones?

 October 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sasha Allen and Audrey Keefe Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1407
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "FOCUS NOW! PHONES LATER," blares the newest school cellphone policy out of Washington County.This "clear message" debuted on the county's website in August, kicking off the 2024 school year with stricter limitations on personal electronic devices.
That message is one that resonates with Maryland's school board candidates. Of the 74 candidates who responded to the Local News Network's campaign questionnaire, 64 favored strict restrictions on cellphones in schools, and only 10 expressed reservations about limiting cellphone use or touted their positive aspects.
Board candidates cited a number of reasons — ranging from disciplinary issues to cyberbullying to phone addiction — for ordering students to put their phones out of sight.
Some candidates offered nuanced proposals for limiting cellphone use — but support for greater restrictions spans the state, from large counties to small.
Rita Montoya, a lawyer who is running for an at-large school board seat from Montgomery County, said the district's cellphone policy should be "away all day" — which is the name of a pilot program in the district this year.
"As a parent, I understand the need for some students to have a cellphone with them at school, but it should not be used at school so as to limit distractions and negative peer interactions including violence," she said.
Washington County already requires all devices to be off and out of sight during instructional hours in its schools. Robin Merchant Spickler, a former kindergarten teacher and current school board candidate in the western Maryland county, fully supports the new policy.
"This has been a long time coming. It is in the best interest of the students' well-being and their academic progress," she said. "It will help the students learn in a positive and productive environment."
A growing trendSchools across the state have already begun implementing stricter cellphone policies in public schools. According to a survey conducted by the Capital News Service this fall, at least a third of Maryland school districts have tightened their cellphone regulations this school year alone.
However, these policies vary. Some schools prohibit students from using their devices throughout the entire school day, while others, such as Anne Arundel County, allow high school students to use them during lunch only.
Some counties have begun forcing students to lock away their phones. In Baltimore County, 16 middle and high schools have issued clear pouches in which students must insert their phones to make them harder to access during class time.
Annette Anderson, the deputy director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Safe and Healthy Schools, said there are good reasons for mimimizing cellphone use among youngsters.
"What we know is that it's shifting the way that the brains of the developing child is growing," Anderson said. "There's a lot of concern in terms of the mental health of our young people."
Between 2008 and 2015, hospitals in the U.S. reported suicidal ideation or attempts among children and adolescents ages 14 to 18 almost doubled, according to a 2020 study. Published by the Canadian Medical Association Journal, the study delved into the relationship between youth cellphone and social media use and mental health.
The study found that internet addiction is "particularly associated" with self-harm and suicidal behavior.
Anderson said cellphone use also hinders students' ability to develop interpersonal connections vital to job performance later in life.
"What's happening actually is that students are so focused on this phone that's in front of their faces that they're not actually having interpersonal dialogue," Anderson said. "They're not having the kinds of conversations at the lunchroom, at the lunch table in their classrooms."
Teachers nationwide are worried about cellphone use, too, according to a survey from the Pew Research Center from June. The survey found that 72 percent of high school teachers alone cite cellphone distractions in the classroom as a "major problem."
Many school board candidates also said cellphones have become a distraction.
In Calvert County, cellphones are banned in classrooms, and school board candidate and former educator Michael Shisler backs that ban.
"This problem did not happen overnight, and it will not be solved overnight," said Shisler, who spent nearly 30 years as an elementary school principal. "Cellphones have moved beyond a distraction to being an addiction — an addiction that brings increased social pressures and the need for constant social validation."
Allegany County school board candidate and Frostburg State University professor Gerry LaFemina agreed. He said the impact cellphones and social media have on students is the most jarring problem in county schools that he hopes to address.
"Besides being a distraction, the dopamine hit of responding to notifications can have an addictive effect on our students. This can lead to educational and disciplinary issues," LaFemina said.
LaFemina did not specify what policies he would implement if elected, but the county has light limitations on use in the classroom, often leaving it up to teacher discretion.
St. Mary's County candidate Mary Washington, who has served on the board for the past 27 years, said she is pleased with the county's new plan to restrict phone use during instructional time.
"This change will focus on increasing learning and achievement, promoting a safe and orderly school, diminishing discipline referrals, and nourishing more face-to-face contact with each other," Washington said.
Different perspectivesWhile most school board candidates throughout the state provided a variety of concerns surrounding cellphone use in schools, many had different perspectives on what a ban should look like in their county.
Out of Prince George's County, lawyer, substitute teacher and school board candidate Angela R. Jones said she supports tighter regulation but not a full ban.
"I propose a balanced cellphone policy that allows limited use during non-instructional times, such as lunch and between classes while prohibiting use during lessons," said Jones, the legislative director for the Maryland State Senate. "This approach respects students' need for connectivity and emergency contact while minimizing distractions during instructional time."
In addition to the social connectivity phones can provide students, some candidates cited the educational use of devices in schools, saying they can be used in the classroom in moderation.
Letonya Smalls is also running for the school board in Charles County. She has a doctorate in education leadership and said she has seen students benefit directly from phone usage in the classroom.
"I remember one of my students pulling out his cellphone to take a picture years ago. I asked what he was doing, and he said, 'I am taking a picture of the homework, Ms. Smalls,'" Smalls said. "He smiled, and I honestly didn't make a big deal out of it because I knew it worked for him. Each student is different, and each student learns differently."
Smalls proposed a strict policy enforced by teachers during instructional time but not a complete ban. However, like some other candidates, Smalls said she believes that students and parents should be involved in developing any new policy. She proposed a contract for cellphone use for both parents and students to review and sign.
In Frederick County, school board candidate Veronica Lowe took a similar stance.
"I don't believe in creating a policy without fully understanding the issues and concerns that led to its development," said Lowe, former director of transportation for Frederick County Schools. "We need to gather a collaborative group that includes parents, students, teachers, support staff, administrators, bus drivers and community members to ensure diverse perspectives are considered."
Lowe also brought up the intersection of school safety and cellphone policy and said she believes that in light of recent school shootings, students need to have a way to communicate in emergencies.
And one candidate — Maisie T. Howard of Anne Arundel County — voiced concerns that a ban would do more harm than good, especially for special needs students, those from rural areas and those who thrive in virtual environments.
"The cellphone is not the enemy," she said. "For many of us, it is our only computer."
In contrast, some candidates, like Ann O'Connor from Talbot County, believe in a full ban in elementary and middle schools, along with emergency access only in high schools. O'Connor, a former high school Spanish teacher and mother of six, said she believes a tougher phone policy could decrease mental health issues, bullying and distraction in schools.
"If Talbot County wants to lead the way on protecting our kids from short attention spans and gaps in core knowledge, this is the No. 1 thing that needs to happen," O'Connor said.
And O'Connor said those most in the know about the county's schools agree with her.
"I have talked to a number of teachers about cellphone use in school, and they unanimously tell me the same thing," O'Connor said. "Ban them."

title: Author empowering young voices
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Author empowering young voices

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment

 Words 

 Read News Document

 Author and educator Jessieca Montgomery is making significant strides in the realm of children's literature with her innovative series of coloring and activity books focused on public speaking for kids in grades kindergarten through 5.A news release said that "by combining creativity with essential communication skills, the Charles County resident is helping young learners build confidence and express themselves effectively."
As an educator with years of experience in teaching public speaking and communication skills, she recognized a gap in engaging resources tailored specifically for young learners, which led her to create a series that not only teaches essential skills, but also makes learning enjoyable and accessible.
The series consists of several titles, each designed to engage children in a fun, interactive way while introducing them to the fundamentals of public speaking.
Key titles include:
"Speak and Shine: A Coloring Adventure in Public Speaking" — This introductory book invites kids to explore the world of public speaking through colorful illustrations and interactive coloring activities. Each section provides simple lessons on key concepts such as voice projection, body language, and audience engagement, all while allowing children to express their creativity through art.
"Confidence in Every Word: Activity Book for Young Speakers" — In this activity book, Montgomery incorporates engaging puzzles, games, and scenarios that encourage kids to practice their speaking skills. Activities range from creating short speeches to role-playing different speaking situations, empowering children to build confidence and develop effective communication strategies.
"The Little Speaker's Toolkit: Coloring and Crafting Your Speech" — This book combines creative expression with practical speech preparation. Children are guided through the process of developing their own speeches, with templates for brainstorming ideas and spaces to illustrate their thoughts. By emphasizing storytelling and personal experiences, kids understand the importance of connecting with their audience.
Montgomery's books, which reflects her commitment to inclusivity and representation, feature diverse characters and relatable scenarios, allowing children from various backgrounds to see themselves in the material. This approach not only fosters engagement, but also helps to build a sense of belonging and confidence in young readers.
Public speaking is a vital skill that lays the foundation for effective communication, critical thinking, and self-confidence. Montgomery's series highlights the significance of these skills from a young age, equipping children with the tools they need to articulate their thoughts, advocate for themselves, and participate actively in discussions. By making public speaking approachable and fun, she encourages children to embrace their voices.
Montgomery's series of coloring and activity books on public speaking is a remarkable contribution to children's literature and education. Through her engaging and creative approach, she is nurturing a new generation of confident communicators who are ready to express their unique perspectives.
By inspiring kids to find their voices and share their stories, Montgomery is not only shaping their futures but also empowering them to shine in all areas of their lives. Her work is a testament to the to the transformative power of education and the importance of fostering communication skills in every child.
For more information, go to www.speakezforkids.com.

title: An open letter on recent education mailers
author: SHARON PEPUKAYI and EMILY JACKSON Talbot County Public Schools
content:
An open letter on recent education mailers

 October 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SHARON PEPUKAYI and EMILY JACKSON Talbot County Public Schools | Section: Columns 
 
 534
 Words

 Dear Talbot County Community,We would like to address the recent mailers that have been distributed to homes throughout our community. This campaign unfairly targets our schools, students, and dedicated Talbot County Public Schools educators.
Our team does face challenges like many school districts, and we face them directly and with transparency. While we do not want to give life to these messages you are receiving, we want to make sure our community knows the truth.
We are working to improve our performance on state assessments. With support from the Talbot County Council, we have made significant investments, including acquiring new rigorous standards-based curricula and hiring and retaining qualified teachers and administrators. Additionally, we have made math one of our priorities and are putting concentrated efforts into the teaching and learning of this curricular area. We also know that student success is measured by many indicators in addition to state assessment scores.
While we know we have work to do, there is growth we can celebrate. The 23-24 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment results showed modest improvement across all Maryland districts. In Talbot County, our overall margin of progress was slightly greater than what the state achieved. In English/Language Arts, out of the 24 school districts, Talbot County Public Schools had the greatest increase in students being proficient. These results inform our continued work on the initiatives put in place to provide our educators with the resources needed to ensure student success.
We adhere to the Health Education Standards set forth by the Maryland Department of Education. Maryland state law requires that parents/guardians be notified about topics covered in the Family Life unit. They have the option of having their student excused if they are uncomfortable with this content being taught to their students by TCPS educators.
Our Talbot County students graduate from our high schools and continue to excel in college, career and life. This is a result of their hard work, the commitment of the TCPS team, the leadership of the Board of Education and the support of the County Council and our many community partners.
Our support staff, teachers and administrators are dedicated professionals who deserve our trust and support. By collaborating openly and constructively, we can ensure that our school system remains a beacon of opportunity and excellence for every child, regardless of their background.
We invite the community to our established public forums scheduled each month through our regular Board of Education meetings. These meetings are open to all citizens, and we encourage everyone to attend and participate in these sessions. Only through collaboration and communication do we truly provide the best opportunities for our students.
We are honored to serve as Talbot County's superintendent of schools and president of the Board of Education, and we are very proud of our students and staff. We believe in and will continue to advocate for TCPS students, families and educators. We are TCPS, and we are committed to transforming and performing together.
If you have questions or concerns, please email us at info@talbotschools.org. We are here for you and all of the children of Talbot County. Thank you for your continued support.

title: Students learn to build and sell in CBMM's Rising Tide After-School program
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Students learn to build and sell in CBMM's Rising Tide After-School program

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The holiday season has come early at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, and boys and girls of a variety of ages are working diligently to craft wooden Christmas trees, stockings, snowmen and marine life to sell as ornaments.As schools across the nation are closing vocational skill programs, the museum's Rising Tide After-School program is filling the gap by providing middle school students the opportunity to learn marketing and vocational skills under the supervision of dedicated volunteers.
This program lasts seven weeks and caters to students in grades six through nine. The students learn project design and development, team collaboration tool management and workshop safety.
Alyssa Zajan, the student and public programs manager, said the students choose the projects they work on for the duration of the program.
"This year, they got in the holiday spirit, so they've been making ornaments," Zajan said. "They've been hand cutting them, using hand saws, as well as some of our saws and our power saws, and decorating them. And they're going to market them to the community."
The ornaments will be included in the museum's store. Students will be choosing price points and learning marketing skills.
All proceeds for the ornaments will go back into the program to help it continue.
According to Jill Ferris, Rising Tide's vice president of education and interpretation, the program began in 2017 as a boat building program and has evolved to better serve the core mission of providing middle school students in Talbot County a fun and safe environment where they can access skills education.
Ferris said schools in the area have not been in the position to provide the vocation training they had in the past. The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum sought to provide that kind of experience for students to be able to work with mentors and educators and learn different skills.
"How do we connect students and help them develop skills to be the future leaders and pursue pathways that they are interested in, and so the idea of taking an entrepreneurial pathway was one that we just thought was really fun and would be really resonant for the kids," Ferris said.
The program runs on a quarterly basis, with the next session opening in January 2025. Ferris said accessibility is a core value of the program, and participants are offered partial to full scholarships as well as transportation for students who live outside of St. Michaels.
Harper Black, a student in the program, said she has enjoyed being in the program and is happy with the work she has been able to accomplish.
"It's really cool to work with things you haven't experienced yet," Black said. "Because you don't have the materials at home. So it's cool to come here and do it."

title: School mailing accusations are false
author: Staff Writer
content:
School mailing accusations are false

 November 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 391
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot county residents have recently been receiving U.S. Postal Service mailings questioning the quality of teaching in our county's public schools. Among its many criticisms, the glossy mailings falsely decry the low English and math proficiency and attribute these low scores to time wasted "forcing harmful gender ideology" on students.Here are some facts: 39% of students in Talbot County are classified as "economically disadvantaged" (data gathered by US News and World Report), and 40% are members of a minority. Fully 14% of students study English as a second language. Talbot County Public Schools is one of only eight districts out of the 24 in Maryland that earned star ratings of three or higher for all schools. (reportcard.msde.maryland.gov)
In 2023 Talbot County Schools boasted an attendance rate of 91.5% and a high school graduation rate of 95%. Schools also showed year over year improvement in academic achievement. These are numbers to be proud of, not scorned.
So where are these accusations and false claims coming from? They are originating from a group identifying itself as "Pay Attention America Inc." with a postal address listed as 1000 N. West St, Suite 1200, Wilmington, Delaware. In its mailings, it cites the "Daily Citizen" whose director of communications claims: "God has declared certain things 'good' and certain things 'bad.' He's given us clear principles to use in considering current events. And He's spoken clearly on the subjects of life, marriage, law and government. We cannot remain morally neutral in our reporting."
Are we all to believe that God has spoken directly to the Daily Citizen and told it what is good and what is bad and facts are irrelevant? The mailings scream "radical politicians are pushing extreme radical agendas" and "radical indoctrination" of children is taking place in the schools.
Unfortunately, our public schools make an easy target for out of state organizations with a defined political agenda. It is sad that their misrepresentations and slurs seek to divide our community instead of seeking solutions in a positive, fact-based approach. We believe it is important, more now than ever, to make decisions based on facts, not gobbledygook.
Ultimately, we question why a Delaware religious organization finds it necessary to alarm us when all Talbot citizens have to do is simply talk to our teachers and our school administrators about our concerns.
That is how local control works.
JIM WILKINS

JIM RICHARDSON
Claiborne

title: Talbot County schools remain beacon of opportunity, excellence

content:
Talbot County schools remain beacon of opportunity, excellence
