 We would like to address the recent mailers that have been distributed to homes throughout our community. This campaign unfairly targets our schools, students, and dedicated Talbot County Public Schools educators.Our team does face challenges like many school districts, and we face them directly and with transparency. While we do not want to give life to these messages you are receiving, we want to make sure our community knows the truth.
We are working to improve our performance on state assessments. With support from the Talbot County Council, we have made significant investments, including acquiring new rigorous standards-based curricula and hiring and retaining qualified teachers and administrators. Additionally, we have made math one of our priorities and are putting concentrated efforts into the teaching and learning of this curricular area. We also know that student success is measured by many indicators in addition to state assessment scores.
While we know we have work to do, there is growth we can celebrate. The 23-24 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment results showed modest improvement across all Maryland districts. In Talbot County, our overall margin of progress was slightly greater than what the state achieved. In English and language arts, out of the 24 school districts, Talbot County Public Schools had the greatest increase in students being proficient. These results inform our continued work on the initiatives put in place to provide our educators with the resources needed to ensure student success.
We adhere to the health education standards set forth by the Maryland Department of Education. Maryland state law requires that parents/guardians be notified about topics covered in the family life unit. They have the option of having their student excused if they are uncomfortable with this content being taught to their students by Talbot County Public Schools educators.
Our Talbot County students graduate from our high schools and continue to excel in college, career and life. This is a result of their hard work, the commitment of the TCPS team, the leadership of the Board of Education and the support of the County Council and our many community partners.
Our support staff, teachers and administrators are dedicated professionals who deserve our trust and support. By collaborating openly and constructively, we can ensure that our school system remains a beacon of opportunity and excellence for every child, regardless of their background.
We invite the community to our established public forums scheduled each month through our regular Board of Education meetings. These meetings are open to all citizens, and we encourage everyone to attend and participate in these sessions. Only through collaboration and communication do we truly provide the best opportunities for our students.
We are honored to serve as Talbot County's superintendent of schools, and president of the Board of Education, and we are very proud of our students and staff. We believe in and will continue to advocate for Talbot County Public Schools students, families and our highly driven team of educators. We are TCPS, and we are committed to transforming and performing together.
If you have questions or concerns, please email us at info@talbotschools.org. We are here for you and all of the children of Talbot County. Thank you for your continued support.

title: Student vets' stories provide unique insight on service
author: Kesha Williams Staff Writer
content:
Student vets' stories provide unique insight on service

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Kesha Williams Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 810
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Administrators and students at Elizabeth City's three institutions of higher education gathered at College of The Albemarle on Thursday for a unique Veterans Day observance.During the event, veterans enrolled at COA, Mid-Atlantic Christian University, and Elizabeth City State University talked about their military experiences and how their decision to serve their country had affected their lives and career choices.
Bobby Martin, a student at MACU, joined the U.S. Navy after high school in 1977. His dad, a Vietnam era veteran and minister, was his role model, he said. When his dad's colleagues visited their home to enjoy meals and football games, Martin said he heard first-hand accounts about what it meant to serve in the military.
"These men were inspirations to me," Martin said. "I have been to the North Pole, Europe, Middle East and East Africa while in the Navy. I'm 66 years old, put my wife and child through school, and now I'm working on my ministry degree at Mid-Atlantic Christian University. "
Wendra Costly, a U.S. Army veteran now enrolled at COA, recalled how she left the U.S. Army in 2018 wondering what she would do. While her job in the military was in information technology, and there are promising job opportunities in that field, Costly wasn't persuaded IT would provide her with the long-term career she was seeking.
And as a wife and mother of four, Costly said she knew it was important to have a rewarding career with good pay.
"I called the aviation department (at COA) and got some information about their program. I finally decided that aviation was the way to go for (me in) our area," she said.
Costly also talked about some of the challenges veterans face when they go back to school.
"We are older, and we have had some experiences that a good amount of college adults will not be able to relate to," she said.
But overcoming challenges is something you learn to do in the military, Costly said.
"Just like all the hard things you accomplished in the military like training, running in the rain, heat and cold — we can do them," she said.
Michelle Barnes, who is enrolled at ECSU, spent eight years working as an aviation electronics technician in the U.S. Navy. Barnes said the fear of traveling to unfamiliar places and the potential of having to face danger nearly delayed her decision to enlist.
But she's glad she did enlist. Barnes said her job in the Navy was challenging and provided steady pay.
Today, she's glad she accepted the challenges the military offered. She met her husband, who is currently enlisted, while she was in service. Serving in the military also has helped her pay for her college expenses.
"Joining the military was the best decision that I could have ever made at the age of 25," Barnes said. "I decided to embrace all that the Navy had to offer me in honor of those who fought and died for this country's freedom. "
Barnes said she will graduate in 2026 with a bachelor of science degree in aviation science with a concentration in professional aeronautics and a minor in unmanned aerial systems.
Dr. Catherine Edmonds, ECSU's interim chancellor, applauded her colleagues at MACU and COA for helping area veterans return to school to learn new skills. She also thanked the veterans who attended the event.
"Although we work every day to assist and honor our veterans, today is set aside specifically to recognize all of our veterans for their service and sacrifices," she said. "We are a military-friendly university, proud to continue a tradition of excellence serving military members, veterans, and their families."
Bane Angles, vice president of student services at MACU and also a veteran, said he was impressed by the student veterans' stories. He also was glad, he said, that the city's three institutions of higher education could come together and offer an event like Thursday's.
"There are many important lessons I learned from serving in the military," Angles said. "Not least of these is the importance of unity. No matter where a person is from, what accent they have, what race they are, or creed they follow, all are part of something bigger.
"In a society that is too divided for many reasons, we can learn from our armed forces that a higher purpose brings us together in unity. I pray for the day when our country is not divided but is united," Angles said.
COA President Dr. Jack Bagwell said the community college was proud to host Thursday's event. He also applauded the veterans in the audience for their service and urged them to help the college serve them better.
"We believe we can get better everyday," he said. "With you helping us there are things we have not thought of yet that will serve you better. Please share those. We are always open to your feedback. We're certainly open to how we can be more military friendly."

title: Athens High School holds Veterans Day event for students
author: Gabriel Scotto APG Media
content:
Athens High School holds Veterans Day event for students

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Gabriel Scotto APG Media | Section: News 
 
 570
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ATHENS - Ahead of Monday's Veterans Day celebrations, Athens High School held a special assembly for its students to talk and hear from veterans throughout Athens County.According to a study conducted by the United States Census Bureau in 2022, 6.2% of the adult population are veterans. However, this number has fallen significantly. In 2005, there were 23.4 million veterans. By 2022, there were only 16.2 million, with nearly half of those being 65 or older. There are only 795,600 veterans who served in the Second World War or the Korean War.
It is for these reasons that Melissa Myers, student council advisor and a French teacher at Athens High School, says this event is important. Myers recounted when she volunteered at an assisted living home while in high school and formed a bond with a Belgian woman who'd lived through the World Wars and how it changed her perspective.
"You can study history and read books and watch movies, but you never truly get an understanding of what people have gone through," Myers said. "It's (about) making those stories come to life and having a better appreciation."
Myers' perspective is also shaped by her father, who served in the Army National Guard, as well as her time serving in the Peace Corps. She hopes talking to veterans will help high school students gain a similar perspective on the importance of service and on fighting for a cause that's greater than oneself.
"Hopefully for our high school students it helps our young people understand, no matter what your positions are on various things, everyone who serves, they're serving their country. It's one single vision."
The main event at the Veterans Day assembly was a speech from Chad Springer, associate superintendent at Athens City Schools and a former United States Army sergeant. Springer felt it was important to share his experience with the students of Athens High School, even if he personally prefers to celebrate Veterans Day quietly.
"Some veterans like to go to the public events and things like that," Springer said. "Generally, I don't, because service is very personal to me, because all of us had our own reasons for serving."
Springer told the story of his uncles, Bob and Howard. Howard was a United States Army Ranger during the Second World War, while Bob served in the Army during the Korean War. Bob was able to rise to the rank of sergeant first class in three years, an impressive feat that would've taken years to achieve during peacetime, but he carried the scars of Korea with him for the rest of his life.
"Most of the family saw him as a larger than life man with a short fuse, a quick temper and a love of the drink," Springer explained.
Springer said that serving in the military and experiencing the challenges of military service gave him a different perspective on his Uncle Bob than the rest of his family had and that had he not served, he would've remembered his uncles very differently.
"I learned to not judge lest ye be judged, because when it came down to it, we were all needed by each other. I became a brother to those around me," Springer said, recounting his time in the Army. "When someone needed me, their needs were met. When I needed something, others were always there for me. It instilled in myself a sense of community and belonging that I have never felt before nor since."

title: It's been a wild ride
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
It's been a wild ride

 November 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 888
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — A colorful, repurposed school travels about Kent County, stopping at various elementary schools to deliver not only their wonderfully imaginative series of children's novels, but some good, old-fashioned face time with the books' authors, Robbi Behr and Matthew Swanson of Chestertown.For several years now the entrepreneurial illustrator and writer pair have been quietly supporting the effort to provide better access to books for kids in Title I schools. With every school they visit, they have been winning kids over with a lively presentation that allows the children to imagine what it's like to be creators themselves.
This agency-invoking exercise would prove to be the catalyst that convinced the married couple to embark on their cross-county, "Busload of Books Tour." The intent to visit one Title I school in every state over the course of a year was the direct result of the enthusiasm that kids and educators alike found in the approachable, friendly and totally immersive experience that Behr and Swanson provided.
A team of educational researchers from Washington College was also assembled to compile the data necessary to ascertain relevant outcomes and impacts that will be used to assess and support the needs of Title I schools going forward.
The trip was chronicled daily by the pair via social media and by others who had the opportunity to see this presentation for themselves. And even though it is more than a year since they all got off the bus, narratives about this remarkable trip and its impacts on the communities of kids visited continues to make news on both the local and national level, with an appearance on The Drew Barrymore Show and articles in both Forbes and People magazines, among many others.
Throughout the 2024-2025 school year, the couple has continued their literacy initiative by planning to visit a total of 12 schools across the country; six in-person and six virtually.
Behr and Swanson, who have a significant portion of their career portfolio anchored in the art of collaboration, have been regular speakers on the topic over the last decade, honing a particular blend of authentic communication skills and humor that resonate with their audiences. As a result, they have been recognized and supported by peers within their creative, collaborative sphere of influence, which has led to other opportunities to share what they know.
Earlier in 2024, Swanson said, they received an interesting email from one such peer who felt they would be a thought-provoking addition to a roster of speakers at this year's Masters of Scale Conference held in San Francisco and sponsored by the podcast of the same name and its parent company, WaitWhat media properties.
The email, which was authored by company CEO, Jeff Berman, was a pitch for the couple to join a distinguished list of thought-leaders in their respective fields who would speak to the conference's theme which leans heavily in all things tech, with a focus this year on the advent of Artificial Intelligence, or AI.
"First of all, I was like, why do they want us to talk at this thing?" Swanson said. "From what we understood, it's like a tech conference and we are kind of like the most analog people with what we're doing. We're driving around in a bus giving out boxes of books."
To date, this would be the largest and most widely recognized conference at which the pair would speak, with notables such as American internet entrepreneur and venture capitalist, Reid Hoffman, the CEO of Chewy, Inc., Sumit Singh, former President Bill Clinton, and Wes Moore, governor of Maryland, scheduled to present.
"However, it totally made sense from the standpoint that Robbi and I have never fit in wherever we've gone," added Swanson. "Our first big speaking gig was the International Illustrators Conference, when we had not published a single book. We were there because of our story being an inspiring sort of tale of entrepreneurship and outside-of-the-box thinking. And to that extent, being invited to Masters of Scale was the same thing. We had done something unexpected that people found inspiring and interesting and that they thought might serve as a model to others about how to look beyond the expected solutions."
So how would they take a presentation geared to elementary school kids and age it up for an adult audience?
"Really there's about 30 different stories, single stories you could tell, right? Behr conjectured. "There's the story of the research, there's the story of the kids, there's the story of the teachers, there's stories of communities, there's the story of us driving around."
The result was an interactive, yet intimate chat with an audience of about 800 people that spoke to the genesis of their outreach, the challenges that Title I schools continue to face, family life on the road in that colorful bus, and the incredible partnerships forged from the very beginning.
By the time the winding tale of an adorable hippo named Jenny whose dream to own an ice cream shop was realized and then threatened by the evil, lactose-intolerant sun, there wasn't a dry eye in the house, as the audience whole-heartedly leaned into their exercise—their attention definitely captured.
Behr and Swanson summarized their talk by relaying that in a sense, we all have the option to create a "colorful school bus" of sorts and drive it down a path of our choosing that represents a change for the better.

title: Maryland conservatives make gains in school board races
author: Adam Hudacek Capital News Service
content:
Maryland conservatives make gains in school board races

 November 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Adam Hudacek Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1263
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Conservative school board candidates saw sweeping wins across Maryland this week, defying expectations in the largely blue state and solidifying the influence of the 1776 Project PAC, the Republican-aligned organization that endorsed 19 candidates statewide.In total, 11 of the political action committee's endorsed candidates either won or narrowly led their races as of Friday morning. Candidates backed by the PAC won control of the school boards in Somerset and Calvert counties, while appearing poised to win in Talbot County. Final results await the counting of some mail-in and provisional ballots, which must be counted by Nov. 15.
Campaign finance records show that the Maryland State Education Association Fund for Children and Public Education — the political arm of the state's teachers union — spent $516,999.57 during the 2024 election cycle. And the 1776 Project PAC clearly sees the teachers' union as its defeated rival in the election.
"Even outspending us by $450,000, the teachers' union couldn't beat us in deep-blue Maryland—their message is just too extreme," said Stefano Forte, executive director of the 1776 Project PAC. "Voters chose raising test scores and graduation rates over their far-left culture war. On Tuesday, common sense won, and that has no price tag."
A fourth school district with candidates targeted for defeat by Democrats — Washington County — also flipped to conservative control without the aid of the 1776 Project PAC.
Of those 11 winners endorsed by that conservative PAC, six had also been targeted for defeat by the Maryland Democratic Party, which selected 24 "extreme" conservative school board candidates in the state to directly invest against — a move the party referred to as "unprecedented." Of those 24, only nine have been lost thus far. The remaining 15 all won or are leading their respective races.
"We are proud that we pushed out some of the most extreme elements in these races," said Luca Amayo, spokesperson for the Maryland Democratic Party. "It's clear, however, that we must continue to bolster our grassroots efforts and make Marylanders aware of the far-right agenda encroaching into Maryland's public schools, especially as they are emboldened under a Donald Trump presidency."
The party considers the 1776 Project PAC a "radical ring-wing group," and helped defeat five of its endorsed candidates from winning office. Ryan James Girdusky, the committee's founder, wrote on the PAC's website that he created the organization "to change public education by reforming school boards and electing reform-minded conservatives who wanted to improve public education in this country."
As of Oct. 16, the PAC had pumped $90,580.50 toward the campaigns of 13 candidates across Cecil, Queen Anne's, Talbot, Calvert, Somerset and St. Mary's counties.
In Calvert County, candidates endorsed by the 1776 Project PAC won all three school board seats.
Retired principal Mike Shisler lost his bid for the board. He said he fears that the new conservative leadership, all of whom were targeted by the state's Democratic Party as well, would create inequity and fear within the county's education system.
"I'm very disappointed in the results," Shisler said Wednesday, "It's not going to be inclusive of everybody. It's going to target folks. It's going to try to undo the work of previous boards of education when it came to stressing equity and diversity, and I think they're trying to roll back the clock."
Joseph Marchio, who defeated Shisler, said he expected a close race going into Tuesday night. His margin was the closest of the three 1776 Project PAC-backed victors in Calvert County.
In Washington County, on the state's panhandle, all four candidates that Democrats targeted for defeat won their election, flipping the county's school board into conservative control. All three non-targeted incumbents lost reelection, while April Ann Zentmeyer, the only targeted incumbent, defended hers.
"I look forward to working with new board members and faithful colleagues to maximize opportunities for students, faculty, staff, and parents; and to identify solutions that will strengthen WCPS," Zentmeyer said in a statement.
Washington County has a county-wide school board election process, as opposed to the school districts where candidates are elected by district. Instead of one-on-one races, all school board candidates in Washington County face each other in a crowded pool, with the top four vote-getting candidates winning seats. Carroll, Allegany and Frederick counties have similar systems.
The success of conservative school board candidates around Maryland reflects a larger trend from this year's election cycle: the state's rightward shift. According to data from the Associated Press, every county in Maryland shifted rightward this year compared to the 2020 election — from two points in Charles County and Baltimore City to eight points in Cecil County.
Some races remain too close to call. In Frederick County, two conservative candidates targeted by Democrats led the race for three seats as of Friday, but two other candidates trailed close behind. Talbot County, which flipped conservative this cycle, saw two 1776 Project PAC-endorsed candidates win seats, while a third trailed by a narrow margin as of Friday with votes still left to tally.
Somerset County, the third district flipped by 1776 Project PAC-endorsed contenders, saw massive margins of victory for the conservatives, with Mary Beth Bozman securing about four-fifths of the vote in her race. Her opponent was Alverne "Chet" Chesterfield — who, the Local News Network reported last month, had a peace order initiated against him in 2022.
The Local News Network also reported that Brandie Edelen, a 1776 Project PAC-endorsed candidate in St. Mary's County, had a state tax lien filed against her in 2019. Edelen handily lost her race to Josh Guy.
In deep-blue Howard County, Andrea Chamblee is in a tight race with Trent Kittleman, an early supporter of the county's Moms for Liberty chapter. Even though Democrat Kamala Harris carried over two-thirds of the votes cast in the presidential race in the county, Chamblee led Kittleman by only 3.5 points as of Friday morning.
Mail-in and provisional ballots, which have leaned in favor of Chamblee this far, are still being counted.
The founder of Moms for Liberty in Frederick County, Jaime Brennan, appeared headed to victory. She said that despite the Maryland Democrats' campaign against her and Colt Black, the other conservative in the race, that effort didn't appear to be all that effective.
"They spent a lot of money in opposition to me and Colt, and to prop up the other side, but I didn't hear from a single person who said, 'Oh, I heard about this and I'm not voting for you,'" Brennan said.
In neighboring Carroll County, where Moms For Liberty lobbied for the removal of 60 books from school libraries — 21 permanently — conservative candidates secured their hold on the board. Greg Malveaux and Kristen Zihmer defeated Amanda Jozkowski and Muri Lynn Dueppen, who together ran an underdog progressive campaign called the Slate for Student Success, which was endorsed by the Carroll County Educators Association.
"It's really a shame that a lot of voters in our county chose to kind of take their marching orders from their political party, rather than considering the opinions of the educators," Jozkowski said. She previously ran and lost in 2022.
Jozkowski said the race was a reflection of the national results, which saw an overwhelming rightward shift in nearly every state and in many down-ballot races. Malveaux and Zihmer were both targeted by the Maryland Democrats.
That rightward shift could also be seen in the school board race in Anne Arundel County's District 3. There, the conservative candidate, Chuck Yocum, fell only 2.76 points behind his opponent, Erica McFarland, despite weeks of controversy over Yocum's 1994 acquittal on child sexual abuse and perverted practices charges.
Local News Network reporters Sasha Allen, Marwa Barakat, Ela Jalil, Colin McNamara and Tolu Talabi contributed to this report.

St. Michaels temporary library opens at Village Shopping Center

 ST. MICHAELS — The Talbot County Free Library, St. Michaels Branch has opened its temporary location at the St. Michaels Village Shopping Center on Talbot Street. To celebrate the grand opening, the library provided free coffee, craft bags and donuts for all visitors on Tuesday morning.The Talbot Free Library on Fremont Street is currently undergoing construction for its building expansion. The temporary location, at the site of the former St. Michaels YMCA, will serve residents of St. Michaels until the expansion is complete.
Shauna Beulah, branch manager for the library, said construction at the Fremont location will take about a year to 18 months.
"A full service library will offer all of the services we had there, a Xerox machine, children's area with all the different kinds of materials they had, and audio books and DVDs, new books, all of those things," Beulah said.
Beulah said the location of the temporary library was important because it needed to be accessible and a familiar space for residents to visit.
Though it is a full-service library, there are some amenities the temporary location does not provide, including meeting rooms and an external book drop, so books will need to be returned during open hours.
But Beulah said the wait would be worth the vast renovation expected at the Fremont location. Renovations include an eating area, social computer rooms, a quiet reading section and a multi-purpose section for all.
Diana Hastings, youth services librarian, said the first few families who visit the new library will get a fall bag with fun crafts for all ages to encourage creativity and family-based activities.
Hastings, who is also an art therapist, said she tries to provide hands-on crafts and activities to young readers to create and explore and prepare for their journey into literacy.
Though the temporary library is a smaller space, Hastings said it provides an extensive array of youth books, including bilingual children's book, fiction, non-fiction chapter books, vox books (live print audio books) and recorded storybooks. If a book is not available at the library, librarians can order it from a different library.
This way efforts are made for residents to still have access to the information they need.
"We hope that families take advantage of coming here, utilizing our resources, and we welcome them," Hastings said.

 EASTON — Talbot County Public Schools is looking at new leadership, according to uncertified vote totals from the Maryland Board of Elections.Cynthia Marrah Jurrius, Karla Wieland-Cherry and Ann O'Connor, none of whom have prior experience on the Talbot County Board of Education, won seats for their districts.
The elected board members said they plan to bring their campaign priorities to the forefront of their terms, which begin Dec. 1 and will last for four years.
Talbot County's Board of Education is made up of seven members from different districts in the county and two student board members. Districts 2, 5 and 6 were on the ballot in the November election.
For district 2, O'Connor won with 52.7% of the vote, according to the State Board of Elections, beating out incumbent Board Member Candace Henry. O'Connor said her campaign provided the opportunity for her to get a better understanding of leading a campaign, school board responsibilities and Blueprint, Maryland's 10-year plan to improve the state's education system.
O'Connor said she has just skimmed the surface and is ready to learn more.
She said she will be prioritizing academics and discipline. With academics, she said she would like to see elementary students reading every night and working on more book reports, and for schools to provide summer reading lists.
For discipline, O'Connor said she has noticed a lack of consistency, or "different rules for different people."
"We need a plan for all the schools that this is the way we're going to, you know, this is the dress, this is the behavior when you walk in the building. If you veer from that, there's going to be this consequence, and you got to, I mean, it's the follow through," she said.
For District 5, Karla Wieland-Cherry won with 54.6% votes, according to the State Board of Elections. Wieland-Cherry, who defeated incumbent Board Member Anna Howie, said she appreciated the support she received from her campaign, though she did mention she "got a lot of negativity." She hopes she can work through any negative sentiments to have a productive four years on the board.
Wieland-Cherry said she will be prioritizing open communication for everyone she works with and promoting the Career and Technology Education Program, which offers job training in various fields.
She said it's important to encourage kids to look at career alternatives for those not interested in college, whether that be training to become a firefighter, plumber or welder.
"I think (the CTE program is) under encouraged, under utilized," Wieland-Cherry said. "And that's where jobs are."
For District 6, Jurrius won with 51.9% of the vote, defeating Kerry Gunshenan, according to the State Board of Elections. Current District 6 Board Member Mary Wheeler did not seek reelection.
Jurrius did not answer calls from reporters in time for publication.

title: Student-parents need support from colleges
author: MIKE MUNOZ
content:
Student-parents need support from colleges

 November 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE MUNOZ | Section: Columns 
 
 711
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After my daughter's mom left when she was an infant, I raised her as a single father while I went to college. As a first-generation student, higher education was my hope for a better future for both of us.Like so many student-parents, I faced numerous obstacles including housing and food insecurity and a lack of affordable child care. I know what it's like when you can't pay for books, food or a place to live. Beyond the scarcity of physical resources, I felt like I didn't fit in.
It's not uncommon for student-parents to feel hopeless and isolated on campus. As president of Long Beach City College, it is my personal and professional mission to make sure all students who come to our campus feel a sense of belonging.
Across the nation, one in five college students are parents. In addition to attending college, student parents engage with multiple sectors including early childhood education, K-12, the labor market and social safety net programs. Together, we must do more to ensure student parents have the support they need to achieve the aspirations they have for themselves and their families.
According to Long Beach Community College data, the majority of our student-parents are mothers of color who are 25 years of age or older and facing financial disadvantages. The majority of our student-parents also identify as single.
When I look back on my own experience, I remember single mothers telling me I was in a position of privilege because I am a dad. I stood out as a single parent, and they saw that people wanted to help me. While research on student fathers is scarce, one study shows that student fathers are indeed more likely to receive help than student mothers.
I believe that being a student-parent is challenging no matter how you identify, but single mothers deal with a unique level of stigma.
When I arrived at Long Beach Community College as vice president of student services, I noticed signs with a stroller and a bar through it saying "No children allowed." We got that changed immediately. That wasn't the message we wanted to send. At the college, we want student-parents to know they are appreciated here, and so are their children.
In addition to the Child Development Center for children ages 2-5, student-parents can also access cost-free after-school care for children ages 6-18 through the Viking Clubhouse, in partnership with the Boys & Girls Club of Long Beach. We also offer a CalWORKs (California Work Opportunity and Responsibility for Kids) program to assist student parents with education, training and job skills. One of the programs that I'm most excited about involves our partnership with Raise The Barr. Through this partnership, single parent students and their families can access affordable child care and housing.
We are making progress, but we have more hard work ahead. Culture change takes time, and we need to continually hold ourselves accountable. A recent survey revealed that more than half of the student-parents on our campus do not know about the resources available to them. We cannot expect student-parents, who are already more likely to face time poverty, to spend hours researching where to find help and navigating disparate processes.
As we strive to improve, we're engaging other partners in this important work. We are one of four community colleges selected for Ascend at the Aspen Institute's Postsecondary Leadership Circle Activation Fund. Through our partnership with Ascend, we are driving two key strategies forward.
The first involves streamlining resources so that student-parents can more easily access services and programs. Our team is in the process of creating a one-stop shop for housing, food, child care, mental health, academic supports and more. The next strategy involves an outreach campaign to make sure students know about available services.
By nurturing our student-parents through degree completion or through the transfer process to a four-year university, we are creating opportunities for one generation to the next. Student-parents model hard work and commitment for their children. Today, my daughter is a community college professor, and I couldn't be prouder.
Beyond providing the very best for their families, student-parents have much to contribute to their campuses and their communities. When these dedicated caregivers succeed, it is a win for us all, and that's why we must continue to dedicate ourselves to their victory.

title: Maryland schools get new rules for shooter drills
author: MARISSA YELENIK Capital News Service
content:
Maryland schools get new rules for shooter drills

 November 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARISSA YELENIK Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 809
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Active shooter drills in Maryland schools will be different next school year under a new set of state guidelines meant to limit the impact those drills have on the mental health of students.The new guidelines prohibit trauma-inducing elements like imitation of gunfire or explosions. They also require school systems to notify parents in advance when students will be practicing what to do in the event of an active shooter in their buildings.
The new guidelines were released by the Maryland Center for School Safety this fall, ordered by a new state law requiring them to draft new parameters and create a new process for collecting and analyzing data on their effectiveness. The center will also look into the psychological impact the shooter drills have on staff, parents and students.
Parts of the guidelines — including bans on gunfire and the requirement to notify parents — have already gone into effect because they are part of state law. The full set of guidelines will be put into effect at the beginning of the academic year in 2025.
"The mental health crisis that we see in our young people is undeniable," said Del. Jared Solomon, who sponsored the measure in the Maryland House of Delegates earlier this year. "As we normalize having to deal with school shootings, we are creating more anxiety and more issues among young people."
While schools have long practiced safety drills, active shooter drills are relatively new, following the 1999 shooting at Columbine High School, according to the guidelines.
School systems have made an effort to keep students safe by implementing active shooter drills, however, concerns have been raised across the country about the impact these drills have on student's mental health. This led to the April passage of the Maryland bill, as well as an executive order signed by President Joe Biden to increase federal guidance on the subject.
Maryland's new guidelines, released in October, call for unified terminology between districts to discourage miscommunication between the school system and the relevant public. They intend to increase communication between staff and students to create an open dialogue where everyone feels comfortable raising concerns, as well as creating a diverse planning team who will work on planning the drills and doing a post-analysis of how it went and any shortcomings it faced.
The guidelines emphasize that active shooter drills are not a one-size-fits-all matter, and should be adjusted to fit the age group.
"These are going to be part of a young person's life for the foreseeable future, but that doesn't mean that you can't do them in a way that is both trauma-informed and age-appropriate," said Solomon. "It's really important that the way school systems do these types of events reflects a care and age appropriateness of the grades that are being impacted."
The guidelines also recommend that a mechanism be established to pause or stop the drill when necessary, for schools to notify parents before and after all drills to increase trust and communication and to allow students and staff who feel uncomfortable to opt-out from the drills.
The Maryland General Assembly sponsors of the bill, Solomon and Sen. Cheryl Kagan, felt that the impact guns have on today's children needs to be mitigated as much as possible, and worked to balance a focus on their safety while prioritizing their mental health.
"The law that Del. Solomon and I sponsored and passed tried to walk the fine line of thoughtful preparation that isn't traumatic," Kagan said. "And we also had to consider parents and community members who are understandably alarmed and concerned when they see the impact of these drills … Our concern was that [the drills] were not being strategic in how they were handled, and were actually causing trauma for those involved."
One active shooter drill that occurred in Solomon's district served as a driving force for his involvement.
"Families were literally getting texts from their kids saying 'I don't know if I'll ever see you again' and it was a drill. They didn't know," said Solomon. "There was no requirement prior to this for a school or a school system to notify families before or after."
Additional drivers for the bill included shared experiences from other parents Solomon spoke to, he said. Many shared frustrations at the lack of foresight they had into when the drills would be taking place and what would happen during them, preventing them from having appropriate conversations with their children to prepare them.
Starting in January, schools will distribute a new survey made by the National Center for School Mental Health to gather feedback from staff, parents and students on how effective the drills are, and the mental impact they have on all involved.
"The goal is not to create fear but to instill confidence and preparedness," the Maryland Center for School Safety said in their guidelines. "By working together as a community, schools can foster safe and supportive learning environments."

title: Character Counts celebrates 24th anniversary
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Character Counts celebrates 24th anniversary

 November 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News

 CENTREVILLE — Celebrating 24 years in the community, Character Counts was recognized for its work in shaping and encouraging positive character traits by the Queen Anne's County Commissioners Nov. 12.Character Counts is an initiative to increase character education by offering resources, training and information about the six pillars essential to character: trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring and citizenship.
Visiting classrooms to share Pillar of the Month lessons to promote positive behavior choices and embrace character development, Character Counts Coaches are now in 10 county pre-k classrooms and all Queen Anne's County middle and elementary schools, according to Coordinator Melinda Ray.
Approximately 4,200 students are receiving character education experiences through Character Counts this year, Ray said.
Since its inception in the county, over 1,600 volunteers have dedicated their time as Character Counts Coaches, and last year, these volunteers put in over 1,000 hours, totaling a $30,000 value to the county, she said.
This year over 100 community volunteers make Character Counts what it is, according to Ray. A dozen Kent Island High School Honor Society student coaches also lend a hand in serving as role models to younger students.
Crediting Queen Anne's County Public Schools as a fantastic partner, Ray thanked the initiatives' Advisory Board, the county commissioners, and QACPS for collaborative support.
With well over 20 years of providing assisting students, the community came together unofficially in 1999 to consider an initiative to support county students in the wake of the Columbine tragedy, before officially forming the character focused resource initiative in the fall of 2000, according to Committee Co-Chair Wayne Humphries.
"Its been a very exciting and very quick time," Humphries said, and credited phenomenal teams of volunteers and the support of the community to ensure the continuation of the legacy.
Over the decades it is estimated Character Counts has reached a total of between 70,000 and 100,000 students, he said.
"Its hard to believe in a county our size, but in 25 years it adds up," Humphries said.
Presenting an official anniversary proclamation, County Commissioner and former Character Counts Coach Phil Dumenil remembered the organization's 12th anniversary and the graduating students at the time who had been with the program since its inception.
"It's obviously a brilliant program," Dumenil said.

title: Talbot Board of Ed bids farewell to 3 outgoing board members
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com

Talbot Board of Ed bids farewell to 3 outgoing board members

 November 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News

 EASTON — The Talbot County Board of Education bid farewell to three of its seven board members at Wednesday's monthly meeting.Board Vice President Candace Henry and fellow board members Anna Howie and Mary Wheeler were thanked by their peers and Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi for their service on the board. Three new members will be sworn in next month.
"Your guidance and direction as board members has strengthened the bond between our community and our schools," Pepukayi said.
Board President Emily Jackson said the three outgoing members were crucial to the Board of Education's work to improve education in the county.
"That (work) is quietly often led by these three, which maybe you aren't aware of in the community. But I'm telling you tonight," Jackson said. "We are going to be cut down at the knees. We will grow back. But we are losing three incredibly important and valuable resources."
Wheeler, the outgoing District 6 representative who opted not to run for reelection, served on the board for 7.5 years. Cynthia Jurrius will assume Wheeler's seat after defeating Kerry Gunshenan in this month's election.
Board Member Amy Dodson said she will miss Wheeler's "pragmatism" and "common sense."
"I hope that I've done some good for the kids in Talbot County Public Schools. If I didn't, I know I tried," Wheeler said. " … Cynthia, the person who's taking my place, is here tonight. I so enjoy your enthusiasm. I've seen you at every meeting since you registered to run, so I'm pretty sure my seat's in good hands."
Howie, an assistant principal at Federalsburg Elementary School, will have her seat filled by Karla Wieland-Cherry following the District 5 election.
Jackson and Dodson said they appreciate Howie's educational expertise in her 1.5 years on the board.
"It has been such an honor and a blessing to see you in this role," Jackson told Howie. "When your name was thrown out there as somebody who could fill the empty (District 5) seat, I think I actually physically cheered. … It feels like you made a huge impact in your short time."
Henry's seat will be assumed by Ann O'Connor, who won the District 2 election over Henry. The outgoing vice president is the director of Salisbury University's Disability Resource Center.
Jackson said she's "so proud of the work" she accomplished alongside Henry, who has often spearheaded special education and accessibility efforts carried out by the board.
"As I step away from this role, I encourage you all to stay focused on what truly matters — every student, and I mean every student," Henry said. "Don't let individual agendas divide you or distract you from the essential work of seeing that every student is seen as valuable and worthy of our full support."
"I wish better for our community," she continued, "but now I get to just hold people accountable from another seat, and that's exactly what I plan to do."

title: DCPS to examine oldest elementary school buildings as teachers demand change
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
DCPS to examine oldest elementary school buildings as teachers demand change

 November 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 574
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Sandy Hill Elementary School teachers filled the Dorchester County Board of Education meeting room Thursday to speak about the school's learning environment and the need for change.Karen McGowan, who has been a teacher at Sandy Hill for about 21 years, said their school is losing "excellent and dedicated" teachers. She said families are moving out of the district because they're concerned about sending their kids to Sandy Hill.
"Our school is old and falling apart," she said.
McGowan brought up plumbing issues in bathrooms, issues with the building's room temperatures and the difficulties of having to teach and learn in open concept classrooms. Other teachers brought up mold problems and critters and bugs getting into the building.
"There's organic growth in the building," Sandy Hill teacher Christy Starling said. "Just two years ago, we had to push back our availability to enter the building prior to school starting due to massive mold infestation that had to be treated within a month before school started."
As part of the consent agenda passed during the meeting, the board voted in favor of having architecture firm Hord Coplan Macht do an ed specifications and feasibility study for the district's oldest elementary schools, including Sandy Hill.
The ed specifications and feasibility study is being funded by Maryland's Interagency Commission on School Construction. The IAC is also allocating money for school capital improvement projects in the county once the study has been completed.
During a Board of Education work session in October, board members heard from the IAC on the different programs it operates and its projected budget allocations to Dorchester County.
For fiscal year 2026, the IAC estimates $2.75 million of its Capital Improvement Program will be allocated to Dorchester County, with a state cost share of 98%. The IAC'S Built To Learn Program, a temporary program created to hand out project-specific grants across the state, has $3.9 million budgeted for Dorchester County. Those funds need to be spent by 2031.
At the meeting Thursday, Assistant Superintendent of Administrative Services Michael Collins said it is important that the district moves forward with the ed specifications and feasibility study quickly because the IAC funding for it needs to be encumbered by the end of the year.
"We want to get this phase done so we can make big decisions on our old elementary schools," he said.
Collins said the ed speculations process will take six months. He said a committee will work with the community to get an idea of what the ideal Dorchester County elementary school looks like. The feasibility study, he said, will determine what makes the most sense for each of the schools included.
"The feasibility study basically looks at each school and says, is it feasible to either renovate this school, replace this school or combine this school in order to make it fit with the ed spec?" Collins said.
Once this process is complete, the district will be able to bid out capital improvement projects. Collins estimated it will take about a year to complete the studies.
At the end of the meeting, board member Talibah Chikwendu told the Sandy Hill teachers that she is sorry it will "take so long" to build a school.
"Because even though the things are in place for us to actually get a large amount of that money to get it done, the process takes a very long time," she said. "I am sorry that you will have to continue to work in those conditions while we do so."

title: 'Share and make merry': International students get a taste of American holidays
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
'Share and make merry': International students get a taste of American holidays

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A native of Ghana, Angelica Maisuh has only been in the U.S for two years, but she's already come to enjoy the American Thanksgiving tradition."I have been to a couple Thanksgiving dinners, and I've loved it so far. It's a whole lot of fun. Eating, eating, eating," said Maisuh, who is pursuing a doctorate in economics at the University of Delaware.
"I feel like over here in America, everybody is like time-constrained, so it's an opportunity for families to come together and friends to come together and share and make merry," she added.
On Sunday, Maisuh was one of 500 international students and their family members who took part in the annual Thanksgiving dinner sponsored by UD's Center for Global Programs & Services. They gathered at the Trabant University Center and were treated to a full turkey dinner with all the fixings, plus pumpkin pie for dessert.
The event is a way to introduce international students to an American tradition, said Vina Titaley, associate director for international student engagement and success.
"It's an opportunity for students who have never experienced a Thanksgiving holiday to experience a Thanksgiving holiday," Titaley said. "But also it's a way of building community amongst our international students."
Each year, UD welcomes nearly 4,000 international students and visiting scholars representing 100 countries.
During Thanksgiving week, the campus shuts down and most students head home to spend the holiday with family and friends. However, international students, for whom home is an ocean away, often stay on campus. The annual dinner at Trabant gives those students a place to celebrate the holiday and feel included.
"This event is extremely important from a sense of creating belonging and really telling our students that they matter," said Ravi Ammigan, associate provost for international programs. "We are grateful to have such a large, diverse international student community on our campus."
Ammigan is from Mauritius and still remembers his first American Thanksgiving nearly three decades ago. He was attending college in Chicago, and a professor invited him and other students over for dinner.
"It was new, but very impactful. I felt that I belonged, because when the campus was empty, I had a place to go," he recalled. "And I think tonight, these students feel exactly the same way. They feel that this campus, this community, this university, cares. And we truly do."
The Center for Global Programs & Services started hosting a Thanksgiving dinner 11 years ago, with approximately 40 people attending. It has since grown into a signature event that students look forward to each year.
"We're all here, of course, to celebrate Thanksgiving," Ammigan said. "But I think it's much more than that. It's to celebrate cultures around the world. It's to have gratitude for friendship and being able to be together in a learning environment like what the University of Delaware is."
Titaley, who is originally from Indonesia, said many students are excited to try new foods.
"Turkey really is the highlight for a lot of students because turkey is kind of like a big icon for Thanksgiving," she said, adding that many students end up discovering that the side dishes are as delicious, if not more, than the turkey itself.
Neha Sindhu, a native of India who is pursuing a doctorate in bioinformatics, said her favorite Thanksgiving food is pumpkin pie. She said she enjoys getting to experience Thanksgiving because it provides a slice of American culture.
"It feels like we belong here in this culture, in this country," Sindhu said. "It feels good to have someone tell us that."
Faith Wanjiku, from Kenya, is experiencing her first Thanksgiving. She came to UD 11 months ago to earn a master's degree in bioinformatics.
She said she was most looking forward to trying turkey.
"This event is very important because most of us cannot go home, so it's a good way to come together and meet with other people and give thanks to be here," Wanjiku said.

title: Caroline Commissioners hear update on potential for new middle school
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Commissioners hear update on potential for new middle school

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 560
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners were given an update Tuesday morning on potential plans for a new middle school in the county.Bill Mengel, director of operations at Caroline County Public Schools, presented a revised fiscal year 2026 capital improvement plan to the commission. That improvement plan includes a priority item of year one and year two funding for a potential new middle school building.
Mengel noted that while the district was in the "talking phase" in August and September, it has "transitioned into the planning phase." This will soon include working with a consultant and eventually procuring a feasibility study, which may be complete in around six to eight months, Mengel said.
"One thing I've learned about building a new school is that it's a very serious endeavor," he said. "It takes a very long time to build one, approximately five years. But things change very, very quickly. That's really what kind of happened here, early October."
Currently, Colonel Richardson Middle School in Federalsburg and Lockerman Middle School in Denton serve as the district's two middle schools. It is unclear if the district will aim to build an entire new school, renovate, or add on. Mengel said those outcomes are largely dependent on the feasibility study's recommendation and the Board of Education's subsequent approval or denial.
The revised capital improvement plan was unanimously approved by the three commissioners Tuesday. Its top priority requests are $500,000 for HVAC work at Denton Elementary School and $5.5 million in early planning and design costs for a new or expanded middle school over the next two fiscal years.
$76 million in requested funding from the state for a new middle school build is listed next on the form. Mengel said that $76 million in requested state funding is around 89% of the total $86 million estimation for years one and two, meaning the county would be responsible for around 11% of the funding.
Maryland's Interagency Commission on School Construction, which the funding form will be submitted to, is looking at an approximate capacity of 126,000 square feet for a potential new build, according to Mengel. Mengel said the district's main point of negotiation is "How do we get more square footage?"
Cost per square foot has risen sharply year to year, the director of operations noted.
"If we get shovels in the ground in FY28 and we're able to move in for FY30 school year, that could be at or north of $490 per square foot," Mengel said. "So that's the driver."
Commission President Travis Breeding asked that the school district keep the county updated on the early planning and feasibility study results.
"Keep us in the loop on the study, because we would like to, if we're on the hook for 11% of this, we'd like to have input into, is it a renovation, addition, new location, all those discussions," Breeding said.
Mengel said he doesn't want work to begin on a large capital project if it's not set to accommodate increases in student population.
"I am aware, and so is the Board of Education, that there are some communities that are planned in and around Denton and points north (in) Caroline County," Mengel said. "We expect that there will be some students moving in impacting our populations. The last thing I want to do a build such as this, and then have it be at 100% occupancy within a couple of years."

title: St. Michaels residents donate hygiene supplies for student success
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
St. Michaels residents donate hygiene supplies for student success

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 560
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Four St. Michaels residents are going out of their way to provide local students with hygiene supplies. They have donated products including dental floss, toothbrushes, toothpaste, mouthwash, deodorant, feminine hygiene products and soap.In collaboration with St. Michaels Middle/High School, this group is working to ensure students can focus on their studies without worrying about basic needs.
The initiative began in September when Kevin and Marybeth Sullivan attempted to make a donation for a back-to-school event hosted by the police station and Christ Church for the Smile Program. The Sullivans were told that the church had all the supplies it needed for the school year.
Wanting to put their donations to good use, they reached out to St. Michaels Commissioner Jay Hudson for an alternative way to help students. Hudson talked with a guidance counselor at the school, who said they were in need of hygiene supplies from pads and tampons to deodorant.
Hudson contacted fellow Commissioner Katrina Whittington. Together they used the Sullivan's funds to buy basic essentials for the St. Michaels students.
"There's so many ways in middle school and high school that you can get embarrassed, but it's not something you think about," Kevin Sullivan said. "But what happens if a young woman goes into her period or something, … They either come from a family that can't afford it, or they're just unprepared for it."
For Hudson, the connection between a child's self-esteem and their academic achievement is incredibly important.
"I think self esteem and quality of life being the real undercurrent of this whole kind of idea," Hudson said. "It kind of pours over because if they're comfortable in their skin and they're confident in their behaviors, then they're definitely going to have the opportunity to be more successful scholastically."
Hudson said any student needing hygiene items can reach out to Rebecca Mielke-Mann, assistant principal at St. Michaels Middle/High School, who is holding all the ready-to-use supplies.
Mielke-Mann said the donations have a significant impact on the school because they removes barriers to student success.
"When students have access to basic hygiene items, they can focus more on their education and less on personal insecurities or distractions," Mielke-Mann said. "It helps create a more inclusive, positive learning environment and demonstrates to our students that their community cares about their well-being."
Mielke-Mann said particularly accessible hygiene products for girls are critical for ensuring that they can attend school confidently and consistently. According to Mielke-Mann, a lack of these items can lead to missed school days, distractions or discomfort, which can impact academic performance and self-esteem.
By providing these essentials, they're helping to level the playing field, Mielke-Mann said.
Although there was no official plan for the duration of the program, Whittington said if funds are running low she would kick in money to replenish the supplies.
The Sullivans and Hudson agreed they would do the same. According to Hudson, the supplies have been well received by students, and Whittington and Hudson will be refilling some of the more used items.
Marybeth Sullivan encourages anyone who has the inclination to support students to work with their local schools and see what needs aren't being met.
"I feel that most people really want to try to reach out and help other people," Marybeth Sullivan said. "I don't think it's a unique thing by any means. So if they know the need, then I think they're happy to try to help."

title: Four Eleven Kitchen aims to feed minds and bellies through food access program
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Four Eleven Kitchen aims to feed minds and bellies through food access program

 November 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 757
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Amanda Kidd knows the importance of bringing the community to the table."A lot of times, we don't know how the person sitting next to us or across from us, how they could be the answer to a problem that we have," the Four Eleven Kitchen founder and executive director said in the nonprofit's licensed commercial shared kitchen.
"And if we never get that opportunity to really engage them, then we don't know," she said.
Reducing barriers to resources and opportunities is one of the reasons that Kidd and a group of others started a recurring community supper event in Cambridge in 2016. It's also one of goals of Feed The People, a local food access program through Four Eleven Kitchen.
Kidd said that through Feed The People, Four Eleven Kitchen aims to feed bellies and feed minds.
Feeding minds entails getting people into the kitchen to learn cooking skills and gather accessible recipe ideas. It entails farm-to-table education, which Four Eleven Kitchen is working on a curriculum for.
"We are developing partnerships and relationships that will allow us to create a curriculum and resources for the local community that desires to be first-generational farmers," she said.
The nonprofit is working with the City of Cambridge and Habitat for Humanity to turn two parcels at Douglas Street and Lincoln Terrace in Cambridge into an urban "learning" farm.
"The community will be able to go, and they'll be able to tend to the farm," she said. "But while they're tending to the farm, they're learning skills, and they're learning how to then go back and implement it."
These programs are aimed at targeting what Kidd called "a starvation of knowledge and education."
Omeaka Jackson, a Four Eleven Kitchen board member, pointed at the small number of grocery stores in Dorchester County.
"I think having a program where we talk about nutrition (and make) sure people have access to food and things like that, I just think that's something that's important in all communities, but definitely Dorchester," she said.
When it comes to feeding bellies, one of the group's goals is to bring back those community suppers that Kidd started with a group of people in 2016. Kidd said the suppers fell off with the pandemic, so they are starting from scratch.
The hope, Kidd said, is to revamp and relaunch the suppers in 2025. She said that she and the other community members involved had a long-term vision that she hopes she can carry out with Four Eleven Kitchen.
The suppers brought together an array of members from the community, Kidd said.
"It didn't matter if you made $5 a day or $500 a day," she said. "Everyone could come and eat."
Jackson said the suppers helped facilitate family conversations around the dinner table.
Kidd remembers hearing a single mom at one of the suppers talk about what a relief it was to be able to sit at the table with her kids and not worry about preparing the food or cleaning dishes.
"And then they got to have other conversations with adults while watching their kids eat and not being isolated," Kidd said. "And so what I saw was ... that experience was offering the sense of family and community."
In September, Four Eleven Kitchen opened its doors to their shared kitchen at the Packing House in Cambridge. Along with having the kitchen space, the nonprofit considers itself a food incubator hub. From cooking classes to tastings, the organization aims to connect with the community regarding all things food.
Jackson said she is "super proud" of Kidd for what she has accomplished.
"She has tenacity and a vision that anything is possible as long as you set your mind and heart to it," Jackson said.
There are multiple ways for people to support the nonprofit, including becoming a "Foodie Friend." In return for monetary donations, Foodie Friends will get access to a library and resource hub that Four Eleven Kitchen is developing. Proceeds from Foodie Friends go directly to the Feed The People program.
Along with that, there are corporate Foodie Friends opportunities where donations go toward the nonprofit's overall operation.
For Kidd, when it comes to the Feed The People program, it's all about addressing the dire — although sometimes invisible — issue of hunger. She said everyone deserves access to food when they're hungry without having to jump through a bunch of hoops.
"Let's normalize giving people the resources they need but meeting them where they are versus making them keep coming to a facility and then making them wait in line, wait for hours, when they're there because they're hungry in the first place," she said.

title: That which brings us together at the library
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
That which brings us together at the library

 November 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Life 
 
 889
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Back in September, I attended a lecture at the library given by Meg Daley Olmert, entitled "Sit, Stay, Heal." Olmert is a writer who has worked on documentaries for Smithsonian World, National Geographic Explorer, and PBS, among others. In 1992 she was asked to join a research team studying the neurobiology of social bonding.Listening to Olmert speak, it became obvious that her work on that study changed her view of history; and I began to think it might change mine as well. So I picked up a copy of Olmert's book on the subject, "Made for Each Other," rushed home and devoured it.
I have referred to Jared Diamond's "Guns, Germs, and Steel" before in this column. That book's thesis, that geography rather than racial superiority gave Western Civilization a leg-up on the rest of the world, is now the lens through which I view and understand the past.
But if Diamond's book posits geography as history's fulcrum, Olmert's work places an even less obvious entity at that pivot point: a simple molecule, oxytocin.
Oxytocin is often referred to as the "love hormone." All mammals produce it, and in all mammals it produces the same effects.
When it's time to give birth, oxytocin brings on labor. When it's time to suckle our young, oxytocin brings on lactation. When animals groom one another — whether it's a ewe licking her lamb or a man helping his wife with a zipper — oxytocin is released and all concerned feel a rush of goodwill.
Oxytocin boosts trust, empathy, fidelity and nonverbal communication; it encourages and solidifies social bonding.
All of this is well known, but what Olmert's book makes clear is that these benefits are interspecific, that is: the effects are the same whether a woman is straightening her husband's tie or removing a thorn from her cat's paw. In both cases, their health improves and their bond is strengthened.
For years it has been received wisdom among archaeologists that humans created their first permanent settlements around 10,000 years ago, with the advent of agriculture. But recent discoveries have pushed that date back to a point 15,000 years before people began cultivating crops. Why then?
Well, it turns out that the earlier date dovetails nicely with humanity's first successful domestication of a wild animal; the wolf became a dog, oxytocin was released, and the bond between man and man's best friend was created. People could now go to sleep in the same place night after night secure in the knowledge that their dogs would alert them if a saber-toothed cat or an enemy band approached their settlement.
If permanent settlement is the necessary first-step toward civilization, then we can thank Fido for Chartres Cathedral and the great pyramids. But before those piles could be erected, oxytocin still had more tasks to perform.
When Homo sapiens first entered Europe, among the megafauna they encountered was a monster that stood six feet tall at the shoulder and sported eight-foot horns: the aurochs. When Caesar saw his first aurochs in Germany, he declared them too vicious to ever be tamed. The general would have been surprised to learn that the cattle marching placidly along in his army's wake were, in fact, descendants of the first domesticated aurochs.
But let's think for a moment about how that animal's vastly significant domestication first took place.
Imagine the courage it took for some Neolithic man or woman to approach a wild aurochs, corral it and slip a rope over its neck. Olmert makes the case that this person, whoever they were, was the test pilot of their day, that their one small step toward an aurochs represented a greater leap in world history than Neil Armstrong's. And it was successful, almost certainly, thanks to the oxytocin released in both man and beast.
If oxytocin helped create the bonds between people and animals that made civilization possible (think horses, camels, sheep, dogs, cattle, pigs, etc.), then Olmert's book closes with a cautionary note about what a deficit of oxytocin might mean for our modern world.
Since the Industrial Revolution, people have been moving in ever greater numbers away from the animals that fueled civilization's development. Today, so few Americans still live on the land that the Census Bureau no longer lists farming as a career category to be checked off.
As we moved away from our farms and our farm animals, two particularly devastating mental disconnects blossomed among our children: autism and ADHD. Both conditions are characterized by low levels of oxytocin in the bloodstream. The severity of both has been found to be reduced by giving affected children the opportunity to care for a non-human animal.
In a study performed in 1995, oxytocin was found to protect adults against the modern world's leading cause of death. Among 369 victims of heart attack, dog ownership was found to be a better predictor of survival than regularity of heartbeat, absence of diabetes, or strength of the patient's heart. One year after their coronary, 20 of the 369 patients studied had died — only one of the 20 owned a dog.
Whether or not you think the world would be a better place if we all spent more time stroking Fido or milking Clarabelle, Meg Daley Olmert's "Made for Each Other" will convince you there's more to both than meets the eye. You can find "Made for Each Other" at that hallmark of civilization: our local library.
