title: More than half of Talbot County students receive free and reduced lunches
author: Tom McCall
content:
More than half of Talbot County students receive free and reduced lunches

 November 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Life 
 
 944
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — More than half of students in Talbot County Public Schools receive free or reduced cost meals at school every week, according to the Maryland Department of Education.Free and reduced meals allow them to eat well at school.
"It is basically healthy for them. They get a fruit, a vegetable, a protein and they get a milk," said Michelle Garniga, assistant coordinator at the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center for the after school program. She has six children in TCPS.
The number of free and reduced meals in a school is a measure of poverty and food insecurity in a community.
The Maryland Department of Education found 58.41% of the students in Talbot County received free and reduced meals in 2022-2023, just under 13% higher than it was the school year prior.
At some county schools, this rate is even higher.
"What drives up the numbers are Easton Middle School and Easton Elementary School," said Catharine Poe of the Talbot Hunger Coalition, an organization of food banks and resources fighting food insecurity in the county. "Easton Elementary is 76% and the Middle School is 64%."
At other schools, numbers alone may not be enough to gauge the full scope of students' needs. Poe said the Easton High numbers trend lower because the kids do not want the other kids to know they need food.
Debbie Gardner, communications director for Talbot County Public Schools, said "We definitely talk about hunger. We consider feeding children to be one of our responsibilities in addition to educating them. We know the needs are greater than even what we see on paper."
FOOD INSECURITYThe increased rate of students receiving free and reduced meals mirrors a growing amount of food insecurity in Talbot County, where costs of food, housing and other necessities are outpacing salary growth.
"If you make $15 an hour (minimum wage) and work every single day for a 40 hour week, you only make $31,000. So if you have a family, that is not going to go very far. As soon as you have multiple children, it becomes impossible," Poe said. She said you need $38,000 for one person to make it in Talbot County.
Emily Moody, cofounder of CarePacks, said they started the nonprofit because "on weekends some kids were not eating until they got back to school on Monday morning. That is the nature of food insecurity — the uncertainty. Free and reduced meals are a lifeline. No question about it."
"Food insecurity is on the rise everywhere," Moody said. "What we have seen in the school system is an increase in the free and reduced meals program. People are working, but at wages that are not a livable wage and we live in an area where the cost of housing is really exorbitant. The cost for basic necessities like food and gas and utilities have increased. The place where the budget gets squeezed is with food at the grocery budget."
Katie Fox, community school program manager at Easton Elementary School, is the school based coordinator for CarePacks.
"Transportation impacts, if you don't have reliable transportation, which a lot of people in Talbot County don't have. That is a non-negotiable," Fox said.
And if you live in the far corners of Talbot County like Tilghman Island, it is hard to even get to a grocery store."
Moody said, "For people who are working full time to be able to afford housing and afford transportation and insurance and utilities. When those needs are met , then ideally there is room in your budget to be able to feed your family too."
It is not an issue of lazy for the working poor.
"It is not that people are not going to work. It is just that living is really expensive right now," Fox said.
FREE AND REDUCED MEALS HELPFamilies in need benefit from the free and reduced meals at the TCPS, which ensure students receive at least two meals a day for five days a week.
"It is not easy to give $4 every single day to four or five kids. That is like $24 a day. It would be fairer if everyone got free food. Just because you make more money, it is not fair for kids not to get the lunch," Garniga said.
Garniga said without the program she would be in debt and that over $100 a week for food would be a lot.
"It takes a lot of pressure off especially if you have a household with several kids. Being able to rely on the school system to provide breakfast and lunch every day, it is one of the biggest roles that the school plays," Poe said.
"They have figured out that it would save the average family $1,200 a child each year. It would end all this, and everybody who goes to school gets a free meal," Poe said.
Children in Talbot County are not alone in experiencing the benefits of free and reduced lunch programs.
At the state level, Gov. Wes Moore has signed a state Senate bill requiring the Maryland Department of Education to report to the General Assembly how much it will cost to provide free meals to all public school students in Maryland.
SB 579 opens with, "The Maryland General Assembly recognizes the positive impact on student's academic, physical and social and emotional health that results from ensuring students have access to breakfast and lunch programs while at school."
Figuring out how much it costs is the next step in pursuing universal expansion of free school meals, lawmakers argue.
The bill still needs to be funded, and it looks like the state budget is getting tighter. According to the latest briefing in the state's Spending Affordability Committee, there is a projected $2.7 billion budget shortfall that will confront the state legislature in January.

title: Maintaining parental rights
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maintaining parental rights

 December 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 I write in response to Ms. Lena Gill's letter of Nov. 30. In referring to the recent election, Ms. Gill states that the newly elected Talbot County school board members Ann O'Connor and Karla Wieland-Cherry are also members of Moms for Liberty. Ms. Gill describes the Moms as a "conservative national group" who advocate for "changes in curriculum and policies."First of all, both Mrs. O'Connor and Mrs. Cherry have repeatedly stated they are not members of Moms for Liberty; they merely participated in a debate sponsored by the Moms in which, to her credit, Ms. Jurrius also took part.
Secondly, Moms for Liberty is a support group for parents, teachers and citizens who are concerned with the education of the next generation. They provide resources for parents as well as information in educational trends throughout the country. While I have never attended one of their meetings, I do receive their newsletter and follow them on social media. Plus I have numerous friends who regularly attend the meetings.
Their agenda is to maintain parental rights through grades K through 12. Additionally, Superintendent Dr. Sharon Pepukayi, and even some of her staff, have attended three or four meetings. If it was so extreme why would they continue to return? Why is this continually portrayed by the Left as a terrible thing?
Thirdly, I wish Ms. Gill had been more specific when mentioning the "changes in curriculum and policies" that the Moms are advocating. Is she referring to better scores in English and mathematics, which the Moms advocate? Is she referring to less violence in the schools and classrooms, which they also advocate? Does she mean the schools' dispensing of contraceptives to children, opposed not only by the Moms but also by many parents?
As for the mention of concentration camps, in 2019 Trump was criticized by the Left for detention centers that had been built by Obama. Remember the children in cages? That happened under Obama, too. Claiborne

title: Ella Morton, 100, celebrated by her former 3rd grade Trappe Elementary class
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Ella Morton, 100, celebrated by her former 3rd grade Trappe Elementary class

 December 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 584
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As 100-year-old Ella Morton walked up to a table full of her former students, she was in high spirits but realized she may have broken one of her most important rules."I'm doing good," Morton said. "But I'm late, and if you remember, I hate that."
The former elementary school teacher's entrance brought the first of many chuckles, laughs and smiles at the Easton Elks Lodge on Friday afternoon. A group of Morton's former third grade students at Trappe Elementary School reminisced over lunch.
Sharing stories with one another before Morton arrived, many said she was far and away their "favorite teacher." Morton, who taught at Trappe Elementary School for more than 20 years and still lives in Trappe, turned 100 on May 24.
"Can you believe it?" said Linda James, one of her former students. "She's 100 years old, and she still knows us."
Fellow classmate Ruth Worm said when she and a couple others realized Morton had recently hit her milestone birthday, they knew they needed to organize a time to catch up.
"When I called her, she was just (so) excited," Worm said. "She said, 'Oh this is going to be so wonderful.'"
"She was just very genuinely nice and kind," Worm said, recalling how Morton treated all of her students the same.
Many of those that joined to celebrate on Friday graduated high school in 1971 and had Morton as their teacher in the 1961-1962 school year. They recalled what made Morton so memorable and impactful on their lives, even at such a young age.
"She left a lasting impression on all of us," James said, adding that Morton was "very sweet" but still garnered respect from the students. "She controlled the classroom. She didn't let us walk all over."
At the time, James said teachers such as Morton were such an integral part of children's lives and growing up. "That's all we knew, was home and teachers," James said.
For Susan Watts, Morton's excellence in teaching had a twofold impact. Watts not only had Morton in third grade, but Watts' daughter had the revered teacher in kindergarten as well. Morton's kindness since Watts first met her has carried on ever since, the former student said.
"She's still really warm, a very warm person," said Watts.
Morton said she "loved teaching" and it's what she wanted to do when going to college. But that aspiration came and went during her college years.
"When I went to college, that's what I wanted to do," Morton said. "And walking down the halls my freshman year (hearing), 'What are you going to do when you graduate in June?'
'Oh I don't know, be a teacher I guess,' And I thought well, that's not for me. So I didn't graduate to be a teacher."
However, the itch came back, and she went back into the education field — a decision that surely changed the lives of many who grew up attending Trappe Elementary.
On Friday, Morton went around the table, talking to each of her former students. She recalled how one student had a knack for rope climbing back in school.
Not one student was a troublemaker or misbehaved, Morton said to the Elks Lodge waitress.
"Now when we got to the fourth grade, that was a different subject," one of her former students joked.
When asked her favorite part of teaching those present on Friday, the same people who sat in her third grade classroom over a half-decade ago, Morton said it was all about the students.
"When you had a group like this, why wouldn't they be good?" Morton said.

author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.ccom
content:
DCPS 'encouraged' by 2024 Maryland School Report Card

 December 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 CAMBRIDGE — As Dorchester County Public Schools leaders pursue their goal of improving the district's state ranking in academic achievement, they are considering the recently published 2024 Maryland School Report Card results as "encouraging."According to a news release from the district, North Dorchester Middle School and Mace's Lane Middle School both gained a star on their report cards. Stars are gained using multiple indicators, including academic achievement, academic progress, graduation rate and school quality.
According to the report card, the academic achievement indicator went up 0.2 points — from 7.6 to 7.8 — overall at Dorchester elementary schools. At Dorchester middle schools, the academic achievement indicator went up 0.6 points, from 6.7 to 7.3 points. Elementary and middle schools can receive up to 20 points for academic achievement.
Dorchester high schools increased their academic achievement overall by 1.1 point, from 12 to 13.1 points. High schools can receive up to 30 points for academic achievement.
The school district news release also stated districtwide improvement in English language arts and math proficiency as well as improved graduation and attendance rates.
"While our schools have shown movement in a positive direction, some areas and schools have seen significant gains with others advancing more slowly," Superintendent Jymil Thompson said in the news release. "To achieve our ambitious goal of moving from 23rd to 15th in academic performance statewide, a larger percentage of growth is necessary. Continued focus on targeted strategies and interventions will be crucial to accelerate this progress."
Since becoming superintendent in June, Thompson has made known his hope of bringing the district's ranking up from 23rd to 15th in the state in four years. This year, the district is focusing on instructional leadership, taking a top-down approach in an effort to improve student success.
In September, Thompson told the Star Democrat that in order to jump from 23rd in the state to 15th in four years, the district will need to be consistent with developing instructional leadership and following through on it.
"Making sure that I'm having meetings with the principals, having conversations on how they're progressing on their goals," he said in September. "And if they're not progressing, how can we shift and go in a little different direction to ensure that they're meeting their goals?"

title: Caroline superintendent projects 'good budget year,' discusses Blueprint
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline superintendent projects 'good budget year,' discusses Blueprint

 December 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 617
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At last week's Caroline County Board of Education meeting, Superintendent Derek Simmons provided board members with a preview into the district's fiscal year 2026 outlook as budget season nears.Simmons said he and his team are in the process of developing a draft budget. What happens in this year's state legislative session is expected to impact how the budget looks, the superintendent said.
"We are really contingent upon what happens at the state level for our funding, and we do expect the General Assembly to be very engaged in things that could impact us budget-wise," Simmons said. "So it is 100% likely we will not have a clear picture of our budget, of our revenue numbers until mid-April at best."
At the Dec. 3 meeting, Simmons reviewed the fiscal year 2025 budget, noting that around 60% of unrestricted funds were spent on salaries and wages. Those funds largely come from the state, as the district received around 66% of its FY25 revenue from the state in unrestricted money.
"When we talk about where our expenses come from, it's people," Simmons said. "No surprise as we've said for years, we are a people business. It takes people to educate children. It takes people to make school work."
Contracted services accounted for just under 7% of the unrestricted budget. Board Member Troy Plutschak said he wants the board to find out how much auditing through outside companies costs.
Simmons said the district is often audited, but that moving audits in-house would be difficult and put the district in a "world of hurt." Potentially, one or two finance-related positions would be added, along with adding a stress onto the workload of school principals, Simmons said.
According to the superintendent, he doesn't expect federal money or county allocations to drastically change heading into fiscal year '26. "We knew '25 was the tight year," he said.
Assuming no major changes are made to the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's initiative to increase education funding, Simmons has an optimistic outlook. That's partly due to increased multilingual learner, special education and overall enrollment in the county.
"We are anticipating what should be a good budget year for Caroline County Public Schools," Simmons told the board.
BLUEPRINTWhile there was positivity in the fiscal year 26 forecast, Simmons made clear to board members that the outlook could drastically change if state legislators enact major adjustments to funding in Blueprint.
Changes to fiscal 26 funding "can have absolute detrimental impacts to Caroline County Public Schools," he said, since Caroline County Public Schools is "not a district that has extra wealth to go to to fill gaps."
"Not trying to paint a dire picture, but I don't want to paint roses where they may not exist," he said. "They should. But I want to make sure that everybody in the public is very clear as well. It should be, but if they go changing things in the FY 26 formula, it will hurt in this county more so than others probably."
State legislators may be tasked with discussions about Blueprint funding this winter, as the state faces a predicted budget deficit of $2.7 million for fiscal year 2026.
Blueprint will require all schools to meet a minimum teacher salary of $26,000 by July 2026. Caroline County Public Schools has not met that mark yet, but Simmons said the district is making progress.
"We are still working to get our starting teacher salary up to the mandated $60,000 by FY27," Simmons said. "We have done a great job through negotiations. We're roughly $5,000 away."
Looking to the next budget cycle, salaries and maintaining adequate staffing levels are at the top of mind for the superintendent and his team.
"We need to stay competitive with salaries and benefits for all employees," Simmons said.

title: Easton Middle School drops a star in Maryland School Report Card
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.co
content:
Easton Middle School drops a star in Maryland School Report Card

 December 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.co | Section: Local News 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In the 2024 Maryland School Report Card, most Talbot County schools held steady or slightly improved their ratings. However, Easton Middle was the lone school in the district to lose a star compared to 2023 ratings.The report card, released by the Maryland State Department of Education on Dec. 3, awards schools points based on performance in four categories: academic achievement, academic progress, progressing in achieving English language arts proficiency, and school quality and student success.
Easton Middle notched a two-star rating and 32nd percentile rank, down from three stars and 48th percentile last year. Star rating and percentile rank are based off of a school's total points out of 100. Easton Middle scored 44, down from 46.1 in 2023.
Easton Middle's 2024 scores in academic achievement (7.7 out of 30) and academic progress (16.7 out of 35) remained the same. It increased slightly in English proficiency, from 2.2 to 2.6 out of 10 total points, while decreasing from 19.5 to 17.1 points out of 35 total in school quality and student success.
Talbot County Public Schools' Director of Communications Debbie Gardner said in a statement that the district is "closely examining" the report card results. "Findings and recommendations" will be presented to the Talbot County Board of Education at its Dec. 18 meeting, she added.
"We are encouraged by the improvement shown in student proficiency in both math and English language arts in all of our student groups," the statement read. "There was progress in other areas as a result of our continued focus on our district priorities. We also see opportunities for additional data collection and analysis to inform our short and long-term planning."
Of the eight schools in the district, St. Michaels Elementary rose from three to four stars, while White Marsh Elementary had the district's largest percentile increase, from the 69th in 2023 to the 82nd percentile in 2024.
OTHER SCHOOLSOf all schools in Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties, Easton Middle was the only one to see a year-to-year decrease in its star rating, though other schools did drop in their percentiles or overall points.
Compared to fellow middle schools, Easton's 2024 rank slots in above Mace's Lane Middle (two stars, 6th percentile) and Lockerman Middle (two stars, 30th percentile), but below North Dorchester Middle (three stars, 56th percentile) and Colonel Richardson Middle (three stars, 62nd percentile).
By student group, the Easton school had mixed results. All student groups saw year-to-year increases in English proficiency except for Black and African American students. Asian students and economically disadvantaged students reached their annual targets in English proficiency, according to the report card results.
However, in math proficiency, only Asian students and multilingual learners improved from 2023. None of the subgroups reached their annual targets in math proficiency.
To view the full Maryland School Report Card, visit reportcard.msde.maryland.gov/.

title: Noam Chomsky at 96: The linguist, educator, philosopher and public thinker has had a massive intellectual and moral influence
author: Robert F. Barsky The Conversation
content:
Noam Chomsky at 96: The linguist, educator, philosopher and public thinker has had a massive intellectual and moral influence

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Robert F. Barsky The Conversation | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1749
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Robert F. Barsky, Vanderbilt UniversityNoam Chomsky, one of the world's most famous and respected intellectuals, turned 96 years old on Dec. 7, 2024. For more than half a century, multitudes of people have read his works in a variety of languages, and many people have relied on his commentaries and interviews for insights about intellectual debates and current events.
Chomsky suffered a stroke in June 2023 that has severely limited his movement, impaired his speech and impeded his ability to travel. His birthday provides an occasion to consider the tremendous corpus of works that he created over the years and to reflect on the many ways that his texts and recordings still critically engage with contemporary discussions all across disciplines and realms.
Chomsky's vast body of work includes scientific research focused on language, human nature and the mind, and political writings about U.S. imperialism, Israel and Palestine, Central America, the Vietnam War, coercive institutions, the media and the many ways in which people's needs are subjugated in the interest of profit and control.
As a scholar of humanities and law, I've engaged with Chomsky's work from an array of perspectives and authored a biography called "Noam Chomsky: A Life of Dissent" and a book on Chomsky's influence called "The Chomsky Effect: A Radical Works Beyond the Ivory Tower." One important theme in his broad corpus is his lifelong fascination with human creativity, which helps explain his vociferous attacks on those who seek to keep the rabble in line.
Early daysAvram Noam Chomsky was born on Dec. 7, 1928, in Philadelphia. He and his younger brother, David Chomsky, were raised in a lively household by Elsie Simonofsky and William (Zev) Chomsky, progressive educators who were deeply immersed in wide-ranging Jewish and Zionist cultural activities.
Chomsky often dates his own interest in teaching and learning to his close readings of Hebrew works with his parents and to the lively educational experiences he enjoyed at the Oak Lane County Day School, an experimental school that subscribed to John Dewey's approach to immersive learning and promoted individual creativity over competition with other students.
A precocious learner, Chomsky at 12 years old read the proofs for his father's book about a 13th-century Hebrew grammarian named David Kimhi. It was an auspicious beginning to a life immersed in philology, philosophy and the study of language and the mind. From very early on, he sought to understand innate human propensities for freedom, dignity and creativity, which inspired his interest in fostering those properties of human nature.
While Chomsky's parents were what he called normal Roosevelt Democrats, he was drawn to more radical approaches to society and to the promotion of noncoercive social structures. At age 10, he read about the Spanish Civil War, which inspired him to write an editorial about the fall of Barcelona for his school's newspaper. This was an early harbinger of his public intellectual work and his vociferous challenges to systems of oppression and illegitimate authority.
As a young man, Chomsky joined a socialist wing of the Zionist youth movement that opposed a Jewish state, and from his readings and discussions he came to favor Arab-Jewish class cooperation in a socialist Palestine. His deep knowledge of Palestine and Israel, bolstered by his ability to read and speak Arabic and Hebrew, helped inform his many vehement critiques of Israeli state power.
Radical pedagogyAfter an early education focused on self-discovery and free-ranging exploration, Chomsky was introduced in high school to rote learning, competition with other students and a mainstream system of values. In reaction, he began to make regular trips to New York City, where he explored bookstores. He also made regular visits with a relative who ran a newsstand on 72nd Street that served as a lively intellectual center for emigrés interested in more radical approaches to society.
In 1944, Chomsky completed high school and enrolled in the University of Pennsylvania. Although he has expressed some dismay about the structures of conformity and status quo thinking he encountered there, he did find inspiration in courses with philosopher C. West Churchman, linguist Giorgio Levi Della Vida and, moreover, linguist Zellig Harris. Chomsky knew members of the Harris family because Zellig Harris' father hosted Jewish services in the Harris home that the Chomsky family occasionally attended.
Chomsky's father's approach to the study of language bore similarities to Zellig Harris' work in Semitics, the study of Arabic, Hebrew and other Semitic languages. Harris invited Noam to read the proofs of his "Methods in Structural Linguistics." This highly anticipated book was rooted in the idea that the function and the meaning of linguistic elements are determined by their their relationship to other components that make up sentences. After working hard to understand Harris' linguistics paradigm, Chomsky eventually abandoned it, but he remained fascinated by Harris' political views and by the unstructured, lively and creative debates that he promoted.
Chomsky met Carol Doris Schatz at the Hebrew School where her mother taught and Chomsky's father was principal. Years later, when they were both students at the University of Pennsylvania, they started dating. They were married in 1949, and four years later they decided to move to an Israeli kibbutz, or communal agricultural settlement. They had expected to find a culture of creative free thinking there. Instead, they were deeply disappointed to find what Chomsky described as ideological conformity to Stalinist ideology. They returned to the U.S. after only six weeks.
The young couple settled in Boston and started a family. Noam pursued graduate work, while Carol paused her own studies to raise the children. She later returned to research on language acquisition, which she eventually taught and researched at MIT and Harvard. Carol Chomsky died in 2008. Noam remarried in 2014, to the Brazilian translator Valeria Wasserman Chomsky.
Chomskian revolution
When Chomsky was a student, most academic psychologists described human language as a system of habits, skills or dispositions to act that are acquired through extensive training, induction, generalization and association. By this account, language grows incrementally with experience, reinforced by a system of rewards and punishments.
This framework was at the heart of a structuralist paradigm, which analyzed the form and meaning of texts as different parts of the same thing. Any language, from this standpoint, restricts how phonemes and morphemes — the smallest units of sound and meaning in language — and other constituents are assembled and distributed. By this view, humans have the capacity to learn language in ways akin to how they acquire other kinds of knowledge.
Chomsky's Ph.D. work, the resulting 1957 book "Syntactic Structures" and his New York Review of Books review of B.F. Skinner's "Verbal Behaviour" challenged this paradigm and heralded the Chomskian linguistics revolution.
Chomsky's starting point was that humans are endowed with universal grammar, which is activated by exposure to natural language. Children gain proficiency in a language by building on innate knowledge. This means that the capacity for language quite literally grows in the mind in a manner akin to how organs develop in the body.
Chomsky's interest in innate human abilities draws in part from a range of philosophical treatises penned in the 17th and 18th centuries and associated with the Port Royal system of logic and Enlightenment philosophy, which emphasized science, individual liberty and the rule of law. He developed these ideas in a book called "Cartesian Linguistics," which outlined his intellectual debt to the writings of, among others, Descartes, Kant, Rousseau and Wilhelm von Humboldt.
By the early 1960s, Chomsky's work had gained him recognition in linguistics, philosophy and psychology. His own research, and that conducted by the growing number of linguists who adopted his approach, led to significant advances in the study of syntax, generative grammar, language and the mind, semantics, form and the interpretation of language.
His political engagement was documented in what I believe is a remarkable collection of interviews and books about U.S. imperialism, the Cold War, the Middle East, Central America and Southeast Asia, including "Problems of Knowledge and Freedom" and "For Reasons of State." Puzzled by Americans' spirit of resigned consensus, he began to collaborate with Edward S. Herman on books including "Counter-Revolutionary Violence," "The Political Economy of Human Rights" and "Manufacturing Consent," which was turned into a popular film by the same name.
Common thread
The common thread connecting Chomsky's many intellectual projects are four "problems" that were the focus of much of his life's work. One is Plato's problem, which considers why it is that humans, whose contact with the world is brief and limited, can come to know so much. The second is Orwell's complementary problem, which asks how is it that human beings know so little given the amount of information to which they have access. The third is Descartes' problem, which pertains to the human capacity to freely express thoughts in constantly novel ways over an infinite range by means that are appropriate to circumstances but not caused by them. Finally, there's Humboldt's problem, which focuses on what constitutes language.
These problems are connected in different ways to how people learn, what impedes human development, and to speculations about the initial state of the language faculty, which he outlined in a range of texts, including "Knowledge of Language: Its Nature, Origin, and Use," "Language and Problems of Knowledge: The Managua Lectures," "The Minimalist Program" and "Why Only Us? Language and Evolution," with Robert C. Berwick.
Chomsky's legacy
Remarkably tenacious and active, Chomsky continued to publish and to speak out on contemporary issues into his mid-90s. His ideas evolved but were rooted in a series of deeply seated ideas about the nature of the human mind. He is one of the most cited intellectuals in history, and he was voted the leading living public intellectual in The 2005 Global Intellectuals Poll. Millions of people have watched his debates and discussions with William F. Buckley, Angela Davis, Alan Dershowitz, Michel Foucault, Howard Gardner, Christopher Hitchens, Richard Perle, Jean Piaget, Briahna Joy Gray and even Ali G.
As the figure widely viewed as the founder of cognitive sciences, Chomsky has been critical of the hype surrounding big data, artificial intelligence and ChatGPT.
As a voice for the downtrodden and the oppressed, he has spoken from the perspective of human rights, intellectual self-defense and the popular struggle through independent thinking against structures of power and subjugation.
Chomsky's extraordinary achievements resonate far and wide — and are likely to continue to do so into the future.
Robert F. Barsky, is a professor in the College of Arts and Science and Associate Faculty in the School of Law at Vanderbilt University i

While his work intersects with culture and politics, the primary emphasis is on his educational and scholarly impact.

title: 'Vision from the beginning': BAAM leaders excited for new academic center
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
'Vision from the beginning': BAAM leaders excited for new academic center

 December 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 559
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The tall, welcoming windows in the classrooms of Building African American Minds Inc.'s new academic center in Easton don't just bring in sunlight. They connect the surrounding residents to new opportunities.Three stories high and nearly 25,000 square feet, the center will house classes, tutoring, youth programs, community gatherings and more. It sits on Jowite Street, next to the BAAM Athletic Center and across from a large residential area.
James Bell, director of instruction, academic support and community wellbeing for the nonprofit, believes the space fits within the organization's mission of creating an educational and social space for underserved children in the area.
"The excitement really is looking out of the windows and seeing the potential," Bell says. "So when you see the community, out of every window here in the facility, it lets you know that it's an opportunity for them as well."
Saturday, Building African American Minds will cut the ribbon on the academic center, which is expected to be up and running in January. The center will allow the nonprofit to significantly expand how many children it serves in after-school and summer enrichment programs.
There is a library, media center and multipurpose dining room on the first floor. Above are eight classrooms, as well as speciality rooms for esports, art and music.
Classrooms are designed with desks situated for full-group, small-group and individual learning.
Dina Daly, executive director of Building African American Minds, pointed out a wellness wing, which will be a private space for health, counseling and more. She added that BAAM's sister agency, private school Polaris Village Academy, will operate out of the academic center in 2025.
While the organization's focus has been serving under-resourced youth in the nearby neighborhoods, its reach isn't limited to children or Talbot County residents, Daly says.
Adult workforce programs will be hosted in the new academic center during the day. On the third floor, Chesapeake College will begin hosting GED and English second language classes in February.
"We had a vision from the beginning," Daly said. "So we're just following up on our vision for what we thought needed to happen, not just for the youth."
In its 20th year, Building African American Minds has long hoped for an academic center like the one that sits on Jowite Street today. Its previous hub, the athletic center next to the new building, isn't going anywhere either.
However, the new academic center was about a $10 million project, Daly said, more than double what the athletic center cost. Private donors, community donations, and state and federal funding made it possible.
"We build for the future," Daly said. "From the inception of BAAM, we always talked about building a school and academic center. It's more than a school now. It's more like a community center, really."
Daly said it's been a long process, but she knows the wait was worth it. Starting small and meeting a select group's needs instead of going too broad, such as when the organization began as a boys-only nonprofit in 2005, was the path to success.
Reflecting on the fact that a 20-year goal is finally coming to fruition, Daly hopes the journey of Building African American Minds can inspire others to start small and dream big.
"That's why I tell people, 'don't give up on your dreams,'" Daly said. "Make smaller goals, make them achievable, and then just keep building it up. And look at what we've accomplished."

title: UD to pay $700K to settle claims it failed to disclose professor's ties to China
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
UD to pay $700K to settle claims it failed to disclose professor's ties to China

 December 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The University of Delaware has agreed to pay more than $700,000 to settle claims that it failed to disclose a professor's ties to China when accepting a grant from NASA.The settlement was announced Monday by the Department of Justice.
"Federal law requires universities, institutions, and researchers to make disclosures, including certain foreign affiliations, when applying for grants so that the granting agencies can assess whether to fund their research and development," U.S. Attorney David C. Weiss said. "My office will hold accountable applicants who undermine the integrity of the federal grant process by knowingly failing to submit complete and truthful applications."
According to the settlement agreement, in 2020, UD accepted a grant from NASA, which is prohibited from using funds to collaborate with China or any Chinese-owned companies. While accepting the grant, UD certified that the money would not be used to collaborate or coordinate with China.
However, the government later learned that one of lead professors associated with the grant, Xiao-Hai Yan, did in fact have ties to China.
Yan is a faculty member at Xiamen University in China, received funding from the National Science Foundation of China and participates in a program established by the Chinese government to recruit individuals with knowledge or access to foreign technology intellectual property, according to the settlement.
The settlement does not constitute an admission of liability by UD, nor does it prevent the government from pursuing criminal charges against any parties involved.
"Along with our law enforcement partners, we will continue to safeguard taxpayer funds that are intended for federal research and development programs," said Adelle K. Harris, a special agent in charge for the NASA inspector general.
Yan has been a UD professor since 1990. He teaches in the School of Marine Science and Policy and serves as director of the Center for Remote Sensing.
According to a glowing profile of Yan on UD's marketing website, he is "internationally known for using satellites in tracking the notorious weathermaker El Niño and in developing new techniques for monitoring global climate change and coastal responses." In 2019, he received the Outstanding Doctoral Graduate Advising and Mentoring Award from UD President Dennis Assanis.
The article also praises Yan for playing "an integral role in the university's efforts to improve and expand the intellectual exchange between UD and Xiamen University" — the Chinese university that UD failed to disclose Yan's involvement with while accepting the NASA grant.

title: Chopping block or all talk: How much will Trump, GOP Congress cut federal education spending?
author: Mike Sunnucks APG Media
content:
Chopping block or all talk: How much will Trump, GOP Congress cut federal education spending?

 December 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG Media | Section: National 
 
 1407
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. Department of Education (DOE) and the federal government roles in K-12 public education are potentially on the chopping block with President-elect Donald Trump and a new Republican Congress taking office next month.That's at least according to campaign stump rhetoric, Trump's own pronouncements and conservative policy blueprints — including the Heritage Foundation's Project 2025.
"Federal education policy should be limited and, ultimately, the federal Department of Education should be eliminated," according to Project 2025's policy recommendations. The agency has a total budget of $241.7 billion.
Project 2025, which stirred criticism from the left during the 2024 campaign, calls for Title 1 federal funding for poorer schools to be shifted back to the states and localities. Title 1 funding totaled more than $18.4 billion in fiscal year 2024, according to the Center for American Progress.
Other federal education spending would be shifted to other departments, converted into grants to states and localities or eliminated.
The goal is to minimize the federal role in education and have localities and states enable (and fund) education savings accounts (ESAs) for parents and guardians to use for charter and private schools and other options.
Trump has distanced himself from Project 2025 saying he was not involved in its formation and he does not agree with all its ideas. But Trump recently told Time Magazine — which named him 2024 Person the Year — he favored eliminating DOE.
"You're going to need some people just to make sure they're teaching English in the schools. Okay, you know English and mathematics, let's say. But we want to move education back to the states," Trump said.
Hezekiah Herrera, a special education teacher in San Diego, has been following the issue and how what happens in Washington might impact school districts and special needs instruction.
"Advocates say that diminished federal power grants states and localities more control to shape policies to suit their specific needs. Some also argue that it will spur innovation and cut bureaucratic red tape, resulting in efficient, more streamlined decision-making," Herrera said. "On the other hand, a lack of federal guidance may exacerbate allocation inequalities, especially in states with fewer resources."
Axing or gutting, Title 1 and other programs aimed at helping poor kids worries Stefano Lodola, owner of Think Languages LLC and Think in Italian (a Wyoming-based foreign language instruction company).
"The consequences of cutting or eliminating the DOE would be widespread and severe. Federal funding, which constitutes approximately 8% of total K-12 education funding nationwide, plays a vital role in supporting programs like Title I, which serves over 25 million students in low-income areas, and Pell Grants, which help nearly 7 million college students afford higher education," Lodola said. "Without these funds, disparities between wealthier and poorer states would likely grow, leaving underfunded schools even more resource starved."
Project 2025 and conservatives also oppose expansions of free and reduced lunch programs at poorer schools. That $17.2 billion program serves 28 million low-income kids and is administered by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
The Project 2025 blueprint and some Republicans also want to eliminate Head Start — a $11.4 billion program that provides preschools to close to 800,000 lower-income kids. They contend it is inefficient and wasteful.
It is administered by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.
Therein lies some of the rub when it comes to a conservative, Trump or government efficiency efforts to be championed by Elon Musk.
Ben Wallerstein, CEO of Whiteboard Advisors (a Washington D.C.-based education policy and consulting firm), said in addition to education programs handled by other agencies, a number of federal education statutes "long predate the creation of the Department of Education."
He said narrow GOP majorities in Congress and the complexities of shuttering an entire agency and accompanying statutes make the odds of a complete DOE closure long.
"Eliminating the department would require statutory change. Republican lawmakers will introduce bills to that effect, but Democratic Senators can rely on the filibuster to stop the process. In the end, a complete elimination of the department seems unlikely," Wallerstein said in a post-election analysis.
Patrick Riccards, who served as an education advisor and consultant to the Clinton, George W. Bush and Obama administrations, said some of the education talk from the right may be just that — talk.
"We've been talking about getting rid of the U.S. Department of Education since it was founded in the seventies," Riccards said.
He said a complete elimination is doubtful, but he does see moves to give states and localities more flexibility in how they spend federal money and how they approach K-12 schools.
"Congress isn't really interested in public education. They believe it is a state and local issue," said Riccards, who also previously served on the school board in Falls Church, Virginia.
That's what the Heritage Foundations and conservatives want.
"The future of education freedom and reform in the states is bright and will shine brighter when regulations and red tape from Washington are eliminated. Federal money is inevitably accompanied by rules and regulations that keep the influx of funds from having much, if any, impact on student outcomes. It raises the cost of education without raising student achievement," the conservative think tank writes in its controversial report.
SPECIA
L EDUCATION
Approximately 7.6 million special needs students receive special education services funded via the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA). That's 15% of all public school students.
When IDEA was approved in 1975, advocates hoped to see the feds cover 40% of special education costs. For 2024, Congress and the Biden administration allocated $15.4 billion under IDEA, according to the Congressional Research Service.
Contemporary funding covers 14.7% of total special education spending, according to the Special Needs Alliance. Full funding requires $43.3 billion, according to SNA.
Lodola worries about special education potentially getting hit hard by federal rollbacks or a downsized DOE.
"The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), which ensures that 7.6 million students with disabilities receive a free and appropriate public education, depends heavily on federal funding and enforcement. Without the DOE, many states may lack the resources or political will to adequately support these programs, leaving vulnerable children and their families to shoulder the burden," he said.
Herrera agrees.
"Without a department, the future of IDEA compliance would almost certainly fall to the states, resulting in wide variation in how (or if) services are provided. This may leave families without the resources or legal protections they currently depend on. Some states may not have the budget to support special education services at the same level without federal funding."
Jacqueline Cooper, a Washington D.C.-based attorney who also holds a special education certification, said she has already seen some states "not providing equitable and sufficient education because of a lack of resources, staffing and content development." She worries about that dynamic if federal oversight is removed.
"I believe in the arena of education we need federal standards that are implemented at the state level. Without the guidance and supervision of a federal agency, many states will not provide support to those who are in need of support," Cooper said.
That could extend to civil rights law and which federal agency takes the lead in those in the education realm. Trump and his acolytes could also focus on high-profile fights over transgender rights related to high school sports and school restrooms.
Riccards said special education parents have proven effective voices for education at the state and local levels and could bring that energy if Congress goes down that path.
He sees Linda McMahon — Trump's pick for education secretary — championing literacy and vocational education programs and giving more education power and flexibility to states and localities. Wallerstein said that is something states have wanted for years.
McMahon served as small business administrator in Trump's first administration. McMahon and her husband, Vince McMahon, both of World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) fame and fortune, contributed more than $21 million to Trump's 2024 efforts, according to campaign finance filings.
Robert Kesten, executive director of Stonewall National Museum Archives and Library in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, expects the incoming administration and Trump's backers in Congress to step up efforts to promote private and charter school vouchers and tax credits and other alternatives to public schools. Conservative lawmakers and policy groups have been pushing for that in various states.
"This is now moving to a steroid version of that," Kesten said.
While conservatives want to see less federal impacts on the education system and more control by local communities and parents, Kesten worries about right-wing agendas being emboldened, increasing their efforts related to curricula, textbook content and school library offerings.
"Those are things we should be alarmed about," he said.

While it touches on national political developments, the core subject is education policy.

title: Budget discussions kicked off at Talbot Board of Ed work session
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Budget discussions kicked off at Talbot Board of Ed work session

 December 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 619
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education was presented with preliminary budget considerations during a Monday work session as planning for the fiscal year 2026 budget is underway.Talbot County Public Schools Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones outlined the priorities her team is focusing on. Those priorities include achieving academic equity in math, fostering an engaging environment for students and staff, and recruiting and retaining staff members.
Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said those areas were determined as priorities during a board retreat last year.
"When the dust all ended, we said that these were the three priorities that we wanted to move forward with," Pepukayi said. " … And then most recently, we've talked about special education being a focus for us as well."
During the meeting, Jones provided an overview of the budget process and how the state's expansive 10-year education funding initiative, The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, allocates money on a per-student basis.
"Every student in our system grades (K-12) qualifies for a base amount, and that's called our foundation funding," Jones said. "That's how we keep our lights on. That's how we have insurance."
Then, depending on student classifications in other categories, such as multilingual learners and special education, more money is allocated to a school. Each school receives different funding based on their enrollment statistics, Jones said.
She added that the expectation from the state is that "at least 75%" of the money given toward a certain school is "spent directly at that school." Costs related to human resources, finance and transportation often aren't school-specific.
According to Jones, the district needs to "make some shifts" in two programs — compensatory education and multilingual learners — in order to comply with Blueprint requirements. No district in the state is fully compliant at this time, she noted, but the Blueprint Accountability & Implementation Board is seeking progress.
"We're just not spending enough money on those areas to meet criteria," Jones said.
Pepukayi said the strict requirements affect funding for smaller schools, a topic that's come up in her discussions with fellow superintendents on the Eastern Shore.
"The foundation funding is insufficient to do all that we need to do, particularly for the smaller schools, the districts that have smaller schools," she said. " … It's compliance-driven and rigidness for our budgeting versus giving us the flexibility to make those decisions and differentiate ourselves."
Schools and departments in the district submit budgets every year, along with providing a list of requested positions. Position requests include teachers, coaches, English second language professionals, special education staff and social workers.
"We're not at the level where we were at last year," Jones added.
Board President Emily Jackson brought up whether or not the district could revisit previous hopes to hire someone for a grants manager position since managing grants is a significant stress on the finance department.
Jones said it's "burdensome" to track all of the necessary results and data from grants.
"You have to have a really detailed knowledge of the public education landscape to be able to write those grants, I would say," Jones said. "And that was our challenge."
However, Jones was optimistic on the prospect that a grants manager could eventually help Talbot County Public Schools bring in more revenue.
"Hiring a grant person might make sense financially," she said. "They might at least be able to pay for themselves, and then hopefully generate some revenue in other ways."
The Talbot County Board of Education will meet with the Talbot County Council on Jan. 7 to discuss a proposed budget. The proposed budget will first be brought to the board at a Jan. 13 work session, and then on Jan. 15 for first reader.
As of now, a public hearing on the budget is scheduled for Feb. 10, with a potential board vote slated for Feb. 12.

title: CBMM summer camp registration opens Jan. 2 for members
author: Staff Writer

CBMM summer camp registration opens Jan. 2 for members

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment

 Read News Document

 Registration for summer camps at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum will open on Thursday. Jan. 2 for membersCBMM offers summer camp programs in St. Michaels for kids age 4 to 15.
Here are some details fo the camps and the registration process via an announcement from CBMM. Learn more about all the fun planned and how to register at cbmm.org/summercamps.
Registration for these weeklong camps sharing the magic of the Chesapeake Bay's people, animals, traditions, and environment is set to open on Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025, with a two-week sign-up period exclusively for CBMM members. Open registration will begin on Thursday, Jan. 16, and continue until camps are filled.
CBMM will offer eight weeks of camps, beginning June 23, with a variety of offerings and themes to fit the interests and needs of our camp community. These include Sea Squirts (ages 4-6), Terrapins (grades 1-3), Summer Workshop (grades 4-6 & 6-9), Museum Masters (grades 4-6), and Inspiration Chesapeake (grades 6-9) camps.
The full day camps cost $375 per week, while the half-day Sea Squirts camp cost is $165 per week. (Note: There is special pricing for the week of the Fourth of July of $300 and $130, respectively, because there is no camp on the holiday.) CBMM members enjoy a 20% discount on tuition. Scholarships are available for campers with financial need.
To become a CBMM member and access early registration as well as the tuition discount, visit cbmm.org/membership or contact Membership Services Coordinator Debbie Ruzicka at 410-745-4991 or druzicka@cbmm.org.
CBMM summer campers explore Bay-themed topics through age-appropriate lesson plans in a small group setting and experience all that CBMM's 18-acre waterfront campus has to offer. The programs put an emphasis on creating a fun, hands-on learning environment that includes stories, games, crafts, environmental and on-the-water activities, and creative projects.
The Sea Squirts camp, open to children 4-6 years old, will be offered on a weekly schedule throughout the summer from 9am-noon Monday-Friday, while the full-day Terrapins camp, for children entering grades 1-3, runs from 9am-4pm.
Both camps will follow a different theme weekly, including Chesapeake Critters: Land & Sky (June 23-27), Red, White, & Bay (June 30, July 1-3), Way Back When (July 7-11), Bay Scientists (July 14-18), Feathers, Fins, & Furs (July 21-25), Inspiration Chesapeake (July 28-Aug. 1), Adventure on the Bay (Aug. 4-8) and Chesapeake Critters: Aquatic Animals (Aug. 11-15).
Geared toward older campers, the Summer Workshops offer an expansion of CBMM's Rising Tide after-school program by mixing traditional camp fun and workshop-based projects.
This program will be offered for campers in grades 4-6 during the weeks of June 30, July 7, July 14, and July 21, July 28, and Aug. 4, and grades 6-9 during the weeks of June 23 and Aug. 11. These sessions run Monday-Friday from 9am-4pm.
The Museum Masters camp offers a behind-the-scenes pass to CBMM to learn all that goes into a museum and its exhibitions. Open to grades 4-6 the week of June 23, this camp presents a unique opportunity to explore CBMM's collection and help create a special group exhibit. One project from last summer's camp is featured in the Sailing to Freedom special exhibition currently running in the Changing Exhibitions Gallery and another remains on display in the Coulbourne & Jewett Education Center.
New this year, the Inspiration Chesapeake art camp runs July 14-18 for grades 6-9. This is an opportunity for campers to immerse themselves in the beauty and culture of our region and reflect their experiences through various art forms.
Contact registration@cbmm.org for questions about this year's camp offerings or for registration support.

title: St. Michaels' Classic Motor Museum donation campaign for new property
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
St. Michaels' Classic Motor Museum donation campaign for new property

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 516
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST MICHAELS — The Classic Motor Museum is seeking to grow its space on Talbot Street, aiming to complete the purchase of an extension by Jan. 17.With about $300,000 left to raise of their $1.2 million goal, volunteers and members of the museum are making last efforts to raise enough donations to make it happen.
The Classic Motor Museum is a nonprofit organization dedicated to appreciating, preserving and showcasing America's heritage of automotive innovation and adaptation.
The extension would be used to provide hands-on experiences for students of the organization's Automotive Technician Apprenticeship Program. This three-year program began in 2022. It comprises 2,000 hours annually of on-the-job training in a local facility with one-on-one mentorship and 160 hours of classroom instruction per year through online resources.
Apprentices are commissioned by an automotive repair and maintenance shop for the program. Additionally, they are given a $4,500 stipend for tools after three months of training.
Gina Verhalen, administrator of the Classic Motor Museum, said so far the Drive Forward Capital Campaign to purchase the 906 S. Talbot St. property has gathered over $900,000 in donations.
"It just shows the incredible support that we have from not just the community," Verhalen said. "We have a number of donors, and we don't even recognize their names, so we know that the support goes well beyond just St. Michaels."
Verhalen said nationwide there has been an active decline in the number of new automotive technicians. According to the TechForce Foundation, an organization providing sholarships and other support to students in tech fields, the automotive industry needs 258,000 new automotive technicians every year, yet only 48,000 are graduated.
Verhalen said the museum's apprenticeship program is providing people with the opportunity to explore new career avenues and learn from experienced instructors.
Jim McCrea, an instructor for the program, said prior to retirement he had worked 48 years in the automotive industry. For McCrea, the development of new property would provide valuable opportunities for the students and also for the town.
The renovation plans for the property would include renovating the building back to a '50s style gas station while providing classroom learning inside. McCrea said currently the property is a bit of an eyesore, but if the museum is able to purchase and renovate the property it could be a classic part of the town.
"The real reason we wanted to get this (property) is so we could have more of a hands-on place for them. It's more realistic as far as working in a shop," McCrea said.
Michael Landolo, director of education at the museum, said those living on the Eastern Shore should feel invested in the outcome of the new generation and have a responsibility to make sure the area has a pathway for young people to find good jobs in their hometowns.
"It's really investing in the future, and it's allowing the young men and women who may not have a pathway to college, may not even have an interest in it, but they still want to have a job where they use their brains, they use their hands and they can be someone who's really contributing to society," Landolo said.

title: 'Rare birds': Apprentices learn the boat building ropes at CBMM
author: Staff Writer
content:
'Rare birds': Apprentices learn the boat building ropes at CBMM

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 595
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's Shipyard announced the graduation of Seip Family Foundation Shipwright Apprentices Kaeo Clarke and Carstan Gage from its state-accredited program.Both have joined the full-time staff at CBMM as shipwrights.
"Kaeo and Carstan embody the spirit of this program," Vessel Conservation Manager Sam Hilgartner said. "It's both earthy and dreamy. It's monotonous, tedious, and humbling, but also stimulating, uplifting, and gratifying. Kaeo and Carstan have moved through everything that it is, and they've come out of the other end of it in good working order, perfectly capable, and with plenty of enthusiasm to keep on going."
Clarke is a native of Annapolis. His father runs the Oak Harbor Marina in Pasadena, Maryland and he was working there in 2021, learning the basics of maintenance and rigging on modern metal and fiberglass vessels, when he applied for the apprenticeship in CBMM's Shipyard to learn the trade of wooden boat building.
"In my interview, I said that I'm much better at moving boats than building them," Clarke said. "I still don't consider myself an expert at woodworking or boat building, but I can tell you that I know a whole lot more now than I did when I got here."
He's also worked on the Maryland Dove build and the refit of Chesapeake Bay buyboat Winnie Estelle.
"It's an honor to be part of Dove's story," Clarke said. "There are a couple portions of that boat I can point at and say, 'Yeah, I did that.'"
Gage is from Oregon and made the cross-country move to CBMM in August 2022 with a design degree and experience working as a carpenter but little familiarity with boats.
"I would say the community is a big part of why I was able to succeed here," Gage said. "All of the people here are very helpful, and they've created an atmosphere where it's OK to take your time and really learn.
Gage has spent most of his time at CBMM focused on helping to maintain its floating fleet. One of the highlights was getting the historic skipjack Rosie Parks fit for sailing for the first time in several years, which included replacing sections of the sheer clamp, side planking, and deck boards, CBMM said in an announcement.
Gage sailed on Rosie Parks this fall to the skipjack race in Cambridge and Sultana Downrigging Festival.
"After all that, I feel confident in saying Rosie is probably the best-looking skipjack on the Bay right now," Gage said. "I had a big part in that, so that's a good feeling."
The pair logged the requisite 4,000 hours of hands-on experience, plus additional skill development training, under the direction of CBMM's staff.
After words from program supporter and CBMM Board Emeritus Tom Seip, Hilgartner, and Shipwright Educator Steve Garrand, the offered his congratulations to the new graduates of a program that is unique in its scope and ambition, not just across the state but nationally.
"This is truly a standalone program," said Maryland Department of Labor's Director of Apprenticeship & Training Chris MacLarion. "This is the only registered one that I can find on the books anywhere in the country left that's doing this through the state or federal government, that's registering apprentices, training them, and graduating them to not only not lose the knowledge and the skills but to carry it down to the next generation."
That impressed Clarke.
"That was really cool to hear," Clarke said. "I didn't know we were such rare birds in this program, but I'm happy to have been one."
CBMM's Shipwright Apprentice Program will add two more Shipwright Apprentices in the new year. Interested candidates can learn more at cbmm.org/Careers.

Lockerman Middle School celebrates new STEM Center

 December 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 DENTON — Lockerman Middle School's new science, technology, engineering and mathematics center was celebrated on Tuesday for providing students with unique opportunities and STEM-related resources.The STEM Center held a ribbon-cutting Tuesday afternoon with partners from the University of Maryland Medical System. A $500,000 grant was given to the Cal Ripken, Sr. Foundation, which is funding STEM centers at 10 different schools in Maryland, including Lockerman.
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said the foundation's contribution is bringing unique experiences to Lockerman students.
"There's no way that this level of resource and these tools would be able to get in the hands of our middle school kids if it wasn't for your partnership and Ripken Foundation's work," Simmons said.
On Tuesday, students showed off the new tools and gadgets that were funded by the grant, such as a 3D printer, coding robots and electronic kits. In the school cafeteria, two students flew drones.
Sixth grader Gracie Spiering showed off her knowledge of how to make backpack security alarms or model cars using littleBits Electronic kits. She knew how to order the kit's pieces and wires, and learned how the coding worked.
"It's been so much fun to have in class," Spiering said. "Everybody's been so ready to come into that class."
Meanwhile, many students have been utilizing the 3D printers to make ornaments for the holidays. Seventh grader Madison Watson said it's been a smooth learning process thanks to the help of her teachers.
"It's pretty fun to have them just at any time we really want them to be here," Watson said.
Lockerman Middle School Principal Jeannine Necessary said students love learning how to use the new materials. Staff members were trained and encouraged to integrate the STEM tools into everyday learning, the principal said.
During the ribbon-cutting, University of Maryland Shore Regional Health President and CEO Ken Kozel said the healthcare system appreciates students involved in STEM because the students are "highly motivated and educated."
"We're here to promote STEM because it's such an important part of the healthcare system," Kozel said. "We're local, we're small, we're a community hospital system, but we need our community to help support our workforce needs."
With a handful of students excited to show off the new technology on Tuesday, Simmons reflected on how much the grant means to the Denton middle school, given the district's financial challenges.
"About 60 to 65 percent of our students qualify for free and reduced meals, which puts a little bit different lens on the opportunities that our kids have to access things," Simmons said. "It also puts a lens on the opportunity the school system has funding-wise to be able to provide those avenues.
"We are thrilled that we were selected by you guys, in partnership with the Ripken Foundation, to be able to provide opportunity and access that we could've never funded for our students."

title: Beloved bus driver 'Mrs. Dea' brings holiday cheer to young passengers
author: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com
content:
Beloved bus driver 'Mrs. Dea' brings holiday cheer to young passengers

 December 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1200
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CECIL COUNTY — Nedean Crawford, more commonly known as Mrs. Dea, is much more than a bus driver to the students she drives to and from school each day, where she makes a lasting impression on their lives through her caring nature and holiday cheer."When they're on my bus, they're my kids," Mrs. Dea said. "It's like you're a teacher, you're a nurse, you're a psychiatrist, you know, you're a mother, you're a counselor, you're all of those things, just not a school bus driver."
Over her 28 years driving with Marshall Bus Company, during which she has averaged around 61 students per semester, Mrs. Dea has made an impact on many lives as a positive female role model.
She greets each and every student entering and leaving the bus each morning and afternoon, and spends extra time getting to know them.
"A little bit of 'hello,' or a little hug or something like that, really makes that child's day," Mrs. Dea said. "And if I see it on their face, that they're not right, we get to the school a little bit early and I say, 'Come on, come and talk to Mrs. Dea. What's going on? Tell me your story.'"
Her route includes Elk Neck Elementary, North East High School and their Twilight program for students who need extra help.
Many of the middle school students who grew up riding her bus look forward to reuniting with her in high school.
"My oldest is now a big sixth grader and says 'I miss Mrs. Dea' because her new bus driver, even though he's nice and all, is just not the same," one parent, Todd Hudson, said.
The feeling is mutual.
"It's the kids that keep coming me back," Mrs. Dea said. "Once they go into middle school for three years, six to eight. I don't see them, but I get them back in ninth grade, and it's such a joy to see how much they've grown since…it's just amazing. I'm 61 years old, and it's just, oh, it really gets to you…on my elementary run, my kids just love me, hug me every day, and it makes my day. And that's what has me coming back day after day after day."
According to Mrs. Dea, retirement is not a decision that's up to her.
"I can't retire, because I get them back in high school and the parents say that you can't retire until my child graduates," Mrs. Dea said.
All four of Ashley Culley-Meekin's children have experienced riding with Mrs. Dea.
"My son, who's in kindergarten this year, calls her the magic school bus driver," Culley-Meekins said, adding that Mrs. Dea cares about the children and is always decorating her school bus and dressing up for each and every holiday.
The interior roof of Mrs. Dea's bus 77 is currently embellished in battery powered string lights with festive colors for the holidays. She hung garland with ornaments above the windows and along the side of the bus as well.
Mrs. Dea started this tradition five years ago when she found out some of her students didn't have a Christmas tree at home.
"So I decorated the bus like it was a Christmas tree so that they could feel and see what a Christmas tree would be like, other than, you know, really not having the green branches, but just giving them an idea with the lights and the garland. And it clicked, so I continued to do it every year," Mrs. Dea said.
When those students came home telling their parents about the Christmas decorations in the bus, their mom had to see for herself, and peeked inside in awe when picking her kids up from the bus stop one day.
In addition to the lights, Mrs. Dea puts on the radio and the students sing along when holiday favorites come on the airwaves, like "Rudolph." Mrs. Dea always makes the students on the bus feel special.
"If they have a bad day at school and they get on Mrs. Dea's bus, they're always happier when they get home…even the little things, like she'll give them Halloween goodie bags and Christmas goodie bags, just to brighten their day," one parent with four children who have ridden on bus 77, Heidi Smith said.
But more than the jolly songs and goodie bags, Mrs. Dea watches out for every child that comes through her bus doors.
"The most important thing besides all that, is her caring for not only my kids, but a bus full…She treats them like they're her own [children]. She's always aware of her bus at all times," Culley-Meekins said.
Smith's son RJ is diabetic and Mrs. Dea carries Smarties candy and bags of chips in case his blood sugar drops on the bus. This happened recently, and when RJ's glucose monitor beeped indicating low blood sugar, Mrs. Dea safely pulled over to ensure his levels evened out before she dropped him off.
"I feel safe with all of my kids on there. But like, RJ, being diabetic, I don't know that I would trust another bus driver," Smith said, adding that Mrs. Dea always checks in with RJ to ensure his blood sugar levels are steady, and carries snacks just in case.
She is attentive to every child on the bus.
"There have been times where she has stopped the bus in front of my house for my kids to get off the bus, and she's quickly closed the doors because a car has ran through the bus," Culley-Meekins said.
Mrs. Dea mentioned that some of her biggest challenges come from outside of her magical bus, with crazy drivers, road conditions, and bad weather causing problems.
Last year during a series of storms, a tree fell across Elk Neck Road, blocking Mrs. Dea's route and leaving the bus full of kids stranded, according to Hudson, a parent of students on this bus at the time who was called to move the tree.
"Mrs. Dea was playing games, keeping the kids occupied…They were stranded for quite a while. So she was tap dancing, doing everything she could to keep the kids entertained, under control, and happy and not scared," Hudson said, adding that she even sent his children home with baked goods the following day as a thank you for clearing the road.
Mrs. Dea is always doing her best to make the children on her bus happy.
Bus driving is an often overlooked career choice and drivers sometimes face the stigma that they are uneducated, but Mrs. Dea emphasized that she could and has pursued other careers, but does this because she loves the kids.
"I don't have to drive a school bus. I choose to drive a school bus," Mrs. Dea said.
Before bus driving, Mrs. Dea graduated in the top third of her class at Glasgow High School in Delaware, went to college, and became a certified dental assistant until she had to have rotator cuff surgery five times and was unable to continue this work.
"I would never go back to the dental field, even if my arm got better…I really enjoy driving the bus. The kids are fantastic," Mrs. Dea said. "There's a lot of times as bus drivers, we get overwhelmed, and sometimes you don't feel appreciated. But I do have a good run…I wouldn't give this run up for anything."

title: Classical charter school looks to open in Queen Anne's
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Classical charter school looks to open in Queen Anne's

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first classical public charter school in Queen Anne's County hopes to open in the fall of 2026.Queen Anne's Classical Charter School (QACCS) is a proposed tuition-free pre-K through eighth grade school to provide an alternative educational approach and complement the work of other public schools to over four hundred students.
The drive for QACCS was formed by local parents, educators, business, and community leaders to provide an educational alternative within the public school system to ensure Queen Anne County students are reaching grade level proficiencies, according to co-founder Audrey Scott, of Queenstown.
Disillusioned with national grade level proficiencies in which a concerning percentage of students in any grade were not meeting grade level expectations, QACCS was founded through the support of local parents, grandparents, and community leaders, seeking to provide alternatives, Scott said.
"If you're aware of what's going on with the education system, you've got to take action," she said.
Researching where students were more likely to perform at grade level and above led Scott to identify classic charter schools of Frederick and Anne Arundel counties with proven track records of proficiency.
"Classical charter schools are rapidly gaining national attention for higher student performance and cultivating character and critical thinking," Scott said.
Scott is a former teacher who said the proposed charter school will provide parents educational "alternatives and enhancements," while still being part of Queen Anne's County Public Schools.
The classical charter school curriculum will include a focus on phonics, Western civilization, cursive, as well as Spanish offered in addition to Latin as part of language arts, she said.
With a board made up entirely of parents, charter schools offer more hands-on opportunities for "tremendous parental involvement," which can make a significant difference in performance, Scott said.
Queen Anne's County Commissioners have been supportive of the initiative and presented a $20,000 grant for an application consultant, she said. This application is due in March, she said.
Students will be selected for enrollment via lottery, with all county students eligible to attend, she said.
Options for school facilities are still being explored with the hopes to mirror Frederick County and Anne Arundel counties' business park locations, Scott said.
"It would be a real feather in the cap of Queen Anne's County to have the first one on the Eastern Shore," Scott said.
A public meeting about QACCS welcomes the community to learn more Jan. 25, 2025 at 10 a.m. at Kent Island Fire Department, 1610 Main Street in Chester.
More information including a petition of support can be found at QueenAnnesCCS.com and its Facebook page.
