title: State eyes new way to count students in need
author: JACK BOWMAN Capital News Service
content:
State eyes new way to count students in need

 December 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JACK BOWMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 376
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland is set to examine its current method of evaluating poverty in schools throughout the next year, potentially opening a pathway to boost funding for schools with students in need.A new study is meant to address the undercounting of poverty in Maryland public schools, according to Maryland Comptroller Brooke Lierman. The Board of Public Works approved funding for the study at its Dec. 4 meeting.
"This issue is exacerbated for undocumented students or citizen children of undocumented parents," Lierman said at that meeting.
The current method of tabulating poverty "really penalizes" schools with large numbers of immigrant students, Lierman said.
The state currently uses proxy measures, such as eligibility for national programs like Medicaid and SNAP, to calculate aid for public schools, according to the proposal for funds from the Department of General Services.
According to the Governor's Office for Children, an accurate count of students in poverty is important to ensure that they get adequate resources. The office also told CNS that the "Blueprint for Maryland's Future created several new school funding streams that rely on counts of low-income students."
Schools currently rely on applications for the free and reduced meals program and enrollment in social programs like Medicaid as methods of calculating student poverty. According to the Governor's Office for Children, "not all low income families participate in these programs."
The office also said that "districts that provide free school meals to all students under the federal community eligibility program do not collect that data."
In the case of immigrant families, some may not qualify or, as the office told CNS, may be hesitant to enroll and reveal their citizenship status.
Other data the state might rely upon is out of date. According to Lierman, the Maryland State Department of Education recently proposed using data from 2013 to calculate school poverty in Baltimore City. Lierman said that many public schools have been shuttered in the city since that data was collected.
"As a Baltimore City Public School mom," Lierman said, "I've got a lot of strong feelings about this."
The board approved the DGS request for $48,000 monthly for "modeling, analysis and providing a presentation on findings."
According to the Office for Children, a recommendation based on the results of the study will be made to the Maryland General Assembly by Dec. 1, 2025.

title: Chesapeake College works to become Hispanic-Serving Institution
author: VERONICA FERNANDEZ-ALVARADO valvarado@chespub.com
content:
Chesapeake College works to become Hispanic-Serving Institution

 January 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: VERONICA FERNANDEZ-ALVARADO valvarado@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 950
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Zulema Delacruz Martinez, a 2024 graduate of Chesapeake College, was described by the school's faculty as an achievement.During her time at Chesapeake College, she was a founder of the Hispanic/Latino Student Union, the chair of the annual Unity Fest and a mentor for area high school students with TRiO's Upward Bound summer program.
"She's the type of person that (Chesapeake College) would love to see her success repeated in many more," said Lorelly Solano, director at the Chesapeake College Cambridge Center.
Delacruz Martinez credited support programs like TRiO, a federal student services program, for her own college success. She said having TRiO provided her opportunities for academic success and to better understand financial resources for education. It is programs such as TRiO that motivated her to lead in the creation of the Hispanic/Latino Student Union.
"In my mind, when I founded (Hispanic/Latino Student Union), it's more like, 'How can I help others? What kind of resources can I create, or kind of resources can become available, so that way the students coming after me, who come from similar backgrounds, they don't have to worry as much, and they can focus more on being students, focus on being essentially teenagers and young adults enjoying college life and creating connections?'" Delacruz Martinez said.
The student union hosts community nights to assist Latino community members who are having trouble filling out the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, commonly called FAFSA.
This form assists current and prospective college students to determine their eligibility for student financial aid. The Hispanic/Latino Student Union has been leading Chesapeake College's Latino student recruitment by hosting events catered to potential students.
Delacruz Martinez said that more than 90% of attendees of FAFSA Nights applied to Chesapeake College. She assisted families from all age groups, including grandparents with limited knowledge of the internet.
Chesapeake College, a public two-year regional community college in Wye Mills, is going through changes to address the growing Hispanic population.
According to Marcie Alvarado Molloy, director of public information at Chesapeake College, over the last decade the Hispanic population at the school has increased by more than 64% and is expected to continue to grow.
The college has made an effort to translate all pamphlets and documents for Spanish speaking families and students. Additionally, the school is trying to increase the number of Spanish-speaking staff, especially in key offices like financial aid. The college has made efforts to collaborate with family liaisons from Talbot County Public Schools and has attended various community events to increase the school's presence and visibility.
Clifford Coppersmith, president of Chesapeake College, said the college is on its way to becoming a Hispanic-Serving Institution. A Hispanic-Serving Institution is defined by the U.S. Department of Education as an eligible institution with an undergraduate enrollment that is at least 25% Hispanic.
According to the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities, in 2023 there were about 600 Hispanic-Serving Institutions in the United States. The U.S. Department of Education offers Hispanic-Serving Institutions 64 grants through the Developing Hispanic-Serving Institution program, and in 2023 the Biden-Harris Administration announced it would award more than $40 million to support Hispanic/Latino students.
Coppersmith said more and more Hispanic students are transferring from Chesapeake College to four-year colleges every year.
"So with our Hispanic population, up until probably fairly recently, the predominant interest has been short-term non-credit, but more and more we are seeing Hispanic students getting into transfer education," Coppersmith said. "They intend to go in and get bachelor's degrees."
GENERATIONAL ACHIEVEMENTSolano said she appreciates the collaboration Chesapeake College does with schools and nonprofits to help accomplish the academic dreams of the Hispanic community.
"When our society is so polarized, and you also hear a lot of negative rhetoric about immigrants, I think it is so important for for these kids and for their families to actually demonstrate to themselves and to others that that they actually can achieve their dreams, that they can show this very dignified side of of their dreams, because, quite frankly, this is about generational achievement," Solano said.
College degrees have generational impacts on families. According to the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis' Center for Household Financial Stability, families with at least two generations of college graduates have median income and wealth that are higher than those of families where fewer generations have college degrees. Hispanic families across the county have been enrolling their children in record numbers over the past two decades, according to the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities.
In 2023, Chesapeake College welcomed its class with Hispanic students making up the largest minority student demographic at more than 43% of the college's more than 1,395 minority students.
During this year's graduation Delacruz Martinez was awarded the John T. Harrison Award. This award is given each year to a student who has demonstrated the highest academic performance, leadership and overall contributions to the college and the community.
Milton Nagel, vice chair of the Chesapeake College Board of Trustees, presented the award to Delacruz Martinez and gave her praise for her commitment to Hispanic and Latino students within the region who are interested in college but may be intimidated by the academic process.
Delacruz Martinez, said she is happy to see schools throughout the Eastern Shore adapting to the growing Latino population through different programs and the efforts to hire diverse faculty and staff. According to Delacruz Martinez, these efforts are not going unnoticed.
"Hispanic Latino students are resilient. We are very, very, very hardworking," Delacruz Martinez said. "We will put in the effort if given the chance. But this issue is that sometimes we aren't given that chance. We have to focus on other difficult situations we are placed in, within our own homes, within their own communities. So invest in us, and we will certainly put in the effort."

 EASTON — Over the last year, Foundation of HOPE, an Easton-based nonprofit, has worked to empower women and girls in the Eastern Shore. In order to celebrate the foundation's accomplishments and to share the upcoming year's goals, the foundation held a gala/luncheon for its supporters on Dec. 14.During the foundation's annual fundraiser event, over a 100 people gathered together to participate in a silent auction and honor scholarship recipients, their experiences and their accomplishments.
Keasha Haythe, founder of Foundation of HOPE, said the fundraiser provides the opportunity for donors and supporters of the organization to see the progress made so far through presentations and speakers, including past students and scholarship recipients.
"It was really good to have people in the room to hear about where we've been, where we're going, what our goals and our priorities are to expand the program to not only have more girls participate, but also to serve the community," Haythe said.
Haythe said speakers for the event included 2024 scholarship recipients Kaleigh Hammond and Michaela Gibson. Gibson, a student at John Hopkins, and Hammond, a student at Chesapeake College, shared their experiences with the program and how the foundation helped them achieve their goals.
Haythe said they were a part of the second cohort of the program, which offers after-school classes to sixth-grade girls.
Haythe said the Foundation of HOPE program was established in 2018 with the goal to teach middle school girls how to be viable contributors to the future workforce. The program covers topics including addressing low self-esteem, bullying, social media, workforce development, and economic and community development.
Haythe said over the years the program has grown to cater to more girls in the community. According to Haythe, the program hopes to grow to include 30 students. Additionally, they hope to start pre construction work for a foundation headquarters around quarter two of 2025.
According to Haythe, the foundation received $150,000 from the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development in December. The foundation has launched the capital campaign to the public.
Haythe said supporters can make donations to the foundation in many ways, but she encourages the public to show their appreciation for women or girls in their lives by honoring them with a Rose of Hope. A Rose of Hope is a donation made in someone else's honor to help support the foundation's Economic Development and Empowerment program. Names of those honored are shared on the foundation's website and listed at the Annual Gala Program.
Haythe said she is proud of the opportunity to help girls in the program. She shared that Gibson wanted to study marine biology in sixth grade and now she is studying at John Hopkins. For Haythe, continuing to foster that growth and belief in young girls is what she enjoys.
"I think looking over the last year, I've been most proud of how the girls who have completed the program have blossomed into young women," Haythe said. "How they are following their dreams. I mean, these dreams that they had in sixth grade, they're manifesting for them… these young ladies are truly understanding who they are, and they're developing in the program, and after completing the program, into nice young ladies that are going after their dreams."

title: Phone pouches improving student focus, discipline in Caroline, district says
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Phone pouches improving student focus, discipline in Caroline, district says

 January 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 624
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An experimental pilot program aimed at keeping students off their phones saw some success in its first semester being implemented at Caroline County Public Schools.Cellphone pouches created by the company Yondr were tested in both Caroline County middle schools last semester.
"We've been pleased with the outcome, Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "You see attentiveness much higher in classrooms, kids learning how to talk to each other, even in the cafeteria. It's been really cool to see at the middle schools."
The students carry locked pouches during the entire school day, with their phones inside but not accessible.
Each student has their own pouch, which travels with them daily from home to school. Phone are locked into the pouches at the beginning of the school day and unlocked at the end using a magnetic device. If a student leaves the pouch at home, they put their phone in the school office for the day.
Every classroom in Caroline County comes equipped with a wired phone for use in case of an emergency, and teachers have been given a special pair of scissors to cut through cellphone pouches if needed.
For students with health needs, the schools offer special services allowing students to check their phones for medical purposes only.
There have been talks within the county of expanding cellphone pouches to ninth graders in coming years, but that determination has not yet been made, district officials said.
In determining whether the pouch program will be expected, the district still has to weigh the pros and cons, officials said. They hope that by the end of the school year they will have a solid understanding of the program's successes and shortcomings.
SUCCESSES
The pouches have done a good job at keeping students off their phones during the school day, district officials said. But beyond that, the middle schools where the pouches have been implemented have seen some other benefits from the program.
The cellphone pouches help prevent cyber bullying in the school during the school day, they said. Students have needed less disciplinary intervention since the pouches were rolled out.
"We've seen about a 21% reduction in discipline incidents," Simmons said.
Simmons also said teachers report that taking cellphones out of the picture has allowed them to better focus on instructing students.
"We ask a lot of our teachers, most of our class sizes average 20 to 20 plus students, so if you're asking them to improve reading or improve mathematics on top of being able to see if they're on cellphones it's a lot," Simmons said. "With the pouches they don't have to be the cellphone police."
Although schools don't yet have test scores back for last semester, the superintendent said pass rates have gone up with the cellphone pouches.
DIFFICULTIES
Reception of the cellphone pouches has not been entierly positive among students and parents in the district, Simmons said.
Students have tried to tamper with or break into their pouches during the school day on multiple occasions.
"They're not indestructible, they're not the end all be all, but they are a great preventative tool to put in place," Simmons said. "They're easy to tell if somebody's tampered with one, It's also easy to tell if a kid has their phone or has a phone out because they don't want their pouch or pouches to look empty."
Some parents do not like the idea of the phone pouches because they prefer to have a direct line of communication with their child, Simmons said.
Students have not yet been polled on their feelings about the pouches, but the districts plans to weigh student attitudes toward the program in any future decisions made.
"I think overall, we're seeing a positive impact on the academics, on the social skills piece. If we asked kids if they'd rather have access to their devices, I'm sure they would," Simmons said.

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education had its first look at the district's proposed budget for fiscal year 2026 Monday.During a board work session Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones presented the draft budget, which totals $85.8 million in unrestricted dollars — an $8.6 million increase from fiscal year 2025, Jones noted.
Jones provided the year-to-year budget changes by looking at 12 different categories of expenditures. The areas in which increases were highest are fixed charges ($2.23 million increase), instructional salaries ($1.7 million increase) and other instructional costs ($1.47 million increase).
Jones added that while $9 million to $10 million in grants are expected next year, anticipated grant funding is more than $5 million less than last fiscal year. That drop in grant funding precipitated a portion of the rise in the requested unrestricted budget.
In Annapolis, it still remains to be seen how Maryland's expected $2.7 billion deficit is tackled and if legislative decisions will impact funding for The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education improvement and funding initiative.
Talbot school leaders say budgeting will be a fluid process in the coming months as they keep an eye on state legislation and the Accountability & Implementation Board, an entity that ensures the state and county governments are correctly implementing Blueprint.
"There's one area where I did do a little bit of hedging our bets, on the conservative side," Jones said of the proposed budget. "I don't think we'll know any of that until April or May. But as certain pieces of legislation gather steam and seem to gather support and seem likely, then I think we will work behind the scenes to figure out how we will address this if this comes to fruition."
In creating the draft budget, Jones and Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized that the district considered its top priorities: academic equity in math, an engaging environment for students and staff, recruitment and retention levels, and meeting Blueprint objectives.
Monday's discussion included a breakdown of 33 proposed additional positions for the next fiscal year. The proposed budget includes a $3.6 million jump in salaries and wages.
"This list is whittled down, if you can believe it, from a longer list of wants and desires," Jones said. "And it was very much informed by school administration. This is what they felt they needed in their buildings."
ADDITIONAL POSITIONSJones outlined the 33 additional positions that are in the requested budget. Six of those positions are for English for Speakers of Other Languages teachers, assistants or coaches.
She cited the district's need to serve its multilingual population, along with the state funding for multilingual learning, for adding the positions.
"Our (Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program) data … demonstrates that we do consistently underserve our multilingual students," Jones said. "And so, we just need to provide more resources there."
Board of Education President Emily Jackson asked if those English for Speakers of Other Languages positions will be difficult to fill.
"Because I know we've had problems — specifically with ESOL in the past — finding people who are qualified and had a desire to do that," Jackson said. "And that's a quarter of the positions we're looking for."
Zulieka Jarmon-Horsey, assistant superintendent of administrative services, systems and strategies, said it's a challenge both in Talbot County and statewide. She said recruitment and retention are key aspects.
"We have to definitely start promoting earlier and just doing the best that we can," Jarmon-Horsey said. "And doing things that are unconventional, like our on-site career fair that's going to be happening here this week."
Other requested positions in the budget include: an art teacher at Easton Middle, a high school math coach, a middle school reading coach, four special education positions at Easton Elementary and a special education teacher at Easton Middle.
One athletic trainer to serve Easton High School and St. Michaels Middle High School was also on the proposed list.
"I'm happy to see that at the top of the list," Jackson said of the athletic trainer role. "I would be in favor of two … making sure that we have coverage for all of our athletic events. I know sports parents, they have eyes on that."
The draft budget will be discussed again at Wednesday's monthly Board of Education meeting before the board hosts its joint meeting with the Talbot County Council on Jan. 22. On Feb. 10, the board will host a public hearing on the budget.

title: Talbot Board of Ed adds makeup day for snow; approves 2025-26 calendar
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed adds makeup day for snow; approves 2025-26 calendar

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During Wednesday's meeting, the Talbot County Board of Education added a day onto the end of this year's school calendar following last week's snowstorm.Talbot County Public Schools was closed Monday through Friday last week due to snow that blanketed the Mid-Shore. However, the 2024-2025 school calendar only had four inclement weather days built in, meaning an additional day was needed to comply with the state's 180-day requirement.
Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, recommended that a day be added in June, moving the last day of school for students to Friday, June 13.
The last day for teachers would be Monday, June 16. Einhorn said that historically, most teachers complete mandated training that affords them with not having to come in on the last day.
The board unanimously passed the adjusted calendar for this year.
2025-26 CALENDAROn Wednesday, the board also chose the district's calendar for the 2025-2026 school year.
At last month's meeting, Einhorn presented a draft calendar with two days off in March and a five-day spring break, which was the recommendation of the calendar committee. Board President Emily Jackson, however, expressed frustration there weren't multiple options posed.
This month, Einhorn returned with three draft calendars. The first was similar to what the board saw in December, with a four-day weekend in March and the shorter spring break. The second draft removed the off days in March and had an eight-day spring break.
A third draft included both the March break and an eight-day spring break, pushing the last student day back to June 10, 2026.
All three drafts included the typical days off in November for Easton's Waterfowl Festival, as well as a winter break from Dec. 20, 2025, to Jan. 4, 2026.
"There is no calendar that we're going to create that is best for every single person," Jackson said.
Jackson said it's clear — based on previous polling and community input — that most families favor the extended spring break. Board Vice President Amy Dodson suggested the board move forward with the second or third calendars.
Board member Karla Wieland-Cherry said she preferred the first calendar with the shorter spring break.
"You're losing a lot of school time for eight days off for students," Wieland-Cherry said. "You're losing a lot of momentum. And plus you're concerned with providing day care. Not all employers are going to allow that. That's quite a long time to take off of work and find day care and so forth."
She added that not all families are looking for a longer spring break.
"My only concern is that if 59% of our students are at the poverty level, we're really talking about more of a smaller group who are really going to financially be able to afford an Easter holiday," Wieland-Cherry said. "… You really could possibly potentially be causing more hardship for something that's more an elitist type thing, quite honestly."
Jackson said while she agrees with Wieland-Cherry's point, she has "to go with what the community is saying."
"We have asked again and again, and the majority of the respondents to any time we've asked this have said they like that spring break," Jackson said.
Following board discussion, Jackson motioned for approval of the third calendar featuring two off days in March and five days for spring break. Her motion included an amendment to the calendar that the March days off serve as two of four inclement weather days for the district.
By a 6-1 vote, with only Wieland-Cherry voting against, the board approved the 2025-2026 school year calendar.

title: Educators need to return to basics
author: Staff Writer
content:
Educators need to return to basics

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I was glad to hear that Gov. Moore had decided to postpone implementing the experimental Blueprint for Maryland in our schools, due to the $2.7 billion deficit accrued by the state of Maryland.The Blueprint has been described as follows:
"It has taken the focus of schools off teaching students the academic and content knowledge they need to be successful adults in our society and made them 'one stop shopping' for services like medical, dental, nutritional, social engineering and mental health. It has promoted the implementation of 'restorative discipline' which has created a generation of students who are out of control and violent since there are no consequences for bad behavior. It has drained our schools of teachers as they flee to other states where working conditions are better even if the salaries are lower. These are just some of the negative impacts." (Easton Gazette, Dec. 20, 2024)
How disappointed was I to read in The Star Democrat (Jan. 15, 2025) that the Talbot Board of Education wishes to implement the Blueprint anyway, especially equity in math, with an $8.6 million increase to the school budget. With nearly 60% of Talbot County students (grades 3-8) showing a lack of proficiency in basic English language skills, while mathematics proficiency for Talbot County students stands at a dismal 17.2%, the last thing we need is for our children to be guinea pigs in yet another social experiment.
What is equity in math? According to Edutopia: "Math teachers can use short activities based on student goals related to equity in order to make classes feel more inclusive and accessible." The key words are "feel" "inclusive" and "accessible."
I was a sixth grader once, a sixth grader who hated math class. We had a strict teacher, of whom most of us were afraid. But we all learned to multiply and divide, in spite of the negative feelings, unlike, it appears, many of today's children who are not even being encouraged to memorize their times tables.
Those negative feelings can give way to feelings of confidence and assurance when a subject has been mastered. I beg our educators to return to basics and stop making our children the latest casualties of yet another half-baked, ill-conceived progressive scheme for remaking society according to the designs of Karl Marx or Saul Alinsky.
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne

title: Local school districts affected by PowerSchool data breach
author: Konner Metz
content:
Local school districts affected by PowerSchool data breach

 January 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 344
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Schools in Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties were impacted by a data breach in late December affecting PowerSchool, a company that provides student information systems to schools across the country.Districts in each county notified families of the data breach earlier this month, shortly after PowerSchool informed districts that for some individuals, personal information such as names, dates of birth, medical information and social security numbers were obtained by hackers.
Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi wrote in a statement to families earlier this month that PowerSchool notified the district on Jan. 7. PowerSchool, according to its website, became aware of the incident on Dec. 28.
"They have confirmed that this includes information belonging to some of our families and educators," Pepukayi wrote. "Through discussions with PowerSchool, the company acknowledged that there was no action that TCPS could have taken to prevent the breach."
Dorchester County Public Schools sent out a similar message to the community on Jan. 14.
"PowerSchool said the incident is contained and the company has enhanced its security protocols," DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson wrote. "We were assured that there is no current and ongoing threat to our students' and educators' data."
"PowerSchool has also made a commitment to conduct a thorough notification process to all impacted individuals," wrote Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons. "We intend to hold PowerSchool to these commitments."
A PowerSchool spokesperson said in a statement that upon learning of the breach, the company "immediately engaged (its) cybersecurity response protocols and mobilized a cross-functional response team, including senior leadership and third-party cybersecurity experts."
According to its website, PowerSchool is working with a credit reporting agency to provide credit monitoring services to those impacted by the breach.
"PowerSchool will be offering two years of complimentary identity protection services for all students and educators whose information was involved and will also be offering two years of complimentary credit monitoring services for all adult students and educators whose information was involved," the website reads. "We are doing this regardless of whether an individual's Social Security Number was exfiltrated."
For more information, visit PowerSchool's incident page at powerschool.com/security/sis-incident/.

title: Dorchester BOE recognizes student contest winners
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester BOE recognizes student contest winners

 January 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News

 CAMBRIDGE — The audience of the Dorchester County Board of Education meeting on Thursday looked a little younger than usual.As the meeting kicked off, three of the winners of the Superintendent's Holiday Card Contest for 2024 sat patiently in the crowd, waiting to be recognized for their achievement.
The contest, which is held every year, gives students across the district a chance to sharpen their colored pencils and show off their artistic talents. Four winners are chosen: one early elementary student, one elementary student, one middle schooler and one high schooler.
This school year, the winners were:
Vienna Elementary second grader Adalynn Haugh.Hurlock Elementary third grader Kali Johnson.North Dorchester Middle eighth grader Elisabeth Claggett.North Dorchester High 10th grader Adrien Sinkeldam.
Theresa Connors, the district's supervisor of English language learners, library media and fine arts, said the DCPS' central office staff loves getting to see the submissions and vote on their favorite every year. She said that each year the number of submissions gets larger.
"Even though they're supposed to screen them at the schools before they send them and choose their best, they send me more and more every year because it's hard for them to make a decision on what to send," she said. "So it's very competitive."
As Connors read the names of each winner, the students got up from their chairs to accept a certificate and show off their designs, which included snowmen, Christmas trees and snow globes. Their teachers were also at the meeting to show support. Sinkeldam was not able to attend.
At the end of the meeting, Dorchester County Board of Education members and Superintendent Jymil Thompson talked about the students and their designs. Thompson said they did a "fantabulous" job.
"I just made that word up," he said, laughing. "I really, really liked the cards. And everyone we sent the cards to liked the cards. ... They did a great job."
Board President Sheri Hubbard called it a "wonderful time" when students are recognized at board meetings.
"That's one of the best parts of this job," she said.

title: Easton ICE arrest not school-related, official says
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton ICE arrest not school-related, official says

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 585
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An arrest made by Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE, in Easton last week was not school-related, according to Talbot County Public Schools.According to police, an ICE arrest happened on Glenwood Avenue near Easton Elementary School Thursday. In an email to The Star Democrat, the district said the arrest did not take place at the school.
School and police officials say rumors of a parent being detained while dropping off a child at the elementary school are false.
Representatives of the Easton Police Department added that the arrest was made due to outstanding warrants for an individual in town and not as a result of any directive from the new presidential administration. EPD officers were not involved in the arrest, but the department contacted the Department of Homeland Security following the incident as rumors began to circulate.
As of Monday, the Talbot school district had not communicated with families regarding the rumors, though counseling and mental health support for students, families and staff has been made available. TCPS' Director of Communications Debbie Gardner said in an email that the district has reviewed its existing protocols around "actions or inquiries by law enforcement."
Last week, State Superintendent Carey Wright sent a letter to Maryland superintendents outlining the practices school employees should take if immigration authorities enter schools.
"If federal immigration officials or law enforcement enter a school building seeking access to students (for interviews and/or questioning), school personnel should contact the local superintendent immediately for guidance," Wright wrote on Jan. 23.
"School personnel should not argue or debate with immigration enforcement officials but should direct them to the local superintendent or designated administrator for further action," the letter read.
Wright's letter comes as Donald Trump's immigration initiatives have brought sweeping policy changes since the inauguration last Monday.
A directive last week from the Trump administration reversed a policy that established places such as schools, churches and shelters as "protected areas." That policy discouraged immigration enforcement agents from conducting arrests in those areas.
"Criminals will no longer be able to hide in America's schools and churches to avoid arrest," Department of Homeland Security spokesperson Benjamine Huffman stated. "The Trump Administration will not tie the hands of our brave law enforcement, and instead trusts them to use common sense."
In her letter, Wright said that if immigration officials request student records, local schools should consult with their attorneys.
"Personnel should immediately notify the student's parent or guardian if an immigration official or law enforcement officer requests or gains access to a student for immigration-enforcement purposes," Wright stated, "unless such access was following a judicial warrant or subpoena that restricts the disclosure of the information to the parent or guardian."
In a statement, Talbot County Public Schools said that superintendents across the state had a meeting with Wright, as well as the Maryland ICE director. The district is following guidance from the Maryland Department of Education on immigration enforcement actions.
Regarding the Easton arrest, a spokesperson for Enforcement and Removal Operations' Baltimore field office did not provide specific information on the arrest or if other arrests in the area have occurred in the past week. Enforcement and Removal Operations is a directorate of ICE.
"ERO Baltimore works daily to prioritize public safety by arresting and removing undocumented alien offenders who pose the greatest threat to our communities, to include those with serious criminal convictions who have violated our nation's immigration laws," an email statement read. "By focusing on these high-priority cases, we aim to uphold the integrity of our immigration system while promoting the safety and security of Maryland's residents."

title: Dorchester County Public Schools faces budget deficit
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County Public Schools faces budget deficit

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 636
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — As Dorchester County Public Schools prepares to submit its fiscal year 2026 budget to the county, it is also preparing for some tough conversations.With $86 million in expected revenues and $97.5 million in estimated expenses for fiscal year 2026, the district is facing a deficit. Currently, with carryover in funds from previous years, the estimated deficit is at $10.19 million.
"We've just got some difficult decisions to make as a district on how we're going to move forward with the current budget crisis that we're in," DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson said during a Dorchester County Board of Education budget work session Thursday.
Jodi Colman, district assistant superintendent of academics and student services, said the budget increases for fiscal year 2026 make it possible to keep the district's current staff in place.
"This would just be to basically maintain the programs that we have right now," she said about the draft budget. "All of those increases were due to just keeping our staff that we have for the most part."
Thompson said "a whole host of things" has caused the deficit, mentioning fixed costs and unfunded mandates from the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state.
Board of Education Member Brandy Dawson Cumberland said that although the board likes a lot of what the Blueprint aims to do, there are "certain unfunded mandates that are going to cut other things."
Thompson said the district is still waiting on exact numbers from the state and county. He said once they have those numbers, it is possible the deficit could be lower than $10.19 million.
"But I don't think that it will be higher than that," he said.
So far, the district has taken a number of actions to reduce the deficit, Thompson said. This includes:
Reducing some positions added with Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief fundingSending emails about non-essential spendingDeciding not to hire for vacated positionsReducing the central office custodian scheduleReducing student support monitorsMerging some job dutiesEliminating the education specialist position
"We did try to make some significant changes," Thompson said. "And there's more that I didn't put up that we have done. But the reality is it's not enough."
The district is looking into more actions that can be taken to reduce the deficit. Some possible actions include revisiting who should have board vehicles, auditing and reducing the number of programs and platforms the district uses, revising overtime policies, sharing resources with the county and reducing staff.
"No one wants this one," Thompson said about reducing staff.
While listing different "cost containment options" Thompson and board members made it clear that the district hasn't made any decisions yet, and is just looking at potential cost-cutting options.
"We are just at the beginning of starting to think about what things we can do to attack that number," Board of Education Vice President Talibah Chikwendu said.
"And that's why we really would like to have public input to know what the public feels are areas we should focus on if possible," Board President Sheri Hubbard said. "Because we want to do what's best for kids, bottom line."
The Dorchester County Board of Education will host another budget work session on Feb. 13. It will also hold one in March. The district's proposed budget must be submitted to the county in June.
Board Member Chris Wheedleton said that if community members are able to do anything, they should talk with their representatives in Annapolis.
"Because we need their help," he said.
Thompson urged that this is the time to work together and not be divided.
"Because at the end of the day, we know that $10 million deficit that we're in, that's going to hurt the kids," he said. "That's going to have a profound impact on how we can provide resources for our students."

title: Sen. Van Hollen talks federal grants pause with Eastern Shore legislators
author: Konner Metz
content:
Sen. Van Hollen talks federal grants pause with Eastern Shore legislators

 February 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 758
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While speaking with Eastern Shore legislators Friday morning, Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) said a short-lived pause of federal funding earlier this week had impacts on local organizations such as fire stations and law enforcement agencies.Monday, President Donald Trump's budget office issued a memorandum ordering a pause on federal grants and loans. A U.S. district judge temporarily blocked the pause Tuesday before the White House rescinded the memo the following day.
"Because of the public outcry, they did pull back on this overall freeze," Van Hollen said. "But there's still a whole lot of uncertainty and confusion. So if you are hearing from folks on the Eastern Shore that are recipients of federal programs that are being disrupted, please let us know."
At the weekly Eastern Shore Delegation meeting, Del. Steven Arentz (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) asked Van Hollen to elaborate on his perspective of what happened.
Van Hollen said the memo from the Office of Management and Budget brought forth confusion for government agencies. The senator heard from thousands that were impacted, he said in an email newsletter.
"It was very broadly worded and very ambiguous," Van Hollen said. "Federal agencies interpreted this based on what it said. Essentially, they did freeze a lot of ongoing payments to organizations that do important community work."
Arentz said some of the spending that was paused could be viewed as "questionable" in the first place.
"I think that's the point that was being made about that," Arentz said. "I keep getting questions on it, because it does look like when you portray it in one way, it looks bad, but in the other way, you look at some spending that people would have questions on. And I think that's part of the explanation I try to give."
"The way the memo was worded and the reason it was retracted was because it was so broad that it appeared to impact everybody," Van Hollen responded.
Sen. Angela Alsobrooks (D-Md.) also attended Friday's Eastern Shore Delegation meeting. She explained to state senators and delegates her line of thinking when voting to confirm recent political appointees, emphasizing that she is prepared to vote on "qualified" candidates across party lines.
"My primary interest and sole interest, really, is making sure that I protect the interests of Maryland," Alsobrooks said.
SUPERINTENDENTSEastern Shore superintendents gathered at the meeting Friday to provide legislative requests and recommendations.
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons, president of the Eastern Shore of Maryland Educational Consortium superintendents' group, framed Friday's discussion around The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education funding initiative.
It comes as Gov. Wes Moore (D) and the state legislature attempt to balance a $3 billion state deficit, in part by making cuts to education funding.
Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson explained the importance for districts to attract a diverse and qualified teacher workforce. However, state requirements, such as teacher salary minimums, sometimes bring about challenges.
"It is not good for a district, especially like mine, since we don't have the funding that other districts have," Thompson said.
Queen Anne's County Public Schools Superintendent Patty Saelens said the Eastern Shore superintendents don't support Moore's proposed funding cuts to teacher collaborative time (out-of-classroom time to grade and plan) and community school initiatives.
"Our number one priority right now that we just can't support is literal cuts to our budget, specifically as it relates to the collaborative time and the community schools," Saelens said. "Those are two major things that will negatively impact our overall state support."
EDUCATIONRepresentatives from colleges and universities attended Friday's meeting, including Chesapeake College President Clifford Coppersmith and Washington College President Mike Sosulski.
Sosulski provided an update on Washington College's Innovation Plant Project, which is a project the institution is collaborating with Chesapeake College on.
"In the year-and-a-half of its development, it's already garnered $3 million in public and private funding to support it," Sosulski said.
Sosulski added that he hopes the Maryland Sellinger Grant Program, which provides independent colleges and universities with state funding, isn't slashed.
"I can't tell you how important Sellinger has been to making a Washington College education affordable and accessible to all Maryland residents," he said. "It is really, and quite literally, the difference for many, many of our students and their ability to achieve the kind of education that we can provide."
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) asked about whether universities are considering raising tuition due to potential state funding cuts.
"We fully understand the need for the governor to cut the budget," said University of Maryland Eastern Shore President Heidi Anderson. "We will not be looking at increasing tuition for our students, and we will abide by that."

title: After 116 years, 'Junior Naval Academy' closes its doors
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
After 116 years, 'Junior Naval Academy' closes its doors

 February 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 A St. Mary's County landmark is no more after Leonard Hall Junior Naval Academy closed its doors last week.The 116-year-old Leonardtown-based academy had just eight students, who are now at other schools.
"It is with great regret that Leonard Hall Junior Naval Academy will not continue with academic instruction for the second semester of the 2024-2025 school year," Amie Milan, the school's board of trustees president, said in a news release sent out Jan. 30. "This has been openly discussed with all corporation and board members and the hard decision made was based on what was in the best interest of the midshipmen."
The school was close to signing a lease at another location in Leonardtown, but that fell through.
Milan added that "LHJNA has faced several challenges over the past several years" and that "our ability to find a facility that will support not only an effective classroom setting, but also the military program has been challenging and has had a direct impact on enrollment resulting in limited financial and staffing/volunteer resources."
In January 2024, the St. Mary's County commissioners decided not to ratify the school's lease, which was slated to end at the close of the 2024-2025 school year.
"It's not about wanting to cancel somebody's lease," Commissioner Mike Hewitt (R) said at the time. "It's about trying to find a plan that allows that school to continue."
In early 2023 an assessment of the school uncovered a host of needed repairs and maintenance for $575,000, with the school on the hook for about $250,000.
In December 2023, the school submitted 10- and 15-year financial plans, but they were largely dependent on a grant and the school seemed destined to close.
But in late January 2024, a post on the school's social media page said "it is my honor and privilege to share with you that we are keeping the doors open."
But the commissioners ultimately ended the lease due to a failing business plan and consistently low enrollment.
"It's a process and it's a fellowship with the teachers and a mentorship built with the administrators," said former student Olivia Flynn, who received 52 infractions in one quarter, but later graduated as a top student leader and returned to the school to teach in 2022. "It helped me deal with conflict, it also helped me build good relationships with people and helped me prepare for life."
The school had been in existence since 1909 and became a military academy in 1941.

title: Eastern Shore legislators discuss education funding and county burdens
author: Konner Metz

Eastern Shore legislators discuss education funding and county burdens

 Speaking to Eastern Shore legislators Friday, the Department of Legislative Services outlined how local governments may assume costs passed down from the state as Gov. Wes Moore and the state legislature aim to tackle a $3 billion deficit.Hiram Burch, the local government research and analysis manager for the department, shared that local governments across the state will have to pick up around $144 million of the gaps in the fiscal year 2026 budget as proposed.
In Caroline and Talbot counties, projected local cost shifts are in the $700,000 range. Dorchester County is at $830,000, while Queen Anne's County leads the pack for the Mid-Shore at $970,000. Kent is the lowest of the five counties with a $300,000 projection.
Many of those cost shifts come in the education realm, including teacher retirement funding.
Del. Steven Arentz (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) questioned whether record education funding that the governor's office has touted was due to the governor's actions or the result of The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's funding plan for education passed under former Gov. Larry Hogan.
"The governor's saying we have record funding to education," Arentz said. "And I'm wondering if that's mandated from The Blueprint."
"Most education funding is formula-based," Burch said. "He's required to put that in."
Burch said while Moore did provide some "enhanced funding," most of the state aid is required by formulas in The Blueprint.
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) said she's hearing from constituents that they're concerned about special education funding amid around $200 million in proposed cuts to the state Developmental Disabilities Administration.
Burch said that none of the state aid reductions will affect special education.
"There were reductions in collaborative learning that impacted the foundation program, the compensatory aid program (and) the English language learners program, but this reduction did not affect special education funding," Burch said.
"That is the one area that has been held harmless by his proposed reductions and postponing the implementation of The Blueprint," he added.
At the close of Friday's budgetary discussions, Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said the state is "very willing to pass unfunded mandates down to the counties."
"What this means really for Eastern Shore citizens, is their tax rates, their rates on their property, are going up," Adams said, referencing increasing property assessments. And that's how we're unfortunately going to be funding Maryland."
"That's my raw take on it, and many of our members are very concerned," Adams said.

title: Talbot school leaders discuss immediate, long-term effects of Blueprint cuts
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot school leaders discuss immediate, long-term effects of Blueprint cuts

 February 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 494
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Budget cuts in The Blueprint for Maryland's Future could have a potential impact of $1.7 million to Talbot County Public Schools this fiscal year, district officials said Monday.That gap is the amount of additional local funding the district may need if the governor's current budget proposal is passed, Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said to Board of Education members during Monday's work session.
She added that the impacts may snowball over the next eight years to the tune of more than $30 million in reduced funding from the state.
"These are deep cuts that are being proposed," Jones said.
Gov. Wes Moore filed the Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act last month, a bill that proposes drastic cuts to education funding amid a nearly $3 billion state budget deficit.
If passed, the most significant cut would be a reduction in the "per-pupil foundation" funding outlined in The Blueprint's original formulas. In fiscal year 2026, it would reduce Talbot County's funding by $685,000, according to district calculations.
That's more than a third of the projected $1.7 million gap created by state cuts this year, which also includes reductions in compensatory education and multilingual learners funding, a decrease in the state's share of nonpublic special education tuition costs, and a hike in how much pension costs districts are required to pick up.
District Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the cuts to foundation funding per pupil, along with the slashes to compensatory and multilingual education, stand out. Superintendents across the state are continuing to advocate against the proposals, she said.
"While this excellence in education bill overall is saving money, it's still not hitting the foundation," Pepukayi said. "That's the main push in the advocacy."
The superintendent said it's been conveyed that districts are expected to go back to counties "to make up those expenses."
"That's all well and good if you live in Montgomery County or Prince George's County," Board Vice President Amy Dodson said. "That doesn't really help us out here."
During the meeting, Jones provided what the cumulative reductions in funding to Talbot County will be if the Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act passes as proposed. For fiscal years 2026 through 2033, $20 million would be stripped from what the current Blueprint formulas outline for per-student funding.
Additionally, $9 million in compensatory education aid and $2.9 million in multilingual learner aid could be slashed over the next eight years, she said.
Board President Emily Jackson suggested board members begin their own advocacy amid the looming cuts.
"If we could, as a board, come together and talk about how we could take a stand here, I think that would be good," Jackson said. "I think that would be a good first step in that direction."
Dodson added on, asking if members of the community could speak up, too.
"Do we want to get people in the community to write letters about this at this point? They're chopping our funding majorly," Dodson said. "It seems like people in the community should also speak up, if they're so inclined."

title: Talbot Board of Ed discusses dress code, school uniforms
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed discusses dress code, school uniforms

 February 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 527
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Board of Education held a discussion during its virtual meeting Wednesday, touching on dress code updates and the possibility of implementing school uniforms.District Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi shared a revision to the district's administrative regulations for dress code. Administrative regulations do not require board approval.
Under the dress code standards, wording that singled out specific clothing items, such as "low rider pants" and "spaghetti straps," was removed. The dress code largely remained unchanged aside from a few strikethroughs.
Board Member Ann O'Connor asked why some of the language was removed. Pepukayi said there were discrepancies of students getting coded, particularly in regards to body shape and size.
"Some of our administrators feel like they spend a lot of their day chasing down specific, indicated things in dress code," Board President Emily Jackson said. "And it becomes a barrier to creating a relationship. And we feel like we are policing tiny little infractions all day long."
The board president later added that when it comes to dress code, she's in favor of standards that promote "the dignity, and value and worth of each student" rather than rules that police "individual items of clothing."
Board Member Deborah Bridges said the revision "guts what we had intended it to be."
O'Connor said while she wasn't on the board for past discussions regarding dress code policy, she doesn't see a need for spaghetti straps to be permitted. She then raised the topic of school uniforms.
"In fact, I know this is probably not the way to bring it up, but I'm in full favor of school uniforms," O'Connor said.
She said uniforms would put everyone "on the same playing field" and "solve all problems." O'Connor asked for it to be put on the table as an option.
Pepukayi said the topic of school uniforms has been discussed since she joined the district in 2022. Rochelle Eisenberg, the board's attorney, said the board does have the power to require school uniforms.
"You can have a policy requiring school uniforms so long as you would be willing to purchase them for children whose families could not afford them," Eisenberg said.
"I'm not opposed to uniforms," Board Vice President Amy Dodson said. "I actually went to a high school that required uniforms, and I personally loved them as a student because I didn't have to think about what I was going to wear."
"I know the kids aren't in favor of this at all, but it would solve many problems," O'Connor said.
Eisenberg suggested no matter how the board proceeds, it should procure sufficient community input.
Jackson, who has been on the board since 2018, said the discussion of school uniforms has come up under past superintendents. She suggested the board look at past data and outcomes.
"I was told that it was once tried and it was not widely adopted, and it was very hard to enforce," Jackson said. "I think that was at one of our elementary schools."
Pepukayi said talking with administrators and advisory committees can be a "starting point."
"I'll talk to team members who've been here to get some historical context," Pepukayi said. " … And then with current groups that we have, we'll formulate some questions and get some information."

title: Rooted Wisdom partners with Bloomberg for guided history walk at Adkins Arboretum
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Rooted Wisdom partners with Bloomberg for guided history walk at Adkins Arboretum

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 694

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Adkins Arboretum and Beech Works are have been collaborating on the Rooted Wisdom Podcast for months. Now, they are working together on a similar project, but with a twist — Rooted Wisdom Walks.Rooted Wisdom Walks consists of audio walking guides for three trails at the arboretum. For listeners of the podcast, the voice sharing history along the 45-minute to hourlong walks will sound familiar.
Rooted Wisdom Walks historian Anthony Cohen guides the listeners through the trails.
According to Rooted Wisdoms producers, Adkins Arboretum best shows natures' role in the Underground Railroad through its diverse landscape.
"Adkins is one of the few places where you can go and see examples from these narratives of the landscape in one place," George Burroughs, one of Rooted Wisdom Walks producers, said.
"It leverages Adkins as a place to come and try to understand and put yourself in the footsteps of a freedom seeker by observing what they might have observed."
Rooted Wisdom Walks offers a digital guide from Beech Works with technology supplied by the Bloomberg Philanthropies Connects app for mobile devices.
"We were looking for an app ... and what would work best for it," Burroughs said. "There is not WiFi on a 400-acre forest. That's another issue. So we came across Bloomberg Philanthropies, and they developed this app, this platform for it, and it's downloadable."
Another big component of choosing the Bloomberg app is the ability to add pictures and videos to the audio, producers said.
"The key to with the Bloomberg Connects digital guide is that it's a multimedia platform. Like, we can put video in there," Burroughs said. "We didn't do it for this one, but we put photographs that were taken by us and Adkins staff to help listeners identify what's being discussed."
Cohen travels with listens and stops at certain points in the trail to give a little background on what the listener is seeing at the park. But the recordings also give the listener some points of independence with the walk as well.
"There are times where there's something that matches that they're talking about specifically," Lauren Giordano, one of Rooted Wisdom Walks' producers, said. "So visitors are prompted to walk to that space and then listen to the conversation there, and then the next stop there.
"They're walking and listening to the next segment of the conversation. So there are times where it's really kind of self-guided, but there's also a choice from the participant, where you can take more time at a spot for reflection."
Cohen believes that time gives listeners a chance to reflect on different wayfinding tactics that were used during the Underground Railroad.
"The probably far too simply put story of the Underground Railroad, or part of it, is the story of wayfinding," Cohen said. "How do you get from point A to point Z and what propelled you along that journey?"
Adkins Arboretum helps tracks attendance via their map box and general attendance at the park each year.
Ginna Tiernan, executive director at Adkins, expects the arboretum will see an uptick in visitors with the new guided walks.
"We have a visitor center here. We have a map box outside that they could use," said Ginna Tiernan, executive director at Adkins. "Of course we have a big, beautiful sign as well. Bloomberg did a fantastic job in allowing the producers to find just the right sign makers, and Lauren Giordano (producer) did all the graphics, fabulous icons that show you the way, what trail to take."
With Rooted Wisdom Walks, listeners don't have to be at the park to experience the audio. They can also just listen at home.
The producers credit Cohen's creativity and knowledge of history to making to audio captivating.
"You have people that know the history, and it's very hard to find people that can help you experience it a bit and get you connected to it," Burroughs said. "But what Tony does so well is the connective tissue in between that someone needs to be conduit and facilitate, and that's what Tony does best.
"That's the experiential history part, we haven't been on anything else around any other subject, where someone performs the work that Tony does, and they and provides that unique perspective that he does."

title: 'Mrs. Hollis was my compass,’ my true north': Pioneering educator and community activist dies at 97
author: DOUG BISHOP
content:
'Mrs. Hollis was my compass,’ my true north': Pioneering educator and community activist dies at 97

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP | Section: News 
 
 479
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Madelyn Matthews Hollis, 97, a dedicated educator who taught for more than three decades in Queen Anne's County schools and became a steadfast community advocate, died Thursday, Feb. 20, while under care at Compass Hospice in Centreville.Born in Accomack County, Virginia, Hollis arrived in Centreville in 1948 when she was hired by then-Superintendent Harry Rhodes to teach mathematics at Kennard High School, which served African American students during segregation.
Hollis taught at Kennard until 1966, when segregation ended in Queen Anne's County. She then transferred to Queen Anne's County High School, where she taught mathematics and driver's education until her retirement in 1981 after 33 years in education.
"She was a really good teacher," said former student Naimbi Davis of Centreville. "She was not a coddler with students. However, she knew how to teach them. Math was never my subject, but Mrs. Hollis taught me the essentials."
Beyond her teaching career, Hollis was deeply involved in community service. She was an active member of New Life United Methodist Church in Centreville and served as president of the Lucretia Kennard Homemaker's Club for at least 16 years.
Perhaps her most enduring legacy came through her fierce advocacy to preserve the former Kennard High School building when it faced demolition after closing. That preservation effort, spearheaded by Hollis and carried forward by alumni, culminated in the 2019 dedication of the Kennard African American Cultural Center and Museum.
Clayton Washington, who led the alumni restoration efforts, said, "Mrs. Hollis was 'my compass,' my true north. She kept me on point. She always told me, 'Boy, don't start something you can't finish!' When we dedicated the Kennard African American Center in May 2019, I was pleased I could say to her, 'We got it done!' I know she was happy."
From 1985 to 1995, Hollis served on the Queen Anne's County Public Schools Board, appointed by then-Maryland Governor Harry Hughes. During her tenure, she was instrumental in establishing Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday as a school holiday in the county.
Former board colleague Elizabeth Broderick described Hollis as "an icon of the community" who "went to college earning her teaching degree when going to college was not open to everyone, especially African American women."
Hollis was known for her strong Christian faith and believed that prayer in schools taught students respect for "a higher being" that could be applied to all aspects of life.
Her former classroom at the Kennard African American Cultural Center features her picture, her name, and writing on the blackboard in her handwriting—a tribute to "living history."
"She was one of my favorite teachers," said Jim Brown, a Kennard High School graduate and former Grasonville Community Center President. "I'd say she was a very kind Christian lady, who was devoted to her church, Kennard, and her work with the NAACP. I say she was a community activist."
A Celebration of Life will be held later in March.

"It's a waste of our administration and teachers time going out there putting out information that is just not being read. With this sign they can just change the information from a computer."
Cole and Murphy both talked about the exposure it would bring to the school and the town, which could get community members out to athletic games and school plays.
The town officials suggested that a change in the ordinance to allow the town to be able to announce other events besides school events on the sign. This change would allow other announcements beside school announcements to be made.
The officials also suggested changing the ordinance name from educational facilities to public school. This allows the town to control the amount of facilities that would need an illuminated sign.
The town government decided to move the ordinance to a second meeting, which would be a public hearing. The meeting is slated for the second town meeting in March.

Post Labor Day start slated for Caroline 2025-26 school year

 DENTON — Caroline County Board of Education members voted on the school year calendar for 2025-2026. The officials decided on a post Labor Day start for the new school year.Tara Downes, assistant to the superintendent, came before the Caroline County Board of Education at the March 4 board meeting. A survey was sent out to parents and staff on what start of school day was preferred.
According to the survey, pre Labor Day start of school calendar was preferred by staff and parents in Caroline County, but survey officials felt from conversations with parents that the post Labor Day calendar was preferred.
"What I have heard has not been this," Board Member Chrissy Bartz said. "Some feedback I've received is that its not their preference."
The board members discussed what factors played into each calendar to make their decision. Teachers having a longer break was one of the deciding factors.
"I worry about our teachers coming back that early and have a full July of summer camp and kids in building," Bartz said. "I think if we could give them a few more days and have that long weekend available for families, I am hearing families would prefer that."
For the 2025-26 school year calendar the first day of school is slated to be Tuesday, Sept. 2. Teachers will return to the building on Aug. 25 to begin planning for the new school year.
Colonel Richardson High School is set to hold graduation on May 27, 2026, and North Caroline High School is set to hold graduation on May 28, 2026.
The last day of school for students is June 17, and the last day for teachers is slated for the day after.
The county has three inclement weather days accounted for in the calendar for the new school year. In the 2024-25 school year calendar, there were four inclement weather days, and all four have been used to account for snow this winter.
"The board can always change the number of snow days that we build in," Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "The board always has the ability to take certain days that are not state required days, we just have appeal to the state."

 EASTON — Last week, the ACE Mentor Program of Maryland's Eastern Shore held its annual awards ceremony at Saints Peter and Paul High School.The organization — which stands for architecture, construction and engineering — is part of a national after-school program that connects high school students with professionals in the design and construction industry.
The awards ceremony March 12 brought together high schoolers from Saints Peter and Paul High School, Easton High School and St. Michaels Middle High School.
This year, Easton High School brought home the gold cup with its project to create a multimodal transportation station in Annapolis. Rachael Whiting, the Eastern Shore affiliate's vice chair and lead mentor, said Easton High's project featured trains, buses, ferries and cars as well as trails and bike paths.
St. Michaels Middle High School's project, complete with an arcade, mini golf and go-karts, aimed to expand recreation in St. Michaels, Whiting said.
Saints Peter and Paul High School's project was called "Connecting Delmarva."
"They did a train station with 11 different stops along the Eastern Shore, connecting Maryland and Delaware," Whiting said.
Projects judges included Aaron Goller with Easton Utilities, Jason Loar with Davis, Bowen & Friedel and Jay Yerkes with Rosin Creek Collaborative.
Whiting said last week's ceremony included a dinner and a keynote speech from Casey Rauch of Rauch Inc.
Easton High School engineering and business teacher Nicholas Werner was awarded the ACE Community Award. He called the award "wonderful."
"It's just a great opportunity for the kids," he said about the program. "I think my biggest part is being the cheerleader for them here. Getting it on Instagram and all the fundraising opportunities so we can raise money and go on these field trips and just get the word out to the kids."
Whiting said the program is important because it helps students understand the world of architecture, construction and engineering.
"These projects, we can help them with the ideas," she said. "But the designing of the building, the designing of the site, the construction part of it, we let the kids figure it out with guidance from us."
Whiting said she and Yerkes are working on starting a Queen Anne's County affiliate of the program. She said they plan to start it in fall 2026.

title: Community school leaders in Talbot County aim to make a difference
author: Konner Metz
content:
Community school leaders in Talbot County aim to make a difference

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 794
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In her third year as community school manager at Easton Elementary, Katie Fox's job is all about removing barriers for students in need and becoming a community resource."The premise of a community school is for you to be the community hub," Fox said of her role. "So you serve as a resource for everyone."
It's a relatively new position in Talbot County Public Schools and across the state. In 2019, community schools were introduced as part of The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's initiative to fund and improve education.
More than 600 Maryland schools are community schools. Two are in Talbot County: Easton Elementary and Easton Middle. Those schools receive extra funds to create services for students and families in poverty.
As future funding remains up in the air this legislative session, Talbot County's two community schools are moving forward at two different stages of the process.
Last school year, Easton Elementary came up with an implementation plan and goals. Those goals are to increase availability of healthy foods, provide mental health resources, raise enrichment by 15%, and add 100 students to the school's Choptank Community Health partnership, Fox said.
Fox, a longtime teacher before taking on her current role, said those needs become apparent.
"You could probably spot test any single classroom teacher. All of those things spike up," Fox said. "Food insecurity, needing materials, clothing. All of that is prevalent in all of the spaces, especially post-pandemic."
Easton Elementary is in its third year as a community school. Starting off, the school received state funding to hire Fox's position and a health care practitioner. In Year 3, it received "per-pupil" funding to begin providing specific services and resources.
Fox said the per-pupil funding has supported before- and after-school programs and Teddy Bear Fresh Produce boxes for family events, among other programs.
Easton Middle, meanwhile, is in its first year. Community school facilitator Shelby Parks is spearheading a needs assessment that includes staff, family, student and community surveys.
At the middle school, Parks says mental health, food insecurity and transportation are focus areas.
"We can't offer too many after-school programs because we just don't have the transportation, and students are struggling," Parks said.
Fox noted that transportation to grocery stores for neighborhoods around Easton Elementary and Easton Middle is a challenge.
"We don't have a current grocery store that's within walking distance, so that's just something to consider," Fox said. "If the family doesn't have their own personal transportation, it makes it more difficult to access any kind of healthy food outside of a few restaurants that are there."
FUNDING UNCERTAINTY
Attempting to close a nearly $3 billion state deficit, Gov. Wes Moore proposed a budget in January with significant cuts and freezes to education funding, including for community schools. Many education advocates pushed back.
His budget proposed freezing community school funding at next year's levels, potentially impacting the money provided to schools such as Easton Elementary in future years.
But last week, the House of Delegates amended some of Moore's education cuts by passing a refined Blueprint education bill. The House struck through his proposed pause to community school funding and sent the bill to the Senate chamber.
Kristen Tilghman, Blueprint implementation coordinator for Talbot County Public Schools, said the district is watching closely to see if community school funding is paused or affected in any way.
The district is "going to move forward because our community clearly has a need," Tilghman added. Easton High, White Marsh Elementary and Tilghman Elementary are the district's schools next in line to become community schools. Job postings for community school program leaders are active for those three schools.
Tilghman said the state funding "sets the stage" for schools to create partnerships and assist families all over Talbot County.
"(It's) vital to the whole community, not just that particular school's community," she said.
'HELPING ALL'
Talbot school leaders emphasized that theme of not just helping the designated community schools but bettering the entire district.
For instance, Fox is involved in monthly food distributions for families across the district, not just Easton Elementary.
"Because we're a small county, I can do this heavy lift at Easton Elementary, but Easton Middle and High and Chapel (District Elementary) and Tilghman (Elementary) can benefit from some of the things that are happening," she said.
As Parks prepares to move EMS into the implementation phase next year, she's watching how Fox makes an impact at the elementary school.
"I'm excited that if Easton High comes on board, we can see trends between Easton Elementary, Easton Middle and Easton High, how it all flows, how we all work together," Parks said.
The concept of working together applies not just for every school in Talbot County, but for every student in each school. Fox said all students benefit from the community school resources and programs.
"You create something for one, it always ends up helping all," Fox said.
