title: ‘Catastrophic’: Could Trump 'defund" Head Start preschools program?
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
‘Catastrophic’: Could Trump 'defund" Head Start preschools program?

 April 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 889
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Jennie Mauer is concerned about a looming "chaotic disaster."Mauer is executive director of the Wisconsin Head Start Association.
Head Start is a federal program offering free preschools to close to 800,000 lower-income kids nationwide and dates to the 1960s.
Mauer and other early education advocates are worried about current Head Start funding and the program's future with President Donald Trump's austerity efforts and a draft White House budget showing no funding for the $12.1 billion preschool effort.
In some rural and poorer communities, Head Start can be one of the only childcare options for lower income and working class families.
"There are many places where Head Start fills a critical void," said Mauer, whose group represents preschools across Wisconsin that receive funding under Head Start.
Earlier this month, U.S. Sen. Patty Murray, D-Washington, said the Trump administration has slowed $943 million in existing Head Start funding that goes directly from the federal government to local providers across the country.
Murray said in a statement the "slow-walk' of money prompted one Head Start provider serving 400 kids in eastern Washington state to temporarily close earlier this month.
"Before our very eyes, Donald Trump is defunding Head Start," said U.S. Sen. Tammy Baldwin, D-Wisconsin.
She said the Trump administration has delayed as much as $35 million in approved Head Start disbursements in Wisconsin so far this year.
Mauer said 40 Head Start providers in Wisconsin are budgeted $258 million annually to serve approximately 15,000 kids.
She said current DOGE efforts — including a short-lived spending freeze right after Trump took office in January and downsizing at the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services — have providers jumping through more hoops to get payrolls approved and the families they serve are concerned about current and future funding.
"It's chaotic," she said.
Mauer and other Head Start backers say the program is the only thing keeping some areas of the country from becoming "child care deserts" with few (or sometimes no) affordable daycare options.
Karen Filipovich, executive director of the Montana Head Start Association, said there is uncertainty about the War on Poverty-era program.
"I think right now there is a lot of wait and see," Filipovich said.
Head Start funding in Montana totals $62 million annually. Filipovich said there are 22 programs, including on Native American reservations, serving more than 3,900 kids.
She said many areas of Montana, which has a population of just over 1.1 million people, are already childcare deserts with few affordable options.
The average cost of child care is $1,000 per month in Montana, Tennessee, Florida and other states and can run even more in other states, including Ohio ($1,400 per month), Maryland ($1,600 per month) and California ($1,800), according to the Economic Policy Institute.
Filipovich doesn't think state governments have the financial bandwidth to take over funding.
"We are already struggling with the capacity to take care of kids," she said.
Head Start advocates said the cuts or an elimination would have its economic toll, making it harder for working class parents and grandparents to afford child care and get jobs.
Filipovich said those families are also concerned about other Trump cuts and potential changes for Medicaid, Social Security and other safety net programs.
Trump's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) austerity programs and congressional Republican efforts have frequently mirrored Project 2025.
The policy blueprint calls for Head Start to be eliminated, saying the program "is fraught with scandal and abuse" and citing a 2020 federal Inspector General's report that said as many as 'one in four' Head Start providers had problems with child supervision and others were not promptly reporting abuse or mistreatment allegations.
"Between October 2015 and May 2020, 12 % of recipients received an adverse finding for child abuse," the 2020 federal inquiry found.
In March, the Trump administration announced it was looking to cut 20,000 jobs at HHS to bring the agency headcount down to 62,000 employees.
The austerity efforts have resulted in the closure of six of HHS's 10 regional offices, including in Chicago, New York and Seattle.
The agency — which has said its restructurings will improve efficiencies and use of tax dollars — has not yet responded to a request for comment on Head Start funding.
Wanda Minick, executive director of the Florida Head Start Association, said the government-funded preschool program also offers hearing and vision screenings as well as meal and nutrition programs for low-income kids.
"At a time when we need solutions to workforce shortages, early education access, and economic disparities, cutting Head Start would be a step backward," Minick said.
Filipovich said Head Start staff are also worried about the future of the program and their jobs.
Head Start preschool programs, which serve infants and toddlers up to age 5, employ more than 250,000 staff across the country, according to the National Head Start Association (NHSA).
That includes 1,300 workers in Montana and close to 11,600 in Florida.
NHSA has called a federal defunding of Head Start "catastrophic" for working class and low-income families.
Last year, the Biden administration issued a new rule raising Head Start teacher pay — which ranged on average between $35,000 and $40,000 nationally — by approximately $10,000.
Republicans pushed back on the pay increases, with U.S. Rep. Virginia Foxx, R-North Carolina, saying "the effort smells like an attempt to form Head Start educators into a unionized political block."
The Trump administration — which has reversed a number of policies from the previous White House — has not yet taken any action on Biden's Head Start pay rule.

 GRASONVILLE — Character Counts coaches focus on building students' character skills and shape a positive school culture in regular visits to classrooms through the Six Pillars of Character: trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and good citizenship.This year Character Counts of Queen Anne's County honored more than 100 dedicated classroom coaches striving to make a difference in the lives of students with its annual volunteer appreciation dinner at Hyatt Place Kent Narrows April 24.

"I am in awe of all of you. You are truly the heart of this initiative," she said.
Whether finishing up a rookie year or going strong with several seasons under their belts, through the appreciation dinner each and every volunteer was lauded by name for their commitment to coaching and mentoring local children.
Finishing out her first year of coaching and receiving a certificate of recognition was Kimberly Kight who, volunteering at Centreville Elementary School with kindergarteners, considered the experience immensely rewarding.

title: PoliTalks transitions leadership as new era begins at Washington College
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
PoliTalks transitions leadership as new era begins at Washington College

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 822
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — The founders of PoliTalks, Washington College students Stephen Hook and Zach Affeldt, are stepping down from group leadership as they graduate next month.While both are preparing for promising careers, Hook assured the crowd at their spring lecture on April 24 at Hynson Lounge that the club's future is in good hands. The event, held on the second floor of Hodson Hall, featured renowned speaker Heather Mizeur, who delivered the lecture "Disagreement is Democratic."
The lecture, free to the public, included an introduction to the new PoliTalks leadership: co-presidents Charlotte Schurman and Grace Walsh. "We feel confident in our team to take the group forward," Schurman said during a catered meal and Q&A session following Mizeur's discussion.
Schurman and Walsh are continuing the tradition of PoliTalks: to provide a safe, respectful forum for political education and conversation.
Hook reflected on the club's success during a politically charged climate, noting that he was pleased to see people with differing views engage in peaceful discussions about polarizing issues during the Trump administration.
Mizeur, a former Maryland state delegate, candidate for Congress, and CEO and founder of WeAreOne Alliance, led these discussions. This was her second time giving the lecture. She discussed the guiding principles she learned while reaching across the aisle and campaigning.
Just as she did at the Toll Science Center on Oct. 17, 2024, Mizeur introduced her mnemonic device: **RESPECTFUL**, which stands for Reciprocity, Engagement, Sovereignty, Pause, Equanimity, Curiosity, Trust, Freedom, Unhook, and Listen.
In this session, she focused on the "S" — **Sovereignty**.
Mizeur defined sovereignty as "the ability to stand in your own agency." She explained that how we respond to political disagreements, while maintaining self-control and understanding, is key to sovereignty.
Mizeur stated that the nation's collective sovereignty is currently under assault. She criticized the Trump administration for trampling due process and weaponizing fear and control, leading to the dehumanization of people.
"The initial response to these policies," Mizeur said, "is to react with fear and frustration, instead of responding with sovereignty, which is a conscious choice rooted in integrity."
Sovereignty, Mizeur explained, is a calming force that leads us to a different path, one that cannot be legislated or controlled.
"It's not earned, but inherited," Mizeur said.
She offered lessons on how to reconnect with one's own inherited sovereignty.
Mizeur emphasized that sovereignty does not mean being a doormat. It requires setting boundaries, practicing a firm "yes" and "no," and avoiding separation from others, which leads to isolation and despair. She encouraged practices like journaling, speaking with a friend or partner, and engaging in joyful activities to help individuals maintain sovereignty.
Mizeur also emphasized the importance of listening to the body's warnings and stepping back from social media to detox and nourish oneself.
"Sovereignty is a practice, not a switch you turn on and off when needed," Mizeur added.
She said practicing these principles brings deeper joy, freedom, and can spark real change in hearts and lives.
The discussion continued over a catered dinner, where guests of all ages discussed how to apply these principles in their own lives. Some shared stories of losing friends or family members over political differences and blocking people on social media. Tensions over political debates had surfaced in families.
One attendee suggested that protests, such as the "Hands Off Rally," should include what participants are fighting for, in addition to what they oppose, emphasizing the positive.
A few attendees remarked that they no longer view people with opposing views as "enemies." A central lesson from Mizeur's talk was to lead with curiosity and learn from everyone, regardless of their political affiliation.
Others acknowledged that life experiences can lead to differing viewpoints, and sometimes, religion plays a role in those differences.
One woman pointed out issues on which everyone could agree, such as the need for more jobs and affordable housing.
Hook, who founded PoliTalks after witnessing the need for peaceful discussions on campus following a Washington College lecture by conservative speaker Robert George, expressed his satisfaction with the club's success. George had cut his speech short on Sept. 7, 2023, due to protests.
"This is the best possible way we could have ended with the club," Hook said.
He thanked everyone involved, especially Mizeur, for her nonprofit work in coalition building through community partnerships. "Heather brings a unique narrative to the conversation around political dialogue that we believe is important for our community to hear," Hook said.
For those who missed Mizeur's talks, they can sign up for her newsletter and receive information about her 2025 programming at [https://www.weareonealliance.org/](https://www.weareonealliance.org/).
What's next for PoliTalks under new leadership?Schurman noted that environmental justice is a strong focus across campus. She plans to invite Serena C. McIlwain, Maryland secretary of the environment, for a future lecture.
As they call for more student involvement, PoliTalks plans to hold monthly meetings.
Several members of the Chestertown government attended the event, including Mayor David Foster and Council Member Sheila Austrian of Ward 1. Austrian found the discussion eye-opening and thanked the college and PoliTalks for reaching out to the community in such a meaningful way.

title: Assanis to step down as University of Delaware president
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Assanis to step down as University of Delaware president

 May 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 University of Delaware President Dennis Assanis will step down at the end of the school year, he said in a surprise announcement Monday.The decision comes as Assanis has one year left on his contract but has faced increasing criticism from faculty over his handling of the university's finances.
"At this point, I believe I have made the meaningful contributions that I set out to accomplish with all of you in translating our shared vision into a reality and advancing our institutional mission and strategic goals," Assanis wrote in a letter to the campus community. "I therefore feel this is the appropriate moment to make a leadership transition, with the institution's best interests always in mind and a thoughtful approach for continued growth and excellence."
Assanis will work through June 30, and then an interim president will take over while the board of trustees searches for a new permanent leader, a process that often takes upward of a year.
Board President Terri Kelly said the interim president will be announced later.
"I want to thank Dennis Assanis for his inspiring leadership and service as the University of Delaware's 28th president," Kelly said in a statement. "His tireless commitment and bold vision have been transformative, advancing the university to new levels of accomplishment, promise and potential. As we look ahead to the next chapter in the university's leadership, President Assanis' legacy of purpose-driven, positive change will forever have an impact on UD's continued future of institutional excellence. We wish him and Eleni nothing but the best for their future."
Assanis' resignation follows a string of high-profile departures in recent months. John Long, executive vice president and chief operating officer, is retiring this week, and Mary Remmler, senior vice president and chief financial officer, resigned last week. Athletic Director Chrissi Rawak left earlier this year.
It also comes at a fraught time for higher education institutions nationwide, which have seen funding cuts and other threats from the Trump administration.
A record of campus growth
Assanis came to UD in 2016, replacing former president Patrick Harker. Before coming to Delaware, the native of Greece was provost at Stony Brook University and had spent most of his academic career as an engineering professor and administrator at the University of Michigan.
In 2021, the UD Board of Trustees announced that it had extended Assanis' contract through 2026. With a total compensation of more than $1.5 million, he was the third-highest paid public university president in 2023, according to rankings by the Chronicle of Higher Education.
Assanis' tenure at UD was marked by tremendous growth at the STAR Campus, including the construction of the STAR Tower, the Ammon Pinizzotto Biopharmaceutical Innovation Center, the Chemours Discovery Hub, the FinTech Innovation Hub and, coming soon, the Securing American Biomanufacturing Research and Education Center and a Buccini Pollin Group apartment complex. UD's role as headquarters for the National Institute for Innovation in Manufacturing Biopharmaceuticals has brought in hundreds of millions in federal funding.
When Assanis arrived in 2016, the STAR Campus was still in its infancy. Now, the site is home to 1.2 million square feet of new buildings and employs 3,000 people, more than it did when Chrysler was there.
On the main campus, UD opened the South Academy Residence Hall and, most recently, the new interdisciplinary science lab known as Building X. Earlier this year, the university announced its largest-ever donation, a $71.5 million commitment from alumni Rob and Kathy Siegfried to construct a new building for the Alfred Lerner College of Business and Economics.
Assanis also launched the First State Promise, a program that aims to cover all tuition and fees for Delawarean undergraduate students coming from families with incomes under $75,000. Approximately one-third of enrolled Delawareans are covered by the program.
On the athletics side, one of Assanis' first hires was Rawak as athletic director and together they aimed to increase the prominence of Blue Hen sports programs, which Assanis often said are the "front porch" of the university. He presided over the renovation of Delaware Stadium, the construction of the Whitney Athletic Center and most recently the decision to move to Conference USA and the Football Bowl Subdivision.
Financial strife
Assanis led the university through COVID-19, a crisis that required the university to quickly pivot to virtual learning and upended the university's finances. At the height of the pandemic, UD reported a $250 million deficit and instituted employee layoffs and furloughs.
As the pandemic waned, the university's financial difficulties continued. In 2024, Assanis reported that UD had a budget deficit of up to $40 million, which he blamed on inflation and skyrocketing health insurance costs.
Assanis instituted a partial hiring freeze, delayed capital projects, restricted employee travel and implemented other austerity measures. The university is forecasting another large deficit this year.
It was Assanis' handling of that situation that prompted criticism from faculty members.
Last spring, a survey of more than 750 university professors found that virtually all believed the university was not transparent about its finances and that it did not prioritize academics when it came to budgeting, according to reporting by the Newark Post's newsroom partner, Spotlight Delaware. About a dozen professors submitted anonymous comments that said they wanted faculty to call for a vote of no confidence in Assanis.
In a study released earlier this year, the faculty union questioned Assanis' "poverty narrative" and argued that the university's continued building spree was to blame for the financial difficulties.
"That's a lot of operating resources to be directed into building," Persephone Braham, the president of the university's faculty union, told Spotlight Delaware. "That's tuition, that's fees, that's research [facilities and administrative] funding, that is a local contribution from the endowment draw down, and only an average of 9-10% is being funded by presidential fundraising."
Town-gown relations
Assanis leaves a complicated legacy in terms of the university's relationship with the city it calls home.
Under his tenure, UD has faced sustained criticism from many Newark leaders and residents for its decision to push more of the burden of housing students onto the private sector, putting pressure on the city to approve more and more off-campus student housing projects, often against the wishes of residents.
In 2019, UD abruptly closed the Christina Towers, thus taking 1,300 beds off the market. The university also took control of the once-private University Courtyard Apartments, which removed the sprawling complex from the city tax rolls.
UD has also faced criticism for not contributing enough to the city's finances. That came to a head last year when city council — against the strong opposition of the UD administrators and students — began lobbying the state legislature for the power to levy a per-student tax on UD. A bill allowing the city to do so passed the state House and is awaiting consideration in the Senate.
Former mayor Jerry Clifton credited Assanis with cultivating a better relationship with the city than previous UD administrations did.
"Dennis made sure that I had all his contact information and could readily reach out to him," Clifton said in an interview Monday. "I've enjoyed our relationship together with Dennis and Eleni, and I certainly will miss that."
He also praised Assanis for agreeing to sell the former Rodney dorm complex to the city at a steep discount, leading to the creation of Hillside Park and the stormwater pond.
"It was a huge win for the city," Clifton said. "There's no way that would be a park today if it wasn't for the university and Dennis cooperating at the level that they did."
That said, UD's public battle against the student tax hurt how the public views the university, Clifton said.
"I think there could have been, and had been some, negotiations, but what they saw as their value to the community was not necessarily the cash that we saw that we needed because of the loss in tax revenue," he said.

title: A dream come true: Italian exchange student spending a year in Maryland
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
A dream come true: Italian exchange student spending a year in Maryland

 May 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 669
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Unlike Mantua, Italy, there is no opera house in Huntingtown. However, to Emma Agazzani, a resident of Italy's "Capital of Culture," living in the U.S.A. in general and Calvert County in particular has hit a high note.According to her, it's been a dream come true.
"It was something I wanted to do since I was very young," the teen told Southern Maryland News, adding that "the language, the culture, the travel" had her determined to pursue the opportunity to experience the life of a foreign exchange student.
"I applied in February 2022 with A.S.S.E.," Agazzani, 17, said.
The American Scandinavian Student Exchange has expanded since it was established in 1976. The exchange has its origins in Europe in the late-1930s. After World War II the exchange gained momentum and today over 30 countries on six continents participate.
On its website, the exchange states its mission is an effort "to foster international understanding through educational and cross cultural programs."
"My parents were hosts," Danielle Higginbotham of Huntingtown told Southern Maryland News in recalling how she and her family opened their home to Agazzani. "I knew it was something we wanted to do. We were researching students and Emma's profile stuck out with us."
Agazzani is a senior at Huntingtown High this year and will walk in the June graduation ceremony before returning to Italy later that month when her exchange program ends. She said since Italian high school is a five-year program she still has another year of secondary schooling to go in her home country before she will be off to a university.
At Huntingtown, Agazzani has been able to experience something that wouldn't be possible in Europe.
Of cheerleading, Agazzani said, "It was another of my dreams. When I think about the U.S. and high school, I think about cheerleading, because cheerleading is not a thing in Italy or Europe in general. It was my only option."
In addition to cheerleading, Agazzani has played lacrosse, a sport that hasn't caught on at all in Europe.
"I just finished lacrosse season and I really like it," she said, crediting her coaches for teaching her how to play the sport and excel in it.
Life for Emma Agazzani of Mantua at Huntingtown High hasn't been all cheers and sports, though. As a student, she is taking classes in Advanced Placement English — she has been taught English since first grade — A.P. Government, pre-calculus, biology, photography and theater.
As for what she will study in college, Agazzani said, "It's going to be something about science. I would like to be a neurologist."
When not in school, the Higginbothams have given Agazzani a chance to see America. She has traveled to several locations in Florida, including Disney World, where she donned a cheerleader's outfit for the annual Christmas parade.
While in Florida, Agazzani also got a chance to swim with dolphins.
"We tried to do a whole bunch of 'must-sees,'" Higginbotham said.
The hosts and exchange student have also traveled to New York City, Atlanta and Philadelphia.
Agazzani recalled one obligatory culinary experience in Philadelphia.
"I had the cheesesteak," she said. "That was amazing."
She also has been to Washington, D.C., and visited the White House during the annual Easter Egg Roll, meeting President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania Trump.
Comparing the urbanized character of her hometown, with its art galleries and opera houses, to the bucolic, wide open expanse of Huntingtown, Agazzani said, "it's very different. In Italy everything is tiny and compressed. Here, everything is spread out and very big."
Of her hometown she said, "We are walkable. We have a lot of history and arts."
Agazzani summed up her Hurricane high school experience, saying, "I really like the school and this town. I'm a senior here. I think it's more interesting."
Higginbotham conceded that the experience of having a teenage cheerleader in her home has been so incredible that, while she will offer aid and advice to other families who want to participate in hosting an exchange student, for now she feels fulfillment from her experiences with Agazzani.
"She's my daughter now," Higginbotham said. "We've created a friendship, a bond."

title: KCHS students explore STEM careers with local businesses
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:

title: Talbot council mulling $1.1 million request from school district
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot council mulling $1.1 million request from school district

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 706
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With less than two weeks until the Talbot County Council adopts its budget ordinance for next fiscal year, education funding hangs in the balance.Talbot County Public Schools is seeking $1.1 million in additional funds for fiscal year 2026 — $600,000 to fill nine new positions and $500,000 for teacher and staff salary increases. The former would add to the district's multilingual and special education staff, while the latter aims to inch the district closer to state-mandated $60,000 teacher salary minimums by fiscal year 2027.
District leaders say it's a "scaled-back" request from its $5.7 million ask of the county earlier this budget cycle.
"We recognize the financial pressures you face," Board of Education President Emily Jackson said at a May 6 budget hearing. "This ask is lean, deliberate and rooted in what's most necessary to keep moving forward."
In the county's budget already is $55 million for TCPS as required by The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's overarching education improvement framework.
Council members are left to mull the best option as they prepare to vote on final amendments to the county's draft $161 million budget. So far, there's no clear decision.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher supported fulfilling the district's full $5.7 million request last month and maintained that stance for the pared down ask at a budget deliberation Tuesday.
"We're going to have to do it sooner or later," Lesher said. "I think it makes sense to do it this year and reduce the pain next year."
President Chuck Callahan said he feels comfortable with honoring the $600,000 part of the request to cover the new positions.
Council members Keasha Haythe, Lynn Mielke and Dave Stepp have all indicated they need more time to consider options.
Any additional funding granted would result in an education supplement to the property tax rate, which is 79 cents per $100 of assessed value.
Talbot County is already mandated by the state to pay $440,000 for teachers' pensions, which will be collected through a supplement of less than half a cent per $100 of assessed value.
Three potential scenarios for tax supplements have been laid out by county staff:
Teachers' pensions only: 0.0045 per $100 of assessed value.
Teachers' pensions and $500,000 for salary increases: 0.0096 per $100 of assessed value.
Teachers' pensions and $600,000 for new positions: 0.0106 per $100 of assessed value.
Haythe said Tuesday she's trying to balance helping the school system with preventing tax increases for residents on fixed income, such as seniors.
"I am in no way, shape or form trying to discount the great work that the school system does and what the teachers do in the classroom," Haythe said.
At last week's hearing, teachers and parents advocated for the council to include the $1.1 million. Lisa Hayes, a parent of three TCPS graduates, said past education investments are paying off now as her children enter the workforce.
"You cannot not fund a budget for our children's education because there is nothing more important than that," Hayes said.
Andy Burke, president of the Talbot County Education Association, which functions as the teachers' union, made his case.
"We continue to see too many educators migrate away to the higher wages and salaries paid in neighboring public school systems," Burke said.
In an emailed statement, TCPS Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said the district made "very difficult choices" to reduce its request to the county.
Jones noted staff will present the Board of Education with a budget amendment package in June, which will adjust the $86 million unrestricted budget the board OK'd in February.
"We will eliminate most of the new positions we had requested," Jones wrote. "We will scale back our requests and defer programs that will have the least direct impact on our goals for our students."
A final decision by the county on the $1.1 million in question, as well as the entire FY26 budget, is expected at the council's May 27 meeting.
While no clear choice was made during Tuesday's deliberations, county and district leaders did agree that state mandates and formulas are creating the tricky fiscal situation.
"It's just become screamingly clear that there's a disconnect at the state level between the requirements that they're putting on local schools across the state, and the funding formulas that are articulated to county governments to pay for their education," said County Manager Clay Stamp.

title: Lockerman Middle School Committee previews two sites for new location
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Lockerman Middle School Committee previews two sites for new location

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 560
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Lockerman Middle School Committee held its first community meeting on the potential new Lockerman Middle School location and specifications Thursday.The meeting featured two potential locations for a new school and a third option of staying at the current location.
The first location would be behind North Caroline High School, and the second would be on Double Hills Road in Denton.
While locations are being looked at, the committee made it clear that the current Lockerman Middle School location would still be there, though it may not remain a school.
The community meeting gave committee members and architects the opportunity to hear the publics thoughts on what historic value should be implemented into the new Lockerman school and on the locations selected.
"We're going to be gathering it, reviewing it," said Robyn Toth, owner of TCA Architects and architect for the potential new Lockerman Middle School. "Then as we go through the site design, we'll be trying to incorporate as many of their concerns and try to accentuate any of the possibilities that they were saying."
The North Caroline High location puts the new site directly to the west of the high school. The potential middle school would sit on a 23-acre parcel.
On that parcel, there is a solar field area that architects would have to contend with. There is also a pasture connected to the Career Center that could impact school placement and design.
Community members brought forward suggestions for what the county could do with the Lockerman location if it moved next to North Caroline High. They recommended students could share bus routes with high schoolers and made safety suggestions for both schools.
The Double Hills road site is located near the Caroline County Sheriffs Office and Caroline County Emergency Services buildings on 76 acres. The county owns the land, and the Lockerman Committee is looking for a 21-acre portion.
Kevin Shearon, engineer for the Lockerman project, brought attention to the size and distance of the road and made considerations for what they would do to the road to make it accessible for the school.
"Double Hills is a 20-21 foot road with no shoulders on either side," Shearon said. "So, we would consider adding shoulders, at least on the school side or the site side for ACLD cell and just a wider feel for the right."
According to Lockerman Committee members, the public water and sewer could be extended from the Denton's systems for the potential school.
After explaining both new locations, Lockerman Committee members and Superintendent Derek Simmons answered questions from residents and heard their concerns and suggestions.
"It was great to see the turnout," Simmons said. "It was great to see the engagement, folks are really passionate about their faults, which is great. Our architects and our consultants need that information now as we're working in the very early stages of design. I'm glad they came out.
"There will be another opportunity on June 2, and I hope the turnout is equally as good as not better. Because the board's got a big decision to make in July, and we want to provide them with the best information we can on the sites that we're considering."
The next public meeting on potential school locations will be held on June 2 at Lockerman Middle School at 6 p.m. Following that, the committee will have a presentation to the Board of Education on July 1 about their decision.

 DENTON — Last week was Teacher Appreciation Week around the nation. For Caroline County Public Schools, honoring the event meant taking time to celebrate teachers and support staff.The weeklong celebration featured free coffee and visits from Caroline County district employees for every school.
"I feel that it is very important to recognize the teachers and support staff that works every day to make learning at our school a worthwhile and important venture for our students," Caroline County Board of Education President Michele Wayman said. title: Removal of Safe Space stickers draws criticism
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Removal of Safe Space stickers draws criticism

 May 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Calvert County School Board member Melissa Goshorn's comment at the panel's April meeting proved to be prophetic."I recognize it's going to make a lot of people unhappy," Goshorn said just prior to requesting that Superintendent of Schools Andraé Townsel to remove "Safe Space" stickers from school buildings.
Goshorn based her request on anecdotal information she received at a National School Boards Association conference during what she described as a "bone-chilling session" presented by the Beau Biden Foundation.
The story relayed to session attendees dealt with a principal who was arrested on child sex abuse charges and may have gained children's confidence by having a "Safe Space" sticker on the office door.
The sticker is widely used as a sign that LGBTQ students will not be discriminated in that space.
"I think we need to have them removed," Goshorn said.
School maintenance staff removed the stickers and the predicted unhappiness manifested itself during the board's May 8 meeting when 19 of the 20 speakers addressed the issue during the public comment segment. While a handful of the speakers indicated support for the sticker removal, many expressed opposition.
Sheri Tardio of Prince Frederick called the issue "manufactured outrage. Safe space stickers do not promote ideology. Diversity is a fact."
"You are not hiding your biases very well," said Stacy Tayman, president of the Calvert Association for Educational Support Staff.
"Removing stickers is not a violation of First Amendment rights," said school board President Jana Post in her closing comments, adding that the April discussion "was twisted" into an LGBTQ issue.
"Real safety comes from a culture of trust," Post said.
At the conclusion of public comments, board member Paul Harrison made a motion to discuss "a flag policy" at a future meeting. That policy would likely be aimed at setting parameters for displays of flags, posters and decals in school buildings. The motion passed unanimously.
Supervisor's post
The school board unanimously approved the appointment of Marc Watson as supervisor of health, physical education and athletics. The Indiana University of Pennsylvania graduate is a familiar face in Calvert County where he has previously served as a teacher, coach and principal.
Most recently, Watson served as principal of King George High School in Virginia.
Watson told the board he was looking forward to "continuing to create this wonderful environment of learning and athletics" in Calvert County.
In recommending Watson for the appointment, Townsel said the returning administrator will provide "training and mentorship for coaches."

title: Robbins YMCA opening reading hub to tackle childhood illiteracy
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Robbins YMCA opening reading hub to tackle childhood illiteracy

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 500
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Robbins YMCA is stepping up after Dorchester County Public Schools faced significant budget cuts this year.The school district started this budget season with a $10 million deficit. Addressing that deficit meant Dorchester County schools lost after-school and summer programming.
The cuts to education come at a time when the county ranks 21st out of 24 school districts (including Baltimore City) in third grade literacy and 22nd out of 24 in overall English Language Arts proficiency in the state.
The Y is partnering with the John and Janice Wyatt Foundation to create a space for the Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading, a campaign that aims to target childhood illiteracy.
{span}The campaign was inspired by the movie "Sentenced," which was produced and narrated by NBA champion Stephen Curry. The film explores the epidemic of childhood illiteracy and its lifelong impacts.{/span}
"Dorchester County has, for a long time, been ranked very low in the state of Maryland," said Matthew Peterson, executive director of the John and Janice Wyatt Foundation. "And so interestingly, now concurrent to all the work that the Y is doing, that we're all doing together, Dorchester County Public Schools is undergoing a strategic plan to go from 21st, to 15."
The Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading plans to approach this goal from multiple angles and with multiple partnerships.
Because third grade is a pivotal marker for childhood learning development, the campaign's target population are children from birth to age 5, so they are better prepared to enter kindergarten, and are less likely to fall behind.
"So we're trying to grab moms as prenatal because we're gonna do infant groups, we're gonna do, you know, toddler groups, mommy and me groups, so we want to bring awareness at early childhood," said Tynice DeShields, director of mental health at the YMCA of Chesapeake.
The campaign's partners include county schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson, the Dorchester County Public Library, United Way of the Lower Eastern Shore, Operation Pathways and volunteers from the community.
"There's a number of agencies we've been working with over the years. You know, as any organization, some were more engaged than others, and so bringing everybody on board, finding out where that alignment fits best, and then trying to leverage that, to do the best we can, is what we've always tried to have," Peterson said.
The reading hub will be a space that is open to the public and YMCA members alike.
"We're building this reading hub as a meeting place where we can have a resource center, we can have meetings with the community, we can have sessions with the parents to teach their kids how to read, how to look at letters and numbers, and not just throw a book in front of them," said Bryant Wittington, director of the Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading.
Peterson, DeShields and Wittington are excited to engage with the community and hope to build a strong foundation of volunteers at the reading hub.
"We want to build that unity in the community," Wittington said.

title: TCPS cuts back on summer school; board displeased with how decision was made
author: Konner Metz

TCPS cuts back on summer school; board displeased with how decision was made

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 535

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot Board of Education members expressed displeasure with cuts made to the district's summer school programs, arguing they should have been part of the decision-making process.Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi outlined Talbot County Public Schools' reduced summer programming during Wednesday's Board of Education meeting.
Summer school will not be offered to elementary or middle school students as it had been in recent years. According to the district, summer school traditionally spanned four weeks, Mondays through Thursdays.
"We decided to make the decision this summer not to have summer school as we've had it prior," Pepukayi said. "To take this time to really reset and to talk to our families and our students and our staff to find out what we could do to have a robust summer programming moving forward."
Previously, summer programs were funded through grants, Pepukayi said. But as pandemic-era grants have dried up, she said the district looked at cutting costs for this fiscal year. Summer school would have cost around $350,000.
The district will continue to have the following programs:
Middle school transition, or 6th Grade Academy.
Credit recovery for high school students.
Band camps.
Summer Career Enrichment Program, a multi-county program held at Easton High School.
Extended School Year for students receiving special education services.
On Wednesday, Board of Education members expressed disappointment that they weren't included in the decision to trim summer school.
"It ultimately affects a budgetary item, and the board was not asked to vote on it," Vice President Amy Dodson said.
Board President Emily Jackson said she's "dismayed" and "concerned" about how the decision was made without board input.
"Why weren't we told that we weren't planning for it, why weren't families told that we weren't planning for it?" Jackson asked. "Why did this decision come out last week to kind of surprise everybody?
"All of those families, all of those teachers, everybody who has counted on summer school for so long for whatever individual, personal reasons they have are now left scrambling to figure out how to pay their bills this summer, or what to do with their students."
In making the decision, Pepukayi said the district kept an eye on what nearby districts were doing.
In March, Dorchester County Public Schools canceled nearly all of its summer school programs as it grappled with closing a multi-million dollar deficit. DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson and board members shared the decision to families through a joint announcement.
TCPS first announced the summer school cancellation in a May 1 superintendent's update newsletter, though it wasn't discussed at any open board meetings prior. A district spokesperson said the final decision was made in late April.
Responding to board members' concerns, Pepukayi said she heard "loud and clear" that it should've been brought to their attention during budget season. She said the board will be included on such discussions in the future.
Along with voicing concerns about communication, board members touched on what students may miss out on with the cuts.
"I was disappointed about the summer programs being cut, because I thought that's what we had to do, especially for our (multilingual learners) to keep them going all summer," Ann O'Connor said.
"We do have students that are still experiencing a COVID gap," Cynthia Jurrius said. "So that's really my number one concern, is the students who are behind."

 WYE MILLS — Skipjacks sailed toward promising new horizons as the 2025 Chesapeake College commencement recognized 260 graduates, with 135 walking, on May 21.College President Clifford Coppersmith welcomed the Class of 2025, epitomizing the can-do Skipjack spirit. He encouraged graduates to never fear, embrace hard work and maintain connections.
"Everyone has to start somewhere, and sometimes the correct way is not the easiest," Coppersmith said. With its legacy of watermen and farmers, the Eastern Shore is known even today for its strong work ethic, he said.
Keynote speaker, former U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin, was presented the college's Community Service Award in recognition of his service as a senior statesman, his Chesapeake Bay protection efforts, his dedication to human and civil rights, and his staunch advocacy for higher education.
"Graduation marks a profound turning point in your life. It is not only the culmination of hard work and dedication, but also the beginning of a new chapter filled with opportunity. What you do with that opportunity is up to you," Cardin said.
"Embrace hope," Cardin said, noting the student body was stronger due to its diversity. "Never give up hope for a stronger, more inclusive, more equitable society," he said.
Cardin urged graduates to recognize history lessons as more than words in textbooks, but as guides on what not to do and on how ordinary individuals can be extraordinary.
"As graduates, you have the tools to think globally and act locally. You are the architects of a world where hope becomes reality," he said.
For her breakthroughs in pushing learning past the pages of textbooks, including unforgettable methods of blending academic rigor with applied learning and creative applications, the inaugural Adjunct Innovative Teaching Award was presented to Cherie Patchett, instructor of psychology.
Opening eyes to the world of psychology, Patchett's impact was also noted to extend beyond the classroom, supporting students by establishing a mental health club on campus.
Patchett encouraged graduates to embrace their individuality to innovate their lives.
The John T. Harrison Award was presented to 2025 graduate Cianni A. Phillips for her dedication and empathy. She exemplified true leadership qualities by developing student-focused campus communities.
Phillips is a member of the Phi Theta Kappa Honor Society and is on the Dean's List with a 3.8 GPA.
Phillips served on the Student Government Association, was president of the UHURU Black Student Union, and, in addition to numerous student clubs, served as a student worker in the Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion. She will transfer to Coppin State University in Baltimore to pursue a bachelor's degree in social work.
Looking upon the graduating class, Phillips noted the students balanced all manner of life, including jobs and families, along with their schoolwork, to successfully earn a place at the commencement, which was more than a ceremony — it was a celebration and victory, she said.
Moving forward, Phillips encouraged her classmates to continually build support networks, pour back into the community, and be the representation so strongly needed.
"Young people need to see what their futures can be," she said.

 It's a heavy issue and the document that the Calvert County public school system uses to enforce it is also ladened with weight. During the the county school board's May 22 work session, Cecelia Lewis, director of student services, presented summaries of the code of conduct and the significant changes that are proposed, including the use of AI.Lewis called the proposed references and policies related to artificial intelligence "a huge highlight this year. Technology continues to evolve."
The "added guidelines for use of artificial intelligence" cover "educational use, academic integrity, ethical use, supervision and monitoring and prohibited conduct."
The code's definition of "academic dishonesty/cheating" is proposed to now include "unauthorized use of digital or AI-generated materials, sharing of local, state or federal test information."
The drafters of the code of conduct's rewrite added "utilizing AI-generated content to harass, intimidate or bully any member of the school community" to the bullying, harassment and intimidation definition in the document's "levels of responses" section.
In a new section of the code entitled "responsible use of technology," there is a mandate listed on "avoiding plagiarism and AI misuse."
In addressing a question asked by Grace Minakowski, the outgoing student member of the board, on allowing for the citing of artificial intelligence and deciding what work might be plagiarism, Lewis said, "the teacher's determination" would be the big factor. She added that an artificial intelligence course for teachers "is being developed."
Board member Melissa Goshorn asked if artificial intelligence training for students is also being considered.
"That is on our radar," Lewis said. "It's something we are developing."
Lewis said the school system's instructional department's technology supervisors will be involved in developing the training for teachers and students.
Jackie Jacobs, chief academic officer, indicated classroom teachers will be giving students direction in the use of artificial intelligence and the extent of its use will be "dependent on what teachers are looking for."
In providing an overview on the code of conduct, Lewis told the board that many stakeholders contributed to the revisions, with a focus on assuring Calvert's public schools have a "safe, welcoming environment."
Much of the code is guided by state law, Lewis indicated during her presentation.
Other proposed changes include the addition of Safe Schools Maryland contact information. The free system is available to students, teachers, school staff members, parents and the general public "to report any school or student safety concerns, including mental health concerns."
Jana Post, school board president, called the work Lewis and the stakeholders did on revising the code "a humongous overhaul" and commended the group for its work.
The revised code will now be posted on the school system's website until late June for public review and comments.
High school theatre group lauded
A school organization used to receiving cheers and applause was showered with more accolades May 22 as the Patuxent High School Harlequins received a recognition from the school board.
The citation noted the group earned a superior rating at the 2025 Maryland Thespians Festival with their production of the one-act play "Everybody," by Brandon Jacobs-Jenkins. The Patuxent troupe earned the most superior scores at the recent festival.
"It's our tradition of unparalleled student leadership," Allen Price, Harlequins' production director, said after the citation was read and unanimously approved by the board. He added the program's long history of achievement was due to "student ownership" and "dedication to our program. The students care about the other students' successes."
Earlier this week, Price told Southern Maryland News that the Maryland State Department of Education is showcasing the Harlequins in a short documentary that focuses on the group's outstanding use of student leadership and student ownership to produce high quality shows.

title: Rocketeers explode onto the scene at nearby farm
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Rocketeers explode onto the scene at nearby farm

 May 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 429

 CENTREVILLE — Over a mid-May weekend at Central Sod Farm, an H-130 rocket flew 1,000 feet through a cloudless sky, burning blue smoke before splitting apart.This was one of many rockets launched May 17 by hobbyists organized by The Maryland Delaware Rocketry Association Inc. following safety guidelines set by the FCC and the Tripoli Rocket Association.
While parachutes guided the nose and body of the H-130 downward, Yorktown Aerospace Club member Gavin La Rue watched his team's rocket's descent through a telescope.
The rest of the club members expressed excitement retrieving the rocket parts over the vast grassy landing zone.
"If you haven't noticed, there aren't many places in the city we can do this," club member Austin Humes said with a grin.
The launching activity at 920 John Brown Road, Centreville, is a learning opportunity for students in the Science Technology Engineering Mathematics field. Association Secretary David Kemp pointed out the rockets that day, large or small, use the same propellant as boosters on space shuttles.
Thanks to the organization's efforts, you do not need to be NASA trained to be a rocketeer.
For example, youth LaShawn Sudler watched his smaller rocket launch beside his step-grandfather, Mark Kraemer. It went 500-600 feet in the air, then released its chute at 200 feet.
A kid of few words, nonetheless Sudler showed pride in his rockets. Kraemer is passing his love of rocketry down to him and has fond memories of buying rocket kits when he was Sudler's age.
"These are just big boy toys," he said. "We love this stuff."
Over in another tent, friends Rich Custer and Erin Dawson from Northern Virginia showcased their rocket made from a fencepost and ceiling fan blades.
Under another tent, married couple Glenn and Adrienne Ramey shared how they even turned Christmas trees into rockets that when launched, spin the whole time.
On the grounds, there was just a handful of rocketeers in attendance, a smaller crowd since the American Rocketry Challenge was taking place in Virginia, said Fred Wallace, president of the association. Even though the conditions were a little windy, he had his high powered rocket with him just in case things calmed.
Although they were low in number that day, it offered a perfect opportunity to learn about the hobby.
That day, most landings were smooth although one rocket had a rough landing, the chute not deploying.
The association encourages all to come out to get their chance to be a rocketeer. People 18 and under fly for free. If you do not have a rocket, they have plenty to start you on your journey.
"Moms and dads, bring your kids," Wallace urged.

title: Easton, St. Michaels high schools celebrate graduates
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton, St. Michaels high schools celebrate graduates

 May 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News

 Seniors at Easton High School and St. Michaels High School marked the end of a four-year chapter with graduation this week, celebrating accomplishments and looking forward to the future.On Wednesday, 291 graduated from Easton High. Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said during her address to the class that the school's yearbook showed just how close students and faculty were during the last four years.
"What stood out the most were the connections I saw," Pepukayi said. "As I turned each page, I saw smiles, I saw groups of students clustered together. … I saw laughing, talking, joking taking place between the students, among students, in between staff and students."
Pepukayi emphasized to the graduates that creating those human connections is vital, especially in a world influenced by artificial intelligence.
"I read that Generation Z, who are the ages of 18 to 28, require a higher level of human connection, whether it's at home, at school, or in places of business," Pepukayi said. "Human connection. Now in the AI-driven world, this is of utmost importance. And that human connection is very evident in this class."
Easton High valedictorian Mia Mazzeo shared a similar theme in her speech.
"When all the information in the world is just a click away, take that extra step and dig deeper," Mazzeo said. "An eagerness to learn and an attentive teacher is all one really needs. It is only when you question how the world works that you can truly change it."
Mazzeo told her classmates that wisdom comes from interactions with one another.
"When I look back at my time in high school, I think I grew the most during late-night conversations with friends and after school chats with teachers," she said. "The experiences you share with others and the advice they have to offer is priceless."
ST. MICHAELS HIGH
On Thursday, 60 seniors at St. Michaels High School threw their caps in the air and joyously celebrated the achievement of being a newly-minted graduate.
Valedictorian Alexandria Rockwell said the Class of 2025 showed "incredible purpose" and encouraged her classmates to maintain that same drive as they go their separate ways.
Rockwell said the last four years tested and pushed the graduating class.
"As we entered high school, many challenges were thrown at us," she said. "Four years felt like forever. But now we're here. It's gone by in a flash, and it's bittersweet because we looked forward to this moment for so long, but now we know we're leaving behind something we'll never quite return to."
School principal Theresa Vener echoed that Thursday's graduation was bittersweet, bidding farewell to the graduating class she's been alongside since starting as St. Michaels Middle High School principal seven years ago.
Vener, retiring this year after 32 years working for the district, was presented with an honorary diploma at Thursday's ceremonies. Students, staff and district administrators thanked her for her dedication and leadership.
The outgoing principal said it was an "absolute privilege" to watch the Class of 2025 grow into caring and confident young adults.
"I have watched you fall, get back up and take those steps forward," Vener said. "One step at a time, but 'always forward,' just like your class motto says."

title: Recipes for graduation celebrations
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Recipes for graduation celebrations

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What an exciting time of the year — graduation has once again arrived. From graduates from nursery school, to grade school, to middle school, to high school, to night school, to college, to trade school, to graduate school to just any kind of school, congratulations.As I sit here and write this column and gather materials, my mind travels back in time to when my mother went to a one-room schoolhouse outside of Selbyville, Delaware. The outhouse being behind the school was no problem, as most of the homes had the same.
There were only 11 grades, and mom was a member of the Class of 1928. She always told me there was no celebration as she was running a farm with her stepfather and had to get back home to work in the fields. She said that her church group celebrated all school children the previous Sunday.
The next graduation I remember was in June 1954, when my sister graduated from Buckingham High School in Berlin. I remember going to the graduation was a formal affair. The boys wore suits, and the girls wore "dressy' dresses with high heels. This attire included dark graduation robes for the guys and white robes for the girls.
A big dinner was held at our house on Sunday to celebrate, and the house was full... and so was the kitchen sink with dirty dishes waiting for "little sister."
I graduated from Stephen Decatur High School in Berlin in 1963 with a "large class" of 72 students. As was the norm, my parents held a large family dinner, and guess who didn't do the dishes. I went to the beach with some of my classmates.
The years go by, and my youngest son graduated in 1996 from Colonel Richardson High School. We had a gathering of family and friends at home with "BBQ and Picnic" foods. Betty Lofland, my neighbor, made a garden flag with CRHS Class of 1996 in the school colors to fly on my pole. I still have the flag.
In 2022, my grandson, Mason Emory Williamson, is a member of the graduating class of Parkside High School in Salisbury. The ceremony was held at the Wicomico Civic Center due to such a large class — 800 kids. Times may have changed in the past 94 years of my family's graduations, but the message is and has always been the same — "The world is at your feet. Take it and keep going. If you fall get right back up".
Now I am hungry so let us fix some food for graduation celebrations.
FRUIT KABOBS
My only tip here is try not to use fruits that will brown, such as bananas, apples or peaches. Think about a variety of color.
Prep the fruit by cutting it into slices, wedges or chunks. Thread fruit onto skewers and refrigerate until eating. Make fruit kabobs ahead of time so they'll be well chilled before serving. They'll keep in the refrigerator for up to 12 hours. For an extra twist, add some whipped cream with shredded coconut as a dip. Mix however many cups of whipped topping with 2 tbsps of shredded sweetened coconut per each cup.
GARLIC BREAD PIZZA DIPPERS
1 can biscuit, 1/4 cup olive oil, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 cup ricotta, 4 oz cream cheese (softened), 2 cups mozzarella cheese (shredded), 1 tsp Italian seasoning, 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes, 1/3 cup marinara, 6-8 pepperoni, 3 tbsp parmesan.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Cut each biscuit in half and roll into a ball. Place each biscuit ball around the edge of an 8-inch skillet. In a small mixing bowl, combine olive oil and garlic powder. Mix and then brush onto biscuits. In a large mixing bowl, combine cream cheese, half of the mozzarella, Italian seasoning and red pepper flakes. Mix until well combined. Pour in the middle of the skillet, spreading evenly to the edge of the biscuits. Pour marinara on top of the cheese mixture and spread it evenly across the top of it. Sprinkle the remaining mozzarella on top of the marinara and place pepperoni on top. Place in oven and bake for 30 minutes. Remove from oven and sprinkle parmesan on top. Serve hot. This recipe makes eight. Adjust accordingly to how ever many guests you are having.
SLOW COOKER BBQ PULLED PORK SANDWHICHES
1 lemon-garlic pork loin filet (about 1-1/3 pounds), 1 can (12 ounces) Dr Pepper, 1 bottle of your favorite barbecue sauce, 6 hamburger buns (split).
Place pork in a 3-qt slow cooker. Pour Dr Pepper over top. Cover and cook on low for 7-9 hours or until meat is tender. Remove meat; cool slightly. Discard cooking juices. Shred meat with 2 forks and return to the slow cooker. Stir in barbecue sauce; heat through. Serve on buns. You can also make this with chicken for a pulled chicken variation.
CHEESEBURGER SLIDERS
1/2 cup mayonnaise, 2 tbsps ketchup, 1 tbsp yellow mustard, 24 slider rolls (I use King's Hawaiian), 2 tbsps olive oil, 1 medium onion, (small diced), 2 pounds lean ground beef, 1 (1 ounce) package dry French Onion Soup Mix, 1 tbsp steak seasoning (I used Montreal), 10 slices American cheese, 24 pickle slices, 2 tbsps butter (melted), 1 tbsp sesame seeds.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Line an 11-by-15-inch baking dish with foil and coat lightly with nonstick spray. Set aside. Slice the slider rolls in half, and place the bottoms evenly into the prepared pan, setting the tops aside. In a small bowl, whisk together the mayonnaise, ketchup and mustard. Set aside. In a large skillet, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the diced onions and cook, until soft and golden, stirring frequently. Add the ground beef to the skillet and cook until no pink remains, breaking the meat while cooking. Drain any excess fat from the skillet. Add in the onion soup mix and the steak seasoning, stirring to combine. Remove the skillet from the heat. Stir in the mayonnaise mixture and coat the meat evenly. Spread the meat mixture evenly on top of the slider rolls. Top with cheese slices, cutting to fit, if necessary. Top each with a pickle slice. Place the slider roll tops on top and press down slightly. Brush the melted butter on top of the sliders, and sprinkle with sesame seeds. Cover the pan tightly with foil. Place the pan on a large cookie sheet and bake for 15-20 minutes, until the cheese is melted. Remove the pan from the oven and keep covered for 5-10 minutes before uncovering and serving. Store airtight in the refrigerator until serving, no longer than 24 hours to preserve taste and freshness of rolls.
ANTIPASTO KABOBS
1 package (9 ounces) refrigerated cheese tortellini, 40 pimiento-stuffed olives, 40 large pitted ripe olives, 3/4 cup Italian salad dressing, 40 thin slices pepperoni, 20 thin slices hard salami (halved).
Cook tortellini according to package directions; drain and rinse in cold water. In a large bowl, combine the tortellini, olives and salad dressing. Toss to coat; cover and refrigerate for 4 hours or overnight. Drain mixture, discarding marinade. For each appetizer, thread a stuffed olive, a folded pepperoni slice, tortellini, a folded salami piece and a ripe olive on a toothpick or short skewer.
RAINBOW SHERBET PUNCH
1 gallon Breyers brand sherbet (rainbow flavored if you can find) 1 liter 7UP/Sprite/ginger ale, 1 liter of Hawaiian punch or a favorite juice of your choice, Whipped cream (optional).
In a large punch bowl scoop in your ice cream. Pour soda over the ice cream and break ice cream apart gently while pouring slowly then add in your juice and mix slightly to incorporate. Serve in tall glasses with a dollop of whipped cream.

title: Lockerman Middle School Committee heard and addressed concerns at second meeting
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com

Lockerman Middle School Committee heard and addressed concerns at second meeting

 DENTON — At the Lockerman Middle School Committee meeting Monday night, Robyn Toth, architect for the new Lockerman Middle School, confirmed that after the state's assessment, the current Lockerman Middle School building cannot be renovated, and the county will go with a new building."We've already reached out to the state and said the renovation of this existing facility as a school is not feasible," Toth said at the meeting. "It is my understanding that (the current school is) going to become a community center. So, this building is going to stay. It's going to keep its history."
Though it was never indicated as a preferred option, staying at the current site and renovating was left on the table at prior committee meetings and discussions on the new school.
The May meeting featured two potential locations for a new school, the first location would be behind North Caroline High School, and the second would be on Double Hills Road in Denton.
After a public hearing at that meeting, the committee came back with models and options for the school at two potential new locations.
"There was a lot of feedback last time about the safety issue for buses coming and going, as well as parent drop off," Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "So, I think the architect did the best they could with the two existing locations that the county has told us to look at to kind of make them as usable as possible."
The presentation given Monday premiered three building layout options for the North Caroline High location and two options for the Double Hills Road location.
The North Caroline High design options included two plans for a two-story style building with wings separated by grade level. Though these designs for the building itself are identical, the building is located in different places on the lot in each design.
One option proposes relocating the North Caroline High baseball and softball fields to a different location. The other keeps the middle school on the left and everything belonging to the high school on the right side of the property.
The third design option would also involve relocating the fields and would also relocate the solar array on the site. The existing barn and fenced pasture would also be rebuilt in a new location.
This third option is a three-story building design, with each floor being a different grade level.
"The different locations on North Carolina High School was interesting," Simmons said. "I think most of us in our heads ahead of time could envision it in one spot, but giving the flexibility of the options really opened up some some pathway."
The Double Hills Road location designs featured the two- and three-story options as at the North Caroline location.
While both options propose that the solar panels currently at the site may need to be located another portion of the county property and that new pump station will need to be constructed, entrance options, building locations and parking locations are different.
"Double Hills Road with the new county road going in in that property does preserve a 20 plus acre plot for to use," Simmons said. "It's good location but again it gives us that flexibility now to see what the buses would look like coming and going. What drop off would look like, what staff parking would look like because there's nowhere near enough staff parking here as well."
Now that the Lockerman Middle School Committee has presented all options, the public will have until before June 9 to respond to an online survey with their comments.
The top ranked designs for both locations will be presented to the Caroline County Board of Education in July. Then the Board of Education will make a decision on a location no later than August to make sure the timeline for construction stays on track.
To participate in the survey, visit carolineschools.org/article/2241492.

title: Stroke of pen loses 75 years of science leadership
author: LENA GILL
content:
Stroke of pen loses 75 years of science leadership

 June 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 713
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. higher educational system may in future years lose $38 billion a year. This is the estimated annual contribution by foreign students. In the school year 2023-2024 it was estimated that 1.1 million foreign students were studying at universities across the U.S., and they generally pay full fare or do work/study. They supported about 378,000 academic jobs.Now we risk driving them away.
On April 19, CNN reported that thousands of international students across the country were informed by email that their student visas were revoked. Six days later the Trump administration decided to restore 1,400 student visas. How many students did not have their visas restored is unknown. We do know that Secretary of State Marco Rubio had a list of about 300 students that he planned to expel. The National Immigration Project is challenging the visa cancellations in court.
Apart from the money that these foreign students bring in, why would we care? Because foreign students began many of the successful startups in Silicon Valley. We care because much research in science done at our universities has brought the U.S. to a revered leadership position in the world in medical science research.
With a stroke of the president's pen this may all disappear. The best brains in the world will not want to come here anymore. Research in advanced cancer treatments, drugs to treat Alzheimer, sudden crib deaths as well as CRISPRs use in treating genetic blood disorders by cutting out a person's faulty DNA will not continue without federal support. The U.S. inventors of CRISPR won the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 2020. We will be taking a giant step backward in the sciences.
In the 20th century up to World War II, Germany won about 30% of the Nobel Prizes in science. The second runner-up was Great Britain with 20% of the Nobel Prizes in science. The U.S. was way down the list with only 6% of the Nobel Prizes in science.
What turned the tide was Adolf Hitler who drove many of the best German scientists, artists and architects (some of them Jewish) to U.S. universities in the 1930s, where they were welcomed. The second German brain drain happened immediately after the war when U.S. intelligence invited physicists like Wernher von Braun (inventor of the German rockets) to the U.S. to work for the space program. The U.S. emerged from the war economically, technologically and militarily better than the rest of the world.
What really propelled the U.S. into today's leadership position was the futuristic vision of what could come, if the U.S. government funded basic research at universities small and large around the country with a promise to keep the government's hands off. The academic freedom and competition created by this decision attracted the best brains from around the world.
Since 2000, the U.S. has won 72 Nobel Prizes in science, of which about 30% were won by immigrants. Great Britain won 16, Germany 7, France 5, Japan 9, Israel 5. Canada, Australia.and Norway won three each.
This rosy picture will change fast if the Trump administration continues to threaten leading universities with withdrawal of funds and academic freedom. Harvard University, which so far has not backed down, was threatened with cancellation of its not-for-profit designation. $2 billion in research grants were withdrawn by the administration. Foreign students' and researchers' visas are being revoked. 27% of the students are from abroad. Attacking an elite university may appeal to the MAGA base, but it is still difficult to understand why President Trump wants to destroy the foremost academic institution in the US!
The Trump administration also is threatening withdrawal of funds from our other world-renowned science research facilities, the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation. A science publication asked its readers if they were affected by government harassment and withdrawal of funds. If so, were they considering moving their research elsewhere? 75% of the 1,600 who responded said they were considering it.
With a stroke of the president's pen, we have lost 75 years of leadership in the sciences.
California, Texas, Illinois, Massachusetts and New York will see the most economic impact. Maryland also will suffer, as we are home to Johns Hopkins Hospital, the site of original cancer research and treatment, and the University of Maryland Medical Center with its world-renowned Shock Trauma Center.

North Caroline grad celebrating more than a high school diploma

 June 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News

 DENTON — Sa'Mauria Ennals graduated from North Caroline High School last month, but she celebrated way more than a high school diploma.Along with graduating from North Caroline, Ennals graduated from Chesapeake College with an advance transfer certificate and became a certified nursing assistant through Chesapeake College's nursing program.
Ennals maintained GPAs between 3.6 and 3.7 at both the high school and Chesapeake College. She plans to attend Towson University and major in nursing starting in the fall. She will already be multiple semesters ahead.
Ennals' love for health care came during her freshman year of high school, but she decided she wanted to be a neonatal intensive care unit nurse during her sophomore year.
"When I just like actually sat down and was able to research and just gather data on all these different branches, that's what really like sealed the deal for me," she said.
Ennals is not the first child of her mother, Maria Bowser, to participate in the dual enrollment program at Chesapeake College. Ennals' two older sisters participated in the program in Talbot County, both graduating with a plethora of college credits to pursue nursing.
Ennals knew from watching her sisters complete dual enrollment classes that the workload was difficult, but she knew she was up to the task.
Ennals said she faced challenges getting enrolled in the courses she needed.
After an auditorium presentation with all juniors at North Caroline explaining dual enrollment options, Ennals went to her guidance counselor to talk about the process of doing dual enrollment and potentially graduating from Chesapeake College before graduating from high school.
"I tried to bring it up to my guidance counselor and they kind of deterred me from taking the dual enrollment classes, and that's when we decided to have a meeting about that and that's what got me into those classes," Ennals said.
"My guidance counselor told me that it was going to be too hard for me, which I was very confused as to why they would think that because I was already ahead when I first came to that school."
Bowser and Ennals met with counselors at North Caroline for several weeks about what course work would be best for Ennals.
"If she wants to be a nurse, and she knows she's going to college, college classes are the better path for her. However, we got a little pushback," Bowser said.
A representative from Caroline County Public Schools said the district was unable to discuss conversations between students, parents and employees.
After more pushback, Bowser and Ennals began to work with the Gabrilla Moreland, TRIO Upward Bound academic coordinator, and Mark Berry, director of TRIO program at Chesapeake College.
The TRIO Upward Bound program offers high school students from Caroline, Kent and Talbot counties an opportunity to gain college and career readiness skills, through tutoring, workshops and field trips at no cost to students.
The group set down with county Board of Education and came up with a plan to allow Enalls to take four college classes during her junior year of high school.
"I wasn't taking the 'no she can't take classes because it's too hard.' How was it too hard? She had a 4.0, and she was managing everything and had all of her high-school credits by her 11th grade year," Bowser said.
Ennals said it became a "prove them wrong type of situation."
"I loved it because it was a lot of motivation knowing that there were education officials telling me that I can't do something. So I just used that as motivation to just let me get through it. Let me kind of not only prove to myself but also prove to them," Ennals said.
