title: Massive lunch debt pressures school district
author: Aamaly Hossain somdnewsintern@chespub.com
content:
Massive lunch debt pressures school district

 June 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Aamaly Hossain somdnewsintern@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 574
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A projected $640,000 lunch debt is straining the Charles public school system's budget.Additionally, a sinkhole, broken fire alarms and faulty HVAC systems are among the pressures forcing the school board to shuffle $5.7 million across its internal 2025 fiscal budget — not to spend more, but to stay within the current year's total budget.
Last week during a school board meeting, Chief Financial Officer Karen Acton and Budget Manager Sherri Fisher-Davis detailed a large budget transfer to cover a range of categories from emergency repairs to unpaid student meal balances, which skyrocketed since pandemic federal meal funding ended.
"We cannot, by law, we cannot be over budget by category," Acton said at the June 10 meeting. "So, we have to move things back and forth."
The unplanned emergencies discussed at a previous board meeting, including a sinkhole, faulty HVAC systems and a series of fire alarm malfunctions, led to this reallocation of funds, Acton said.
She asked to move several funds in differing categories, including $1 million from contracted administration services, $3.5 million from instruction, salary and wages (to cover teacher wages during summer months), and $200,000 from special education (without disrupting programs, according to school officials).
Lunch debt is now projected to be $640,000 for the school year that just ended, a dramatic increase from pre-pandemic levels of roughly $18,000 to $20,000 per year. Board members said the debt likely stems from families choosing not to pay or failing to submit annual free/reduced lunch forms.
The school system did not respond for more information by deadline.
"These are families who make above whatever the threshold is to qualify and they are able to pay for lunch. They are able to pack their student's lunch. … There are options," board member Jamila Smith said. "It's a choice just not to pay."
The board provided school principals lists of students with outstanding balances to contact families, encouraging repayment plans and assisting with lunch forms.
"And we do recognize that families are in different situations now, given that there are work closures, reductions in force, a variety of things that are happening," Smith said. "But this has been going on well before that even began."
Board member Samichie Thomas emphasized the importance of filling out the lunch forms every year, or the school does not know if a family qualifies for the program that reimburses the school system for low-income students' lunches.
"I was a parent of four. You get all these forms and all these things at the beginning of the school year," Thomas said. "Make sure you take the time to fill out the form because that's how the school can help you. … You can do it online."
The board is now considering stronger actions, including possibly sending unpaid debts to collections. The board will revisit the issue in July once the end-of-year payment window closes and final figures are available, giving families until end of June to pay their outstanding balance.
For now, board members are stressing outreach at every level to make families aware.
Board member Dottery Butler-Washington said, "You have to say something three or four times for somebody to actually get it."
The full transfer plan vote is set for July when actual figures replace projections.
New substitute bus wages OK'dThe school board unanimously approved a raise for substitute bus drivers, boosting hourly wages.
New wages will be between $20 and 22.50, up $2.50 per hour. The increase, tied to 2026 budget, keeps pay competitive with full-time drivers and will cost an estimated $20,000 extra.

title: Book festival gets kids reading
author: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com
content:
Book festival gets kids reading

 June 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com | Section: News

 Despite a scramble to get out of the rain and into the library itself, the North East Branch Library's annual Children's Book Festival drew over a thousand young readers and their families to the library on Saturday.While traditionally held in tents outside the building, rain and air quality concerns caused Cecil County Public Library organizers to move the authors and attendees indoors. Despite the weather, the event had drawn over 1,000 attendees by noon, which was rapidly approaching last year's 1,200 attendee total, according to North East Library Branch Manager Jennifer Carter.
"In my opinion, it's the best thing we do all year," said Carter.
Each family selected a free book upon arrival, and then was free to speak to the many children's authors present, or take part in the numerous activities on offer. These ranged from magic shows to facepainting to musical performances.
Local author Annette Whipple, a former Elkton and North East resident who now lives in nearby Oxford, Pa., said that the change in venue didn't seem to affect the enthusiasm at the event.
"It's been incredible. The families have turned out in full," Whipple said. "Although we are inside, it hasn't dampened our spirts at all."
Whipple, whose bibliography features such titles as "Woof! The Truth About Dogs" and "Scurry! The Truth About Spiders", writes what she calls "fact-filled, fun" books.
"I think facts are fun," said Whipple. "So I write nonfiction for kids. And I love animals."
While many of the activities and authors were popular among attendees, little could compare to the crowds near the water ice and ice cream trucks that set up shop on the street.
Members of the Dolly Parton Imagination Library were present at the event, helping families sign up for the program and conducting surveys of members. According to them, the festival was a great example of the Imagination Library's mission to get kids reading at a young age.
"The crowd here shows the county's families are interested," said Sharon Rosenberg. "It's a tribute to the libraries themselves.

title: Caroline commissioners weigh potential locations for new Lockerman Middle
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline commissioners weigh potential locations for new Lockerman Middle

 June 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 666
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — During the Caroline County Commissioners' open comment report Tuesday morning, Commissioners Vice President Larry Porter brought up the discussion on Lockerman Middle School's proposed locations.Porter said he preferred that the new middle school go on the North Caroline High School property, one of two locations being considered during the design processes for the building begin. The other location, near the county sheriff's office on Double Hills Road, presents several challenges, Porter said.
"I think at this point I would like to say that I am in favor of the North Carolina location as opposed to being built in town," Porter said.
Commissioners Frank Bartz agreed with Porter and cited traffic and safety concerns on Route 404.
The commissioners also had discussions about the school's location at their meeting two weeks ago.
At that meeting, County Administrator Kathleen Freeman presented the two location options. Commissioners President Travis Breeding sparked a conversation about how much sway the commissioners have over the school's location.
"How much influence do the commissioners actually have over where the school gets constructed?" Breeding asked two weeks ago. "As part of the funding of this, other than a survey, we haven't really been consulted."
Breeding then explained the issues they would run into with each potential location.
"From what I gather, it seemed like a lot of people really preferred the Double Hills location. But, with Double Hills, we've got to work out a ton of details with the Town of Denton as far as sewer, water allocation for that to work, potentially pump station upgrades," Breeding said.
He then mentioned traffic issues on Route 404 with beach traffic towards the end of the school year and students from northern county towns like Marydale, who would have to take the bus a long distance to the potential Double Hills location.
Porter, said he didn't recall that "the county did not have a lot of input" on the design of new county buildings in the past.
Freeman assured Breeding that the county will be involved with the full feasibility study for both sites to determine which site makes the most sense.
Breeding also brought forward discussion of how much influence the commissioners will have for the design of the school.
"Then also, how much input do we have over the the design?" Breeding asked. "I mean, we don't want a situation where we're building something that's way more expensive than it needs to be or making it as functional as we can and keeping the cost as low as we can."
Bartz raised an issue where if the county has to build a new detention center, a school on the Double Hills Road site would cause a problem. The Caroline County Sheriff's Office is located near that Double Hills Road site, making the location logical for a detention center, he said.
The county is in talks with Queen Anne's County about a new 388-bed regional detention center that would house all Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent county prisoners. After conversations about control and cost of the center, discussions between the three counties have slowed down.
Lockerman name
Porter pointed out conversation that are being had about the Lockerman's name staying at the location of the current building instead of being attached to the new school.
Though the existing building will no longer be used as a school when the new school is built, Porter said he was in favor of keeping the Lockerman name attached to the facility in the interest of honoring its history.
"I think it's going to be important that the history of the school and the name of Lockerman be retained," he said. "I don't know what the future use is going to be for that building, but it's important, I think, from the alumni standpoint, from the community standpoint, that the history be be kept there for whatever use is going to be done in the future."
Breeding suggested drafting a letter of intent to the Caroline County Board of Education stating that it would be the commissioners' intention to retain the name of the building.

title: Foundation of HOPE's new building to expand middle school girls program
author: Konner Metz
content:
Foundation of HOPE's new building to expand middle school girls program

 June 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 559
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Since 2017, the Foundation of HOPE has grown into a beloved nonprofit in the Easton community, building bright futures for middle school girls. Soon, the foundation will have its own building.A project to create a dedicated Foundation of HOPE space on the corner of South Washington and South streets is moving along after the Easton Planning Commission approved its site plan Tuesday.
Founder and President Keasha Haythe remembers comments made by the first girls she welcomed into the organization's after-school program eight years ago.
"They said, 'Ms. Keasha, are we going to have our own space?'" recalled Haythe, who also serves on the Talbot County Council.
A building wasn't always in the cards, Haythe said, but in 2020, she and the nonprofit's board realized a separate space could be beneficial. Since schools shut down, and that's where the program's classes took place, the program was put on hold during the pandemic.
"If something like this happens again, it would be better if we have our own space," Haythe said.
For nearly a decade, the foundation has brought on a cohort of sixth grade girls each spring to engage in programming on economic development, entrepreneurship and self-confidence. The girls are followed through high school, and some that are heading off to college receive scholarships.
The after-school program would typically take place in Easton Middle School. Most recently, Haythe's nonprofit added St. Michaels Middle School and 10 students to the cohort.
Now, the Foundation of HOPE is planning its own 5,200-square-foot, two-story building. It's a $2.2 million project, with over $1.8 million already raised, Haythe said. Construction could begin as soon as September.
Once it opens, girls from Easton Middle would be within walking distance to attend the after-school program, and Haythe hopes for St. Michaels students to be bussed to Easton. Expansion will occur, too.
"I've had parents reach out from private schools as well," Haythe said. "I do believe the building will allow us to open it up to those that may be home-schooled as well."
Planning Commission members complimented the design work done by the Foundation of HOPE and architect Crosby & Associates, saying it fit the commercial character of South Washington Street but didn't stick out too much from the residential homes on South Street.
"Fantastic job with this site design," said Vice Chair Michael Ports. "It's a perfect transition to these two different areas. It's quite awesome."
During discussion, some concerns about safety were raised, stemming from the South Washington and South streets vehicular intersection and the fact there aren't marked crosswalks.
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said independent of the project, the town is aware of those safety concerns and is looking to improve the intersection for pedestrians, bicyclists and vehicles.
While the nonprofit has obtained OKs from the Planning and Historic District Commissions, Haythe noted there are still steps left in the approval process, including permits.
But the building may soon be a reality for future cohorts of girls. Along with office space, Haythe envisions a reading room, fun area, cooking lessons and much more for the sixth graders. And it could help spark even more excitement from the students once they have a building to call the Foundation of HOPE home.
"For them to come to the classroom for the after-school program, it's asking a lot of them to stay in that building until we're done with our sessions," Haythe said. "This will break that up."

 GREENSBORO — St. Paul's United Methodist Church is partnering with Greensboro Elementary and the Town of Greensboro to start a shoe drive for Greensboro Elementary students.The Rev. Bonnie Shively, pastor of St. Paul's, came up with the idea as a way to serve the community.

title: Ed Spec Committee recommends North Caroline site for new Lockerman Middle
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Ed Spec Committee recommends North Caroline site for new Lockerman Middle

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 467
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Board of Education is one step closer to picking a new location for Lockerman Middle School.At the monthly Board of Education meeting Tuesday, the Lockerman Middle School Ed Specs Committee said that after the feasibility study and community input, the recommended location for the new school is on the same property as North Caroline High School.
Board of Education members decided not to formally vote on a location after receiving almost two hours of information from the Ed Specs Committee. The board decided to push the decision back to the August meeting.
Multiple reasons came forward on why the North Caroline High site was recommended over the Double Hills Road site.
"Some of the highlights that came out throughout the analysis and the surveys was again, the infrastructure. If you're not spending a lot of money on that, the site readiness, the educational alignment, a lot of really exciting ideas came out during the community meeting of ways that you could really have mentorships and things like that with the older and the younger students being on one site," said Robyn Toth, architect for the new school.
Reason included the use for indoor and outdoor activities and the ability to share space for events at North Caroline High.
"There's clear paths for the indoor and outdoor activities," Toth said. "There's no crossing of streets, lots of capabilities there also because you are sharing more spaces… There were some concerns about large events and right now, if they're at Double Hills or if they're at Lockerman now, where do we go for these large events? That don't happen that often and you don't necessarily need to build more space that the state's not going to support. Well, you've got a high school right there that's got a large auditorium. It's got a large gym."
With the North Caroline High location, development prices will be about $500,000 cheaper. The site development for the North Caroline High location will be $10 million, while Double Hills Road would cost $10.5 million.
Although in the community meetings multiple builds were shown, the new middle school, regardless of the location, will be a two-story building with a two-wing design.
According to the Ed Specs Committee Powerpoint, the new anticipated project budget would be $103.82 million with state funding coming in at around $80 million and local funding covering the remainder.
The only concerns brought up about the North Caroline High site were the solar array on the property and the traffic Central Avenue could receive from a new school being added to the location.
To purchase the solar panels on the property, it would cost about $180,000, which doesn't include the cost of relocation.
The Board of Education will take all the information received and make a decision on what location will be picked at its August meeting.

title: Dorchester schools prepare for more cuts
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester schools prepare for more cuts

 July 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 322
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dorchester County Public Schools are projected to lose over $642,000 in federal funding after the Trump Administration suddenly announced the decision to withhold $6.8 billion in federal education cuts, according to DCPS communications specialist Casey O'Bier.The U.S. Department of Education cut 28 K-12 programs saying "states and localities, not the Federal government, are best suited to determine whether to support the activities authorized under this program or similar activities within their own budgets and without unnecessary administrative burden imposed by the Federal government," or stating the program has not been proven effective, or that cutting funding is to restore fiscal discipline in the states.
In an email to the Star Democrat, O'Bier said those cuts will impact a variety of programs including teacher training, internal and external student experiences, and English Language Learner programs.
"DCPS would need to reallocate existing funds to sustain programs that were originally funded through some of these federal grants or eliminate various programs in a worst-case scenario," O'Bier stated as one of the district's central concerns.
The federal funding cuts to education come at a time when Dorchester County Public Schools are already struggling financially.
In January, DCPS faced a budget deficit of $10.19 million, which they reduced to $5.59 million in March. To further reduce the deficit, DCPS got rid of their after school and summer programs.
The county had to reduce staff sizing, but Superintendent Jymil Thompson said he wants to keep class sizes small and retain teachers at all costs.
The Board of Education has been making concerted efforts to move DCPS from 23rd out of 24 school districts — including Baltimore City — in state education ranking, but the federal funding cuts make those efforts more difficult.
"Moving forward, we will be proactively looking closely at unique ways to reallocate pre-existing funds to support the inclusion of these federally funded programs which are a major asset to Dorchester County Public Schools and the enrichment of its students," O'Bier said.

Superintendent and commissioners discuss Lockerman

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners and Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons discussed Lockerman Middle School at the County Commissioners meeting on Tuesday.At the last commissioners meeting, the commissioners discussed their role, responsibilities and preferred location for the new Lockerman Middle School.
The superintendent came to the commissioners meeting to discuss the approval of its fiscal year 2026 budget. After the discussion the commissioners talked about Lockerman Middle School and the next steps.
"I think it'd be good for us to say that we are working together on the Lockerman Middle School construction," Commissioners President Travis Breeding said. "We were asking questions about what role the commissioners officially play in siting and construction, they were just questions that we were asking. It wasn't like the Board of Ed's going to run all over us and make crazy stupid decisions and we're going to be stuck with it. It was just what influence do we have over the process."
Breeding explained the consensus the commissioners have come to on their personal choice for the new school location.
"I think we talked about it, and our consensus is that the most logical place to put it is probably next to North Carolina High School for us," Breeding said. "We understand that there's a whole process that has to be going through, fact finding, the Board of Ed will review that and make their decisions based off of that. But we were just saying that that questioning what influence we actually had over the process."
Simmons clarified they understand the commissioners wanting understanding of their role and told the commissioners how the process will go.
"Board of Education selects the site," Simmons said. "The feasibility study, which was presented to the board on July 1st, indicated North Caroline High School was the better of the two locations. We did review the two sites that we were asked to review that were basically the county-owned, which is cost efficient way to do it.
Simmons said the board received the feasibility study that night and should be making its decision on a site at the August meeting. He added the site selection does not include picking what the design of the building will be.
After looking over potential designs for the new Lockerman Middle School, Breeding suggested having athletic facilities have their own location and not sharing fields.
"One of the major things that stuck out with me was, relocating the athletic facilities around there," Breeding said. "If we can get dedicated facilities so we're not sharing space like we have been doing forever, where lacrosse or soccer is using the outfield of the softball and the baseball field, if we can actually get dedicated space, that would be a priority of mine."
He noted that facilities in surrounding counties should be studied.
"We've got one bite at the apple here, let's get it right," Breeding said.

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Board of Education met Thursday for the first time since hearing about massive U.S. Department of Education budget cuts.According to the Maryland Department of Education, the Department of Education informed them that they will not be receiving the $360 million that federal officials had allocated to the state.
Dorchester share of the funding cuts will be about $642,000.
This comes at a time when Dorchester County Public Schools are already struggling financially, having dealt with a $10.19 million deficit in January that forced the county to make hard decisions like cutting afterschool and summer programs.

The board approved a five-year writable contract for grades 6-12, which is critical for writing instruction and assessments tied to state standards. Board members did not renew or approve Lexia, a widely used computer-based literacy program designed to help students improve their reading skills, because of concerns and issues with its effectiveness like inaccurate data, lack of instructional alignment among teachers and staff, and its high cost.
The board will meet again in August to discuss policies regarding digital devices, AI and dress codes.

title: 'Closing gaps': TCPS data shows some literacy, math improvements
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Closing gaps': TCPS data shows some literacy, math improvements

 July 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 586
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Test score data from last school year is showing key math and English improvements for some Talbot County students, according to school officials.Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi presented data sets to the Board of Education last week. She's especially pleased with jumps for the district's Black and Hispanic students.
"We are closing gaps and moving the needle on the subgroups," Pepukayi said in an interview.
School data from the Measures of Academic Progress, or MAP, testing program shows 68% of kindergarten students scored in the 50th percentile or above in math in the 2024-2025 school year. That's up from 54% the year prior.
The percent of students, sorted by grade, meeting or exceeding that 50th percentile for the math and ELA tests mostly increased across the board. Dips were seen for third and fifth graders in ELA performance.
And in subgroups, there were many green arrows for Black and Hispanic students. For instance, both Black and Hispanic third graders saw a 31% year-to-year jump in testing at the 50th percentile mark or above in math, and a 21% year-to-year increase for that same mark in ELA.
"I'm really glad to see such improvement in the Latino and Black community. That's huge," said Board Member Deborah Bridges at the July 16 meeting.
Pepukayi attributes the hikes, in part, to improved curriculum and the dedication of Talbot County's teachers.
"I can't pinpoint to say that was it, but I think we're on the right track of students learning skills that are aligned to standards," Pepukayi said. "And we're looking at students being proficient on standards versus just getting a grade."
The tests discussed at last week's board meeting included MAP testing and the Dynamic Indicators of Basic Early Literacy Skill test. Statewide test scores typically are released in August or September.
DIBELS scores weren't drastically different from the year prior. A higher percentage of rising first and third graders tested above the literacy benchmark in 2024-2025 than 2023-2024, but second graders above the benchmark dropped by 5%.
In the MAP testing, the percent of fifth graders meeting the 50th percentile for ELA dropped by 6.6%. That decrease was mirrored by ELA drops for fifth graders in the following subgroups: Hispanic students, students with disabilities, multilingual students and students on free and reduced meals.
Data also shows this year's incoming sixth-grade class performed 4.1% worse in ELA in fifth grade than they did in fourth grade.
"Fifth graders are the kids that didn't get to finish kindergarten because of COVID," noted Board Vice President Amy Dodson.
Pepukayi said the next step is to fix those trends by focusing on the elementary-to-middle transition. She said in an interview that TCPS is vying to fill open reading and math coach positions for the middle schools — roles that have been beneficial at the elementary schools.
"That's what we're working on," Pepukayi said. "I would say that's probably the challenge, of getting our staff and finding the staff to really do the interventions needed in the middle-school levels."
She emphasized that schools are collecting data on a smaller, classroom scale in order to know what's working and what's not.
"While we still have work to do, I think we do have to celebrate the small wins," Pepukayi said.
Board President Emily Jackson thanked Pepukayi and administrators for diving deeper into the year-to-year trends.
"We have been asking for these kind of results for a long time," said Jackson, who's served on the board since 2018. "And the way that you showed up with the full transparent picture of what is happening in our schools, I think is really important."

title: Talbot, Kent see rise in student homelessness
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot, Kent see rise in student homelessness

 July 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 674
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — State numbers show youth homelessness on the rise in parts of the Eastern Shore. Local shelters aiding families and single parents are noticing similar trends.Data from the Maryland State Department of Education shows Kent and Talbot counties had the largest year-to-year increase, by percentage, of students experiencing homelessness.
In the 2022-2023 school year, Kent County reported 66 homeless students; in 2023-2024, it took a 55% jump to 102 students. Talbot County's increase rate was 39%; 233 students experienced homelessness in 2022-2023, and 324 students in 2023-2024.
Counts for 2024-2025 haven't yet been released — the most recent data was published in February — but leaders of nonprofit shelters have been seeing the increases in recent months.
"We are definitely seeing an increase in calls for families needing shelter," said Julie Lowe, executive director of Talbot Interfaith Shelter.
Last school year, Easton-based Talbot Interfaith housed 31 children, Lowe said. That's a "steady increase," she noted, though the shelter is limited on how many families it can help due to high demand, requirements for shelter residents and bedroom sizes.
Just three of Maryland's 24 districts saw a year-to-year drop in student homelessness, state data shows. The counts are collected as required by the federal McKinney-Vento Act, which ensures students experiencing homelessness receive an education.
A reason for the increase in Kent County is that school staff are better trained to identify the students defined as homeless under the McKinney-Vento Act, according to Kent County Public Schools spokesperson Dan Divilio.
"Homelessness in Kent County looks different from the common perception of someone living on the street or in a car," Divilio wrote in an email. "Unhoused students often still have a roof over their head at night, but it may belong to an extended family member or a family friend."
Divilio added that in addition to free school meals and the efforts of social workers and counselors, the district maintains partnerships with local organizations that serve families and children in need.
Talbot County Public Schools officials say the pandemic has played a role in the increased count.
"The number of students experiencing homelessness is generally a reflection of the current economic climate in the nation, state, and region," a statement from the district read. "The increase from SY 22-23 to SY 23-24, which is evident in the data for nearly all Maryland School Districts, was largely due to economic challenges faced by many families following the COVID-19 pandemic."
In Talbot, around 7% of students are homeless under the McKinney-Vento report, per state enrollment data. Nearly 6% of Kent County's 1,700-plus students experienced homelessness.
Those marks in other Eastern Shore districts like Dorchester (3.6%), Queen Anne's (2.9%) and Caroline (2.2%) are lower, but the need to help the youth still remains, nonprofit leaders say.
Stefanie Johnson, executive director of the Denton-based shelter His Hope Ministries, has seen an increase in families and single parents seeking assistance, too.
The McKinney-Vento data for Kent County doesn't come as a shock to her. And Divilio, the KCPS spokesperson, noted that the district's count for 2024-2025 is 108 children, including children enrolled K-12 and toddlers in the district's early learning programs.
"Absolutely a lot more calls coming to us from Kent County, so I'm not really surprised by that unfortunately," Johnson said.
Shelters on the Eastern Shore are moving to assist homeless youth, but helping that age range comes with its own unique set of obstacles.
Johnson said a specific challenge in the 13- to 18-year-old range is that her shelter can't take on children without some sort of guardianship or family present.
"With that 18 to 25 (age range), it's a little easier to kind of help them navigate," Johnson said.
Lowe said the Talbot Interfaith Shelter serves many single parents — some of them with two or three kids. The shelter offers life skills and job readiness assistance, as well as a transitional program for people to begin paying partial rent before being able to graduate to full payments.
But with the murky affordability of rentals in the area, Lowe said it's not always easy for families to make that transition.
"Homelessness is a housing problem," she said.

title: Lockerman High School celebrates 95th anniversary
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com

Lockerman High School celebrates 95th anniversary

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News

 DENTON — On Saturday, The Lockerman Schools Association Inc. celebrated the 95th anniversary of Lockerman High School.The celebration Saturday featured a theme of "Capturing our history, preserving our legacy and advancing our future."
Lockerman Schools Association Chairperson Willie Woods called the event "gratifying" as different generations came together to celebrate Lockerman.
"It was very gratifying to see the community continuing to just work together and come together to celebrate the rich history that Lockerman has and the role it has played in the lives of multiple generations of residents of Caroline County," Woods said.
Lockerman School started in 1930, when Isaac Thomas donated land to the Black Parent-Teachers Association for a school. In 1931, the school was named after Joseph H. Lockerman, a Black educator who was born 1862 near Denton.
The school remained Joseph H. Lockerman High School until 1966, when the school closed its doors as a Black high school and became the integrated Riverview Middle School.
The Lockerman name was restored in 1993 at a Lockerman Middle School pre-dedication ceremony, which highlighted the history of Lockerman School.
The president of the Caroline County Board of Education at the time was George W. Fisher. William D. Brown was president of the Concerned Friends of Lockerman, the forerunner of the current Lockerman Schools Association Inc.
The Lockerman Schools Association Inc. was established in 1993 as a nonprofit to engage in educational, literary or charitable activities that benefit students who have ties to any of the Lockerman Schools.
Woods described the process of planning Saturday's event as honoring the past and addressing the present.
"You sort of share the vision, the idea, brainstorm with individuals and then begin to establish It's a working plan," Woods said. "...Then we look at some things we want to recognize and honor. If you look at our theme, capturing our history what other kinds of things are happening or we're experiencing that we can bring to the forefront, so that our members and the community in general are aware and some of those were highlighted during the presentation of awards and certificates."
Members of classes 1935, 1945, 1955 and 1965 came to celebrate class anniversaries.
While some members weren't able to attend, family members or friends accepted plaques and small trophies on their behalf. Caroline County and Board of Education officials attended the anniversary event.
The Lockerman Association also presented 13 scholarships to Caroline County students pursing higher education.

New learning center in southern Maryland provides resources for children with autism

 A zip-glide, slide and shelves with toys and games welcome children with autism to play with same-aged peers at a new learning center in Waldorf.SPARKS ABA, which uses personalized therapy treatments for children with autism, serves 30 Charles County families at home or at the center, Genevieve Marshall, senior regional director at SPARKS ABA, said.
Having a location in Waldorf offers a space for families who are not always available to stay at home during sessions.
Leah Jones, a behavioral analyst at SPARKS ABA, said, the learning center opened in May for children to have an open space to learn, play games, and work on arts and crafts.
"There's a lot of natural opportunities to learn and grow and spend time with peers," Jones said.
Center-based and applied behavioral analysis-based services offer a different experience for different families, Marshall said.
Every child who comes for care is assigned to a technician for one-to-one support, Marshall said.
They also offer multi-learning instruction where children are matched with a peer or peer group. This could be circle time, like in preschools, or learning in small group interactions like sharing.
"Having that opportunity for social interaction and developing meaningful peer relationships is really important, especially at the preschool level," Marshall said.
During a child's first visit, SPARKS ABA does an initial assessment, which tells them how many hours a week a child needs to visit.
Programs aim to change the trajectory of a child's learning so they can catch up to their peers with the duration of treatment being measured in six-month increments.
"We want to try and get as many learning opportunities in as possible," Marshall said. "The goal that we have is therapy to be part of their everyday life."
Applied behavioral analysis looks at three things, Marshall said.
"Applied" considers problems or skills people have and looks for solutions based on positive teaching opportunities. SPARKS ABA takes guidance from science to inform their practice.
"Behavior" looks at things SPARKS ABA can see and measure. They focus on the individual, which includes looking at social interactions, language and navigating sensory issues.
"Analysis" evaluates data on the child to ensure the goals that were selected are changing.
"We know we're doing a good job when we've worked ourselves out of a job," Marshall said.
SPARKS ABA plans to have a Halloween-themed "Truck-or-Treat" open house on Oct. 25 from noon to 2 p.m.

 If you love to read and you love horses, there's a local rescue organization working in partnership with Calvert public schools that will give you a chance to combine those passions."I love horses," Morgan Chambers, 9, of Huntingtown said. "Horses are my happy place."
"She would rather spend every waking moment in a barn," Melissa Chambers said of her daughter's unabashed affection for the noble animals.
During an early August afternoon, Morgan, a student at Calvert Elementary, was one of several youngsters who used some summer vacation time at Freedom Hill Horse Rescue in Owings to read a book or two for the enjoyment of several of the facility's 10 retired equines.
Clutching a copy of "Harry the Dirty Dog," the nearly 70-year-old Gene Zion classic, Morgan Chambers prepared to read to Apollo, a 29-year-old quarter horse.
Although Freedom Hill has been almost the exclusive venue for the program (another facility, Traveller's Rest Farm Sanctuary in Hughesville has also hosted reading to horses events), school officials said the strategy could be used for just about any animal.
Marcy Gruver, who currently serves as Calvert County Public Schools' coordinator of Blueprint for Maryland's Future, told Southern Maryland News the local program is called "Read to the Animals." It's a similar initiative as one that was done in Baltimore County.
Calvert's Read to the Animals program is available for kindergarten to fifth-grade students.
"We've almost been fully booked every time" an event is held at the sanctuary, she said.
"The approach fosters reading fluency in a calm, supportive setting while also helping animals become more comfortable with human interaction," Gruver said. "Students also learn the value of service and compassion. Increased community presence at rescue centers can positively impact adoption rates and generate greater awareness and support for these organizations."
According to Gruver, school officials also reached out to local shelters housing dogs, cats and smaller animals, who graciously declined "due to staffing constraints and high intake numbers."
"It shows the students really caring about the animals," Melissa Huffman, supervisor of elementary English language arts, said.
"We're trying to do more outreach within the community," Beth Meader, the secretary of the Freedom Hill Horse Rescue board said. Of the Read to the Animals program, she added, "It's a win-win for the children."
"The kids seem to enjoy it and the horses seem to enjoy it," Lori Harrington, Freedom Hill's board president, said.
In its mission statement, the nonprofit's members affirm their dedication to "rescuing horses from neglect, abuse, abandonment and slaughter. We strive to improve the lives of horses by providing a haven for healing and rehabilitation."
Founded 21 years ago, Freedom Hill Horse Rescue is located on the grounds of historic Hampton Manor.
Reaching out to youth and adult organizations, Harrington said, has become a major focus at Freedom Hill. In addition to public schools, the organization also partners with homeschool groups, Scouts, first responders and veterans organizations.
Freedom hill hosts "about two or three programs a month," Harrington said, adding that no programs are held during cold weather months.
Meader said there is hope the reading initiative might inspire some of the participants to consider volunteering when they are older. A Freedom Hill volunteer must be 13 or older.
Gruver said Meader and the other volunteers at Freedom Hill "have gone above and beyond to prepare the horses for student visits."

Backpack fair provides hundreds of kids with school supplies

 August 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 385
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Hundreds of backpacks stuffed with school supplies were handed to families Wednesday ahead of the first day of school Monday.For All Seasons hosted its annual School Supplies Giveaway and Resource Fair at Easton Middle School, moved indoors from Idlewild Park due to rain. The turnout, though, remained steady. Kids picked up supplies, played indoor games like cornhole and enjoyed free snow cones.
Carly Palmer, For All Seasons' outreach coordinator, said 800 backpacks were prepared for the event with help from the Talbot County Department of Social Services.
Those that weren't given away Wednesday will be delivered to local schools, Palmer said.
She added that the resource fair helps equip families with a stock of supplies even if they already went school shopping earlier in the summer.
"At the start of the school year, you may have some school supplies," she said. "But they need that care throughout the year as well. This is just to really get them started."
Over 25 community organizations and partners set up tables inside Easton Middle's gymnasium to give out free supplies and resources. The Talbot County Free Library brought more than 400 cartons of colored pencils, while Eastpoint Church provided kids with drawstring bags filled with notebooks, markers and more.
For All Seasons CEO Beth Anne Dorman said the supply giveaway checks one thing off the list that can often make parents stress in the build-up to school. And it makes students more confident walking in on day one, she said.
"The child can walk in knowing that it's one thing that they're prepared for," Dorman said.
In addition to supplies, Dorman said For All Seasons assists children who are experiencing stress due to school starting up. This time of year, the organization sees an uptick in mental health requests from students, Dorman said.
"The transition is difficult, especially for kids who are new to a school or kids who are transitioning into one school or another," she said.
Especially for low-income children, the supply giveaway is a chance to build community, Dorman and Palmer both said.
"Children who don't have maybe what other kids have understand they're not alone," Dorman said.
"Folks identify it as a safe space," she said of the event. "That's the beautiful thing about not only what we're doing with the school supplies, but having all of our partners in the community together."

title: As students return, Chapel District Elementary begins next phase of renovations
author: Konner Metz
content:
As students return, Chapel District Elementary begins next phase of renovations

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 513
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CORDOVA — Renovations at Chapel District Elementary School are well underway as the school prepares to welcome students next week.This summer, construction teams completed the second phase of the project, which includes the school cafeteria and some classrooms. Talbot County Public Schools Director of Operations Kevin Shafer updated the Board of Education on the project at a work session on Monday.
"We did squeeze a lot of work into a very small amount of time, which was a bit risky," Shafer said. "But the team has pulled it together, and things look fairly good."
As crews worked inside and around the building, teacher and staff moved in for the school year earlier this week.
"Staff returned today and it was very smooth according to (Principal Kari) Clow," Shafer said Monday.
The renovation is a multimillion-dollar effort that includes around $27 million in county funding as well as state funds from Maryland's Interagency Commission on School Construction. Construction is led by the Whiting-Turner Contracting Company.
The project is fully renovating the existing building, adding around 16,000 square feet. The Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers site located in the building was redone as part of phase one. Construction is expected to finish in 2026.
Chapel District Elementary is one of five elementary schools in the district. It was built in 1952 and last renovated in 1994.
Shafer acknowledged a few concessions had to be made in order for the school to welcome students back in time. Some hallway flooring hasn't been replaced, but he said it will still be safe in the meantime.
The school's gym won't be ready on the first day, either. It should reopen by the end of September, Shafer said. For now, PE will be held outside or in select classrooms.
Furniture for the first two phases arrived on time, Shafer said. The district had to rework its furniture plan, placing orders this spring before tariffs took effect and drove up prices, Shafer told board members at previous meetings.
Furniture for the third phase was ordered at the same time and is being kept in warehouses by the supplier at no cost to the district, Shafer said.
Drivers passing the elementary school on Cordova Road will likely see significant construction work obstructing the front of the building. That's the third phase of construction, which includes renovations to the administrative offices and some classrooms. A new media center is also being added to the school.
A temporary front office is located at the back of the building where the Critchlow Adkins Children's Center is located, according to a recent school newsletter. Parking will remain limited during construction.
"By the time students come next week, everything should be in good order," Shafer said on Monday.
On Thursday, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi shouted out Chapel District Elementary administrators, teachers and staff.
"They are going to be teaching through the sounds of loud noises, construction, dust," Pepukayi said. "They packed up their rooms at the end of the year. They just unpacked their rooms this year. And they are still managing to assemble classrooms to be ready for our students to walk through the door on Monday."

title: Dorchester schools seek to curb student violence
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester schools seek to curb student violence

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 532
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — This summer, North Dorchester High School became the first school to pilot Risk Threat Crisis' Violence Prevention Initiative.The proposed initiative comes at a time when students in Dorchester County saw 1,682 long- and short-term suspensions in the last school year with 1,232 of those suspensions related to violence, according to Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson.
"The numbers can fluctuate a bit from year to year; however, the main issue is that numerous violent acts occur within our school district, and we have to figure out a way to combat the violence," Thompson wrote in an email to the Star Democrat.
Thompson and founders of the initiative, Rebecca Redmer and Phil Whitelock, met with Cambridge City Commissioners on Aug. 11. The group requested funding to launch a Violence Prevention Initiative course within the school system for students, parents, guardians, teachers and staff.
"For this to be successful in our community, or in any community, it has to be a multi-tiered approach because you can't teach one sector without teaching the other when they're all working together," Redmer said at the meeting.
Redmer said the pilot program hosted at North Dorchester High School garnered great student feedback. School officials, Redmer and Whitelock are prepared to start the courses in September but are currently being held back by financial constraints.
This comes at a time when Dorchester County Public Schools are already struggling financially, having dealt with a $10.19 million deficit in January that forced the county to make hard decisions like cutting after-school and summer programs.
"We are in the process of searching for more funders to assist with this program," Thompson wrote. "We are looking for multiple funding streams, including grants, philanthropists and other organizations."
Whitelock said private investors and foundations can make tax-deductible donations through Redmer's nonprofit, Someone to Walk With.
Whitelock, who wrote a book on violence prevention last year, said they will begin the courses in Dorchester County starting in September regardless of their fiscal status.
Currently, the program focuses on Cambridge-South Dorchester High School and Mace's Lane Middle School, where the majority of the suspensions from the previous year came from.
The goals of the program are to reduce youth violence and behavioral disruptions; to strengthen communication, problem solving and conflict resolution; and to build collaboration among schools, communities and corrections.
"One of the biggest concepts of the book is that violence is just a way people communicate," Whitelock said.
For Whitelock, prevention-focused education and training, rather than response-oriented approaches, are necessary. He said it is important that the burden is not all on the students.
"We want parents to go through the course as well, because we want you to know what we're teaching your kids, and we want you to be involved and helping to emphasize positive habits and positive reinforcement," Whitelock said.
Whitelock, Thompson and Redmer want the initiative to extend outside of the schools as well, emphasizing the importance of a community approach. Redmer described this as "the termite takeover" approach: slow but effective.
"Cambridge faces some of the same issues found in larger metropolitan areas that impact the school setting," Thompson wrote. "That is why this must be a collective effort involving the entire community to help reduce the violence that affects our schools."

title: If we want reading success, we need to invest
author: TRISH BRENNAN-GAC
content:
If we want reading success, we need to invest

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TRISH BRENNAN-GAC | Section: Columns 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland is about to see how well we are addressing the reading crisis that has plagued our state since 2013 when NAEP test scores began a decadelong decline.Test scores are lagging indicators — by the time they drop, years of missed investments are already behind us. That means that the 2025 MCAP test scores, scheduled for release on Tuesday, are likely to reflect a mix of old decisions and new strategies but will not fully reflect the bold policies now on paper.
The central question is: Has our state done enough to expect dramatic improvement? Unfortunately, our answer is no.
In 2023, the state Board of Education took an important step forward by adopting a reading resolution and recruiting Carey Wright as state superintendent. Wright has worked with urgency to establish the frameworks and infrastructure needed for real change: creating a pre-K–3 Literacy Policy, revising standards, launching a process to update assessments and, most critically, building a statewide coaching model to help teachers transform instruction in line with the science of reading.
But policies without resources do not change outcomes.
Since taking office less than two years ago, Wright has secured:
$40 million over five years from the U.S. Department of Education$6.8 million from the IBIS Group for Science of Reading trainingOver $3 million in private funding for a statewide literacy coaching program
That is nearly $50 million in federal and private funds — a lifeline for Maryland's reading agenda. But these investments are time-limited and unsustainable. We need to sustain this early investment with a permanent dedicated state commitment.
Implementation of the Pre-K Literacy Policy is beginning with clear expectations for how local education agencies should deliver literacy instruction and steps they must take to help struggling children. Teachers now have access to no cost training in the Science of Reading. But coaching is a necessary component to help teachers apply what they have learned so that our children receive the maximum benefits of their reading instruction.
If we want the kind of results Mississippi achieved, we need the kind of investments Mississippi made. When Wright led the Mississippi Department of Education, the legislature passed the Literacy-Based Promotion Act, which dedicated roughly $15 million annually — just 0.2% of the state's budget — to literacy coaching and support. That investment powered Mississippi's dramatic gains.
By contrast, in Maryland, Wright asked the General Assembly to fund a statewide coaching program. The Excellence in Schools Act authorized a school leadership training program that included "a research-based model for coaching school leaders and 25 instructional coaches." Yet the Legislature appropriated zero dollars for implementation.
Meanwhile, the only state program we can identify that directly supports reading — the funds for Targeted Support and Improvement — is expiring.
The message is clear: Maryland cannot coach its way out of this crisis on outside dollars. Federal and philanthropic grants cannot replace state commitment.
If Maryland is serious about a reading comeback, the state must do more than hire the right superintendent. Our legislature must invest real, sustained resources in literacy — just as Mississippi did.
It's time for the Maryland legislature to step up and fund a reading agenda worthy of our children's potential.

title: Talbot County students return to school
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County students return to school

 August 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Students at the Talbot County's eight public schools returned to classrooms Monday, getting an earlier start compared to other districts that begin after the Labor Day weekend.In St. Michaels, a crossing guard stood on S. Talbot Street, directing drivers toward the St. Michaels Elementary School entrance. Car drop-off was relatively smooth, and all the buses arrived on time.
St. Michaels Elementary Principal Indra Bullock greeted families at the car drop-off starting at 7:30 a.m., while teachers showed kids the way to the front door. Some students walked in with smiles, while others were emotional for the first day.
Dan Schwartz dropped off his two kids, Henry and Eddie. Henry started kindergarten Monday, and Eddie started pre-K at the Critchlow Adkins Children's Center facility within the school building. The boys were excited for the upcoming school year, Schwartz said.
"I think they're just excited to meet new friends and get to know their teachers and the new school," Schwartz said. "Eddie's excited to play, and Henry's just excited to learn."
Schwartz, from Royal Oak, said his kids previously went to daycare in Cambridge. He's looking forward to their start at a new school.
"It's been a bit more of a schlep," he said of the commute to Cambridge. "Now they're just excited to be going to school close to home."
"We're really, really happy to be in this school district," Schwartz added. "We're excited, and have a lot of friends who had their kids in St. Michaels schools and have had a really good experience."
ON THE HORIZON
Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said on Monday that the district's cell phone pouch policy will be implemented in the fall for St. Michaels Middle School students. The policy requires students to lock their phones in pouches during the school day in hopes that academic achievement and student engagement will both rise.
The pouch program was piloted last year at Easton Middle School. "So far, so good," Pepukayi said of Easton Middle's cell phone rules.
St. Michaels Middle will begin to roll out expectations for the cell phone pouch policy before implementation around October, Pepukayi said.
Meanwhile, teachers across the district will have a new policy to adhere to later this year: emergency lanyards. The lanyards will have buttons for staff to request help to their precise location during an emergency.
The superintendent said the lanyards, from the company Centegix, will also be a "slow roll out."
"It's just one more layer, not just for students, but also staff," Pepukayi said earlier this summer.

title: State test scores: Mid-Shore school districts see mixed results
author: Konner Metz
content:
State test scores: Mid-Shore school districts see mixed results

 August 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Department of Education released English and math test scores Aug. 26, revealing a major jump for one Mid-Shore school district and mixed results for others.Test results from the 2024-2025 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program, or MCAP, show that statewide, students made slight gains in both subjects. English proficiency is at 50.8%, up from 48.4% the previous year. Math proficiency is at 26.5%, up from 24.1% last year.
The Mid-Shore's five counties — Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot — didn't always follow those state trends.
In English, Dorchester County outpaced all other counties in year-to-year gains. Dorchester's English proficiency saw the largest increase statewide — up 7.6% to a 41.3% proficiency rate, which ranks Dorchester 19th of 24 districts.
Dorchester Superintendent Jymil Thompson said in a press release that the improvement is a sign the district's work to climb the state rankings is paying off.
"These results show that belief leads to action — and action leads to results," Thompson said. " ... Today, we can proudly say Dorchester is on the rise."
Caroline tied for the fifth highest year-to-year improvement in English proficiency at 3.5%. The district's new English proficiency rate of 49% now ranks it 14th in the state.
Meanwhile, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties were three of only four districts in Maryland with lower English proficiency rates than last year.
Queen Anne's is still above the state average at 57% proficient, ranking ninth despite a 1.5% drop. Kent dropped 0.5% to 40.7% proficiency, ranking the district 20th statewide.
Talbot is 16th in the state with a 45.4% proficiency rate after a 1.9% year-to-year decrease, the largest decrease in the state. In a statement, Talbot County Public Schools Director of Communications Debbie Gardner said the district is in the process of analyzing MCAP data and will make a presentation to the Board of Education in September.
PROGRESS IN MATH
All 23 counties and Baltimore City are seeing progress in math. No district decreased in its math score from 2023-2024, and over a quarter of Maryland students are proficient in the subject.
Dorchester, again, saw the biggest hike of the Mid-Shore counties at 4.1%. The county is still just 20th statewide at 16.4% proficient. Kent follows at 21st with a 16.3% rate, up 3.7% from last year.
Kent County Superintendent Mary Boswell-McComas said in a statement that the district has worked on professionally developing school principals in math.
"We're seeing the payoff in how our principals coached teachers in developing students' mathematical reasoning and how our teachers incorporated that in their classrooms," the statement read.
Queen Anne's remains the Mid-Shore county most proficient in math at 31.6%, a 2.9% hike from one year ago. The district ranks eighth in the state.
Caroline jumped 2.5% to hit 22.2% proficiency, which ranks the district 15th.
Caroline Superintendent Derek Simmons wrote in a statement that he's "very encouraged" to see the district's growth rate outpace the state's.
"Our sustained focus on what matters, and consistency around evidence-based approaches will continue our growth," Simmons wrote.
Talbot math proficiency remained almost even, going up 0.6% to 18.9% this year. The district ranks 18th in proficiency. Only two other districts had year-to-year changes worse than Talbot.
UP AND DOWN IN SCIENCE
Proficiency rates from the fifth and eighth grade science tests show Queen Anne's schools are well above the rest of the five Mid-Shore counties. In fifth grade, Queen Anne's is 10th of 24 districts with 29.3% proficiency, according to data on the Maryland Report Card.
But Talbot saw the state's second-highest yearly increase, climbing 5.9% to 22.8% and 15th overall.
Kent comes in at 16th in fifth grade science at 20.9%. Caroline is 18th with 19% and Dorchester is 20th with 17.4%.
In eighth grade science, Queen Anne's lost its first-place ranking from last year as other districts made significant jumps. But the county is still third in the state at 44.3%, down slightly from last year.
Caroline's eighth graders were 16th in the state at 23.8%, a 4.5% jump. Dorchester increased by 4.6% to 19.9% proficiency, landing it at 18th.
Talbot tied with Queen Anne's for the worst year-to-year change at -0.8%. It is ranked 19th now with 19.3% of eighth graders proficient on the science test.
Kent comes in at 16.8% proficiency, up from 13.4% last year.ENGLISH SCORES

title: Cellphone pouches are back in Caroline County middle schools
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Cellphone pouches are back in Caroline County middle schools

 August 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 352
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County Public Schools will be bringing back cellphone pouches in middle schools for the second year.Cellphone pouches were introduced in the 2024-25 school year as a pilot program aimed at keeping students off their phones. Students carry locked pouches during the entire school day, with their phones inside and not accessible.
Each student has their own pouch, which travels with them daily from home to school. Phones are locked into the pouches at the beginning of the school day and unlocked at the end using a magnetic device. If a student leaves the pouch at home, they put their phone in the school office for the day.
According to CCPS, year one of the pilot program was a success.
"We saw it was a good first year with it," said Caroline County Superintendent Derek Simmons.
"The recommendation ... the board accepted was to give it another year at our middle schools. One year does not mean a trend. We saw good good results, but we want to track it for another year before we make any determinations about if we were to move it forward to the high school level."
The cellphone pouches were created by the company Yondr and were tested in both Caroline County middle schools last school year.
During the June Caroline County Board of Education meeting, district staff presented statistics for the school year. Compared to the year prior, CCPS saw 30.6% fewer referrals last school year, with 130 fewer attacks, threats or fights and about 200 fewer instances of disrespect and disruptions.
According to Simmons, student and parents have been receptive of the cellphone pouches.
"Last year it was minimal resistance," Simmons said. "You bring in something new, people are going to have some concern. They ask questions, administrators at the building level handle the questions really well. By and large, everything went well with compliance. It's funny, we've had hardly any asks this year going in the middle because it just has become the expectation."
After one more school year at the middle school level, CCPS will revisit the topic and potentially incorporate the cellphone pouches to the high school level.

title: Dorchester schools climb in state rankings after first year of ambitious reform plan
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester schools climb in state rankings after first year of ambitious reform plan

 August 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 509
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last year, Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson set out on a mission to change the school district's current ranking of 23rd out of 24 in the overall Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program evaluations. A year later, the results are in, and they look promising.The "23, no more" initiative is a three-year plan to move DCPS from the 23rd spot to 15th. Testing data released by the state this week shows the county has successfully moved up two spots overall, and it improved from 23rd to 19th in English Learning Arts proficiency.
While DCPS' climb in the rankings may not be massive, district leaders say it shows notable progress.
"So we looked at the numbers as to what it would take for us to get to the middle of the pack, and we said, 'Okay, 15. If we move this amount of kids every year, we can at least get to 15. And then if we go higher than 15, that will be just added bonus,'" Thompson said.
The superintendent said key strategies to get to 15 include setting a clear vision, conducting quarterly walkthroughs, focusing on instruction, rallying the team around a goal, supporting teachers, differentiating learning, simplifying processes and putting structures and systems in place.
The district's strategic plan, called "Believe in Us," guides these efforts and emphasizes core values such as joy, putting children first and accountability. This plan has four key priorities: advance academics, optimize operations, pursue partnerships and cultivate conversations.
For Thompson, it is crucial that the community outside of the school system is involved in this process for it to work.
"I think that education is a community issue because I don't think there will be one person that would say that they don't want kids to be educated," Thompson said. "That's the emphasis, that's the nucleus, right there. Everyone wants kids to be educated, so it's everyone's responsibility to ensure that the kids are being educated, not just the school system."
Thompson hopes the school system can act as a catalyst for countywide transformation through incremental progress and innovation.
Efforts are underway to recruit more certified teachers and administrators to improve the attractiveness of Dorchester County Public Schools to parents and families in the area.
Though these early results are promising, Thompson knows there will still be challenges to accomplish his ambitious goal. He said these do not deter him. "There's no challenges that I don't think we can overcome as a district and community working collectively together that can be a hindrance for us to move to 15," he said.
As long as community members are willing to come up with creative solutions, Thompson firmly believes that there is no challenge they won't be able to overcome.
"We're not turning anybody away and we want everyone to be involved in the process because I think at the end of the three year journey, I think people will be happy about our progress as a school system," Thompson said. "But I don't want them to be happy as innocent bystanders. I want them to be happy as active participants in the process."

title: Country Cooking: Welcome back to school and school lunches
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Welcome back to school and school lunches

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 School bells ringing, doors open, buses pulling up, teachers and other staff waiting for the students to walk the path to enter the building. Over in the "car riders" lane, the parents are assured the kids will have a great day.This all seems familiar, doesn't it? No matter how old your children, grandchildren, great grandchildren or other children may be, this scenario has occurred for decades.
Watching the children in their new school attire, including new shoes, reminds me of my young elementary school days back in Bishopville. On the first day of school, we were waiting for the bus quite uncomfortable in new clothes with the tags freshly cut off. Posture was not a problem — store starch was even worse than Mom's cooked starch. Y'all remember that Argo starch mess.
In a future column, I will include "them new stiff school shoes."
Now, to the lunch boxes. Breakfast was very important on a school morning because the next meal seemed to be "hours" away if you had nothing for breakfast. On a winter morning, there was always a freshly cooked pot of oatmeal or cream of wheat.
If we got up early enough, there could be scrambled eggs, and scrapple or sausage, and/or toast. Suddenly the yell came — "Bus is coming." We grabbed the lunch boxes and out the door we flew.
We all had the same packed lunch so you could not grab the wrong one.
Then came the '60s with those special lunch boxes — Roy Rogers, Lone Ranger, Hop-Along-Cassidy, Cinderella, Alice in Wonderland and many more. My late younger brother would tell you the boxes were made from metal and tin — because I would hit him with mine, so he really did know.
A great occurrence has happened with school lunches — most counties have free school lunches for all students regardless of income. This was long overdue, as buying lunch foods to pack is expensive.
However, many of us have that child or grandchild who insists on a packed lunch. Let us explore foods that are convenient and not very expensive to purchase.
Walking through the grocery store, I see such a variety of foods that kids love. Let's go back to the '50s lunch box and see what we find — a sour pickle wrapped in foil, chunks of sharp cheddar cheese, several crackers — white or Ritz, a bologna and cheese sandwich, leftover chicken wings or legs from supper the night before, or the popular peanut butter and jelly sandwich.
Then comes my children going to school in the 1970s and 1980s. School cafeterias had changed greatly by this time. In middle school, there was a jukebox, round tables as well as the long style, and a "huge" change in school food. Some lunches were spaghetti with meatballs, garlic bread and a salad. There were submarines with small bags of chips, and the ever popular "a la carte" foods. You could purchase candy bars, ice cream, individual sandwiches and add a bowl of soup. Lunch boxes turned into lunch bags or insulated bags. The change was good — and the staff size grew immensely.
At this point, I need to say "hat's off" to the food staff in every school district in every state. Your jobs are very necessary to help the school day be enjoyable for everyone.
Packed lunches in the '80s and '90s included foods like beef jerky, cheese sticks, hot chips and pop-top cans of soups. Lunch had very few sandwiches, as students would buy lunch on "pizza days" and "taco days."
Schools started serving breakfast, lunch and afternoon snacks. What a wonderful addition to our school systems for our most precious and valuable assets to our country.
Now, we are exploring school lunches from 2000 to 2025. There seems to have been a rise in allergens such as peanuts, gluten and dairy in 2025 that makes it more difficult to get a big variety of food on the menus. Most schools are now offering two or three different lunch choices and that ever so popular a la carte menu.
As I close this column today, I realize going back in time brings back so many memories of my school years. Some mornings are calm; others feel like a race against the clock. On the busiest days, a few shortcuts keep me sane. I keep a "lunchbox basket" in the pantry filled with pre-portioned snacks like trail mix, whole grain crackers, or fruit leather, so I can grab and pack without digging. In the fridge, washed and sliced produce goes into small containers or bento compartments right after grocery shopping, so it's ready to drop into the lunchbox.
A community park is now in the spot where Bishopville Elementary School once stood. The playground area is still there, thankfully. As I look at where the school once stood, I am flooded with memories. No matter what type of lunch bag or box you carried. No matter what kind of biscuit or bread you used and no matter what kind of filling was on that sandwich — we were all the same children from a small town.
Let's see what is on the menu for packed lunch. Here are a few recipes from my back-to-school column last year.
BBQ CHICKEN CUPS
1 roll of Pillsbury Grands biscuits (usually the Southern style works best but you can use any flavor your child likes), 3 lbs chicken breast, 1 cup chicken broth, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp pepper, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp onion powder, barbecue sauce.
Place chicken breasts in the bottom of the crockpot. Pour chicken broth and seasonings over chicken. Cook on low for 6-8 hours or high for 3-4 hours. Remove chicken from the crockpot and shred with two forks. Mix with your favorite barbecue or hot sauce. Bake the biscuits according to directions, then immediately when they are done tear a biscuit in half and flatten it, place it into a muffin tin, top with chicken and shredded cheese, and bake at 350 degrees for 15-20 minutes.
PB&J APPLES
2 apples, 1/4 cup peanut butter, 1/4 cup jelly.
Slice apples into ¼-inch rounds. Use a small cookie cutter to cut the core from the center of each slice. Spread peanut butter on jelly on half of the slices then cover with the remaining halves. This is one that you'll want to make in the morning so the apples don't brown overnight.
PB&J SUSHI
4 slices white bread, 1/2 cup smooth peanut butter, 1/2 cup grape jelly.
Remove crusts from bread. Using a rolling pin, roll bread until very flat. Spread with peanut butter and jelly and roll tightly. Cut into 2-inch pieces and serve.
PICKLE ROLL UPS
4 slices of your child's favorite lunch meat, mustard or mayo, cheese, pickle wedge.
Spread mustard or mayo on the slices of meat, layer some cheese then another layer of meat. Roll a pickle wedge up and pack tight. You can use any variety of meat, cheese or condiments in this dish.
TURKEY CLUB ROLL UPS
4 slices deli turkey, 2 tsp mayo, 2 slices cheddar (halved or quartered), 1/2 cup shredded or chopped lettuce, 1/2 tomato (sliced), 1/4 red onion (thinly sliced), 1/2 avocado (sliced), 4 slices cooked bacon, kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper.
On a clean work surface, place two slices of deli turkey and spread a thin layer of mayo on top. Top with 1 slice cheddar, half of the lettuce, tomato, red onion and avocado, and 2 slices bacon. Season generously with salt and pepper. Roll up and secure with a toothpick, then repeat with remaining ingredients.
GRILLED CHEESE ROLL UPS
8 thick slices of soft white bread, 1.5 cups finely grated cheddar, 2 tbsp melted butter.
One by one, slice the crusts off of each slice of bread, then use a rolling pin to flatten. Add a pinch of cheese to each slice, making sure you leave a small strip at the end to brush with butter. Tightly but carefully roll up each slice to the end, brush with butter, then roll shut and place seam-side-down. Brush all over with butter. Add roll ups to a dry pan seam-side-down over low-medium heat and fry until golden all over with the cheese starting to leak out. Use your tongs to frequently turn them. You may need to do this in two batches depending on the size of your pan.
NUTELLA BANANA SUSHI
This recipe is by the single serving, so repeat as many times as you need.
Nutella, 1 banana, 1 whole wheat wrap.
Lay your wrap on a breadboard and slather with Nutella, Place the banana on top of your chocolate coating, Roll the wrap as you would sushi or a burrito and carefully slice into rolls.
