title: Gen Z’s lessons on Sept. 11: A generation raised in its shadow calls for deeper lessons
author: ADDISON NOGAR
content:
Gen Z’s lessons on Sept. 11: A generation raised in its shadow calls for deeper lessons

 September 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ADDISON NOGAR | Section: News 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Addison Nogar is a junior at Kent Island High School and contributing writer this semester.In high school today, Sept. 11 is not often taught in detail. Some history teachers mention it briefly, but rarely explore the full impact.
Growing up in the shadow of Sept. 11, piecing together fragmented narratives from stories, documentaries and secondhand accounts, I never fully grasped the enormity of that day until I stood at the 9/11 Memorial — a member of the generation that inherited its aftermath.
My first realization of the tragedy came while eating dinner in 2013. My mom turned on the movie World Trade Center. The graphic image of a man dying under debris was the first thing I saw. I watched the entire film but never again. For years, I looked for it to come on again, but the only outlets covering Sept. 11 were news sources. After that, every year I hoped to learn and hear more stories and perspectives from that day.
The one lesson that stayed with me came from my fifth grade teacher. Most people aren't aware of the story of the Red Bandana Man. I wasn't either until she played a video. Welles Crowther, a 24-year-old volunteer firefighter, lost his life that day. He had played lacrosse at Boston College while studying economics, later finding a job in the South Tower of the World Trade Center.
He wore a red bandana under his helmet while playing lacrosse, a gift from his father when he was younger. Crowther saved more than 18 lives on the seventh floor, carrying injured people down the stairs. He covered their faces with the red bandana to help them breathe through the smoke.
Crowther made one more trip into the building before it collapsed. He never made it back out. Today he is remembered as the Red Bandana Man — a symbol of courage, compassion and selflessness. Thank you to my fifth grade teacher for sharing his inspiring and heroic act.
On April 22, 2023, I visited the National September 11 Memorial and Museum. Reflecting on the names etched on the wall and the site where the twin structures once stood, it was surreal to grasp the transformation over the past two decades.
I took a 90-minute tour of the museum and memorial. The indoor and outdoor experience examined what happened on Sept. 11, explored the history and rebuilding of the site, and highlighted the stories of those affected by the attacks.
The most memorable part was the Survivor Tree — a Callery pear tree that survived the attacks. Severely damaged, it was discovered at ground zero and later removed by the New York City Department. After recovery, the tree returned to the memorial in 2010. New smooth limbs grew from the stumps, showing the connection between the tree's past and present. It now stands as a living reminder of resilience, survival and rebirth.
Sept. 11 deserves our deepest respect and appreciation. Now that we're old enough to grasp the tragedy more fully, it's fitting for teachers to dedicate time to discuss it — sharing narratives from that day and honoring the moment of silence it has earned.

 EASTON — High school students squared off in the inaugural Mid-Shore Constitution Bowl on Saturday, putting their knowledge about one of the nation's framework documents to the test.Hosted by the Mid-Shore Constitution Alliance at the Talbot County Free Library, five high schools from around the area entered: Easton and North Caroline in the large division; and St. Michaels, Sts. Peter & Paul and The Gunston School in the small division.
Students from Easton and St. Michaels claimed victory in the hard-fought matches, tackling questions on the amendments, Congress, government-related vocabulary and more.
In a close race in the small division, St. Michaels erased a 10-point deficit by correctly answering the last prompt of the contest: a question on the 20th Amendment, also known as the Lame Duck Amendment, which moved term start dates for the president, vice president and members of Congress up to January.
"We just wanted to represent our school, prove that we were the best," senior Sebastian Cornish said.
The four St. Michaels students attributed their victory to James Kunz, their former AP Government teacher. They said taking his AP class two years ago prepared them for the competition. Some last-minute practice during lunch this year helped, too.
"He let us know about it briefly last year, and it came up again at the beginning of the school year, and we were like, 'We're all still down to do it,'" senior Tyler Murphy said.
Kunz and other teachers, along with family and friends, watched from the crowd in what became an especially competitive environment inside the library's side room.
Students hovered their hands over the answer bell as questions were read aloud in a race to acquire as many points as possible. Wrong answers resulted in deductions.
Easton High School's Constitution Bowl team took down North Caroline High School in Saturday's first match. By scoring the most points across both divisions, Easton High secured the grand prize, which included a plaque and a copy of the U.S. Constitution. The event was hosted by the Mid-Shore Constitution Alliance — led by Richard Holman, Michelle Ewing and Julie Quick — in conjunction with the Colonel Tench Tilghman Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution. It capped off a string of events held during Constitution Week from Sept. 14 to 20.

Members of the winning St. Michaels team said they encourage younger students to participate in the future or learn more about the Constitution itself.
"Even if they don't really know about it, I'd encourage them to come watch," senior Brody McDaniel said. "It teaches them a lot about government and the Constitution."

title: Queen Anne's denies charter school application
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's denies charter school application

 September 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 896
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — In a 3-2 vote, the Queen Anne's County Public Schools Board of Education voted to uphold the superintendent's recommendation and deny application for what would have been the first classical charter school in Queen Anne's County Sept. 10.Presenting a final report and an overview of the Queen Anne's County Public Schools Charter School Application Review Committee process, charter school liaison and supervisor of instruction Micheal Bell said the committee recommended denial of the Queen Anne's County Classical Charter School application Sept. 3, "due to significant and substantiated deficiencies in academic planning, operational capacity, and demonstrated need."
According to Bell, "the application lacked evidence of innovation, financial and governance readiness, and failed to articulate how it would meet the diverse needs of Queen Anne's County students."
The extensive review process is aligned with Maryland Charter Law, the Code of Maryland Regulations, and precedents established through the Maryland State Board of Education guidance, he said.
Noting the district had not received the in-depth responses necessary, Interim Superintendent Matthew Kibler's recommendation mirrored the Committees citing "major gaps remained despite multiple opportunities to cure deficiencies," including: insufficient evidence of operational readiness, staffing, and facility acquisition planning; a pre-K program plan that is not feasible without Maryland Accreditation and EXCELS Level 4 status; financial assumptions that lack contingency planning for enrollment shortfalls, grant delays, or facility overruns; limited and underdeveloped plans for serving students with disabilities, English learners, and other student groups and an instructional program that remains underdeveloped and not adequately aligned with Maryland College and Career Ready Standards.
The committee acknowledged the charter school's group enthusiasm for the classical charter model, timely responsiveness in communication, and a strong commitment to the idea of school choice, Bell said.
"But the team also noted authorizing a charter school is not simply about approving an idea, it's about assuming full responsibility for students, staff, and the community under our umbrella," Bell said, a level of responsibility that requires readiness, compliance, and sustainability, "none of which were determined to be sufficiently demonstrated within their application."
Following the turbulent meeting Sept. 3 filled with heated discussions in the face of the application's proposed denial, the Queen Anne's County Classical Charter School group returned to the Board Sept 10. to present answer questions and allow for an in depth application review for the Board's decision.
Lead by a Board of Directors with expertise of former teachers and education professionals, the motivation to establish the classical charter school arose to provide options to parents and enhance the current system upon seeing current dropping proficiency rates, founder Audrey Scott said.
Charter Committee Board of Directors President Ashley MacLeay noted that although seeking autonomy through waivers, the proposed classical charter school would ultimately be a public school part of the QACPS system that the Board of Education would oversee.
Student enrollment would be based on a lottery system.
The charter committee claimed it was not afforded opportunities for collaboration and was provided little assistance in certain application aspects, like identifying facilities.
If approved by the Board of Education, the charter school would continually seek collaboration with QACPS in establishing a charter agreement, as "one holistic school system," she said.
To start, the charter school would need six teachers and has already received far more resumes than that of interested teachers, Scott said.
The group claimed interest has been overwhelmingly positive from the community including partners like the Giving the Edge Foundation and letters of support from the Queen Anne's County Commissioners.
While not initiated yet, the committee received support from the county to direct mail to every county home to serve as a first general introduction to parents, Scott said.
While letters of support have been received from the community overall, the QACPS Board of Education questioned student sustainability and a "demonstration of need" and claimed a lack of parent voices interested in enrolling students.
Charter committee officials stated they have personally spoken to multiple families in full support of the program, just without time to write letters of support or a hesitancy to speak up at Board meetings.
With a potential program so monumental looming for the county, Board of Education member Mathew Drayer questioned how parents couldn't find the time to voice their support.
A broad petition of county residents as well as outside of the county collected "well over two hundred signatures," that included parents, MacLeay said.
Although limited with polling data, the committee said it was happy to perform more surveys and was confident in the need.
The charter committee would ensure future marketing to all 8,000 students across the county's districts, Targeting families with elementary age children including homeschooled, the charter school would welcome reaching where families are, including libraries for an active presence and share what the potential school would entail, MacLeay said.
"We are trying to ensure we have viable schools with the right teachers and support and staff and everything they need to be successful," Board of Education President Shannon Bent said, and needed to hear from the community if there were additional needs to address.
Scott credited the above and beyond thoroughness forth by QACPS staff and Board of Education in reviewing the application.
"We are all in this for the children," Kibler said, and encouraged the committee to strengthen their application and resubmit next year.
The applicant retains the right to appeal to the Maryland State Board of Education or to resubmit during the next application window.
The QACPS Board of Education will next meet Oct 1. at 6 p.m.

title: Caroline County officials learn about Early Head Start cut
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com

Caroline County officials learn about Early Head Start cut

 DENTON — On Tuesday, Charles Huester, executive director for Maryland Rural Development Cooperation, discussed Early Head Start funding cuts with the Caroline County Commissioners.MRDC, which runs the Early Head Start programs in Caroline and Cecil counties, announced on Aug. 27 that the Early Head Start program would be ending effective Sept. 2 after it did not receive funding from the Office of Head Start.
The free program supports pregnant women and young children's learning and development.
Huester said they were surprised to hear the program did not receive the necessary funds given that that the MRDC hasn't officially heard back from Office of Head Start about its grant application. Huester said their competitors for the funding told them they didn't receive the grant.
"I'm not really sure the practice of Office of Head Start not replying to anyone. We found out through a third party, direct competitor for funding actually. Maryland Family Network let us know what was going on," Huester said.
Huester explained the funding was cut because of a decision to apply as a direct recipient instead of a subrecipient.
"We have over $1 million in funding. We applied for $3 million in funding, so essentially what we learned is if we continued as a subrecipient with Maryland Family Network, we probably would have had funding, it would have been no issue, but because we chose to apply as a direct recipient, we didn't receive funding," Huester said.
The decision to apply independently was made by the organization's board, but Huester said if MRCD knew that applying as a direct recipient would impacted its funding, MRDC would've made a different choice.
Huester said that MRDC reached out to Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st), who sent a letter to the Office of Head Start. Harris said he has not received a response.
Addressing concerns from residents about the program's end, Huester said MRDC has explored options to provide for the toddlers of Caroline County.
The options include introducing a Patty Center model, which aims to help the family as a whole, allowing parents to come on site for services like resume building and job searching while their children are looked after. There is also fee structure option, which consist of exploring what residents could afford to pay to keep a center open at spaces in Greensboro and Federalsburg.
Huester also discussed converting existing Head Start spots and a collaboration with the Maryland State Department of Education for classroom models.

title: Talbot school board dives into test score trends
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot school board dives into test score trends

 September 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 695
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot school officials took a deeper look at state test scores last week, indicating upward trends in math and English for some grades and dips in others.At a work session on Sept. 15, Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, presented to Talbot Board of Education members breakdowns of 2024-2025 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program scores by grade and student group.
The presentation showed increases from the previous year in English proficiency for third and fourth grades, but drops for fifth and eighth grades. Math proficiency spiked year-to-year for fourth, sixth and seventh grades, but the number of students proficient algebra significantly fell.
The deeper dive came after the state released test score data for the 2024-2025 school year last month. While proficiency rates increased statewide, Talbot County students saw mixed results. English proficiency dropped to 45.4%, 16th in the state and the largest year-to-year decrease (1.9%) of all districts.
In math, 18.9% of students were proficient, 18th in the state and nearly even with the previous year's mark. Other counties, such as Dorchester, saw notable gains, rising spots in the statewide rankings.
Two days after the Sept. 15 work session, Talbot Board of Ed Member Deborah Bridges said at a monthly meeting that the district's results kept her up at night.
"After our work session on Monday night, I couldn't sleep," Bridges said. "Our scores, it upset me so much. And I wondered, what are we missing? What is going on in our schools?"
Board members largely agreed that the results aren't a matter of pointing fingers at teachers or staff. Instead, they are focused finding solutions to fix some of the problem areas.
Board President Emily Jackson said at the work session that she hopes school officials can begin to pinpoint some reasons behind the data trends.
"If I look at us, and we're going down, whereas a neighboring county who has a similar population of kids and they're going up, I want to know why," Jackson said.
Einhorn said while the state tests are an "important measure," it's one of many ways to assess academic achievement and growth.
"This is one assessment given at a single period of time, which does not always accurately reflect what students know and what they're able to do overall," Einhorn said.
ENGLISH
Fifth and tenth grades suffered the largest proficiency drops of 5.6% and 10%, respectively. But fourth grade proficiency rose to 50% in the most recent results. And while third grade proficiency dipped from last year's 47.9% mark, it's still at 43.6%, an improvement over a 35% rate two years ago.
"This really speaks to the work that this board has invested in early literacy, and starting to see that trend move up," Einhorn said at the work session.
Meanwhile, most student groups followed the district's overall trend of slightly decreasing in English proficiency. Asian students fell from 68.9% to 51.2%, while Talbot's multilingual learners dropped from 8.7% to 5.1%.
MATH
One of the sharpest drops came in Algebra II proficiency: 32.8% of students passed the state test in 2023-2024; only 7.1% passed in 2024-2025.
Einhorn acknowledged that as an "area of need." She noted that new math standards for K-8 will go into effect next school year. And in two years, the district will begin integrated algebra courses, infusing geometry concepts, she said.
Fourth grade rose nearly six percentage points to 32% proficiency this past year, while seventh grade had a similar hike from 11% to 17%.
By student group, one result stood out: Black students in the district remain under 5% proficient in math. Einhorn admitted the shortcoming.
"The less than 5% is indicating that we are still underserving our Black students and that we still need to continue looking at strategies that better prepare them to show what they know and are able to do in mathematics," Einhorn said.
Board Member Dyshekia Strawberry said she'd like to see the district work with community partners to specifically tackle the gap in math proficiency for Black students.
Board members thanked Einhorn for presenting the detailed trends, acknowledging that there's work to be done to get some of the numbers going in a positive direction.
"We have to do better, and we're open to hear how we're going to do that," Jackson said.

title: Maryland Supreme Court coming to Easton for first time since 1851
author: Konner Metz
content:
Maryland Supreme Court coming to Easton for first time since 1851

 October 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Maryland Supreme Court is taking a field trip to Easton High School this week.The state's highest court is holding a special oral arguments hearing Friday morning inside the Easton High School auditorium, giving students a glimpse at how the Maryland Supreme Court operates.
Two cases, one civil and one criminal, will be heard beginning at 9:30 a.m. Friday. Both are open to the public.
The civil case deals with whether a court, when asked by an unlicensed landlord, can require tenants to pay rent. The criminal case is centered on whether police officers can initiate traffic stops for suspicion of cell phone use "when they observe a driver manipulating a mobile phone," according to the case's online summary.
For each case, lawyers on both sides will have 30 minutes each to make their oral arguments, which build off of their written briefs to the court.
Students from local high schools and Chesapeake College are expected to attend.
Maryland Supreme Court Justice Brynja Booth, of the 1st Appellate Judicial Circuit encompassing the Eastern Shore, said the special hearings are a way for the public to become involved in the judicial process.
"I really do believe that it's critical for the public's confidence in the judiciary," Booth said inside her Washington Street office on Tuesday.
Booth acknowledged a recent "erosion of public confidence," something she hopes can be quelled by the Maryland Supreme Court's off-site trips to places outside its Annapolis building.
Chief Justice Matthew Fader and six other justices, including Booth, comprise the Supreme Court. Formerly the Court of Appeals, the Supreme Court usually hears cases after accepting a petition from a party regarding the Appellate Court of Maryland's decisions.
Booth noted the Supreme Court's trip to Easton as historically significant. From 1805 to 1851, the then-Court of Appeals sat in Annapolis and Easton, Booth wrote. The court hasn't sat in Easton since 1851, she said.
Off-site oral arguments are a relatively new endeavor for Maryland's most prestigious court. They're made possible through an administrative order, Booth said, which facilitates hearings at educational locations across the state. Arguments have been heard in Prince George's, Baltimore, Montgomery and St. Mary's County, she said.
Booth and other Supreme Court of Maryland officials worked with Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi and Assistant Superintendent Helga Einhorn to coordinate Friday's event.
On Tuesday, Booth said she'd love to see students get involved in the judicial field, especially given what she sees as a lack of attorneys on the Eastern Shore.
Booth, a longtime Easton-based attorney, said the Eastern Shore is a "wonderful place to practice law and raise a family." She hopes Friday's special hearings will encourage students not only to explore law, but consider the Eastern Shore as a place to do so.
"You can be a little fish in the big pond, or you can come back to the Shore," Booth said. "You can be a big fish in a little pond."

title: 'Priceless': Students watch Maryland Supreme Court hearings at Easton High
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Priceless': Students watch Maryland Supreme Court hearings at Easton High

 October 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 837
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Instead of a play or concert, the Easton High School auditorium played host to something much different on Friday morning: the Maryland Supreme Court.Seven justices of the state's highest court, along with attorneys and court officials, took to the stage to dive into two separate court cases, one civil and one criminal.
It was a departure from their normal courthouse setting in Annapolis, and they did it in front of hundreds of local high school and college students — part of a new endeavor to periodically travel to educational institutions across the state.
"This was such a unique experience to be able to see the Maryland Supreme Court at my school," said Lorelai Yacks, an Easton High School junior.
Friday was the first time the state's highest court sat in Easton since 1851, back when it was known as the Court of Appeals and regularly alternated between Annapolis and Easton.
Justice Brynja Booth, of the 1st Appellate Judicial Circuit encompassing the Eastern Shore, spearheaded the effort to bring the court to Easton High alongside Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi and Assistant Superintendent Helga Einhorn.
The goal: expose students to the law field and allow them to interact with the justices through a question-and-answer session and sit-down lunch following the hearings.
Pepukayi beamed in an interview after the event about the rare opportunity students had just received.
"The best thing for me is the real-world examples and experiences that our kids get," she said. "It's one thing to read about it in a textbook, to hear in a lecture from a teacher. To see it in action, priceless."
The court on Friday heard oral arguments for a criminal case involving whether police officers have reasonable suspicion to pull over drivers for touching or manipulating a cell phone while driving. The justices also heard arguments in a civil case dealing with whether a court can require tenants to pay rent when asked by an unlicensed landlord. Opinions from the court are expected at a later date.
Pepukayi said she think the cell phone case will resonate with students and members of the public who attended.
"I think the next time someone reaches for their cell phone while driving, if they were sitting in this room, they're gonna think twice," she said.
Yacks took interest in that case, in particular because the issue at hand of texting and driving was easily understandable. The professionalism and legal vocabulary used by attorneys on both sides of the case impressed her, she said.
Going in, Yacks said she knew the Maryland Supreme Court opening session at the high school was "unprecedented." She left with a lot of useful insight as she considers pursuing a career in the law-adjacent political science field one day.
"It was awesome to see a similar example of what it might look like in the future," Yacks said.
Justices give advice
After the oral arguments concluded, students from Easton High, St. Michaels High, The Gunston School and Chesapeake College lined up behind two microphones to pick the brains of the seven justices on the Maryland Supreme Court for nearly an hour.
Questions ranged from asking about how Supreme Court hearings differed from trials, to how justices check their personal biases at the door, to what cases have stood out as the most interesting.
Justices refrained from naming specific cases as their "favorite," but Justice Stephen Gould said a worthwhile one is usually dependent on the attorneys involved.
"My favorite kind of a case is a case in which we have excellent lawyers before us," Gould said. "Fortunately, because we get to pick our cases, for the most part, we virtually almost always get really, really good lawyers, and I think today was an example of that."
Gould emphasized that lawyers have their own styles and strategies, which were on display for students Friday. Each case had an attorney for the appellant, the side appealing a lower court's decision, and an attorney for the appellee, the side asking the Supreme Court to rule the opposing argument moot or back up the lower court's previous ruling.
But for all attorneys, Gould noted: "They're prepared. They know their stuff."
One student asked the justices what common misconception they often encounter. Justice Angela Eaves said many don't realize that they aren't deciding cases based on personal feelings.
"We resolve based on the factual record and what the law says about it," Eaves said.
The justice for the 2nd Appellate Judicial Circuit (Baltimore and Harford counties) added that the court's job is more than just assessing the specific case before them.
"We're really looking at the broader implications of what the law should be with respect to the type of issues that come before us," Eaves said.
Justices were asked to give advice to students that want to study law.
Chief Justice Matthew Fader emphasized that law isn't a narrow field, meaning people studying it should "keep (their) learning broad." Attorneys are tasked with helping clients who come to them with real-life problems in a variety of areas, he added.
"Anything that happens in the world can end up in a piece of litigation," Fader said.

 When the teachers and volunteers led students to the field outside of Mechanicsville Elementary School recently, they were excited to find several stations dedicated to teaching them about farm animals, fruits and vegetables, and healthy eating.The St. Mary's public school system has hosted Farm to School events for 16 years. School nutrition specialist Kaitlin Fraer organized events at three different elementary schools in the county this October, which is National Farm to School Month. At the first station, guided by youth nutritionist specialist Beth Palumbo from the American Dairy Association, students learned about cows and fresh milk. Palumbo and her team were excited to share that milk — yes, even chocolate milk — can keep you hydrated after physical activities.
Christine Allred, a former project leader and nutrition educator, and Deon Littles from the University of Maryland's College of Agriculture and Natural Resources showed the kids where their fruits and vegetables come from at the University of Maryland Extension station.
Allred read a picture book called "Up, Down, and Around" and instructed the kids to stand up, sit down, and spin around as the seeds were planted.
Each student received a plastic toy version of a fruit or vegetable to throw in the "fruit salad" — a colorful parachute that they raised in the air to mix the fruits and vegetables together.
Farmers from Beagle Hill Farm, located near the elementary school, brought tractors to show the students while also teaching them about growing sweet potatoes.
Adrian Hill and Greg Butterfield from Beagle Hill Farm assisted at the station.
"A lot of kids just don't have that connection of where their food comes from, or their clothing, or what agriculture can mean to them," said Butterfield, who has helped with the event for the last four years. "Maybe we'll make the next generation of farmers because I feel like it is getting less and less every year."
The students were invited to plant sweet potatoes, pull fresh vegetables out of the dirt and use a planter to plant seeds.
The youngsters had a chance to meet farm animals, including horses, pigs, goats and bunnies.
St. Mary's Farm Bureau Ambassadors Susannah Wathen and Sam Wathen introduced the students to a horse named Willa, who the kids were intrigued to learn is blind in one eye.
After moving through the stations, the students were served hamburgers and cheeseburgers with ground beef from Deere View Farm and Meats, Russell Bros LLC and Part Green Hill Farm.
"Living in a farming community, many people take advantage of the fact that they can get local produce most of the year, but it takes hard work to make that a reality," Fraer said.
Students will continue to engage with healthy eating thanks to curriculum provided by the University of Maryland Extension Program. The Food and Nutrition Services' dietitian is preparing marinated vegetables, roasted carrot fries and cheesy cauliflower for the students' lunches this month.

title: Talbot Board of Ed OKs contracts for EHS auditorium, Chapel Elementary windows
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed OKs contracts for EHS auditorium, Chapel Elementary windows

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education on Wednesday approved contracts for two upcoming projects: auditorium lights at Easton High School and windows at Chapel District Elementary School.New auditorium lights at Easton High will be installed in the summer of 2026, Director of Operations Kevin Shafer told board members. The $1.1 million contract was passed unanimously.
Shafer said some preliminary work will be done this spring before school ends. The school play and other concerts or events won't be impacted, Shafer said.
Over in Cordova, the under-renovation Chapel District Elementary School will receive glazing for its new windows. The window glazing is a security film, Shafer said, a safety measure that "prevents easy access to the school building."
All other schools in the district have the window glazing.
Chapel District Elementary is currently under renovation, a multimillion endeavor expected to be done sometime in 2026.
The contract is through a Maryland Center for School Safety grant in the amount of $132,000 for the window glazing. Shafer said the district couldn't move forward with it during construction of the renovated school building due to cost limits during the bidding process.
Shafer said he hopes the window security upgrades can be completed this summer. The board unanimously approved the contract.
Board President Emily Jackson added that she has "slight hesitations about privacy" as it relates to windows in classrooms and libraries at Chapel District Elementary and other schools.
Jackson asked that the board hear more about potential school safety grants in the future, particularly "in the privacy arena to provide more screening for our students."

title: Empowerment Center offers after-school education
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Empowerment Center offers after-school education

 October 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 298
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The kids were dropped off by school bus and greeted by Miss Tammy who knew each child by name. On this particular afternoon, the children were making Halloween decorations and doing arts and crafts.The Cambridge Empowerment Center is a non-profit located on historic Pine Street, offers after school, summer learning and pre-school programs, hosts food drives, clothing drives, food distributions, senior health and enrichment programs, learning seminars and more.
Director of Children's Programs Tammy Washington oversees programs from pre-kindergarden through 13 years old. The pre-K program is free and runs from 9 a.m. to noon. Washington said there are slots available for this program. Those interested may sign up on the website.
The after-school programming runs from 3-6 p.m. with themed days including math, art and IXL, a subscription-based learning site. In addition to the educational programming, the children get a meal and a snack after school.
The summer program costs $125 for six weeks and offers breakfast and lunch, field trips, education and a tennis program and an additional cost with licensed child care providers.
One of the third grade children who attends the after-school program said she loves coming to the center and enjoys multiplication, reading, painting and learning about Harriet Tubman. Her favorite book is "Llama Llama Mad at Mama."
The center opened in 2003 and has been licensed for child care for two years. Previous to the pandemic, the empowerment center solely operated through donations and via volunteers. Now, it runs on grant funding in addition to donations. Staff are paid and certified to work with children though they still welcome volunteers.
"After the pandemic, we started all over again," board member Julia Barker said. "We had to reinvent ourselves."
The center is hosting an open house on Nov. 9 for community members to check out this reinvention.
